    Navigation: Receivables Manager > Setup > System > System Options
    Four Tabs:
        Accounting: Gain and Loss, Tax, Cross Currency Rounding, Create Detailed Distributions, Automatic Journal Import
        Transactions and Customers: Transaction options, Late Charge Options, AutoInvoice Options, Customer Numbering Options
        Claims
        Miscellaneous

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Standard Memo Lines Setup
    Navigation: Setup > Transactions > Memo Lines
    Memo lines can be setup for different types of lines (invoice lines, freight, tax, chargeback etc)
    They can be chosen in invoice entry and default a revenue account

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Activities Setup
    References
        Page 2-170 of the Accounts Receivable User Guide
        Oracle Receivables Implementation Guide Release 12 Part No. B31212-01 pp 6-20
    Navigation: AR Superuser > Setup > Receipts > Receivable Activities
    Activities are receipt transactions which default accounting onto miscellaneous receipt transactions
        Define receivables activities to default accounting information for your miscellaneous receipt, finance charge, chargeback, and adjustment transactions
            They can be positive or negative
        The activities you define appear as list of values choices in the Receipt and Adjustment windows.
        You can define as many activities as you need.
        The accounting is assigned in the Activity definition
        The account is debited with the activity amount
            The corresponding credit is to the Receivables Asset Account (the customers' AR balance)
    There are several Activity Types and each activity is assigned one of these seeded Types when it is defined:
        Adjustment - used in the Adjustments window. At least one activity of type 'Adjustment' must be defined
        Bank Error - used in the Adjustments window and used to reconcile bank statements in Oracle Cash Management
        Earned Discount
        Endorsement
        Finance Charge
        Miscellaneous Cash
        Short Term Debt
        Unearned Discount
        Receipt Write-off
        Claim Investigation
        Credit Card Refund
        Prepayment - originating in Order Management and not enterable and an AR Receipt Application
        Payment Netting
        Credit Card Chargeback
        Refund
    Activities appear as LOV's in several Receivables windows
    Finance charge activity accounting is used on finance charges in statements and dunning letters
    Activities can be made innactive to remove them from LOV's, using the Active Flag on the Activity Definition form
    The GL Account Source field in the Activity Definition Form determines if the activity uses an Account Code or Distribution Set
        Distribution sets are not allowed on all activities

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Adjustments, Adjustment Activities and Auto Adjustments (Mass Adjustments)
    References
        http://www.oracleappshub.com/accounts-receivable/ar-adjustments-detailssetup-flow-accounting-and-api/
        https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wo2u7yPLBAE -- youtube video showing adjusting invoices
        http://docs.oracle.com/cd/A60725_05/html/comnls/us/ar/recpts10.htm
        http://www.apps2fusion.com/apps/fm/1265-handling-bad-debts-in-oracle-receivables-in-r12 -- bad debt write-off
    Receivables lets you make either positive or negative adjustments to ..
        invoices, debit memos, chargebacks, on-account credits, deposits, and guarantees
    Adjustments are primarily write-offs
    Prerquisites for Adjustment Entry
        Define an Activity of Type Adjustment
        Define approval limits for the Adjustment
            Navigation: Receivables Manager > Transactions > Approval Limits
            Based on User Name and not employee - not OPU-specific
            When you enter an adjustment that is outside your approval limit range ...
                Receivables assigns the adjustment a status of Pending until someone with the appropriate approval limits either approves or rejects it.
        Define Reason QuickCodes for the Adjustment
            Navigation: Receivables Manager > Setup > System > Quickcodes > Receivables > Query (ADJUST_REASON)
        Set the profile option: AR: Cash  Allow Actions (hides or shows the Chargeback and Adjustments buttons on the Application window in Receipts Workbench)
    Steps to Record an Adjustment in the Receipts Workbench
        Navigate to the Receipts Form
        Enter a new receipt or query an existing receipt
        Choose Applications and select the transactions to apply to the receipt
        Click the 'Adjustments' button on the Applications page (note: it may be hidden through profile option: 'AR: Cash  Allow Actions')
        Enter an Activity Name and select the type of adjustment: invoice, line, charges, freight or tax
            The Type allows the adjustment to be applied to a specific component of the transaction
        Save the work - Oracle generates a unique number for the adjustment
        You can also enter an adjustment directly against a transaction from the Transaction Summary Form
    Adjustments can also be recorded directly against transactions in the Transaction Summary Form
        Query a transaction
        Navigate: Menu > Actions > Adjust
        Enter an adjustment
    Approving Adjustments
        Navigation: Receivables Manager > Control > Adjustments > Approve Adjustments
    Bad Debt
        Set up an adjustment activity 'Bad Debt' that charges the bad debt account
        Enter the bad debt as an invoice adjustment either directly or through receipt application
    Auto Adjustments (AutoAdjustments)
        Navigation: Receivables Manager > Control > Adjustments > Create AutoAdjustments
        Allows for creating adjustments on a large number of invoices
        Set profile optoin AR: INVOICES WITH UNCONFIRMED RECEIPTS = 'None' or concurrent program will end in error

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Receipt Classes and Receipt Methods
    References
        How to Restrict the Transaction Sources And Receipts Methods List of Values to One Operating Unit Only (Doc ID 783733.1)
    A Receipt Class is defined with one or more receipt methods
        A Receipt Class defines the processing steps for automatic or manual receipts (the Creation Method, Remittance Method and Clearance Method)
        The Receipt Class Creation Method (Automatic, Manual, Factoring etc) Drives the Region for entering Receipt Methods
    A Receipt Method defines the bank account and the GL accounting for the receipts
        Accounting includes the bank cash account and the unapplied, on account receipts and discount accounts
        Each Receipt Method is assigned a Payment Method which is assigned on the AR Invoice
        You must assign a Bank Account to a Receipt Method
            Receipt Classes and Methods are Global
            The Bank Account assigned to the Receipt Class enables Receipt Methods in LOV's because it determines the OU (e.g in the AR Transactions form)

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Receipt Sources
    Navigation: Receivables Manager > Setup > Receipts > Sources
        Navigation: Receivables Manager > Setup > Receipts > Sources
    Receipt Sources control automatic and manual batch numbering on receipts
        The current batch number can be reset at any time (last number used)
            If multiple receipt sources are used, batch starting numbers need to be spaced to avoid overlap
        Sources can be manual (received outside or automatic (generated)

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Distribution Sets Setup
    Navigation: AR Superuser > Setup > Receipts > Distribution Sets
    Distribution sets used on miscellaneous receipt transactions (non-invoice related receipts)
    They attach account distributions to the transaction
    These receipts can include:
        refunds,
        revenue from the sale of stock,
        interest
        investment income.
    Distribution sets are predefined groups of general ledger accounting codes
        They determine the credit accounts for positive miscellaneous receipt amounts
        They determine the debit accounts for negative receipt amounts.
    Distribution sets reduce time spent on data entry.
    You can also use distribution sets to apply percentages of other receipts to different accounts.
    You can have an unlimited number of distribution set lines in one set.
    The total distribution lines must equal 100% before you can save your distribution set.
    Receivables displays active distribution sets as LOV's in two forms:
        Transactions
        Receivables Activities

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Credit Holds and Credit Checking
    References
        Order Management Credit Check / Exposure Setup (Doc ID 444837.1)
        Oracle Order Management Implemenation Manual
        MOS Note: 732480.1 - Oracle Order Entry Credit Check Setup Test
        MOS Note: 551971.1 - Include Payments At Risk Flag In Credit Check Rule
        MOS Note: 205106.1 - Oracle Order Management Credit Check Activity Test
        MOS Note: 579051.1 - Orders Going On 'Credit Check Hold' When Booked
        MOS Note: 783464.1 - Orders On Credit Check Failure Hold Do Not Automatically Release You Are Not Authorized
        MOS Note: 1639006.1 - Credit Check Troubleshooting in Order Management
    Credit Hold
        Customer Account Profile Tab, Credit and Collections region, includes Credit Hold and Credit Check
            Also at Bill-to Site, Profile Tab for a bill-to site level hold
        Checking Credit Hold puts future orders on hold
        Unchecking Credit Hold releases all held orders automatically
        Credit Hold can enabled at the Customer level and site level (bill-to)  
    Credit Check Rule on Order Management Transaction Types
        A Credit Check Rule must be assigned to OM Transaction Types
        This rule defines behaviour for four OM phases: Ordering, Picking/Purchase Release, Packing, Shipping
    Payment Terms
        Payment Terms have a credit check flag
    Credit Limit on Customer
        Profile Amounts Tab on Account and Site: Order Credit Limit and Credit Limit
    Credit Check Rules
        Navigation:
            Order Management > Setup > Credit > Define Credit Check Rules
        Define how and when a credit check is applied
        Check Level: Sales Order or Sales Order Line
        Hold Level: Sales Order or Sales Order Line
        Override Manual Release (and Days to Honor Manual Release)
            Overrides credit checking if an order is manually released, but for a given number of days)
        Exposure Tab (of Credit Checking Rules)
            Exposure is defined as a basis for applying credit checking
            Two type: Online and Pre-Calculated
                Online calculates on the fly
                Pre-Calculated references a summary table updated by concurrent program 'Initialize Credit Summaries'
            Include/Exclude in Exposure
                External Credit Exposure
                Open Receivables Balance
                Payments at Risk (not cleared the bank)
                Uninvoiced Orders
                Freight and Special Charges
                Tax
                Orders Currently on Hold
                Returns
    Credit Usage Rules
        Define the currencies included in the credit check process

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Multi-Fund Accounting
    References
        http://oracleapplicationsimplmentation.blogspot.com/2009/06/r12-multi-fund-invoice-accrual.html -- example using memo lines
    A fund is a source of money (funding)
        Each fund may have a different purpose and reporting requirement
    Allows posting invoices and receipts to multiple balancing segments
    Individual transactions can post to multiple funds or balancing segments
    The balancing segment on the AR invoice for the AR account is derived from the balancing segment on the sales credit one of two ways
        Account Method - the balancing segment and all other segments except the natural account are copied
        Balancing Method - only the balancing segment is copied
        Both the Account and Balancing Methods are seeded Journal Line Definitions in SLA that must be assigned to a custom/copy Application Accounting Definition
    The balancing segment on the receipt is derived from the corresponding sale
        Create accounting must be run on the invoice before the receipt is created

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Customer Import Interface
    Customer Interface
        Used to import current or historical customer information into Receivables
        The program that imports data from the staging tables to AR is "Customer Interface"
            The program validates the data prior to import, and subsequently imports the records.
        Staging tables include:
            RA_CONTACT_PHONES_INTERFACE
            RA_CUSTOMERS_INTERFACE - stores customers, addresses and business purpose information
            RA_CUSTOMER_PROFILES_INTERFACE
            RA_CUSTOMER_BANKS_INTERFACE
            RA_CUST_PAY_METHOD_INTERFACE
        It has two modes: insert and update
            Update allows importing additional addresses or updating existing customer information
            The field INSERT_UPDATE_FLAG ("U" or "I"is a required field on the following interface tables:
                RA_CUSTOMERS_INTERFACE
                RA_CONTACT_PHONES_INTERFACE
                RA_CUSTOMER_PROFILES_INTERFACE
            Update mode cannot be used on DFF's (i.e. ATTRIBUTE fields) for CUSTOMER, SITE_USE and ADDRESS
        A report is produced by the interface "Customer Interface Transfer Report" with three sections
            Summary of the process run
            Statistics of tables updated
            Error messages for rejected records.

        AR_PAYMENT_SCHEDULES_ALL -- All Payment related info
    AutoInvoice Import Setup
        References
            Troubleshooting Transaction Flexfields in AutoInvoice (Doc ID 1077555.1)
            Troubleshooting Grouping Rules In AutoInvoice (Doc ID 1084554.1) -- includes queries for checking grouping attributes on transactions
            Troubleshooting AutoInvoice Date Derivation: GL Date, Invoice Date, Due Date, Ship Date, Billing Date, Rule Date (Doc ID 201241.1)
            How Does The Invoice Date Get Derived From The Sales Order Line? (Doc ID 300311.1)
        AutoInvoice is a standard API process for importing invoices
            These are typically from an Order Management System
            The program runs as 'AutoInvoice Master Program'
                The program has a 'Number of Instances' parameter which sets the number of parallel processes (on separate CPU's)
                    Formula to use is Number of Instances = Number of CPU's - 1 (for maximum throughput)
                This parameter works in conjunction with other profile setting including
                    Profile Option: "AR: Maximum Lines Per AutoInvoice Worker"
                    AutoInvoice Parameter: "Organization" - All or one specific organization (feature available in R12 only)
                    AutoInvoice Parameter: "Number of Parallel Workers" - Maximum number of workers, this value can be overridden by AutoInvoice for performance reasons.
                References
                   Autoinvoice Master Program: Why are Multiple Concurrent Autoinvoice Import Programs Spawned? (Doc ID 1311477.1)
        Date Rules in Autoinvoice for non-Deferred Revenue Recognition or Unbilled AR (i.e. no Invoicing Rule)
            Uses GL_DATE if specified on interfaced transaction
            Uses SHIP_DATE_ACTUAL if no GL_DATE is specified on transaction and 'Derive Date' on source definition is 'Yes'
        Date Rules in Autoinvoice for Deferred Revenue Recognition
            GL Date - Latest date on the accounting rule (i.e. the same x days after the period starts, but in the last period) based on start date actual on order line
            Trx Date - GL date if not explicitly set in the interface (OM does not explicitly set)
            Bill Date - First BFB Bill Date on or after the Trx Date (based on the BFB cycle dates)
        How To Control the Invoice Date for Non-Shippable Lines? (Doc ID 1089077.1)
            OM: Set Receivables Transaction Date as Current Date for Non-Shippable Lines

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Revenue Recognition
    Tip
        You must run Revenue Recognition from the AR menu before running Create Accounting, or
        Run Create Accounting online, which submits Revenue Recognition automatically as a pre-step
    References
        http://oracle.anilrpatil.com/2009/12/22/what-is-revenue-recognition/ -- business overview
        http://www.oracleappshub.com/release12/release-12-whats-new-in-oracle-receivables/ -- R12 overview
        How To Setup And Troubleshoot Invoicing Rules and Accounting Rules (Doc ID 1116934.1)
            Invoicing and accounting rules are defaulted from Order Management transaction types when processed through AutoInvoice
        Understanding and Troubleshooting Revenue Recognition (Doc ID 1121944.1)
        http://www.anilrpatil.com/oracle/Revenue_Recognition_1.htm
        Error: Please Define All Periods In Which Revenue Is To Be Recognized Or Credited (AutoInvoice and Transaction Workbench) (Doc ID 455691.1) 
    In R12 ... Revenue Recognition Based on Rules and Events
        Time Based: Ratably over time or upon expiration of contingencies
        Event Based: upon payment or customer acceptance
        Rule Based: payment term thresholds, refund policy thresholds and customer credit worthiness
    In R12, run Submit Accounting or Create Accounting to generate GL entries
        Submit Accounting is a wrapper for Create Accounting which also runs Revenue Recognition
        Submit Accounting is an AR Application Process
        Create Accounting is an SLA Application Process which must be added to AR request groups
    Business Rules for Revenue Recognition
        For sale of finished goods (Inventory Items), revenue is recognized at the date of sale (some interpret this as the date of shipping or the date of delivery)
        For sale of services (e.g. support services), revenue is recognized when the services are performed (delivered)
        For sale of Asset Items (other than inventory items like finished goods), revenue is recognized at the point of sale (i.e. when the customer is invoiced)
        For revenue from other activities like rent for using company's Fixed Assets, revenue is recognized as time passes or as assets are used
    Accounting
        Initial Invoicing
            DR Receivables
            CR Deferred Revenue Revenue Recognized (products or services delivered or used)
            DR Deferred Revenue (for fractional amount earned)
            CR Revenue/Sales (for fractional amount earned)
        GL Dates on Entries for Invoicing Rule 'In Arrears'
            The GL Date for Receivables is moved to the last period in the accounting rule
            The GL Date in the last period is the same number of days from the start of the period as the original GL date before it was moved (the entered GL date)
                This GL date applies to the revenue deferral entries also, in each deferral period, is the same number of days after the start of each period as the original date
    Setups in Oracle
            You can assign a different accounting rule to each invoice line
            Accounting rules specify the percentage of revenue recognized in each period
        Define Accounting Rules
            Navigation: AR SuperUser > Setup > Transactions > Accounting Rules
            Enter a rule name and period type, and number of periods
            Check 'Deferred Revenue' to account for all revenue as deferred
                If this feature is enabled, the Revenue Accounting Wizard (RAM) must be run later to recognize the revenue in each period
            Enter a percentage amount to recognize in each period
        Assign Accounting Rules to Billable Items
            Navigation: AR Superuser > Setup > Items > Define Items > (Query Item) > Invoicing Tab > Accounting Rule
        Recognize Deferred Revenue
            Only applies to revenue recognized in advance (invoicing rule in advance)
            Navigation: Revenue Management Superuser > Revenue Accounting > (Query Transactions) > Manage Revenue
            Also used to record acceptance from the customer
    Responsibilities
        Revenue Management Superuser

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Invoicing and Accounting Rules
    References
        How To Setup And Troubleshoot Invoicing Rules and Accounting Rules (Doc ID 1116934.1)
        https://blogs.oracle.com/ebs/resolving-autoinvoice-date-issues
    Invoicing Rules are used to determine when the Receivable is Recognized for invoices spanning multiple accounting periods
    Accounting Rules determine when the revenue is recognized
    You can only assign one invoicing rule per invoice
    There are only two seeded invoicing rules (you cannot define additional rules) which are:
        Invoice in Advance
            AR is debited when the first revenue recognition period happens
        Invoice in Arrears
            Unbilled AR is debited when the first revenue recognition period happens
            Unbilled AR is credited and AR is debited when the final revenue recognition period happens
    Invoicing Rules apply to accrual accounting and not cash accounting
    Invoicing Rules determine when the AR Receivable is recognized
        They are separate to Accounting Rules which determine when the Sale is recognized (revenue recognition)
    Invoicing and Accounting Rules are defaulted from Order Types (Order Transaction Types - header and line levels) or Inventory Items (Invoicing tab) or entered manually on invoices
        They are not defaulted from Customer Profile Classes or Invoice Types
        References
            Why Does OM Populate Invoicing_rule_id As -2 In AR Iface When Setup In OM Is Null Rule? (Doc ID 1958685.1)
        Defaulting on the Order has a defaulting hierarchy
            Agreement
            Line Type (Transaction Type at Line Level)
            Inventory Item
            Order Header (derived from associated sales agreement, then order transaction type.
        Navigation: Order Management Super User > Setup > Transaction Types > Define
        Navigation: Receivables Manager > Transactions > Transactions > Main Tab (lower region)

Accounts Receivable (RA and AR Schema) Notes on Concurrent Processes
    Run General Ledger Interface Program (ARGLTP) - posts journals to the GL
    You can submit directly as 'General Ledger Transfer Program'
    You can submit it from the menu under AR Responsibility -> Interfaces -> General Ledger
        If you submit with the option to import journals and there are no journals the import program will throw a warning
        There is no option to disable journal import if no journals are created
    Program 'General Ledger Transfer Program' kick off additional jobs:
        Update Posting Control
        Journal Import - which ends in warning if there are no journals to import

Advanced Collections (IEX Schema) Notes on General Functionality
    Collections in R12
        The Customer Account form is obsoleted in R12
        Account Details is available under the Receivables Manager Main Menu (Receivables Manager > Inquiry > Account Details)
        Contact Information can be added through eBusiness Center (navigation: Collections Manager > Collections > Query Customer > Doublclick Customer Name
            References: R12 Cannot Create And Save Contact Information In Collections Form (Doc ID 1319601.1)
    Call Notes
        Call Notes can still be entered via Account Inquiry > Transaction Overview > Tools > Call
        This is unsupported in R12 and may be removed
            References: The Customer Call form is still available in the Tools Menu under Transaction Overview (Doc ID 1314999.1)
        References: How to Enable Customer Call History in R12. (Doc ID 464053.1)
    Collections Work Queue
        A high level list of actionable work that is pushed to the collector agent (automated collections management flow)

Advanced Collections (IEX Schema) Notes on Implementation Options
    Dunning Plan or Strategy (either is driven by a score)
    Navigation: DII Collections Administrator > Setup Checklist > Dunning Plans
        Dunning letters can be sent when scores are reached
            Dunning based implementation includes dunning letters and followup calls
        Strategies drive collections tasks when scores are reached
            Strategy based implementation includes manual activities (tasks), dunning letters, followup calls and workflows
            Allows greater control by collectors who can remove or add tasks
            Strategic customers can be protected

    Work Items in the Work Panel

        Provides drill down to the relevant tab in Workbench
        Columns can be added, moved by Metadata

Advanced Collections (IEX Schema) Notes on Promise-to-Pay and Payments
    Promise to Pay is now an entered transaction
    Customer commitment to make a payment
    Keeps track of broken promises (promise date plus grace days)
    Optionally sends a Promise Confirmation Letter
    Profile Options for Promise to Pay
        IEX: Activity enabled in Promises - enables Interaction History when promise is entered
        IEX: Approval required for Promise - forces approval before Promise to Pay is recorded
        IEX: Callback Days for Broken Promise - number of days after a promise is broken a callback task will be created
        IEX: Item Type for Promise Workflow - the approval workflow for promise to pay approval
        IEX: Maximum Promise to Pay Range - the maximum future days a promise can be scheduled
        IEX: Promise Grace Period - additional days before promise is broken
    Concurrent program 'IEX: Promise Reconciliation' generates broken promises (in Collections Administrator responsibility)
        Feeds to the Universal Work Queue node
    Issues
    Cannot See Broken Promises in UWQ
        Promise Grace Period Not Set
        Reference: Why is the UWQ blank or not Showing Correct Data? (Doc ID 784274.1)
            Run batch processes to generate broken promises from Collections Administrator responsibility:
                IEX: Promise Reconciliation (and IEX: Promise Reconciliation Report)
                IEX: Scoring Engine Harness (options 2,1,6,7)
                IEX: Strategy Management (if you are using strategies)
                IEX: Update AR Transaction Summary Table (ONLY if 12.1.2 or higher)
                IEX: Populate UWQ Summary Table  (To clear table, leave date blank and Y to Truncate)
     Payments
         To enter a payment (EFT or Credit Card) you must setup the payment account or card on the customer payments profile
         Also create a receipt class 'Automatic' with Remittance Method 'Standard' plus the related accounts in Receipt Classes
             Reference
                 R12.1 PN Payment Method LOV Is Empty (Doc ID 968062.1)
         Also setup the operating unit as a payee in Funds Capture, or you will get error APP-IEX-240197 Invalid Payee

Advanced Collections (IEX Schema) Notes on Delinquencies
    Overview
        Delinquencies are not generated for items that are in dispute
    Followups
        Find how to set a Delinquency Grace Period
    Run 'IEX: Populate UWQ Summary Table' to populate delinquencies
    References
        Why is the UWQ blank or not Showing Correct Data? (Doc ID 784274.1)
        How Do You Score Invoices with Partial Disputes? (Doc ID 460992.1)
    The data that is displayed in the UWQ Delinquent Customer, Delinquent Account and Delinquent Bill To nodes, comes from the IEX_DLN_UWQ_SUMMARY table.
        This table is populated by the IEX: Populate UWQ Summary Table concurrent process which takes input from:
            Credit summary data comes from the AR_TRX_BAL_SUMMARY table.
            TCA data comes from the HZ_PARTIES and HZ_CONTACT_POINTS tables.
            Delinquency information comes from the IEX_DELINQUENCIES_ALL and IEX_PROMISES tables.
            Strategy Work Item information comes from the IEX Strategy and Work Items tables.

Advanced Collections (IEX Schema) Notes on Delinquencies and Scoring Engine
    This is the backbone of the Collections module
        Comprises scoring components and a scoring engine
        Derives a single collection score
        Used to determine what type of dunning plan or strategy is assigned to a customer
    Scoring Example
        Each metric has value ranges and assigned scores
        Scores are weighted
        Weighted scores are summed for a total score
        The total score drives the dunning plan or collection strategya


Advanced Collections (IEX Schema) Notes on Dunning
    References
        How to Setup and Troubleshoot Dunning Plans (Doc ID 1542067.1)
    R12
        Delinquencies must be created in R12 before dunning letters can be created
        Dunning can send copies of invoices and generate callbacks
        Methods:
            Overdue: based on oldest delinquency
            Staged: based on minimum days between letters (each letter is a stage)
        Setups
            know business level - Collections Admin > Setup Checklist > Questionaire
            Assign collectors - to each customer Doc 1397139.1, Doc 314374.1
            Define a dunning contact - in the collections agent form Collections Agent > Collections > Questionaire
            Set dunning flag on the custommer - in statements and dunning region of customer setup
            Decide output: print, email or fax. Doc 401619.1
                Custom Dunning Letter Template or Seeded Template (Doc ID: 1360212.1)
                Staged letters are normally custom
            Set profile options
                IEX: Check Dunning Amount at Functional Currency
                IEX: Hold Dunning if Full Amount is promised
                IEX: Use Csutomer Language for Dunning Letters
                IEX: Minimum Dunning Amount Profile Check

Advanced Collections (IEX Schema) Notes on Reports
    Additional References
        How Do I Run the Collections Reports? (Doc ID 1127586.1)
    Overview
        Collections reports are very limited and custom reports are needed to meet requirements
    Standard Reports are:
        IEX: Collector Campaign Schedule Report - This report compares campaign and collector activities with promises to pay and with payments.
        IEX: Payment Campaign Report - This report compares the results of a campaign for the past hour or for the day and compares them with a stated goal.
        IEX: Payment Collection Report - This report compares the collector's promises to pay and payments collected for the hour or the day and compares them with a stated goal.
        IEX: Promise Reconciliation Report - This report compares promises to pay with receipt of promised payments

Advanced Pricing (QP) Notes on General Functionality:
    Advanced Pricing is a general pricing engine that can be called by multiple modules;
        Order Management
        Procurement
        Customer Relationship Management
    The primary entities in advanced pricing include:
        Qualifiers and Qualifier Groups - determine who is eligible for price lists and modifiers (discounts)
            Used in eligibility rules linked to price lists and modifiers
            A number of qualifiers are seeded
            Examples include: Customer, Bill-to, Sales Channel, Order Type, Line Type, Shipment Date, Shipping Method, Payment Terms, Freight Terms, etc
        Modifiers - discounts and incentives
    Price Lists
        Price lists contain item and item category prices
        Price lists can have one of the following pricing types (or methods)
            Fixed price
            Formula price (price based on another price list and arithmatic operators)
            Percentage price - a price expressed as a percentage of another item
            Price breaks (or pricing tiers) - prices based on volume ranges
        There are primary and secondary price lists
            If an item cannot be found on a primary price list, it is searched on secondary price lists
            Each price list can have one or more secondary price lists
            Secondary price lists have precedence values - the lowest value precedence is checked first.
        Price Lists can be built as a percentage of other price lists
        Price lists can be maintained by mass update to propagate the same price change across multiple lists

Advanced Pricing (QP Schema) Notes on Flexfields:
    Pricing Attributes DFF

Advanced Pricing (QP Schema) Notes on Key Tables:
    QP_LIST_HEADERS (and _TL) - price list headers and modifier headers
    QP_LIST_LINES - price list lines and modifier lines
    QP_QUALIFIERS - price qualifiers
    QP_PRICING_ATTRIBUTES - price attributes

Advanced Product Catalog (APC) Notes
    APC centralizes product and component information through out Oracle applictions into a central repository - including products, components, services and assets
    Provides a master index to BOM's, document specifications, change requests, and change orders
    Catalog categories can be structured hierarchically with three characteristic types: attributes, custom functions and lifecycles.
    These catalog structures can be browsed interactively with each category showing their contents.
    Attributes can be unlimited and have units of measure associated with them
    Functions can be associated with catalog categories and presented to users as dynamically rendered buttons on forms when the items are displayed
    Access security is based on roles which restrict access by organization, category or individual item
    Each role defines actions that can be performed on an item or category
    Each attribute group can be secured with a role privilege to restrict access to information at the attribute level
    Searches can be simple string or parametric (contains, starts with, ends with) and can be stored for reuse
    Searches can be associated with display formats for presenting the results of the search or filtering results.
    Searches can be: exact match, inexact match, word positioning, associative match, boolean, and stemming
    A search index is built using the concurrent program: 'Item Catalog Text Index Build' - this must be run by a person with Development Responsibility
    You can compare items side by side resulting from a catalog search
    Lifecycle tracking uses association to a project to move a product through different stages as the project progresses
    Attachments can be associated to individual items
    Items and attributes and item roles can be imported through a standard API (item-roles update security role associations with items)
    Item attributes can be imported for items
    Stucture types can be set up to classify the structure of an item. Structure types include: Engineering BOM, Manufacturing BOM and Service BOM.
    Hierarchies can be setup for structure types so that Electrical BOM's, Mechanical BOM's will inherit the attributes of the Engineering BOMs.
    Change categories can be setup to capture changes to items. Categories include: original issue, change request, change order etc)
    User defined attributes can be attached to changes, such as cost information

Advanced Product Catalog (APC) Workflows:
    Workflow routes item changes to people who have roles associated with the change object to approve the proposed changes

Advanced Product Catalog (APC) Patches
    3016576 - PLM Minipack B, also known as 11i.EGO.B
    3192398 - APC Java Documentation 11.5.9 B

Advanced Product Catalog (APC) Schemas
    EGO - Oracle Engineering Online

Advanced Queuing (AQ)

Advanced Supply Chain Planning (ASCP) Best Practices:
    Global sourcing rules for centralized procurement

Advanced Supply Chain Planning (ASCP) Notes on General Functionality:
    ASCP introduced with Oracle 11. SCP was available in version 10.7 - ASCP produces an cost plan given various constraints
    Optimization goals are max profit, max on-time delivery and max inventory turns
    ASCP output publishes back to each participating Oracle instance and organization: order releases, reschedules and cancellations.
    ASCP produces a plan for multiple inventory organizations, multiple time periods, multiple plan types and multiple manufacturing methods (holistic planning)
    ASCP plans using input from multiple Oracle instances and from non-Oracle applications
    Finite planning is constraint based (not 'infinite') planning including: material and supplier capacity, manufacturing capacity, transport capacity constraints
    Plan types supported by ASCP are: Distribution Plan (like a DRP), Production Schedule (like an MPS) and Manufacturing Plan (like an MRP)
    An MPS is the same data structure as an MDS but netted for existing inventories.
        An MPS is a high level plan of finished goods items to make (high level demand) and when they can be made
        It is based on manufacturing capacity.
    The Planner Workbench in ASCP supports KPI's:
        Inventory Turns,
        On-Time Delivery,
        Margin %,
        Margin Value,
        Resource Utilization, and
        Cost Breakdown.
    KPI targets can be set in BIS for reporting against, in the ASCP Planner Workbench.
    ASCP runs on a separate server for performance reasons.
        This also facilitates collection of planning base data from multiple instances
    Basic supply chain modeling is done with standard setups:
        item make or buy attribute,
        item source organization and subinventory.
    Multi-org planning must identify the organizations included in the plan from each instance of the applications
    Supply sourcing is modeled with sourcing rules, bills of distribution and assignment sets
    Sourcing rules are planned sources of supply
        They can be global to all inventory organizations within an Operating Unitor local to a single organization
        Sourcing options include:
            make within the org,
            buy from an outside supplier, or
            transfer from another org (as limited by delivery networks)
        Priority codes and percent splits define which sourcing options are considered first (highest priorities)
        Priority codes also establish how sources are split (eg between suppliers)
    Sourcing is defined by a sourcing rule or bill of distribution (supplier rules), linked to a distribution set (item rules)
    Sourcing rules and bills of distribution can be global (all inv orgs) or local to a single inventory organization
    A Bill of Distribution is a collection of sourcing rules
        It is used where the same sourcing rules apply to multiple organizations.
        Bills are local to their named orgs
    Assignment Sets specify items for sourcing rules
        Assignment Sets can be done for specific categories, items or org restrictions.
        Multiple sets are allowed for different purposes like planning, or simulation.
    One assignment set is specified in the planning options for a single plan
        So an assignment set should cover all items/orgs for a specific plan
    Several assignments can be valid for a single item (item specific, category specific and org specific).
        The lowest level rule takes precedence.
    Aggregate resources in a plan are supported by defining a resource as aggregate type
        and grouping all resources in a department to the aggregate resource
    Supplier capacity constraints are specified in approved supplier (ASL) list attributes
    Penalty factors are stored in descriptive flexfields
        that are created by running the concurrent program: 'Create Planning Flexfields'
        Penalty factors are entered in the Plan Options window, on the 'optimization' tab
        Penalty factors escalate the costs of resources for overuse (eg overtime costs) as input to cost/margin optimization.
        Late delivery penalty is a fraction of the item value, per day late
    Explicit objectives can be set/weighted for:
        inventory turns,
        plan profit,
        on-time delivery (on the Optmization tab of the Plan Options form)
    Implicit objectives always optimized in ASCP are minimum:
        late demand,
        resource exceptions,
        safety-stock violations,
        alternate resources,
        alternate routings,
        inventory carrying cost
    Lot for Lot planning ensures each demand generates a separate plan order to mfg
         It is not consolidated to a single order.
         Set with the Lot for Lot option on the Plan Options window
    Plan options allow specification of actual route scheduling for plan orders in the 'daily bucket' portion of the plan - see 'plan options' form
    Run the 'Planning Data Collection' request set to kick off data collection
        (request set - includes planning data pull and planning ODS load)
    Results of the plan are viewed on the ASCP Planner Workbench.
        Work orders can be released from the workbench.
    Planned orders can be firmed, rescheduled, or added to, via the Supply/Demand form
        after the plan has been run (release from the PLan menu option)
    Plans can be copied to save, and then rerun in multiple simulations.
        Use the Plan menu item, and the Copy selection.
    The seeded workflows in ASCP are all exception based notifications and only generate from a plan named 'PRODUCTION'

Advanced Supply Chain Planning (ASCP) Responsibilities:
    ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNNER

Advanced Supply Chain Planning (ASCP) Setup:
    Overall - define supply chain, create flexfields, define instances and DB links,
        name a plan, demand priority rules, plan names and options
    Define planning descriptive flexfields that store penalty factors for implicit objectives:
        run 'Create Planning Flexfields' concurrent program and set parameters to define structures
    Define instances to collect data, on the 'Application Instances' form
    Name a plan in the Supply Chain Plan Names form
    Create named priority rules and set the priority criteria within each rule.
        A priority rule default is required for a plan. Use the 'Define Priority Rules' form
    Create a named plan and set the planning options for the named plan on the Plan Options form

Advanced Supply Chain Planning (ASCP) Profile Options:
    MSO: Inventory Carrying Costs Percentage
        average percent of item value that is carrying cost for optimization calcs. Can be overridden at the item level
    MRP: Plan Revenue Price List, and MRP: Plan Revenue Discount Percent
        used to calculate revenue for margin optimization on forecast demand (not on sales orders where actual prices are used)
    MSO: Penalty Cost Factor for Late Demands
        establishes the penalty fraction per item per day for late deliveries.

Advanced Supply Chain Planning (ASCP) Forms:
    Sourcing Rules -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Sourcing/Sourcing Rules
        named rules that define transfer or buy rules from other organizations or vendors (linked to assignment sets to determine sourced items)
    Planning Parameters -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Setup/Parameters
        to define the time buckets for a plan
    Bills of Distribution -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Sourcing/Bills of Distribution
        a collection of sourcing rules with multiple receiving organizations, rather than a single org, all sharing the same sourcing
    Sourcing Rule/Bill of Distribution Assignments -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Sourcing/View Assignments
        associates sourcing rules or BOD's with assignment sets to specify items covered by the rules
    View Sourcing (Assignment) Hierarchy -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Sourcing/View Sourcing Hierarchy
        shows all sourcing rules/BOD's and assignments applicable to an item and which rule applies
    Plan Options -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Supply Chain Plan/Options
        used to set planning contraints and options, including by time period and overall planning constraints for a single assignment set
    Application Instances -> ....... to define the different instances for data collection and planning
    Priority Rules -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Setup/Priority Rules
        to define and name a priority rule and its criteria and associate with a plan.
    Supply Chain Plan Names -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Supply Chain Plan/Names
    Collection Workbench -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Collections/View Collected Data
        to view data in the planner pulled by the collection process
    Planner Workbench -> ADVANCED SUPPLY CHAIN PLANNER/Supply Chain Plan/Planner Workbench
        to view plan run results and release work orders
    Supply/Demand -> via the Planner Workbench and right click on an action in the Actions tab
    Gantt Chart of scheduled jobs -> Right click on an order in the supply/demand window
        allows drag/visual changes to existing planned schedules
    Preferences -> choose Tools/Preferences from the menu bar
        to modify the appearance of the workbench and the data displayed

Advanced Supply Chain Planning (ASCP) Concurrent Programs:
    Create Planning Flexfields - to establish descriptive flexfields to store plan penalty factors

Advanced Supply Chain Planning (ASCP) Interfaces:
    Sourcing Rules/BOD API, Sourcing Rules/BOD Assignment API
        imports sourcing rules, bills of distribution and their item assignments and sets

Advanced Supply Chain Planning (ASCP) Seeded Workflows:
    Item Forecast - notified overcommitted items, below safety stock, shortagees, excess inventory, or expired lots
    Sales Order - notifies late sales orders and late supply pegged to sales orders
    Rescheduling - notifies past due orders and orders with compression (within their manufacturing lead time)
    Project - notifies items with shortages or excesses on projects
    Material and Resource Capacity - notifies material constraints

    Alert History
    Definition Sets and System Options
    Key Tables

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Troubleshooting, Tips and Tricks:
    Avoid duplicates on summary alerts by using :DATE_LAST_CHECKED in the Where clause (a self referencing alert)
        Formatting the date is required otherwise an error will be thrown
        e.g. WHERE TO_DATE(creation_date, 'DD-MON-YYYY HH24:MI:SS') > TO_DATE(:DATE_LAST_CHECKED, 'DD-MON-YYYY HH24:MI:SS')
    You won't see history in Alert Check if there is no retention to 'Keep x Days' in the Alert definition
    Test a Periodic Alert to verify it is working by running Alert Check
        If the Alert is disabled (Enabled box unchecked) it is not runnable from the Alert Check process
        On the Alert Manager menu, choose 'Request' > 'Check' and run the Alert
        Initially Set the Alert Option to Keep History for 7 Days so you can view the Actions from the Alert
            If you don't set this option, action history will be blank and unavailable for debugging
        After running the Alert, review the results and Actions of an Alert via Alert History
            Navigation is Alert Manager -> History -> (Query Alert) -> 'Find Checks' or 'Find Exceptions' or 'Find Actions'
                'Find Checks' finds each execution of the Alert Check process for an alert
                'Find Exceptions' displays the values of output variables from each run of the Alert
                'Find Actions'
        The 'Verify' button on the Alert Definition form parses the SQL but does not run it
        The 'Run' button on the Alert Definition runs the SQL but does not invoke any actions
            Running from this button will not create output - you must run the Alert Check process
        Duplicate checking won't work if Alert history is set to zero
    For 11.5.10.2 RUP4 and above, Alert uses Workflow Mailer and not Unix Sendmail
        Mails will not go out if Workflow Notification Mailer is disabled
            Mails will queue up in WF_NOFIICATION_OUT and can be seen with a query
                select * from wf_notification_out;
            To see if the Notification Mailer is disabled, run
                SELECT COMPONENT_STATUS from APPS.FND_SVC_COMPONENTS where COMPONENT_ID=10006;
    Add SQL*Plus format masks to output variables using a "#" pound sign delimiter
        e.g. &QTY#999999 formats the number as six digits with no decimals
        e.g. &LNAME#A15 formats the string as 15 characters
    Set the value of an input variable in SQL through the Alert Input Form
        Navigation: Alerts -> (Query Alert) -> Alert Details -> Inputs (tab)
    Pass an input variable to an output variable, select the input into the output
        e.g. Select name, :INVAR into &NAME, &INVAR from table
            This passes :INVAR into &INVAR for formatting into the action output
    Event Alerts cannot take before and after pictures of what changed
        This is because they fire after insert or after update - not before
    Debug the Alert SQL SELECT statement in SQL*PLUS before importing it into the Alert for further testing
    Avoid Event Alerts because they are resource intensive and fire every time a table is updated
        Use Periodic Alerts instead
    Define one Concurrent Manager to run the ALECTC processes
        ALECTC is the Alert concurrent request (Alert Event Check)
        exclude ALECTC from other concurrent managers to optimize performance
        Note that ALECDC is the equivalent concurrent process for periodic alerts
    You can delete an Alert if there is no enabled action set, or action history

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on References:
    http://docs.oracle.com/cd/A60725_05/html/comnls/us/alr/selfref.htm - self referencing alerts

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Profile Options:

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Terminology:
    Action Set - a collection of one or more defined actions
        Action Sets are tied to Alerts and Actions within an Action Set are processed with the Alert
        This allows multiple Actions to be performed in sequence (by grouping under an action set)
            However it creates an uneeded wrapper layer if only one action is required
    Alert Check - the process of running an alert (either ALETC for event or ALECDC for periodic)
        This is run from the Alert Manager window and executes the Alert and related actions
    Alert Exception - a single row returned by the Alert SQL script when the Alert fires

Alerts (ALR Schema) Notes on Responsibilities:
    Alert Manager (AM) - this is the only seeded Alert responsibility

Alerts (ALR Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Alerts trigger actions such as emails or execution of scripts or concurrent programs
    There are two types of alerts:
        A Periodic Alert is a Select query that runs on a schedule and performs an action for each line returned
        Periodic Alerts fired by a clock (concurrent schedule), and
            Periodic Alerts perform actions based on a set schedule or On Demand
            On Demand firing requires a user to request the Alert to run via the 'Alert Check' process
        Rows returned by a Periodic Alert Statement indicate a condition has been met
            An action is performed if the condition is met (i.e. one or more rows are returned)
        Event Alerts fired by an event such as a database event (row insert, update, but not delete).
            An Event Alert is a Select query that fires on a database trigger and performs an action for each line returned
            Event Alerts are basically triggers - they are based on a non-periodic event
            Triggers include insert or update actions on a record in a table
                Delete actions are not tracked by Event Alerts
    Input variables can be defined for an Alert with ":" notation (e.g. ":MY_VAR")
        There are several implicit variables defined automatically by Alert: ":ROWID", ":MAILID", ":DATE_LAST_CHECKED"
        These can be used in the Alert
    Output variables can be defined for an Alert with "&" notation (e.g. "&OUT_VAR") and included in email templates
    The Select Query in an Alert cannot be an update or insert - it must be a select
    Updates must be defined as Actions or in PL/SQL Packages 'selected' by an SQL statement
    Alerts maintain a history of previous alert runs to enable checking of repeated alert events
    Alert History also supports auditing of exceptions
    Response processing parses email responses from users for follow up actions
    Actions must be wrapped into Action Sets to tie to an alert - even singular actions require an action set wrapper
        Event alerts cannot capture before/after pictures - they only fire after insert or update
    Oracle Applications ship with a number of precoded Event Alerts for DBA and Alert management
        These precoded alerts are embedded in the applications
    Alerts are defined under individual applications (they must be named uniquely within an application)
        The application is used to determine the Oracle ID used to log onto the system when the alert is run.
        It establishes privileges for the alert
    Alert exceptions are found by executing an SQL SELECT script when the event (or periodic schedule) occurs:
        each row returned by the SELECT script is an exception
        Multiple exceptions (return lines from the SQL statement) can be evaluated for a single outcome or
            grouping of outcomes (summary action) with a threshhold
    Alert actions can be: SQL scripts, Operating System scripts, email, or concurrent requests
        Alert actions have levels:
            Detail (one action for every line returned by the SELECT statement,
            Summary (one action for all lines returned by the SELECT statement)
            No Exception (one action defined if there is no exception found)
                You can use this level to send an alert if no exception if found
    Alerts has an interface with email for outbound notifications and inbound responses
        emails are the most common actions taken by alerts
        Mail distributions can be downloaded from 'mailto' tables for dynamic routing
    Response processing in alerts handles responses to alerts made by users.
        Response processing can trigger actions just as alerts trigger actions

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Defining an Alert
    Exercise: Define an Event Alert
        1. Define the Alert -> <Alert Manager>/Alert/Define
            Name the Alert and it's Application (names must be unique within application)
                The Alert Application is used for a namespace
                The Alert Application also gives the Alert its database credentials
            Check or uncheck the Enabled check box to activate or suspend the Alert
                If the Alert is disabled it is not runnable from the Alert Check process
            Choose the Periodic Alternate Region or Event Alternate Region
                If the Periodic Alternate Region is chosen
                    Set the schedule for the Alert or choose "On Demand"
                If the Event Alternate Region is chosen
                    Choose the table the Alert will trigger from (Application and Tablename)
                        The Application for the table can be different to the Alert Application
                        The table must be registered with the Oracle Applications Library
                    Set the trigger mode as Insert or Update
                        Check both boxes to fire the Alert on both modes
            Enter the SQL Select Statement
                The statement must contain an Into clause
                    The Into Clause must have one output variable for each column selected
                    Output variables are designatd with a leading "&" ampersand
        2. Create Alert Details -> <Alert Manager>/Alert/Define/(Query the Alert)/Details
        3. Define Actions -> <Alert Manager>/Alert/Define/(Query the Alert)/Actions
        4. Define an Action Set -> <Alert Manager>/Alert/Define/(Query the Alert)/Action Set

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Message Actions:
    Message actions are based on user responses to an alert
        Actions can respond to parameter values in the response
    Followup actions are defined to trigger if no response is received in a set time period
    Alerts can make efficient substitutes to developing custom reports
    Alert history is maintained and can be reviewed.
        Alert history is needed if duplicate alert supression is needed
    The event table for an event alert is the table on which the alert sets the trigger
        This trigger is set to fire and execute the Alert SQL SELECT statement
    Output variables are defined with a leading '&', populated from the SELECT statement in the alert
    Input variables are defined with a leading ':', and used as parameters in the SELECT statement in the alert
    Implicit inputs supplied by Alert to the SELECT are :ROWID, :MAILID and :DATE_LAST_CHECKED
        :ROWID is used to identify the row that triggered the event
            It is internally assigned by Alert logic from the trigger that set off the event
        :MAILID is the mail address of the application user
            It defaults to the user name or operating system user id if the mail address is not setup in the user profile
        :DATE_LAST_CHECKED is set internally by Alerts to the date of the last event for the alert.
            It can be used in the SELECT to limit the query

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Internal Architecture:
    There are three concurrent programs that run alerts:
        ALEPPE - Periodic Alert Scheduler (finds periodic alerts to schedule the next day)
        ALECDC - Check Periodic Alert (scheduled by ALEPPE for each periodic alert each day)
        ALECTC - Check Event Alert (fired by a database trigger)
    For event alerts, a database event (trigger) submits the concurrent alert program
        The program (ALECTC - Check Event Alert) receives the name of the Alert as a parameter
            It runs the SQL Select statement defined in the Alert.
        ALECTC processes the SELECT statement in the alert to identify a condition
            If a condition is met (i.e. row returned) ALECTC executes the Alert action
    For periodic alerts, a concurrent program runs every 24 hours (ALEPPE - Periodic Alert Scheduler)
        ALEPPE creates a separate scheduled instance of "ALECDC - Check Periodic Alert" for each periodic alert
            Only those periodic alerts with schedules pending in the next 24 hours are scheduled
            ALEPPE searches (and creates a schedule) for all upcoming Periodic Alerts in the next day
        Each scheduled ALECDC starts the SELECT clause in the Alert to test for any returned rows.
            ALECDC executes the Alert Action if the condition is found true (one or more rows are returned)
    For concurrent program actions, output parameters can be specified in the alert definition.
        Multiple parameters are separated by a space. Constants must be quoted
    For email message alerts, distribution lists can be setup and used in address fields.
        Multiple email ID's are comma separated.
        The email server address is the 'replyto' address in the setup form for email message actions
    For email alerts requiring automated response processing,
        a response set must be defined and referenced (response set includes response text and valid values)
    Message text for notification emails can be imported by choosing 'File' and entering the file path as a variable name
        or entered directly as text. Message maximum length is 2000 characters
    Output variables ('&var's) can be inserted in the message text that goes with the email notification
        (eg '... your journal &HEADER_NAME for ...')
    Exercise: Create a message alert distribution list: AM/Distribution List, and specify mail-to recipients
    The Application associated with an Alert Definition determines the database authority it runs under

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Actions:
    Define by clicking the 'Actions' button on the Define Alerts form
        Name each action and it's type/level: detail, summary, no-exception.
    Define the details for each action by clicking on the 'Details' button on the Actions form.
        Choose one of four responses: message, concurrent program, SQL script or operating system script
    Action type = Message sends an email to a list of recipients for each row returned by the SELECT statement
    If a Summary Action is chosen for a message action type -
        one message is sent for each unique combination of output variables
        there is one row in the message for each row returned by the SELECT statement
    Action type = Concurrent program lets you choose a concurrent program and specify the parameters
    If a Summary Action is chosen for a concurrent program action type
        the concurrent program executes once for every unique combination of arguments returned by the SQL script
    Action type = Operating System Script lets you name a script
        (or an Oracle App and script - Alerts uses the BIN subdirectory to look for the script) to execute.
        Separate parameters with a space.
    If a summary action is chosed for an operating system action type -
        the operating system script is executed once for each unique combination of values returned by the SELECT statement in the alert
    You can type in a script directly instead of referencing an external file name.
        This allows you to embed output variables in the script.
    Action type = SQL Statment Script.
        Each statement must end with a ';' or '/' to work.
        If an application is specified, the SQL filename must be in the /sql subdirectory under the application top.
        Output variables '&...' can be used as filenames to point to the SQL file
    If a 'No Exception' action level is chosen -
        you cannot reference any output variables in the action definition
        the output variables will be NULL - the SELECT statement will return no lines

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Escalated Actions and Duplicate Suppression
    Trick
        You have to check the Alert Output in Alert Check to see if Duplicate Suppression is Working
            Alert Check will show notifications created even though duplicate suppression is turned on
            The Suppression is in the output file - and shows if the emails were actually sent
            It is also a good idea to check actual email output in a mail account to see if suppression is working
    You must use an Escalation Group to use Duplicate Suppression
        Duplicate Suppression prevents the same message being sent out twice within the History Retention period
        To enable Duplicate Suppression
            Define an Escalation Group for the Alert (from the Tools menu)
            Include the Alert Action in the Escalation Group
            Include the Escalation Group in the Alert Action Set (don't include the Alert Action)
            Enable the Duplicate Suppression Flag on the Action Set and individual Action Set output members
            Set the Alert History Retention to a non-zero value
            Run the Alert twice - first to establish an Alert History and then to check duplicate suppression
    Escalating alerts allow new alerts if an exception condition remains uncleared.
        It requires escalation history be active for the alert
    Escalating alert actions are defined in escalation groups
        Each action in an escalation group must have the same action level (summary, detail, no exception)
    Individual actions in an escalation group are escalated based on level
        Level is lowest to highest and can be checkmarked as disabled, or end dated.
    Exercise: Define an Escalation Group -> AM/Alert/Define and choose Escalation Groups from the Tools menu
        to define an escalation group and attach individual actions and define the escalation level for each action

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Summary Threshold Groups:
    Summary threshold groups are action groups that combine a detailed action and summary action.
        The detail action is triggered unless ...
            the number of exceptions reaches a threshold
            in which event the summary action is triggered to summarize the larger number of exceptions
    Exercise: Define a Summary Threshold Group -> AM/Alert/Define and choose Threshold Group from the Tools Menu.
        Select a summary and detail action with the same action type (eg message, or SQL script)

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Action Sets:
    Multiple actions can be defined for a single alert
        Action sets decide the order of execution, what to do if the action fails, and threshold levels for threshold groups
    Multiple action sets are allowed for a single alert and can be sequenced in the Action Set form.
    Action sets can be enabled or disabled with a checkbox or end date on the action set line.
    On Error Actions for each action listed in an action set can be
        Abort (finish processing the action),
        Set (specify the sequence number of another action set to run, or
        Member (specify the sequence of another action in the same set to run)
    Exercise: Define an Action Set -> AM/Alert/Define and choose Action Set from the Tools menu.
        If multiple action sets are needed, specify a sequence number for each to execute when the alert triggers

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Response Sets and Response Processing:
    Response processing initiates actions based on valid, invalid, or lack of response to message actions issued by alerts.
        It is only valid for message actions
    Response values that are returned with the response allow different actions to take place, only if the response is a valid response.
    Response actions are actions triggered by response to an alert action such as a message.
    Response sets group response actions the same way action sets group the original actions.
        Response sets determine the sequence of response actions
    Response variables can be defined for response actions - these variables are set by the response to the original alert action.
        Response variables are defined with leading '&'s the same as action output variables
    Response variable names are entered without the leading '&'.
        Response variable names must be different to alert output variable names
    Response action types are:
        valid,
        invalid and
        no-response.
            For no-response types, the wait time is defined in the action definition as Response Days
    Response actions are defined behind each type button on the Response Definition form,
        along with the valid response actions
    A valid response action definition requires a text message with the Response Variable = '?' embedded in the text.
        Subst the "Response Variable" with the actual variable name.
    No text response definition is needed for an invalid or 'none' response
        only the list of actions to be processed if an invalid response or no response is received
    An invalid response action can notify the responder that their response was invalid, and to resubmit a valid response.
    The response set and response days are linked to message actions on the message action definition form
    For Ver 11, Oracle Office must be installed to support response processing
    Message responses are tracked by a message handle (alert installation no. plus sequence no.) for each outbound message.
        This value is returned with the response
    An Oracle Office mail account or some other mail account must be setup on the system to accept the responses
        (ie an alternative is email notification mailer)
    Exercise: Define a response set -> AM/Alert/Define, and click on Response Sets for an alert
    Exercise: Define a response variable for a response set -> from the Response Set form, click on Response Variables

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Predefined Event Alerts for Apps DBA Tables:
    Several periodic alerts are predefined on the Oracle DBA tables that are in the SYS or SYSTEM schemas
    Indexes near maximum extents- raises alerts if any index is within 5 extents of reaching the maximum allocated extents.
        Customizable to a specific index or application user account (ie application)
    Indexes too large or fragmented - identifies indexes with over 100,000 blocks or over 20 extents.
        Customizable to check only blocks, only extents and limit to one application user account (ie application)
    Indexes unable to allocate another extent - identifies all indexes unable to allocate another extent.
        Customizable to check an indvidual index or application user account
    Tables near maximum extents - same as alert for indexes near maximum extents, but for tables
    Tables too large or fragmented - same as alert for indexes too large or fragmented, but for tables
    Tables unable to allocate another extent - same as alert for indexes unable to allocat another extent, but for tables
    Tablespaces without adequate free space - identifies tablespaces with either
        1. less than 100kbytes free space, or
        2. less than 10kbytes contiguous free space
    Users near tablespace quota - identifies any application user account with 95% of assigned tablespace in use
        (or less than 100kbytes free)

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Predefined Event Alerts for Oracle Alerts Tables:
    Purge alert and action set checks
        purges concurrent requests of ALECTC or ALECDC alert processes over 30 days old.
        Both the alert process and the Action Set Check process are purged.
            Action set checks are not purged if responses are still pending.
    Purge concurrent requests - purges all concurrent requests over 30 days old, plus the output files and the log files
    Purge Oracle office messages - purges old messages in Oracle Office
        those more than 60 days old in the Reviewed and Reviewed_OK folders.
        Can be customized to specific folders or for specific users

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Periodic Alerts and Periodic Sets:
    Periodic alerts are alerts fired on a predefined schedule or on demand.
        They can monitor exceptions, system conditions, trigger actions and perform routine tasks
    Periodic alerts are defined the same way an event alert is defined, except
        the alert is on a time schedule, instead of a table insert or update
    Periodic alerts are defined under an application to inherit logon access privileges when they are run.
        Alert names must be unique within the application
    Periodic alert Period Details include:
        Frequency, Start, Finish and Check Interval (optional).
    If the period is set to 'On Demand' then
        the alert can be fired using the 'Request Periodic Alert Check' menu selection under 'Requests'.
        This initiates the ALECDC process
    Check intervals are the time intervals with which Alerts will run a periodic alert multiple times in a single scheduled period
    To run the alert multiple times a day,
        define start and end times for the entire period (eg 8:00 to 5:00 pm) and set a check interval of one hour
    Periodic Sets group periodic alerts onto a single schedule for execution
    Exercise: Run a periodic alert on demand ->
        AM/Request/Check and specify the Application and Alert
        (remember, Alert names are only unique within an application)
    Exercise: Define a periodic alert -> AM/Alert/Define, and choose the alternate region 'Periodic'
    Exercise: Define a Periodic Set -> AM/Alert/Periodic Set, and
        define a periodic set (within an application) and the periodic alerts to run within the set.
        Use the Sequence Number to define execution order

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on the Periodic Alert Scheduler
    The periodic alert scheduler runs every night and schedules periodic alerts that run the following day
    Exercise: Setup the Periodic Alert Scheduler -> Alert Manager/Request/Schedule
        then click the Activate button for the Periodic Alert Scheduler
    It is not available directly under concurrent manager and must be activated using the menu navigation Alert Manager/Request/Schedule

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Alert History
    Enable Keep > 0 to see Alert History otherwise no Alert History is viewable
    Alert History keeps every Alert Check executed
        all the exceptions found (where one row returned by the SQL is an exception)
        which action sets were executed by the alert exceptions
            for the retention period on the Alert definition
    Histories of Responses and Response Actions are also kept against each action history item
    Message duplicats (same output variable values) are flagged
    Exercise: Review Alert History -> AM/Alert/History and query the alert,
        then click Find Checks (alerts run), Find Exceptions (SELECT results found)
            or Find Actions (Action Sets and Actions executed)

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Definition Steps and System Options:
    Install Alerts and setup System Options in five alternate regions:
        Mail,
        Oracle Office,
        Message Elements,
        Response Processing and
        More Options
    Define the alert - as event based or periodic, and specify the SQL SELECT statement for the alert to retrieve the exception lines.
        Verify the alert
    Create actions - as either detail, summary or no-exception.
        Define the type of action: SQL, Message, Concurrent Process, and System Script.
            If a response is sought, a detail message action is needed
    Create response actions
        use output variables and response variables as needed
        test for valid response, invalid response and no response
    Define Escalation Groups and Summary Threshold Groups - optional
        to escalate alerts or create summary alerts if detail alert volume crosses a threshold
    Create Action Sets - to group and sequence individual actions for an alert.
        Multiple action sets are allowed and one action set can fire another
    Create Response Sets - group response actions that will trigger in sequence for a single response set.
    Associate the Response Sets to the Actions (for message type actions that elicit responses).
        This is done on the Message Action Definition form
    The Email System options in System Options specifies the mail system to use and the address to invoke the system
    The Message Element options in System Options allow you to specify the header and footer text sent with a message action
        plus the text for a Response and a Returned Message
    The Response Processing options in System Options include:
        parameters for enabling the response processor including
            the unique Alert ID that goes out on messages for response processing
                plus the scheduled run times for the processor
    The More Options in System Options provide default mail accounts for the user
        and the name of the concurrent manager to use, plus other configuration options.
    Exercise: Setup system options for Alerts -> AM/System/Options
        check each alternate region for required Alerts setup parameters

Alert (ALR Schema) Notes on Key Tables:
    All Alert tables originally in the APPLSYS schema with an "ALR" name prefix are now moved to their own ALR schema
    ALR_ALERTS - main alerts registry
    ALR_ACTIONS - actions for alerts
    ALR_ACTION_SETS - action sets for an alert
    ALR_OUTPUT_HISTORY - output variable values for each run of an alert check in ALR_ALERT_CHECKS
    ALR_ALERT_CHECKS - list of every instance of the Alert Check process running.

Application Desktop Integrator (ADI) and WebADI (BNE Schema) Tips and Tricks
    For R12, the menu 'Oracle Web ADI Menu' is no longer used. It must be replaced with Desktop Integration Menu
    Macro security must be disabled in Excel 2010 Trust Center
    'Allow status bar updates via script' must be enabled in Internet Explorer
    There are two symbols or flags used in WebADI
        A circle means the line has been inserted and was not in the original template. It can be turned on or off by typing or removing the letter m in the cell. This symbol is inserted automatically on any new lines inserted by the user.
        A flag means a character has been typed into the Upl column to indicate the row should be uploaded using the Upload Flagged Rows option. It can be turned on or off by typing any character in the cell and tabbing out of the cell.
