    To enable Debug, set the BNE Profiles:
        BNE Server Log Filename = <provide name>
        BNE Server Log Level = TRACE
        BNE Server Log Path = <set to the value of the $APPLTMP> OR <match the value given in the webadi.properties for 11i.

Applications Desktop Integrator and WebADI (BNE Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    ADI is a spreadsheet interface to the Oracle Applications
    ADI is a client component up to and including 11.5.10 and a web component starting with 12i (WebADI)
    ADI can perform upload of budgets and journals prepared on a spreadsheet,
        upload of fixed assets and submission of concurrent requests
    ADI (client version) operates in connected or disconnected mode with the applications
    ADI observes segment value security rules associated with responsibilities
    Request Center on the client version allows running and downloading of reports (including FSG's) to the desktop for web browser, text or spreadsheet import.
        Request Center is replaced by Report Manager in R12
    ADI includes an Account Hierarchy Editor with drag and drop editing of the structure of the chart of accounts child and parent values
    Web ADI is introduced in Version 12 through new responsibilities and has no client-installed component
        The client version is not supported in R12 - each WebADI runs under its own application
        WebADI is a framework for building integrators
        It has over 200 pre-built integrators including an integrator for Microsoft Project and for Microsoft Word
        Several integrators are implemented as standard configurations
            Enterprise Performance Foundation: Hierarchy Integrator
            Enterprise Performance Foundation: Member Integrator
            Financial Consolidation Hub: Intercompany maps
            Financial Consolidation Hub: Dimension Hierarchies
            Financial Consolidation Hub: Value Set Mapping
            General Ledger - Budgets
            General Ledger - Journals
            Intercompany - Single Batch Entry
        There are additional integrator that can be added into the 'Desktop Integrator' responsibility
            These must be manually added into the 'Desktop Integration' menu assigned to the responsibility
            The additional integrators are in Projects, Procurement etc and documented in those application guides.
       For R12, in the Oracle Web ADI responsibility the menu 'Oracle Web ADI Menu' is no longer used.
           It must be replaced with Desktop Integration Menu
       WebADI uses standard MIME types (Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions)

Application Desktop Integrator and WebADI (BNE Schema) Notes on Schema Configuration and Customization
    References
        WebADI - Is It Possible to Change the Upload Parameter Values that Default When Creating Document and Uploading to GL? (Doc ID 344780.1)
        How to Set Default on Journal Templates to "Validate Before Import" in Release 12 (Doc ID 790334.1)
    Options can be set on the form function BNE_ADI_CREATE_DOCUMENT to default upload options for GL Journals
        Append bne:import=N to default the 'Import after upload' option to No
            This is set under System Administration, Functions (Form Functions) and querying BNE_ADI_CREATE_DOCUMENT
        Also set the profile option 'ADI: Allow Set Parameters' to 'No' to prevent users changing upload options

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on NLS, Character Sets and Language Support
    References
        Globe Icon Greyed Out For Standard Oracle SLA Setup (Doc ID 1669076.1)
        NOTE:414630.1 - R12 How Is The Field 'Journal Entry Language' Used?
        NOTE:601459.1 - CANNOT ENTER TRANSLATION AS THE GLOBE ICON IS DISABLED
        Customizing Translation in Oracle E-Business Suite - R12(1382124.1)
        Customizing Translation in Oracle E-Business Suite - R11(372952.1)
        R12: When is Oracle going to update to SEPA Rulebook Version 6.1? (Doc ID 1514293.1)
        R12: AP: An Invalid Character Was Found In Text Content. When Format Payment Instructions With Text Output Is Opened (Doc ID 1611585.1)
        AP: SEPA: Which Character Set is supported and validated in SEPA XML Output Format? (Doc ID 1307781.1)
        Globalization Guide for Oracle Applications Release 12 (Doc ID 393861.1)
        How to Display Attachments in the Correct Character Set (Doc ID 231543.1)
    Troubleshooting
        Profile Option FND: NATIVE CLIENT ENCODING should match NLS database parameter 'NLS_CHARACTERSET' to avoid invalid characters in output files like SEPA payment files
            Set at the user level to match the encoding on the local machine
        select value from nls_database_parameters where parameter = 'NLS_CHARACTERSET';
    Overview
        In Forms, any table with a _TL table will support MLS translations and the World Globe on the maintenance form will be active
        The Globe icon in Forms is only available for forms which are associated to a MLS table.
    NLS or National Language Support supports viewing forms and reports in a national language
        Languages other than than American English are supported
        The chosen language is based on the chosen responsibility
    MLS or Multi Language Support is a superset of NLS and can support multiple languages on a single instance
        MLS supports different languages by a user on the same instance
        MLS also supports different languages on preprinted forms and report text
        MLS tables are the _TL tables
    Character sets can be 7 bit, byte or double-byte (Japanese).
    Only one character set per instance is currently supported by Oracle
        Asian and European character sets cannot co-exist.
            Multiple instances are needed.
    Database Settings
        select value from nls_database_parameters where parameter = 'NLS_CHARACTERSET';
        select parameter, value from nls_database_parameters where parameter like 'NLS%';
    UTF-8 supports multiple languages in double-byte format
        This includes both Asian and European languages on a single instance
    National Language compiled versions of all forms and reports
        They are stored under the $APPL_TOP for each application
        Text is compiled into these files and cannot be modified dynamically
    Adding a language can be done during or post installation
        It requires staging the additional translation patches for the new languages (NLS patches)
        If done during installation, the base language patch must be installed first
    Locale is a combination of Language, Territory and character set
        Naming is "language[_territory][.codeset][@modifier]" (e.g. en_US.UTF-8)
        Set the locale in concurrent requests using the Language button
            Choosing multiple languages will add Layout lines in the Options area for BI Published reports

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Responsibilities and Menus
    References
        Checking Functions Associated with a User Menu or a Responsibility (Doc ID 948512.1) -- for scripts
    Responsibilities are Oracle's method of controlling access to the applications.
        Responsibilities have an associated primary top level menu
    Responsibility 'Preferences' allows configuration of the personal homepage
    Responsibilities can be customized with new menus
        Menus can include forms from multiple applications to match specific job roles
            This eliminates constant 'hat switching' (responsibility switching)
        An example of this is the Procure to Pay Administrator responsibility in Purchasing
            It includes menus from purchasing and payables.
    Responsibilities are tied to a Business Groups with the profile option "HR:Business Group"
        It is done through a Profile Option rather than through the Responsibilities form
    For each instance of the Oracle applications, there is only one instance of the AOL
        This meands there is only one setup of users, passwords and privileges.
        This applies regardless of multi-org setups
    Security Rules limit access based on data values
        This is done by defining exclusion rule groups and tying to responsibilities
            see flexfields
    High level menus are often customized when associated with responsibilities during an install
        Submenus are most often not customized
            they are simply included or excluded from the top level menus
    Submenus correspond with entries on the AOL navigator
        The lowest level entries on the Navigator correspond with forms
    Menu changes trigger the process 'Compile Security' (FNDSCMPI) or 'Compile Security Menu' (FNDSCMPM)
        These populate APPLSYS.FND_COMPILED_MENU_FUNCTIONS with valid function/menu combinations
        An error ' The Function Is Not Available Under The Responsibility' may appear if it does't work
        Solution:
            Manually run the 'Compile Security' concurrent program with parameter "YES"
            Shut down Middle Tier (Apache)
            Restart Middle tier
            Test the menu item 
    Key Tables
        APPLSYS.FND_RESPONSIBILITY
        APPLSYS.FND_RESPONSIBILITY_TL
        APPLSYS.FND_COMPILED_MENU_FUNCTIONS

Applications Object Library (AOL FND and APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Form Folders
    Profile Option: Folders:Allow Customization - can be disabled to lock most folder functions
    You can delete Form Folders via System Administrator Responsibility
        System Administrator > Application > Folder Management
    Form folders are defined in the FND_FOLDERS and FND_FOLDER_COLUMNS tables
        The WHERE clause is in FND_FOLDERS  for folders saved with a query
    You should never save a folder with the embedded SQL as part of the folder definition
        Do this by setting AutoQuery to 'Never' before saving
    You can restore a default folder if it has been overwritten
        Create a throw-away folder ands save as 'Default'
        Then delete the custom folder - it will restore the original system default folder
        Save the system default folder with the name 'Default'

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Database Links and Database Files
    Database links can be established to connect data tables from different instances
        Database links are created at the SQL command line to allow access to tables in another database
            This is done by referencing the instance to a fully qualified tablename.
    Tablespaces correspond to operating system files
        One tablespace can include multiple files but two tablespaces cannot exist in the same file.
    All permissions to all tables in Oracle applications are granted to the APPS schema
    Apps server directory structure hierarchy is
        $APPL_TOP/MODULE/VERSION/bin (runtimes)
        $APPL_TOP/MODULE/VERSION/log (messages)
        $APPL_TOP/MODULE/VERSION/install (scripts, source and patches)

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Security Reports
    List all users assigned to a responsibility
        -> System Administrator/Concurrent Requests/Users of a Responsibility

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Data Groups:
    A Data Group is a list of applications and their database schema accounts
    The purpose of a data group is to assign a Database schema ID to a responsibility
        so the form/concurrent process can access the database when it connects.
    Each responsibility is attached to a data group
        The responsibility accesses the database using the Oracle user id matching the application called
    One responsibility can have several applications
        The form or concurrent process identifies the application
        It then selects the correct Oracle ID from the data group
    Each responsibility has a data group/application pair
        This identifies the application for the responsibility
        It then looks up the Oracle User ID from the datagroup that matches the application
    One data group can be shared across multiple responsibilities
        But each responsibility must choose a specific application in the data group to use
            (and inherit the corresponding Oracle ID)
    The seeded responsibilities have two possible data groups:
        'Standard' and 'Multiple Reporting Currencies'
    Exercise: Review Data Groups -> System Administrator/Oracle/Data Group
        to see existing datagroups or collections of application names and database accounts
    Exercise: Create or Review Oracle Database User Accounts
        -> System Administrator/Security/Oracle/Register, to see existing database accounts
        -> System Administrator/Security/Oracle/Data Group, to see data groups and their component applications

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Securing Attributes:
    Securing attributes are used by Self Service Applications
        They limit the rows of data a user or responsibility can view in self service applications
    Securing Attributes can be assigned to a user or to a responsibility or both
    Securing Attributes in the responsibilities block of the user menu can be assigned to users
        They limit what a user can see in self service forms (web apps)
        The securing attribute value is checked each time a function is selected from a responsibility
        Functions that expect certain securing attribute values may throw errors if they don't find valid values
    Securing attributes are defined in the Web Applications Dictionary as the columns in the WAD tables
    Examples of securing attributes are:
        ICX_HR_PERSON_ID - is the person you 'become' in self service apps for iExpense
        TO_PERSON_ID - is the requestor for a requisition in self service procurement

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Profile Options
    MO: Operating Unit - associates an operating unit to a responsibility.
        Assigned at the responsibility level and defaulted at the site level
        Assigns an operating unit organization to a responsibility to restrict access to transactions
    ICX: Session Timeout
        the maximum duration in minutes of inactivity for a single user connection
        site level profile
        Reference: "R12: Forms Timeout More Than 2 Hrs Is Not Working After R12 Upgrade [ID 734077.1]"
    ICX: Limit Time - the maximum time in hours a user can be continuously connected
        regardless of inactivity - site level profile
    ICX: Limit Connect
        the maximum number of connections that can be requested in a single session
            site level profile
    Viewer:text browser
        Sets the output of log files to the browser and HTML instead of an Oracle Apps window
    Utilities:Diagnostics    Yes
        Turns on Tools/Examine without needing the Apps password
    FND:Diagnostics
        This is the self-service equivalent of 'Utilities:Diagnostics'
    Java Color Scheme
        Sets the color scheme for the navigator to blue or white. 
            11.5.8 is 'blue'
            12.1.3 is 'swan'
        References
            Performance Degradation in Forms in R12 When not Using Swan Color Scheme (Doc ID 786582.1)
    Flexfields:Validate on Server   No
        Eliminates the error setting up expense charge account rules in purchasing (Yes causes the error)
    Flexfields:Open Key Window
        Opens the flexfield window automatically when the cursor is positioned on the accounting keyflex
    Flexfields:Open Descr Window
        Opens the descriptive flexfield window automatically in forms
    Personalize Self-Service Defn
        at the user level to display personalizations links on all self service web pages
    ICX: Client IANA Encoding
        Sets encoding for output reports

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Report Review Agent (RRA)
    RRA is implemented with the FNDFS Executable Functionality
    RRA is the default text browser in Oracle Applications
        It allows viewing of log files and output
        it is also referred to as the executable 'FNDFS'
    FNDFS - FND File Server and Report Reviewer Agent
        is used to retrieve reports from the Concurrent Manager server
    This default viewer must be configured correctly
        before external editors and browsers can be used to view output
    FNDFS is a listener program that communicates with client requests
        via TNSNAMES.ORA configuration and Net8 communications
    FNDFS enables reports residing on the concurrent manager server
        normally on the database node or backend tier to be displayed on the client tier
    The TNS Names entry on the dbserver includes an alias FNDFS<node_name>
        which maps to a fake SID "FNDFS" which launches the FNDFS executable
    If multiple FNDFS processes are run between multiple applications
        each application must have a profile option set "RRA: Service Prefix" set to the correct service name
    Profile Option: RRA: Enabled - must be set to Yes for RRA to return report results
    Metalink Notes:  111383.1 The Basics About Report Review Agent (FNDFS) on 11i

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Printers Setup
    References
    Analyzer: E-Business Reports & Printing (Doc ID 1610143.1)
    EBS Printing Information Center (PIC) - Component Tools - Overview (Doc ID 1511969.2)
    EBS Print Pasta Product Information Center (PIC) - Component Tools - Overview (Doc ID 1514541.2)
        http://oracle-dba-quickanswers.blogspot.com/2012/02/how-to-investigate-printing-issues-and.html
        System Administrator's Guide - Configuration Release 12.1 Part No. E12893-04
        How To Investigate Printing Issues and Work Towards its Resolution? (Doc ID 297522.1)
        PASTA Required For Printing With UTF8 For Any Release Of 11.5 (Doc ID 135137.1)
        Oracle Reports 6i Setup Guide for Oracle Applications 11i (Doc ID 189708.1)
        PASTA 3.0 Release Information Note (Doc ID 239196.1)
        Activating and Configuring IX Library (Doc ID 240864.1)
        11i : Pasta Printing Setup Test (Doc ID 264118.1)
        How To Set The PASTA Debug Option (Doc ID 267026.1)
        How To Print Reports In PDF Format Directly From The Concurrent Manager (Doc ID 308949.1)
        How To Print XML Publisher PDF Reports Via The Concurrent Manager? (Doc ID 338990.1)
        How to Setup Pasta Quickly and Effectively (Doc ID 356501.1)
        The Pasta Landwide Driver Truncates / Cuts Off The Right Side Of The Report (Doc ID 358879.1)
        How to Setup Pasta for Non-Postscript Ready Printers (Doc ID 365111.1)
        How To Effectively Remove An Oracle Applications Printer (Doc ID 370372.1)
        Understanding and Implementing direct printing of PDF using Ghostscript (Doc ID 409458.1)
        Not Able To Print PDF Documents (Doc ID 460002.1)
    Search Terms
         PDF Publisher - the required print style in R12 to print PDF
         pasta_pdf.cfg - the Pasta PDF Configuration File
    Overview
         Printing is in PCL (Printer Control Language) or PostScript format
         Printers are defined in Oracle with a specific type (e.g. HPLJ4 is a type)
             Printers are registered by assigning them a Printer Type
             All the resources needed to implement printing are seeded in Oracle against Printer Types
             Once a printer is registered (assigned a Printer Type) is can be used
         Printer Types have multiple combinations of Styles and Drivers
             Each combination represents an implementation of a style for a specific printer type
         Styles are defined for each type and are not specific to printers or printer types
             The style determines the dimensions of the printed page (e.g A4)
             Styles are independent of printer types
                The same style can be assigned to multiple printer types (and therefor printers)
         Drivers are assigned to Styles to send print command strings to printers to implement the style
             Drivers are a series of instructions sent to a printer to implement a printer style
             Drivers in Oracle can also include the name of a linux driver file on the file system that can be read and used
             Drivers implement Styles for specific types of printers - each printer type may have a different driver for the same style
         SRW Files (SQL Report Writer files) are only used by Oracle Reports to format Oracle Reports output
             SRW files reside on the file system and include page dimensions and meanings of special commands (new page, new line, bold etc)
             If output is not to be printed, the SRW file assigned to the style is used by Oracle Reports
             If output is to be printed, the SRW file assigned to the printer driver is used by Oracle Reports
    PASTA and PCL
         PASTA is an Oracle executable utility to convert text files to PostScript so they can be printed on PostScript (i.e. Laserjet) printers
             PostScript is a Laserjet printing language developed by Adobe Systems
         The PASTA patch includes the printer type, printer driver and SRW driver files
             There are three seeded driver files which set page height, width and control character values and are very generic:
                $FND_TOP/reports/PSTLL.prt 66x132 (HxW)
                $FND_TOP/reports/PSTWL.prt 66x180 (HxW)
                $FND_TOP/reports/PSTPL.prt 66x80  (HxW)
                Custom drivers are often defined with different hight and width combinations
         It is a post processing program invoked only if printed output is requested
             PostScript formats output in computer memory and sends the result to the printer, rather than sending printer formatting commands (i.e. PCL)
             The PASTA executable is $FND_TOP/bin/FNDPSTAX
                 The executable has several command line options which override the configuration options in the pasta.cfg file (see below or see Pasta User Guide)
             The standard configuration file for setting PASTA options is $FND_TOP/resource/pasta.cfg on the file system
                 FNDPSTAX reads this file for run-time settings when it is invoked (although run time parameters override file values)
                 The standard config file can be overridden with the -F command line option in the printer driver defined in Oracle
                 This allows the pasta_pdf.cfg file to be substituted (or an other custom configuratoin file)
                 pasta_pdf.cfg is a seeded file to support pdf printing
                     pasta_pdf.cfg contains a 'preprocess' directive to convert postscript to pdf (e.g. preprocess=pdf2ps {infile} {outfile})
             The Printer Type in Oracle is '--Pasta Universal Printer'
                E-Business Suite (EBS) is seeded with this printer type '--PASTA Universal Printer Type'.
                It can be associated with a Postscript printer and it's ready for use with minimal changes or modifications
                This printer name can be modified in $FND_TOP/resource/pasta_printername.cfg
         Command Line Arguments for PASTA's FNDPSTAX Program can be appended to the printer driver definition
             Reference: http://oracleappstechnology.blogspot.com/2008/06/command-line-pasta-through-fndpstax.html
            -c specifies the number of copies to print.
            -el Specifies the error log file's path and name. The path is the absolute path to the error log file.
            -f<?lename> specifies the input file name. Example: -fmyfile.txt
            -F Specifies the configuration file's path and name.
            -h Adjusts the space between lines. The default value is 1.0. If is larger than 1, the space between lines will be larger.
            -w Adjusts the space between characters. The default value is 1.0. If is larger than 1.0, the space between characters will be larger.
            -l Print in landscape mode. (The default is portrait).
            -o<?lename> specifies the output file name.
            -s Overrides the font size option in pasta.cfg.
            -bs Overrides the font size in -s and fontsize for bold font.
            -np No print option.
            -ph specifies the paper height in inches.
            -pw specifies the paper width in inches.
            -pform Converts a PostScript file to a PrintForm file .
            -pf specifies a PrintForm file to be merged in a Pasta output at runtime.
            -pn specifies the printer name.
            -t Banner option for use with the Unix lp command.
            -v Displays the version number.
            -xauto]> Specifies the output format. Two output formats are supported: PostScript ("ps") and text ("text").
        PASTA uses the pasta.cfg file (located for example .../<Host>/oracle/test/apps/apps_st/appl/fnd/12.0.0/resource/pasta.cfg)
            All the definitions for the PASTA printer type are seeded in Oracle
            For Unix, pasta.cfg contains:
               % for UNIX platform
               printCommand=lp -c -d{printername}
           For Windows, pasta.cfg contains:
            % for Windows platform
            ntPrintCommand=print /D:{printername}
        The printer names must be defined in /etc/cups/printers.conf for the command "printCommand=lp -c -d{printername}" to work
        Setting up your system to use Pasta is much simpler than the standard Oracle E-Business Suite printer setup procedure. 
            The Printer Type, Printer Driver, and SRW driver files are provided. 
            The only setup required to begin printing is the registration of the printer with Oracle E-Business Suite.
        Many printing options can be defined using the Pasta configuration file (pasta.cfg). You no longer need to maintain multiple drivers and styles for each printer.
        Pasta is provided as an executable named FNDPSTAX.
        PCL is Printer Control Language - an alternative to PASTA and Postscript
            PCL sends formatting commands to the printer directly and is faster and simpler
            The Printer Type in Oracle in not '--Pasta Universal Printer' but one or more different values like 'HPLJ4SI'
    CUPS Printers
        CUPS Printers are defined in Unix/Linux to support printing over the network
            CUPS uses the underlying LPD/LPR (Line Printer Daemon/Line Printer Remote) protocol and linux commands - a network protocol for submitting jobs to remote printers
            Configuration files for CUPS are in /etc/cups/printers.conf, /etc/cups/cups.conf & the contents of the /etc/cups/ppd/  (Postscript Printer Definitions)
    Printed output is created by Oracle Reports calling an SRW (SQL Report Writer) driver
    SRW defines page breaks, line feeds, bolding based on an SWR Driver File
        SRW stands for SQL Report Writer (driver file)
        The SRW driver file is named in the print styles form
        There is an SRW file assigned to each Printer Style and Printer Driver definitions
            The SRW driver on the Printer Style definition is used for output that is not sent to a printer
            The SRW driver on the Printer Driver definition is used for output that is send to a printer
    Report dimensions are defined in the print styles form
        They override any values in the SRW file
    The concurrent manager calls the print process in one of three modes:
        Command - default mode of invoking an operating system command
            In this mode, the concurrent manager provides four values;
                file name of the print file
                operating system name of the target printer
                title of the file, which appears on the output
                number of copies
        Program - calling a custom program to execute the print process
        Subroutine - calling an Oracle subroutine to invoke the print process
    Printer Styles define the output format of the report
        Oracle can associate a different printer driver to each style
    Key Tables
        FND_PRINTER_STYLES (and _TL)
        FND_PRINTER_DRIVERS
        FND_PRINTER (and _TL)
        FND_PRINTER_INFORMATION - relationships between printer types, styles and drivers
        FND_PRINTER_TYPES
    Troubleshooting Commands
        Printer type, print style and printer driver information is cached in memory; in order for any printer setup form changes to take effect, you will need to bounce / restart the concurrent managers
        FNDPSTAX -v to get the current version of Pasta
        lpstat -a to see all the printers defined in Linux
        lp -d to check if a printer is working at the OS level (wher lp is the 'Line Printer' command
        lpr - the 'Line Printer Remote' command that is implemented in CUPS for network defined printers
    Specific Configurations
        For payments in IBY such as 'Format Payment Instructions' (IBY_FD_PAYMENT_FORMAT') use PDF Publisher as the style

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Auditing Tables - Tips and Tricks
    The audit table only snapshots the record before it is changed, not after
        To get the after picture, join the audit table to it's production counterpart
        The current record state is in the production table

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Auditing/Journalling Database Row Changes
    References
        http://garethroberts.blogspot.com/2007/08/audit-trail-must-do-bank-accounts.html
        Oracle Applications System Administrators' Guide - Chapter 3 User and Data Auditing
        Metalink Note 60828.1 Overview of Oracle Appications Audit Trails
        Metalink Note 69660.1 Understanding Data Auditing in Oracle Application Tables
        How to Enable Audit Trail On Tables [ID 848039.1]
        Metalink Note 105624.1 Troubleshooting (Audit Trails)
        Audit Report : When You Click Button "Select Columns" Nothing Happens. (Doc ID 758457.1)
    Turning on database row auditing creates a shadow audit table to the table being audited
    The shadow table is named the same as the table it is auditing, appended with an "_A"
    There are no standard reports for auditing
    Auditing table that have no unique record key makes reporting on audited records difficult
        The primary table records and audit records cannot be linked
    Auditing should be limited to non-transactional data to avoid performance degradation
    The profile option "AuditTrail:Activate" must be set and requires logout/login to be activated
        Normally this is defaulted to "Yes" at the site level
        It must be set at the application level (e.g. General Ledger) explicitly
    The applicable schema should be enabled for audit
        Navigation -> System Administrator/Security/AuditTrail/Install
            The "Oracle Username" on this form is the schema short name (eg "APPLSYS")
            It is also the corresponding Oracle database Username
    Define an "Audit Group" and associate the schema/application and tables to be audited
        Navigation -> System Administrator/Security/AuditTrail/Groups
        Ensure the "Group State" is "Enable Requested" or it will be skipped for processing
            Otherwise the group will be ignored by the "AuditTrail Update Tables" process
        A group can contain one or more tables from any application, regardless of the application assigned to the group
            'Audit Report' is run by group so a report can only choose from the tables within a single group
        You can define the same table as a member of multiple different groups
    Define the columns to be audited for each table in the audit group
        Navigation -> System Administrator/Security/Audit Trails/Tables
        The User Table Name is the same as the table name - query based on table name
        The primary key columns will always be added automatically if not chosen explicitly
            This can be a number of columns in the table
        The standard audit fields are automatically added (eg CREATION_DATE, CREATED_BY)
        The chosen columns affect all Audit Groups that reference the table
    Run the "Auditrail Update Tables" concurrent process to create the shadow "_A" table
        Ensure the schema is valid for auditing and any related schemas (foreign keys) are enabled
        Two views will also be created for each audited column with the names <audited table>_AC# and <audited table>_AV#
    Troubleshooting
        A Troubleshooting note is in Metalink note 105624.1
        A report "AuditTrail Report for Audit Group Validation" can also be run
            It confirm views, triggers and procedures were built correctly
        If the Audit Group setting "Group State" is not set to "Enable Requested" ...
            the required process "Audit Trail Update" will not pick it up for processing
        The profile option "AuditTrail:Activate" must be set to "Yes" first.
    Use SQL or PL/SQL to access the audit data using the shadow table or associated views
    Records must be purged manually after disabling the audit feature for the tables to be purged
        Navigation -> System Administrator/Security/Audit Trail/Groups
        Choose the group which owns the table to be purged and set the group state to "Disable - Purge Tables"
        Run the "Audit Trail Update Tables" process
        Purge the tables manually using the SQL delete command
        Enable the group and run the "AuditTrail Update Tables" process
    Purging
        As System Administrator, select Security -> Audit Trail -> Groups
        Select the Security Audit group and set the group state to Disable Purge Table
        Run the Audit Trail Update Tables Report
        Purge the data from the shadow table
        Select Security -> Audit Trail -> Groups
        Select the Security Audit group and set the group state to Enable
        Run the Audit Trail Update Tables Report

Applications Object Library (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Auditing Tables - Reporting
    There are reporting options built in
    Navigation: <System Administrator>/Security/Audit Trail/Audit Trail Reporting
    Templates can be created and added to the navigator
    Navigators can be opened to show what is currently being audited - navigate through each template
        This is 'Audit Hierarchy Navigator'
        There is also the 'Audit Query Navigator'that drills down into the table's key values
    Audit reports can be created and run from a report builder page
        Navigation: <System Administrator>/Security/Audit Trail/Audit Trail Reporting/Audit Report

Approvals Management Engine (AME) (HR Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Approvals Manager uses approval rules to route documents to non-standard approval routings
        Non-standard approval routings are routings different than employee-supervisor or position hierarchies
        Examples include routing based on charge account segment ownership or item
            Cost Center approvers (based on the Cost Center flexfield qualifier)
            Account (financial account) approvers (e.g. for expense budgets)
                This would be based on the Account Segment flexfield qualifier
            Special approvers (laptop computers, fleet expenses) based on the catalog item or category
    AME uses a role based model for rule assignment in the new security model
        There are five predefined roles in AME

Approvals Management Engine (AME) (HR Schema) Notes on Primary Setup Entities
    Primary setup/configuration entities in AME are:
        Transaction Types, Rules, Attributes, Conditions, Actions and Action Types, Approver Groups
        Setups for rules, attributes etc are all performed within the context of a single transaction type
            In the setup forms, the values displayed or created apply only to the current transaction type context
        Rules
            Rules determine the approval groups that will be invoked for a specific transaction type
            Rules can be defined across multiple operating units or within a single operating unit
            Rules include conditions and actions
                Conditions determine if a rule is valid - the rule is valid if all conditions are met
                    Multiple rules can be defined if one of multiple conditions need to start an action (i.e. OR condition)
                Actions define the steps taken - which is to invoke an approval group
                Multiple actions can be defined in sequence to invoke multiple approval groups
                Actions Types are also typed as rule types:
                    Chain of Authority
                    Substitution
                    List Modification
                    Pre-List Approval Group
                    Post-List Approval Group
                    Production
        Attributes
            Attributes are system variables used in Condition definitions
            Examples are: preparer, requisition_total, line_item
            Many attributes are seeded but new ones can be defined
            Attributes can be static (numbers or text) or dynamic (ERP data references)
                Dynamic attribute queries include calls to packages to retrieve current values
                    that are stored as part of the current transaction (e.g. account segments)
                Dynamic attribute SQL definitions can be valided within the definition form
            Attributes can be header or line level
                Header level attributes apply to the entire transaction - there is only one value per transaction
                Line level attributes are different for each line if the transaction has multiple lines
                Line level capability in OAM is enabled through sysadmin functions for each transaction
        Conditions
            Conditions use attributes to create rules through simple expressions
                e.g. Requisition_Total (the attribute) >= 150000 (the condition)
            Conditions can be numeric (number, date, currency), boolean or character
            There are three types of conditions: normal, exception and list modification
                normal - allow multiple values in a list (like an SQL 'IN' clause)
                exception - can only be used in an exception rule
                list-modification - applies to a specific approver in the approver group only
            The item class on a condition is derived from the underlying attribute item class
                It cannot be over-ridden in a condition
        Actions and Action Types (Previously Approvals and Approval Types)
            Action Types are collections of actions that follow the same rule for selecting approvers
                Actions are performed when a Rule is evaluated as 'true'
                Both an Action Type and one member Action is specified as the outcome of a rule
            An Action is an instruction to AME to include a given set of approvers in a transaction's approver list
            Action Types represent different methods and approver types used to determine the approvers added to an approver list
                Chain of Authority
                List Modification
                Substitution
                Pre-List Approval Group
                Post-List Approval Group
                Production
            They define the steps taken if the rule is valid (i.e. all conditions are met)
            An Action Type comprises one or more individual actions which fires an approval group
                The actions can be fired in sequence, in a named order or together using a voting method
                Since Approver Groups have voting methods, this means voting methods are supported at two levels
                    Between approver groups (action type voting method) and
                    Within approver groups (approver group voting method)
        Approvers and Approver Types
            Approver Types are different database entities such as users, people and positions
                An new SQL package must be built and registered to add a new approver type
            Approvers are members of the Approval Types (such as a person name in the People type)
            Approvers and Approver types are selectable when defining members of an Approver Group
        Approver Groups
            Approver Groups define collections of 'who' is in the approval chain
                These collections are static (listed or named) or dynamic (queried or derived) approvers
                If the group is static, the members must be listed
                If the group is dynamic, a query must be written instead of a list
            Members of the group can individually or collectively approve transactions
            The rule for approving is set in the Approver Group Definition as 'voting method'
                Order Number - each approves in sequence based on their assigned order number in the group
                Concensus - the transaction is approved if the majority in the group approves
                First Responder Wins - only one member of the group need approve - whoever is first
                Serial - approvers must approve in the physical order listed in the group
        Rules
            Rules can be one of several types:
                List Creation - generates a default chain of authority for approval
                    List Creation rules only use 'normal' conditions (not 'exception' conditions)
                List Creation Exception - create exceptions and incorporate exception conditions
                List Modification -
                Substitutions
                Pre-List Approval Group
                Post-List Approval Group
            The first four are different ways to establish an approval chain
            The last two are modifiers to an approval chain that is already created (by another rule)

BI Publisher or XML Publisher (XDO) Tips and Tricks:
    .rtf templates are limited to 63 columns - export as XSL-FO for more columns using the BI Publisher Desktop tool 'Export' in MS-Word
        The maximum page width is also limited to 21 inches using custom page size definition
    Don't use Report Template Names longer than 64 chars - they cause a trigger error in NLS settings in SRS
        The actual template rtf file name can be longer but not the wrapper name for the template in Oracle
    Keep data synonyms in embedded XDO data templates short or they will throw errors
    XDO is XML Data Objects
    You can specify functions using xdlfx, xdoxsl and xsl-fo libraries
    You can include data at parent levels using XSL Xpath navigation from the lower levels (../../..)
    You can get the XML output through the Concurrent Manager Diagnostics page after running the process
    Force text by surrounding data tags as follows: <fo:bidi-override direction="ltr" unicode-bidi="bidi-override"><?XML_ELEMENT?></fo:bidi-override>
        The bidi is the bidi-rectional override attributes on a string and is part of the XSL-FO features
        It is implemented in HTML as BDO for 'Bi=Ddirectional Override'
    Force numbers to format as currencies with two decimals using: <?format-number:FIELD_NAME;'L999G999D.99'?>
    Use the xdo function extension ?xdofx:to_number(Nominal_Conversion_Rate)?> to convert text to numbers
        The extended NLS version options are: <?xdofx:to_number(Actual_Conversion_Rate, 'NLS_NUMERIC_CHARACTERS = '',.'' )?>
        The XSL-FO function doesn't work on negative numbers so avoid it -> <?format-number(Actual_Conversion_Rate, #.00000)?>
    MIME Types must be defined to be used by XML Publisher
        See Note 790854.1 on Defining Excel as a MIME type in fnd_mime_types_tl
    RTF templates create spanned Excel columns if you exceed margin boundaries on the RTF layout - so avoid this

BI Publisher or XML Publisher (XDO) Troubleshooting and Issues:

    You cannot extract a schema definition from the XML used - must use a third party inference engine
    If you don't set the profile option "FND: Native Client Encoding" to UTF8 it may not display XML for foreign characters
    Metalink Note 364547.1 - Troubleshooting Oracle XML Publisher For The Oracle E-Business Suite
    Merged or spanned columns are caused by alignment differences

BI Publisher or XML Publisher (XDO) Notes on General Functionality
    XDO is the document extension (file type) for XML Publisher documents
        An xdo document is an XML report definition specifying the data source and report layout
        It is similar/analogous to an .rdf file in Oracle Reports
    A java based application that generates and registers XSL-FO objects for transforming XML into formatted documents
        XSL-FO is XML Style Language - Formatting Objects
    It utilizes the W3C XSL-FO (Formatting Objects) standard for Extensible Style Sheeting
    XML Publisher uses data definitions and templates to publish reports in the desired format
        This includes output from concurrent programs and from spreadsheets
            Data definitions are linked to concurrent output by giving them common short names
    Primary Features include:
        Template library of report formats that can be references by concurrent processes
        Supports multiple formats: Acrobat, Word, Excel
        Supports multiple languages and delivery options
    Core Components:
        FO Processor - to generate PDF from XSL-FO documents and data documents
        PDF Document Merger - creates PDF documents from text data and XML maps
        PDF Form Processor - adds publishing effects to merged PDF documents
        RTF Template Parser - reads RTF document formats and creates XSL-FO schemas
    A Template Manager registers and stores document templates and associates them with data sources
        Data templates are data definitions that point to a data source
        Template Manager can register data sources such as concurrent manager processes (data source registration)
        Template Manager also registers format templates to apply to the date sources (template registration)
            Format templates can be PDF, RTF and XSL-FO formats
        Template Manager provides Publisher API's for other Oracle processes to call report builder processes directly
    Third party forms (templates) can be downloaded and populated by data from Oracle
        Examples are tax forms that can be mapped to an Oracle data source
    Desktop Components
        Publisher includes desktop components to expedite template development
        Metalink Note 36734.1 contains a link to the components for download
            The download for Desktop Publisher 5.6.2 is 5097966 (5.6.3 was released in Nov 2007)
                This patch provides an MS Word toolbar, user guide and samples
        The desktop includes an extension to MS Word for template building in .rtf format
        The template viewer provides advanced viewing of .rtf formats
    Tags in XML Output
        <LIST_G_HEADERS> the start of a repeating group of headers
        <G_HEADERS> the start of a single group of headers

BI Publisher or XML Publisher (XDO Schema) Notes on Date Formats
    You must format the XML native date to canonical format as YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+HH:MM to use date formatting

BI Publisher or XML Publisher (XDO Schema) Notes on Steps for Publishing a Standard Report
    1. Run the standard report
    2. Change the output to XML
    3. Run the standard report as XML
    4. Create a template in MS Word - load the XML
    5. Define a data definition in Oracle that matches the concurrent program name
        The Data Definition short name must match the concurrent program short name
    6. Upload the template and associate with the data definition

BI Publisher or XML Publisher (XDO) Notes on Key Concepts and Embedded Tags:
    Uses placeholders and groups to build a template in MS Word (.rtf)
        Placeholders reference a field in an XML document (e.g. <?CUSTOMER_NUM?>)
        Groups reference fields in the document that repeat for each occurance (e.g. <?for-each: CUSTOMER_NUM?> ... <?end for-each?>)
    There are several tags that can be used to define the primary behaviour of a document
        Create headers and footers:
            <?start:body?><?end:body?>
        Loop through repeating elements:
            <?for-each?><?end for-each?>
        Conditionally show text: <?if: CUSTOMER_NUM=200?> ... <?end if?>
        Select one of several options conditionally:
            <?choose:?><?when: CUSTOMER_NUM < 100??>...<>end when?><?otherwise:?>...<?end otherwise?><?end choose?>
        Regroup based on a value in the grouped data
            <?for-each-group: CUSTOMERS; CUSTOMER_TYPE?><?end for-each-group?>
            This groups the parent element based on repeating/grouping values in one of the child elements

BI Publisher or XML Publisher (XDO) Notes on Integration with Concurrent Manager
    Concurrent Manager output can be send to the XML Publisher through a template
    There is a new block of output options reachable through the concurrent parameter settings
        This displays the templates tied to the concurrent job
        It requires patch 3435480 "Publishing Concurrent Requests with XML Publisher"
            If this patch is not applied, you must run 'XML Report Publisher' request after running the report
            If this patch is applied, you still need to run 'XML Report Publisher' to print checks
    There must be a data template with the same name as the concurrent process short name
        This enables the template to show up in Concurrent Manager Completion Options
        The output format on the concurrent process definition must be XML for this to appear
        The template must be registered as the default template for the concurrent process
            This allows the user to override the default with different output options
            Use the System Administration Responsibility to set the default template

BI Publisher or XML Publisher (XDO) Notes on eText
    eText is a table based formatting template method used by BI publisher for EDI and EFT formats
    EDI is delimiter based and EFT is fixed position based, otherwise they are similar
        This output type is identified in the header as <Template Type>
            FIXED_POSITION_BASED
            DELIMITER_BASED
    Each record or group of records at the same level (nesting level) is a table
        Within each nesting level there can be one record or group of records
        Record lengths can be several hundred characters
    Special handling is implemented by global level (e.g. character replacement) or record/table level commands (e.g. sorting)
        Global level commands are declared in a setup table in the template header (under the 'Format Setup' section heading)
            It is always the first series of tables in the template
        Row level commands are declared in command rows within the record level tables (under the 'Format Data Records' section heading)
            Command rows have no column headings but always have two columns: command name and command parameter
    At runtime BI constructs the output file based on the format in the table
    The system loops through all instances of the XML element corresponding to the table/level and prints the corresponding information
    Data tables start with a <LEVEL> entry which ties the template to a point in the XML Data hierarchy
    The BI Publisher Desktop Tool supports working with eText but not via the MS Word interface
        Navigation: Windows > Oracle BI Publisher Desktop > Template Viewer
        Choose the working directory as a directory where both the eText Template and the XML Data file are stored
        Choose a template and an XML file from the dialog and click 'Start Processsing'

    xdo_ds_definitions_b -- links to concurrent request with common definition code
    xdo_ds_definitions_tl


Bill of Materials (BOM Schema) Notes on Best Practices:

    Rationalize products using the 'bill compare' report to compare two similar bills of materials
    For flow manufacturing define 'product families' to group products with similar manufacturing processes

Bill of Materials (BOM) Notes on Responsibilities:
    BILL OF MATERIALS

Bill of Materials (BOM) Notes on General Functionality:
    Bills of Materials are product configurations
    Oracle BOM maintains information about configurations for assembled items
        Assembly can occur in manufacturing or picking for shipment
    There are five types of BOM:
        standard,
        model,
        option class,
        planning
        engineering
    BOM's consist of
        an item number
        revision number and name
        the routing through work cells needed to make the item
        a hierarchy of each component needed (including optional components)
        resources needed to make the item
    BOM's are used by Order Management for
        Pick to Order (PTO) and
        Configure to Order (CTO) items
        to create the configuration to be picked in the warehouse for shipping
    Phantom BOMs are an engineering convenience
        Phantom BOM's are non-inventoried intermediate manufacturing assemblies
        They are used to define final assemblies.
        Phantom assemblies are consumed in a higher level assembly as soon as they are made
        They are not stored physically in inventory
    Planning BOMs are statistical averages of components used in an assembly for planning purposes
    Routings comprise a sequence of operations to make the item.
        Routings include the time needed to setup to make the item and to cleanup afterwards
        These lead times are used by Order Management to calculate ATP dates to a customer
        Routing times are used by MRP
            to calculate lead times used in the manufacturing process for an item
            to schedule arrival of parts
    Resources are associated with operations on a routing
        Resources are absorbed when the operations are performed
        Resources can include labor time, and machine time
    Flow manufacturing uses BOM's and routings but does not use jobs or workorders
        Orders are assigned to a line w/out a workorder
    Configuration items are new items created from a model BOM
        when a configurator order is placed for ATO or PTO assembly

Bill of Materials (BOM Schema) Notes on Workday Calendar
    A workday calendar defines the valid working days and hours for a manufacturing organization
    It is defined by a pattern of days on and days off between two dates
    Exceptions can be defined between specific dates
    Exercise: Display the workday calendar - <Bill of Materials>/Setup/Calendars
    Periods are stored in the BOM_PERIOD_START_DATES table
        One monthly period is generated for each month within the start and end dates
    Calendars must be built or rebuilt once they are defined or changed
        Choose Options/Build from the Calendar menu
        This runs the 'Build Workday Calendar' concurrent process

Cash Management (CE Schema) Notes on General Functionality
    Cash Management works with the subledgers to match bank payments and receipts and create clearing journal entries from Cash Clearing to Cash
    Cash Management is two components:
        Bank Statement Reconcilation - measuring the match between the Bank Account and the Oracle Financials records in the subledgers
            This includes reconciling the Payables Cash Account (Disbursement Account)
            The actual reconcilation matches Bank Statement Lines to AP Checks for the Bank Account Setup in AP (11i) and CE (R12) (using AP_CHECKS_ALL in 11i)
            For AR the actual reconciliation matches Bank Statement Lines to AR Receipts in the AR Cash Receipt History table
        Cash Forecasting - enables projecting cash account balances at a future point in time using format templates
    Cash Management is integrated with: General Ledger, Payable, Receivables and Order Entry, Payroll and External Systems
        Integration with AP and AR is for reconciliation of bank accounts and for forecasting of scheduled receipts and payments
        Integration with GL is for posting of journal entries for transactions originating in Cash Management (e.g. Bank Charges)
            You can also match bank statement journal entries to journal entries in the General Ledger (account 'book' entries like Interest Accruals)
        Integration with OM (Order Management) is for forecasting cash receipts
        Integration with PAY (Payroll) is to match transactions originating in Payroll
        Integration with XTR (Treasury) for Cash Forecasting including money market investments and foreign exchange deals
        Integration with PA for budgeted inflows in costing and unreleased Project Billing Events in Project Billing
        Integration with External Systems allows matching against transactions accounted in external systems but imported to Oracle to reconcile the account
    Cash Management reconciles bank statements with payables records for each bank account
    Cash Management is a subledger application that generates accounting entries to the General Ledger - primarily to clear the Cash Clearing Account
        Clearing in AP marks the payment as cleared and generates a journal entry to move the payment accounting from clearing to cash
            Cash Management generates this transaction but it is recorded in Payables and transfered to the ledger from there
        Clearing in AR marks the AR receipt as cleared and AR generates the accounting entries to the ledger
        Both AR and AP accounting entries generated by Cash Reconciliation are transfered to the General Ledger using the standard transfer processes
            Both sets of entries pass through the GL Open Interface (in 11i) or SLA (in R12)
    Cash Management also originates accounting entries for bank charges and interest
    The standard electronic bank statement file is the SWIFT MT940 (or SWIFT 940), BAI2 or EDIFACT?
        Cash Management has seeded templates for these three formats
        SWIFT MT940
            MT940 is a widely used standard for bank statements including opening balance, transactions and closing balance
            MT940 documents can contain bank account statements for multiple accounts
        BAI2 - Bank Administration Institute (United States)
        EDIFACT - Electronic Data Interchange for Administration Commerce and Transport

Cash Management (CE Schema) Notes on R12 Upgrade Changes and New Features
    Obsoleted Tables in 11i (used by AP and AR, but hosted in the AP Schema)
        AP_BANK_BRANCHES
        AP_BANK_ACCOUNTS_ALL
        AP_BANK_ACCOUNTS_USES_ALL
    New Tables in R12
        CE_BANK_ACCOUNTS - internal bank accounts,  contains Legal Entity Level bank account information. Each bank account must be affiliated with one bank branch.
        CE_BANK_ACCOUNTS_V - r12 view of all bank accounts
        CE_BANK_ACCT_USES_ALL: stores Operating Unit level bank account use information
        CE_PAYMENT_DOCUMENTS: Payment Documents to be used for Printed type Payments
        CE_BANK_BRANCHES_V: view: Bank/Branches Info
        CE_BANK_ACCT_USES_OU_V: view: Internal Bank Account Uses Info
        IBY_EXT_BANK_ACCOUNTS - external bank accounts for suppliers and customers
        CE_BANK_BRANCHES_V - view of bank brances that references TCA tables in R12
    TCA Tables Used in R12 to Store Banks and Branches
        HZ_PARTIES
        HZ_RELATIONSHIPS
        HZ_RELATIONSHIP_TYPES - party relationship types (not account relationships on customer accounts)
        HZ_ORG_CONTACTS
        HZ_ORG_CONTACT_ROLES
        HZ_CONTACT_POINTS
        HZ_PARTY_SITES
        HZ_LOCATIONS
        HZ_ORGANIZATION_PROFILES - change history and additional bank attributes
    In R12, Internal Banks are setup in Cash Management
        External banks are setup in Supplier and Customer Maintenance
        Internal banks cross operating units and grants are required in User Management responsibility to assign them across organizations
    In 11i, Internal and External Banks are setup in AR and AP (Banks) and all are stored in AP
        They are operating unit-specific.
    R12 Upgrade New Features
        Bank Account Model: New model provides a single access point for defining and managing internal bank accounts for AP, AR, Oracle Payroll, Oracle Cash Management and Oracle Treasury. 
        Each bank account is associated with a Bank and Bank Branch defined in Oracle's common Trading Community Architecture (TCA). 
        Multi Org Access Control (MOAC) enabled. 
        Subledger Accounting: available for setting up accounting rules and for generating journal entries related to Cash Management transactions. 
        Bank Account Balances and Interest Calculation: New Bank account balance types are supported for all internal bank accounts. Users are able to track closing ledger and available balances as well as month-to-date and year-to-date averages. 
        Bank Account Transfers: Earlier available in Treasury only. 
        Cash Pooling: Earlier available in Treasury only. 
        Bank Statement Accounting: Allows users to define mapping rules that can automatically create and reconcile transactions in Oracle Cash Management based on reported prior-day bank statement lines. Was available in Treasury. 
        Bank Account Signing Authorities: Users are able to indicate single and joint signing limits for each bank account as well as signer group categories, effective dates, approval status, and other relevant information. Was available in Treasury. 
        Cash Positioning Intra-day Activities: Provides additional flexibility in how users view intra-day bank statement activity in their cash positions. Was available in Treasury.

Cash Management (CE Schema) Notes on Bank Reconciliation
    Reconciliation creates entries in several Ledger Accounts: Cash, Cash Clearing, Realized Gains and Losses, Bank Charges and Bank Errors
    Steps include loading bank statements and reconciling bank statement lines against payments and receipts in the sub-ledgers
        Load Bank Statements - into API tables using 'Bank Statement Loader'
        Import Bank Statements - either manually or automatically via API tables, including account balances, receipts and deposits
            Concurrent Programs include:
                Bank Statement Import - to load a bank file into Cash Management
                    To run this program the bank statement must first be loaded into the interface tables
                        CE_STATEMENT_HEADERS_INT_ALL - API for importing bank statement headers
                        CE_STATEMENT_LINES_INTERFACE - API for importing bank statement lines
                    Import errors are stored in:
                        CE_HEADER_INTERFACE_ERRORS
                        CE_LINE_INTERFACE_ERRORS
        Reconcile Bank Statements - either automatically or manually
            Manual reconciliation requires user input to match bank statement lines to subledger payments and receipts
                It can also be used to match off any bank statement lines that were not auto-reconciled
            Concurrent Programs include:
                Auto Reconciliation - produces an Auto Reconciliation Execution Report with matched and unmatched transactions
                    This report is reviewed after running auto-reconciliation and manual reconciliatons can be done to complete matching
                        Use the View Bank Statements form to manually match remaining transactions
                        Also use the Bank Statement Detail Report to examine the bank statement lines
                Import and Auto Reconciliation (streamlined as one process)
            Auto Reconciliation can be run any number of times after correcting underlying data to recast the reconciliation
                It compares the Bank Statement Balance to the Ledger Cash Account balance, adjusting for unreconciled and error lines
                Errors are put in CE_RECONCILIATION_ERRORS
            The Bank Statements Detail Report (or online via 'View Bank Statements') gives a view of reconciled and unreconciled lines
            Reconciliation tags bank statement lines as: Reconciled, Unreconciled/Unmatched, Error (e.g. unknown bank code), and External
                External transactions are transactions not accounted in Oracle - they are treated as reconciled by default.
                Bank lines posted in error by the bank and reversed can be reconciled by matching together and not to a transaction in Oracle

Cash Management (CE Schema) Notes on Interfaces
    Run 'Bank Statement Import' to import and reconcile bank statements
    Run 'AutoRecociliation' which submits the 'Auto-Reconciliation Execution Report'
    Cash Management Bank Statement Open Interface
        Loads bank statement information provided from the bank (can optionally be loaded manually) in BAI or SWIFT MT940 format
            Tables loaded are:
                CE_STATEMENT_HEADERS_INT_ALL - API for importing bank statement headers
                CE_STATEMENT_LINES_INTERFACE - API for importing bank statement lines
        Each bank statement is a single bank header and multiple lines
            The header includes the bank account number, statement date and statement number (and optionally currency and branch/bank name)
            The lines include payments, receipts, miscellaneous transactions (e.g. charges), open interface txns and journal lines
                Each line has a line number, amount, date cleared and transaction type.
                Optional line information includes currency, bank transaction code, original amount, value date, comments and others
        Bank Transaction Codes must be setup in advance to define the Transaction Types that will be read from the Bank Statement
            Navigation: Cash Management > Setup > Banks > Bank Transaction Codes
    Cash Management Reconciliation Open Interface
        Loads bank transactions from external systems that must be included in the Bank Statement Reconciliation
        Steps include:
            Loading the transaction lines into the open interface tables (using SQL*Loader or similar)
    Cash Management Forecasting Open Interface - imports cash flow transactions from external systems for cash forecasting
        Includes Open Interface Inflow and Open Interface Outflow transaction typs

Cash Management (CE Schema) Notes on Cash Forecasting
    References
        http://oraapps-raghuraman.blogspot.com/2009/04/cash-forecasting.html#links">Oracle Applications: Cash Forecasting#links
    Cash Forecasting allows user defined templates to project cash forecasts in spreadsheet format (using Oracle Report Exchange)
    Cash Forecasting can include cash transactions imported from external systems
    In a template you define:
        Rows - as sources and uses of cash (and which sources to include)
        Columns - as time periods including GL Periods, or Days (and which periods to include)

Cash Management (CE Schema) Notes on New Features in 11i
    Cash Forecast Integration with Oracle Projects using budgets, billing events and expenditures
    Cash Forecast Integration with Oracle Sales using Sales Opportunities by stage, channel, win probability and status
    Cash Forecast Integration with Treasury for money market and foreign exchange deals
    Cash Forecast Integration with Payroll for reconciliation of payroll cash accounts
    Improved reconciliation support for voided payments (in AP) and reversed receipts in AR (against the original receipt)
        Both voids and reversed receipts can be excluded as available for reconciliation
    Value Dates on payments recorded on payments are updated by actual value dates from bank statements
        Value dates determine the time at which a deposit starts earning interest or a disbursement impacts the balance and interest

Cash Management (CE Schema) Notes on New Features in R12
    Cash Management becomes the owner of Internal Bank Accounts in R12
        The internal bank accounts are stored in CE_BANK_ACCOUNTS

Cash Management (CE Schema) Notes on Configuration Steps
    The general sequence of configuring Cash Management is:
        Set Profile Options
        Set System Paramenters for each GL Ledger
        Define Bank Transaction Codes
        Setup the Bank Statement Open Interface
        Setup the Reconciliation Open Interface
        Setup the Forecasting Open Interface
        Define Cash Forecasting Templates
        Setup Sequential Document Numbering
        Define Request Sets
        Define Descriptive Flexfields
    Transaction Codes used by the Bank must be setup in Oracle and mapped to internal Oracle transaction types
        This must be done for each Cash Account being reconciled to a Bank Account
        This setup is used by Accounts Payable to determine the GL Account for Transactions matching the code
        Transaction Types available to classify Bank Transaction Codes are:
            Payment
            Receipt
            Miscellaneous Payment
            Miscellaneous Receipt
            Stopped - stopped or voided payments in Oracle Payables
            Rejected
            Non Sufficient Funds (NSF)
        Run the Bank Transaction Codes Listing to get a full list of Bank Codes defined in the system

    Other Transaction Reports

Cash Management (CE Schema) Notes on Archiving and Purging
    References
        11i/CE: Purge Interface Tables In Cash Management before upgrade (Doc ID 2092799.1)
        R11i: CE: Can the Interface Tables Be Truncated Before Data Conversion in R12 Upgrade? (Doc ID 1614838.1)
    Purging is available for the Bank Statement Open Interface and for the Bank Statement Tables
        Concurrent Requests > Archive/Purge Bank Statements
        Purging unreconciled clears from CE_STATEMENT_HEADERS_INT and CE_STATEMENT_LINES_INT
        Purghing reconciled also clears from CE_STATEMENT_HEADERS_ALL and CE_STATEMENT_LINES (old statements imported and reconciled)
    You can configure automatic purging of the Bank Statement Open Interface after each successful import
    Archived headers and lines are stored in the CE_ARCH_ ... tables

Concepts in 11i Notes on the File System and Directory Structures:
    Directories for the database install of the applications on the data server are:
        DATA or DATA_TOP (all .dbf files for the apps) and
        DB (Oracle home for the DBMS system)
    Directories on the applications server are: APPL or APPL_TOP (all application files),
        ORA (Home for the Oracle technology stack of software,
            including Apache and Forms/Reports 6i software)
        COMN or COMMON_TOP (common log files, output, java and HTML)
    The APPL_TOP directory has multiple subdirectories for application files
        forms,
        reports,
        utilities,
        c files,
        includes,
            all grouped by Application and version.
            Each application subdirectory has one subdirectory for each version of the product
    Applications use environment file settings to control execution. There are four environment files with extensions .cmd (Windows) and .env (Unix)
        You can set environment variables by running the .env script for the middle tier
        Look for the file in $APPL_TOP (similar to /(vmhost)/oracle/dev/apps/apps_st/appl/, change permissions and run the .env file (looks like APPS<SID>_<sid>.env e.g. APPSDEV_dev.env)

Concepts in 11i Notes on Schemas:
    Every application has a 'base product' database schema owner (of data only)
        The database level user ID and password are set the same as the application abbreviation (eg GL/GL)
        This gains access to the database objects for the app (not the application user forms)
    The base product schema owner is used to install all the data tables: tables, sequences, indexes and constraints
    The APPS schema (ie schema being 'owner' of the tables, views, sequences etc) has access to all database objects for all the applications (apps/apps).
        Apps is granted ownership to all the application data tables by the base schema owner
        APPS is granted access to all table objects installed by the base product schema owner
        APPS is used to install and directly own the code objects: packages, procedures, triggers, functions and views.
    APPS in the application database objects are analogous to the SYSTEM schema which has access to all objects in an empty database installation.
        It has access to all code objects and data objects
    APPLSYS is the schema owner for AOL data objects, AD data objects and ALR data objects. APPS is granted access to these objects

Concepts in 11i Notes on Tablespaces:
    The main tablespaces in 11i are System, Rollback, Temporary, and Application
    The System tablespace is owned by the SYS account and holds the data dictionary tables.
    The Rollback tablespace is used to track transactions until they are committed
        This tablespace needs to be set large if upgrading, to accomodate upgrade transaction volumes to 11i
    The Temporary tablespace TEMP is used for sorting data.
        All applications can reference a single TEMP tablespace for sorting purposes
    Every application has a tablespace for data (suffix 'D') and a tablespace for indexes (suffix 'X')
        This simplifies licencing and improves performance. For AP, this would be APD and APX tablespaces
    Application tablespaces are owned by the APPS account
    Tablespaces are created as locally managed using the temporary file option with a uniform allocation size
        This is all for performance reasons
