Concurrent Manager (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Responsibilities:
    System Administrator (SA) - to define new requests.
        Most responsbilities have access to viewing and running requests.
    Application Developer (AD) - to define concurrent processes and their underlying executables

Concurrent Manager (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    References
        Concurrent Request Data Gathering (Doc ID 740770.1)
        Oracle Automatically Bringing Users To 'View Request' Form After Requests Submitting (Doc ID 1328842.1)
    Request Sets get an id on FND_CONCURRENT_REQUESTS
        Each child of the request set gets it's own id when it is submitted
    Requests stay on FND_CONCURRENT_REQUESTS after they are completed
    Concurrent managers include Internal, Standard, and Conflict
    There are also concurrent managers for each application (eg. GL, AR)
    Concurrent Request log files reside on APPLCSF/log and <Product_Top>/Out
    PMON is the 'Process Monitor'
    Concurrent Managers in Oracle manage background processing and prevent resource overload
    A Concurrent Manager process is used to execute each batch job submitted.
    There are three administration concurrent managers:
        ICM - Internal Concurrent Manager, starts up and shuts down other managers
        SM  - Standard Manager, runs request not defined to run on a specific application managers
            typically configured to run a max of 5 processes
        CRM - Conflict Resolution Manager, checks concurrent programs for incompatibility rules
    There are specific product managers that run requests from the applications
        Each is typically configured to run a max of 2 processes
        Examples are: Inventory Manager, Receivables Tax Manager, etc
    A Concurrent Process is initiated and managed by the Internal Concurrent Manager (ICM) which is a separate program
    Internal Concurrent Manager (ICM) manages all the concurrent manager workers
        ICM polls the table FND_CONCURRENT_REQUESTS to kick off actual batch executions
            It then calls the operating system to run the corresponding executable
    The ICM will normally have only two managers (ie workers) per central processor running on a machine at any time
    In a concurrent request definition you can setup reports to email multiple recipients when the report is complete.
        These emails are processed by the Email Notification Server which must be installed
        The email recipients are established in the concurrent request submission window
            Look in the 'Upon Completion Options' section
    Concurrent jobs can be scheduled to run repeatedly on a regular calendar or schedule, through setup of the process
        Scheduling is done through the 'Schedule' button on the concurrent requests window.
    Incompatibilities are concurrent request sets with individual jobs that cannot be run at the same time.
        They are set as incompatible to ensure they are not scheduled to run concurrently
        Incompatibilities are defined at the concurrent program level through System Administration
    Job priority on concurrent requests is defaulted from the job priority profile option on the user's id
        It can also be set in the job definition
    Jobs are spawned as independent processes to the operating system
        by building a command line of the job name and parameters in the operating system format
    Paramaters can be:
        positional (for sql*plus or shell scripts),
        label (for .rdf reports) or a string in the execution options (for SQL*Loader jobs)
    Parameters are implemented through a DFF with Value Sets assigned to the DFF's
        This limits the options entered by the user to valid options where required
    Concurrent manager schedules a request set as a single job until it initiates
        then it schedules a separate job for each request in the set, with the request set job as a parent
    Requests can be submitted from operating system scripts using CONCSUB (ConcurrentSubmit)

Concurrent Manager (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Request Phase and Status Codes
    Phase Codes:
        I - Inactive,
        P - Pending,
        R - Running,
        C - Completed
    Status Codes:
        U -  Disabled
        W -  Paused
        X -  Terminated (canceled while running)
        Z -  Waiting
        M -  No Manager
        Q -  Standby
        R -  Normal
        S -  Suspended
        T -  Terminating (canceling while job is running)
        D -  Cancelled (cancelled before job started)
        E -  Error
        F -  Scheduled
        G -  Warning
        H -  On Hold
        I -  Normal
        A -  Waiting
        B -  Resuming
        C -  Normal
    Phase Code and Status Combinations
    Innactive (Phase 'I') - Unable to run
        These can be cancelled (or call for help - the Manager may be down and need restarting)
    Pending (code 'P') or "waiting to run"
        Statuses are ('I', 'Q', 'Z'):
            Normal (code 'I') - Waiting for a Manager to run
            Scheduled (code 'F') - scheduled for a future date and not supposed to be running (yet)
            Standby (code 'Q') - program is incompatible with other requests running and on-hold
            Waiting (code 'Z') - waiting for a predecessor process to complete in a set
    Running (code 'R')
        These requests can be terminated rather than cancelled
        Statuses are ('R', 'W', 'T'):
            Normal (code 'R') - the request is running normally
            Paused (code 'W') - the request has been paused by the system and will soon restart
            Resuming (code 'B') - the request has resumed from a pause
            Terminating (code 'T') - the request has been cancelled by the user while running
    Completed (code 'C')
        Statuses are ('C', 'D', 'E', 'G', 'X'):
            Normal (code 'C') - request ended normally or 'Completed'
                This status accounts for most of the entries on FND_CONCURRENT_REQUESTS
            Error (code 'E') - requests ending with an error
                This status accounts for a large number of entries on FND_CONCURRENT_REQUESTS
            Warning (code 'G') - the request has completed but exceptions were found
            Cancelled (code 'D') - pending or inactive requests that were cancelled through SRS
            Terminated (code 'X') - running requests that were terminated through SRS while the job was running
            Disabled (code 'D') - the requested program is flagged as disabled and cannot be run
            On Hold (code 'H') - pending requests placed on hold through SRS
            No Manager (code 'M') - the request cannot be assigned to a manager (none are available) and will not start

Concurrent Manager (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Request Setup:
    An executable is defined to link the actual source file or compiled executable to the concurrent request
        Executable definitions are set up within each application
        An Executable Name must be unique within a single application name
    The application name assigned to an executable defines the directory structure where the source program is sought.
    The execution method is used to determine where to search for the program and how it is run.
        Examples are: Host (script), Reports, PL/SQL Stored Procedure, SQL*Loader, SQL*Plus (script)
        SQL*PLus Scripts are stored in the Apps Server Directory under the applicable application top, for example ...
            /u01/oracle/stage/apps/apps_st/appl/dmcar/1.0/sql
    The executable program name is the actual name of the host file, or PL/SQL stored procedure
        For PL/SQL programs use PACKAGE.PROCEDURE naming convention
    Once the executable is defined, the concurrent program request is defined which links to the executable.
        The application assigned to the program definition determines the application password it uses
        The application also drives where it places output and log files
    Request Types in the Program Definition are optional
        They can be used to limit which programs are run by each concurrent manager or worker.
    Parameters are entered of the Program Defintion form
        LOV's, titles, and default values can be registered for each parameter
    Exercise: Define an executable for a concurrent request -> SA/Concurrent/Program/Executable
    Exercise: Define a concurrent program request -> SA/Concurrent/Program/Define, and assign a name to the concurrent program
        Link the executable and define the program parameters
    Exercise: Define parameters for a concurrent program request -> SA/Concurrent/Program/Define
        Click the 'Parameters' button after defining the program

Concurrent Manager (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Request Set Setup:
    Request Sets have owners but the owner can be left blank
        If blank, only the system administrator can see the request set and change it

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Tips and Tricks:
    The % sign is not needed at the end of strings in search expressions - it is an implied suffix
        This is not the case in the DQM module (Data Quality Management) but is implemented elsewhere (all other pages)
        Searches in DQM are tailored and based on match rules
    Searches are not case sensitive - use uppers or lowers in search strings
    Turn on Duplicate Prevention to have the system identify existing persons when creating contacts
        The same applies to creating people and referencing to existing organizations
        Otherwise Oracle will create a duplicate for the organization or person
    If you enter a new person as a contact all the information (e.g. address) is tied to the contact record
        It is not tied to the person record. The same applies to creating new organizations (as employers)
    To validate geographies in R12 you must assign HZ_LOCATIONS before validating HR_LOCATIONS_ALL
        You don't need to validate HZ_LOCATIONS but you need to assign it.
        Otherwise you get an error when setting validation levels: "Please create a default address style ..."

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Additional References:
    How to control the Phone Number format (Doc ID 454618.1)

Technical Stack
    Oracle 11i vs Oracle R12 Differences
        References
            Mod_plsql and Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12 (Doc ID 726711.1)
    Database 
        Database Version in 11i (11.5.9 & 11.5.10) was 9i Rel 2 where as in Release 12 its 10g R2 (10.2.0.2)
    Application Tier:
        Tech Stack in Application Tier consist of iAS(1.0.2.2.2) & Developer 6i (Forms & Reports 8.0.6) but in Applications R12 it is build on Fusion Middleware (10g Web Server and 10g Forms & Reports)
    Sub component in Application Tier
        HTTP Server or Web Server in R12 is Version 10.1.3 which is built on Apache version 1.3.34. In apps 11i it is Version 1.0.2.2.2 built on Apache Version 1.3.19
        Jserv in apps 11i is replaced by OC4J (mod_jserv is replaced by mod_oc4j)
        Forms Version 6i in Apps 11i is replaced by Forms 10.1.2.0.2 in R12
        Reports Version 6i in Apps 11i is replaced by Reports 10.1.2.0.2 in R12
        JDBC version is changed from version 9 in apps 11i to version 10.2.0 in Apps R12
        modplsql or mod_pls is removed from Apps R12 (What will happen to my mod plsql applications- coming soon* )
            References
                Using Oracle Application Framework (OAF) and Application Development Framework (ADF) (Doc ID 563047.1)
        Java processes use JDK/JRE version 1.5.0 in R12 against JDK version 1.3.1 or 1.4.2 in Apps 11i

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on General Functionality
    TCA maintains a model of customers and organizations in the commercial community used by Oracle Applications
    Parties are:
        people,
        organizations,
        branches,
        subsidiaries,
        legal entities,
        holding companies, and
        groups that have commercial relationships
        essentially they are people and organizations
    Accounts fall under parties and there can be multiple accounts for a single party
    Customer Data Hub is a separate Oracle module (IMC schema) and part of Fusion Middleware
    It's primary function is to centralize maintenance of core customer information
        This provides a platform for improving the quality of customer data
        It also allows linking of multiple customer records across multiple systems
            This provides a consolidated view of the customer
    Customers are one of two different subtypes: either Organizations or People
    It can be implemented independent of Oracle Applications to serve third party application needs
    Customer Data Hub is also known and published as "Oracle Customers Online"
        "Oracle Customers Online" is actually the set of java forms and applets used to view customer hub data
        Most of the responsibilities for Customer Data Hub include "... Customers Online" terminology
    There are two products actually two products in Customer Data Hub:
        Customer Data Hub (base functions) and
        Customer Data Librarian (for the data administration component)
    Customers can be organizations or people - the two fundamental types
    Synchronization is provided with source systems to receive updates and transmit/publish changes out
        Source system cross references are maintained to publish out future changes (pub/sub model)
        Source data cross references create a subscriber list for different element types to receive updates
        Updates from and to sources can be real time or scheduled (for periodic updates)
        There are approximately 50 different integration points (data entities) that can be published separately
    Customer data must be initially imported from multiple feeder systems into the hub for inquiry
        It is consolidated by choosing attributes from different records within the data administration
        Conflict resolution allows one attribute to be chosen over the same attribute from a different source
    Duplicate records can be tagged manually and merged through the overview form
        Master records are created from the collection of attributes in the duplicate records
            Users can choose which data components are used from which records to create the master
        Merging requires a special data librarian responsibility to access the "Data Quality" tab
        Merge nominations are submitted to the data librarian for final review and completion
        Match rules are invoked when new records are received or searched, to identify duplicate candidates
            New duplicate records can be prevented in the match rule process
            Existing duplicates can be found in queries which invoke the match rule logic
    Validation is provided with standard address validation
    360 Degree View - is a feature of the data hub where it imports and displays transactional data
        Data can include quotations, sales, tasks or actions, interactions, contacts, attachments, relationships, and hierarchies
        Transaction data is presented by querying the source systems and not loading the data into the hub
        Hierarchies can be obtained from D&B and added to the profile
        Using the "Enrich" button on the customer tab
        Hierarchy visualization is supported by a Java application for visual drill through of relationships
    Question: can the hub be used to centralize location data across multiple applications

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (TCA) Notes on Suppliers Maintained in iSupplier Portal:
    Suppliers who manage their own profiles in iProcurement and the iSupplier Portal are recorded in the TCA architecture tables

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Business Drivers
    Customer Data Hub centralizes customer data to improve its quality and consistency
        It provides embedded tools and filters to identify and eliminate duplicate entries
    It provides additional attributes for tracking customer information not found in satellite systems
    It simpifies data warehousing reducing cross-references between data from different sources

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Technical Architecture
    The Customer Data Hub schema is "IMC"
    The hub uses a GUID (Globally Unique Identifier) to guarantee uniqueness of customer records
    The GUID structure used in the hub complies with the Open Source definition for GUID's
        (i.e. 16 bytes or 128 bits, e.g. "3F2504E0-4F89-11D3-9A0C-0305E82C3301")

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Data Content
    Customer Data Hub centralizes certain but not all data entities required by various satellite systems
    Classes of data entities incorporated into Hub include:
        Customer (Company or Person)
        Relationships between customers (employment, subsidiary etc)
        Addresses of Customers and Relationship entities (e.g. people and employee addresses)
        Contact information (email addresses, corporate domains, phone numbers)

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Contacts and Employer/Employee Relationships:
    Contacts are established within the Relationships area of the Customer Maintenance form
        Contacts within an existing organization can also be queried from the 'Relationships' form area
        A contact is an employee within an organization
    To assign an existing person to an organization (or vice-versa) query the person (or org)
        Then choose the Relationships submenu and enter the existing organization (or person)
    "View History" in the Relationships form allows restoring contacts previously end-dated
    Creating a contact under an organization creates a person with an employee relationship to an organization
        Equally, creating an organization when creating a person also creates the Org as a new org
        To avoid this, leave the organization blank and enter it in the relationships form for the person
        If Duplicate prevention is enabled, a warning is issued if a duplicate 'hit' is found when the org is entered
            Duplicate prevention is enabled through profile options:
                HZ: Enable Duplicate Prevention at Party Creation
                HZ: Enable DQM Party Search -- must be enabled for duplicate prevention but also implements DQM search in Customer setup
                HZ: Match Rule for Organization Duplicate Prevention (seeded default value is SAMPLE: SEARCH)
                HZ: Match Rule for Person Duplicate Prevention (seeded default value is SAMPLE: SEARCH)
    There is a "Switch To" drop down on the Person/Contact pages that allow flipping between a person and their contact record
        Addresses can be assigned to a person or a contact separately
        For a contact address, it only exists within the context of the contact (eg. employment relationship)
    If an organization is entered with a new person a contact relationship is created and any address becomes a contact address

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Classifications
    Classifications can be assigned to organizations and people
    Classifications include a Class Category (the actual class) and a Class Code (the actual values within the class)
    For organizations only, standard classifications can be used
        These include SIC, NACE and NAICS
    You cannot assign classification values to contacts - switch to the person for this
    Classifications are maintained or created through the administration tab

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Duplicate Identification and Elimination:
    Customers can be queried based on a character string and selected for duplicate checking
    These duplicate candidates are sent to the administrator as potential duplicates to be combined
    The administrator privilege allows processing these duplicates under the "Data Quality" tab

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Differences beteen IMC and TCA
    The data hub is based on the TCA data model and uses the TCA registry
        The OCO Administration tab provides access to most of the TCA Administration tools
    Customers are created as parties on the TCA tables (HZ_PARTIES)
    The "Registry ID" on the Customer Overview page is the key to the HZ_PARTIES table entry

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Potential Benefits:
    Eliminate existing interfaces between OE and AR for customer updates

Customer Data Hub and Trading Community Architecture (IMC and TCA) Notes on Integration and Interfaces with Other Systems:
    Data Hub uses the Oracle Data Librarian to connect with other systems
    Inbound integration requires the feeder system to send an XML message to Oracle
        The feeder system must provide the trigger to create and transmit customer data
        The customer content is posted through the Oracle XML Gateway to the Customer Data Hub
        Inbound XML integration is intended only for customer master information
            Since the XML gateway is an HTTP listener it will accept data payloads in real time
        The XML Gateway authenticates the source and invokes a duplicate checking package in the hub
        Transactional information intended to be fed to the hub - the hub "punches out" (to Oracle Apps) to retrieve it
        Transactional information is displayed in the hub by querying the Oracle application tables directly
    Outbound integration is simplified through Oracle 10g Application Server connectors
        Using the tools available through Oracle 10gAS multiple export protocols are available (not just XML)
        However, there are no pre-packages outbound interfaces so each outbound interface requires development
            This is standard Oracle practice for any outbound interface
    Additional integration functions are provided to the Oracle E-Business Suite
        Real time data checking is implemented to prevent duplicates being created in the Oracle applications
        After customer merge, apps support merge of historical transactions to point to the merged customer record
        Merging also supports automatic realignment of Business Intelligence summary records to match customer merged data
        Oracle apps integration also displays transaction detail from the other applications in the hub forms
            This includes orders from Oracle Order Management and invoices from Oracle Accounts Receivable
            There is no integration to Oracle Accounts Payable for supplier maintenance
        Other transactional integration (through hub reporting) is provided for:
            Oracle Marketing (Campaigns and Events)
            Oracle Leads Management (Leads)
            Oracle Sales Online (Opportunities)
            Oracle Quoting (Quotations)
            Oracle Installed Base (Installed Equipment)
            Oracle Teleservice (Service Requests)
            Oracle Collections (Delinquencies and Broken Promises to Pay)
        There is no integration with Oracle Projects (Billing)
    Customer Accounts linked to organizations are part of Oracle Accounts Receivable integration
        These integrations are not supported for third party products
        The link supports drill downs into account information within Oracle AR
        The supported account attributes (Profile Class, Sites, Contacts) are specific to Oracle AR

Dataload (www.dataload.net) Tips and Tricks
    Use 'Esc' to escape a dataload
    There are a number of predefined spreadsheets at the Dataload website
        There is a link in the information window in the Dataload application
    Watch out for dependent fields in loads - fields enabled by a setting in another field
        These fields will throw out the tab sequence on selected records
    Check that all records exist before running dataloads that update existing records
        If a record does not exist it will throw the dataload and stay stuck in query mode.

Dataload (www.dataload.net) Notes on General Functionality:
    Dataload is used to input data into forms by simulating key strokes to the Oracle forms
    Updated versions of the software are available at http://www.dataload.net
        Dataload classic is free and dataload professional has a licencing fee attached
    Precede a command in dataload with '\' to enter data literally
        If there is no '\' prefix the cell is interpreted as a command
        Commands can be entered as literals also (e.g. \{TAB})
    Timing settings do not affect cells with repeat counts on commands (e.g. {TAB 8})

Dataload (www.dataload.net) Commands
    Any keyboard key can be sent to Oracle via Dataload using the appropriate combination of keys
    See the command reference at http://www.dataload.net/help/macro/keystrokes.htm
    All commands and their decoded values are also listed in /Edit/Commands on the Dataload menu
    Keys have default behaviour and special behaviour.
    Most commands are synonyms for actual commands and are indicated with a leading *
    TAB and ENT are the only command keys that do not require a leading *
    \ means literal or 'keystroke' entry intp a cell - the contents following the \ are keyed literally and not interpreted
    {} means special (often 'non-printing') interpretation of a set of keys
    SHIFT, CTRL, ALT and Right ALT are represented by +, ^, % and & in a dataload sheet
        To send +, ^, % and & to the application directly enclose them in {} to assign them special (non-default) behaviour

Dataload (www.dataload.net) Notes on Running a Dataload
    Create a spreadsheet of the needed commands
    Copy the spreadsheet into Dataload
    Set key delays for all keys used (/Tools/Delays)
        scroll down the list to see all keys
    Choose command group '11i' on the main dataload form to use the 11i keyset
        You can see these commands at /Edit/Commands for each command group
    Open the form in Oracle that needs to be loaded and set focus on the first field
    Run the Dataload

Dataload (www.dataload.net) Notes on Fast Excel Import:
    Open or create a spreasheet and highlight all the cells you want to import to Dataload
        Make sure any new spreadsheet is saved - otherwise Dataload won't pick up any data
    Choose /Tools/Excel Import and Dataload will automatically import the data
    Set Excel import options uner /Tools/Options to load entire sheets, selected data and run immediately

Demantra Notes on General Functionality:
    Demantra is a Demand Planning and Forecasting Module purchased by Oracle in June 2006
        It implements Bayesian-Markov Multi-attribute analysis of causal factors in demand to build forecasts
        This allows what-if impact analysis on the changes due to pricing, promotions, product mix, seasonality and other factors.
    Demantra has a long term relationship with J.D. Edwards
        It is intended to close the gap left by Oracle Advanced Planning and Scheduling
    Demantra has several components in its 'Spectrum Suite'
        Demand Management
        Real-time Sales and Operations Planning
        Trade Promotions Management & Optimization
        Retail Planning and Store Replenishment
    Demantra integrates with Oracle APS to provide demand forecasts
        Oracle APS provides supply network modeling, inventory optimization and supply planning
    Demantra improves on existing products offered by Oracle
        Oracle Demand Management will remain supported and have Demantra as an option
        Oracle Trade Management (QZF Schema) will remain supported but is less functional than Demantra's trade management component

Debugging and Tracing (Trace) Notes on General Functionality:
    References
        How to enable and retrieve FND debug log messages [ID 433199.1]
        How Can Trace and Debug Be Turned On For A Concurrent Request? [ID 759389.1]
        How to Collect an FND Diagnostics Trace (aka FND: Debug) [ID 372209.1]
        How to Obtain Debug Log in R12 [ID 787727.1]
    FND Debug logs store error messages that are written by the PL/SQL code or Java code of the application to common debug table
        Debug messages were decentralized prior to 11.5.10 but are now centralized in FND_LOG_MESSAGES
        Debug messages are written into the PL/SQL code this way:
            fnd_log.STRING(log_level => fnd_log.level_statement
              ,module    => 'xxpo.packagename.procedurename'
              ,message   => 'debug message here');
        Errors message text has different levels and anything equal to or greater than the requested level will write messages:
            LEVEL_UNEXPECTED     : Internal Level Id is 6
            LEVEL_ERROR          : Internal Level Id is 5
            LEVEL_EXCEPTION      : Internal Level Id is 4
            LEVEL_EVENT          : Internal Level Id is 3
            LEVEL_PROCEDURE      : Internal Level Id is 2
            LEVEL_STATEMENT      : Internal Level Id is 1 - this corresponds with Statement Level on the associated 'Level' profile option
    Trace messages (SQL Traces) are written by the SQL Execution (database) Engine on the database and show the SQL executed
        Trace messages are formatted by TKPROF
            How to Enable and Retrieve Trace and Tkprof Files (Doc ID 2100928.1)
    Enable FND Logging using system administrator responsibility
        Set the following profiles at the USER Level
            FND: Debug Log Level = Statement
            FND: Debug Log Module = %
            FND: Debug Log Enabled = Yes
    Run a concurrent process (e.g. Invoice Validation in AR) as aconcurrent request.
    Provide the results of the script after the request fails in a text file:
        select log_sequence,module,message_text,log_level
        from fnd_log_messages
        where transaction_context_id =
        (select transaction_context_id
        from fnd_log_transaction_context
        where transaction_id =&con_request_id)
        order by log_sequence;
    Alternatively search the fnd_log_messages table based on current date and user_id
        Oracle also suggest getting the maximum value before setting the trace and then querying all lines that exceed the initial maximum value
    Search for the following in the debug output
        ORA-
        Return Status = E (for eBTax only)
        Return Status = U (for eBTax only)

Debugging and Tracing (Debug, Trace) Notes on Additional References
    http://oracle.anilpassi.com/fnd-debug-log-debugging-oracle-apps-code.html
    Setting a Trace File  Doc ID:  Note:135710.1 in Metalink Subject: How  to Create a User Event Trace in 11i

Demand Planning (MSD Schema) Notes:
    Based on algorithms from Geneva Planning corp.
    Predefined dimensions are: time, sales channel, geography, sales rep, product and ship-from location. Two added dimensions are user-defined
    Oracle Demand Planning generates forecasts or provides a place to import and record forecasts
    Forecast entries are dated forecast values for specific items
    Forecast sets are groups of forecasts for the same item and organization that combine to give a complete forecast
        (eg to group individual customer forecasts).
        A forecast can only belong to one set.
    Several forecast sets can be defined for different purposes which forecast the same items, examples of different forecast sets could be: Optimistic, Pessimistic and Realistic.
    Forecasts are always for items, and can be at customer level or address level
    Focus forecasts - generated from MRP/INV fit the best of five statistical methods to past shipments and forecast using this method
    Forecast Consumption - reduction in forecasts from incoming orders to avoid double counting.
    Backward and Forward Consumption - reduction in forecast due to sales orders around the order date
    Bucket Type - daily, weekly etc. Used to consume forecasts. All forecast values inside a bucket are consumed before fwd/bwd consumption starts
    Outlier Percent - percent of a forecast in a single bucket that can consumed by a single order (eg 1%). Bwd/Fwd processing still applies
    Demand Class - stamped on forecast and order types, to match forecast consumption (trade channel, geography etc)
    Bluebirds - orders that should not consume demand in a forecast.
        Unplanned orders caused by extraordinary one-time events
    Forecast events are promos, phaseouts, new products/cannibals. Each has a predefined format and entry form

Demand Planning (MSD) Notes on Forms:
    Dimensions -> DEMAND PLANNING SYSTEMS ADMINISTRATOR/Setup/Dimensions (based measures for a plan such as product, customer, location)
    Hierarchies -> DEMAND PLANNING SYSTEMS ADMINISTRATOR/Setup/Hierarchies (tie levels into a hierarchy - multiple independent hierarchies allowed)
    Levels -> DEMAND PLANNING SYSTEMS ADMINSTRATOR/Setup/Levels (establish levels that fit in a hierarchy)
    Demand Plans -> DEMAND PLANNING SYSTEMS ADMINISTRATOR/Demand Plans (to enter a demand plan)

Demand Planning Responsibilities:
    DEMAND PLANNING SYSTEMS ADMINISTRATOR - configures the demand planning express server
    DEMAND PLAN ADMINISTRATOR - assigns segments of the plan to individual planners
    PLANNER - develops and maintains plans
    PLANNING MANAGER - reviews and adjusts overall forecasts

Demand Planning Interfaces:

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Tips and Tricks
    Desupported by Oracle in June 2017 (replaced by OBIEE Oracle Business Intelligence Enterprise)
    There are a number of registry settings on the Disco server that govern behaviour like query limits
        See http://download.oracle.com/docs/cd/B25016_07//doc/dl/bi/B13916_04/registry_settings.htm
    MaxNumListRows is a registry setting that governs the number of rows that can be returned - it defaults to 100000
    Set the Profile Option 'ICX: Discoverer Use Viewer' to no to get access to Discoverer Plus from the Navigator
        If this profile option is set to 'Yes' then choosing Disco Plus will cause Disco Viewer to start
    Define item classes to speed up parameter searches - assign the item class to the parameter by assigning it to the data item the parameter references (i.e. the condition item)
    You can define a run parameter as optional but only from within Discoverer Plus edition
    Use Page Items to improve performance by moving data columns into the worksheet header
        This can limit the amount of data returned in a single query run
    Choose 'Open in Current Database Account' to run a report if you have access to the business area underlying it
    Reload Disco Desktop after making changes to folders in Admin Edition - Desktop caches the folder definitions so changes need to be flushed through
    You can give a description to a workbook but not a worksheet - see the section on naming for guidelines
    The tips and hints that appear in Disco Viewer parameters are system generated for date fields and LIKE conditions
    Access and Privileges to BA's is govered by Administrator
        The Owner or any other with Admin privileges must assign access and check 'Admin Privileges in 'Tools -> Security'
        The assigned user must have Admin rights also via 'Tools -> Privileges'
    Avoid using DECODE statements because the results can't be pivoted in Disco using standard crosstab features

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Troubleshooting
    Java Look and Feel - set to a non-null value eliminates the issue of a Java Null Pointer Error in 12.1.3

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Environment Settings
    You can add profile context for your environment to Disco folders by adding to the where clause
        and org_id = fnd_profile.VALUE('ORG_ID');
        and gl_set_of_books_id = fnd_profile.value('GL_SET_OF_BOOKS_ID')
    In SQL you can query these values directly with
        select fnd_profile.VALUE('ORG_ID') FROM dual;
        select fnd_profile.value('GL_SET_OF_BKS_ID') from dual;

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Discoverer software components consist of multiple tools:
        Desktop User Edition - a client application for building workbooks and worksheet
            Discoverer Desktop is a full featured client application to build Disoverer Reports
            User Edition manages the workbooks and worksheets that select data from the folders
        Administration Edition - to administer security and build end user layers and their business areas
            Administrator Edition manages the EUL schema tables and defines business areas (collections of folders) and folders (queries)
    Discoverer Viewer is an HTML page based application launched from within Oracle Applications to run reports
        You cannot build new reports in Viewer and you cannot copy and modify existing reports
        Discoverer Viewer automatically displays hints under parameters based on data types (e.g. dates) or 'LIKE' conditions (e.g. %)
    Discoverer Plus is a Java Applet version of Discoverer Desktop allowing you to create new worksheets
        You can set parameters as optional in Disco+ and this feature is not available in Disco Desktop
        You cannot save a workbook to your local host or open a workbook from your local host in Disco+
    End user layer - provides report building tools to extract spreadsheet data from the administration level views
    Administration Layer - provides design tools to create metadata (data about data) and views of application base tables
    The hierarchy of objects in Discoverer is:
        End User Layer - a collection of Business Areas i
            An EUL is seeded by Oracle and can be extended
        Business Area - a collection of folders in and EUL
            A Business Area is best defined to correspond to an application (e.g. AP, AR, GL)
        Folder - a query of the underlying database - similar to a database view
            Each business area may have several folders or views
            Folders are denormalized views of data such as journals, balances, invoices etc
        Workbook - a collection of worksheets
            Workbooks are used to group together worksheets but have little logical value
            You can have one worksheet per workbook (often the case)
        Worksheet
            A report run by the user and defined based on a folder
            Similar to a spreadsheet
            There can be multiple worksheets driven off the same workbook
            Each worksheet is the result of a query

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Discoverer Desktop vs. Discoverer Plus vs. Discoverer Viewer
    Discoverer Viewer displays hints under parameters based on the parameter datatype or attached condition (e.g. LIKE)
        It will display a date format on date fields and a tip to use % on parameters attached to LIKE conditions
        You cannot build, copy or modify workbooks in Discoverer Viewer
        The tips and hints that appear in Disco Viewer parameters are system generated for date fields and LIKE conditions
    Discoverer Plus will only save workbooks to the database - it cannot save workbooks to the desktop
    Discoverer Desktop will save books to the database or local host

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Lauching Viewer and Plus from the Navigator
    References
        How to launch 'Discoverer Viewer' in a new browser window. (Doc ID 302827.1)
            Add 'Invoke Web Discoverer' to any menu
    Set the Profile Option 'ICX: Discoverer Use Viewer' to no to get access to Discoverer Plus from the Navigator
        If this profile option is set to 'Yes' then choosing Disco Plus will cause Disco Viewer to start
    You can copy and modify the function 'Invoke Web Discoverer' to force it to display Plus or Viewer regardless of profile options
        On the Function Definition, Form tab, set Parameters = 'mode=DISCO&viewer=Y'

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Worksheets and Workbooks
    A workbook is a collection of worksheets in the same way a spreadsheet is a collection of individual sheets/tabs
    A worksheet is a report and stores the logic for presenting data
    A worksheet is based on a single folder in a business area
    Each worksheet in a workbook can be based on a different folder within the same business area
    There can be multiple worksheets driven off the same workbook and each worksheet is the result of a query

Discoverer (EUL5_SU Schema) Notes on Profile Options
    ICX: Discoverer Use Viewer - causes Discoverer Viewer to display when Discoverer Plus is chosen from the menu
    Java Look and Feel - set to a non-null value eliminates the issue of a Java Null Pointer Error in 12.1.3
        This happens when linking from EBS to Discoverer and the profile option is required to fix it
    FII: GL BIS Discoverer access - enables custom responsibility access to GL data
    ICX: Discoverer Launcher - path to Discoverer Plus Servlet
    ICX: Discoverer Viewer Launcher - path to Discoverer Viewer Servlet

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) References
    Oracle Discoverer 10g Handbook, Oracle Press, Michael and Darlene Armstrong Smith

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Naming Worksheets and Workbooks and Adding Descriptions
    You can only do this from Discoverer Plus by double-clicking or right-clicking on worksheet tabs
    Rename a worksheet from the menu -> Sheet -> Rename Sheet (in Disco Desktop or Disco +)
        You can't create a description for a worksheet -> it is not supported anywhere
        You can give a workbook a description (File -> Manage Workbooks -> Workbook Properties (in Disco Desktop))
    Rename a workbook from the menu -> File -> Manage Workbooks -> Properties
        You can also change the description of the workbook with this navigation

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on End User Layers
    An end user layer is a set of database tables on the Oracle Applications Database
    The schema for the standard Oracle Discoverer EUL is 'EUL5_US'
    The end user layer consists of all the metadata used to define the folders in each business area
        This includes column renames, list of values, business area names etc

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Key Tables
    EUL5_US.EUL5_BAS - business areas
    EUL5_US.EUL5_DOCUMENTS - workbooks
    EUL5_US.EUL5_QPP_STATS - statistics on what workbooks were run by whom and when

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Business Areas, Folders and Data Items
    Seeded Business Areas
        References
            Discoverer Workbooks and Business Areas obsolete in R12 (Doc ID 551354.1) 
    Business Areas or grouping of data queries/views - are normally for a specific set of requirements or functions in a given department
        Typically they should be defined per application - one Business Area per application is a good start
    Business areas and folders are established through Discoverer Administrator
        Business areas are securing entities that consist of folders.
        All folders within a business area can be secured to a responisibility
    A folder is a single query from the underlying database table, view, or set of joined tables.
        Complex Folders include items from multiple folders (fields from multiple tables) related by joins
        Without folders, a business area would be empty
        Folders are based on tables in the underlying database
        A folder can be created from a table directly through Insert/Folder/From Database in the Administrator menu
        A folder can be created by copying a query from TOAD or SQL*plus
        Create folders -> New/Custom Folder
            To add folders, choose the EUL Owner as the owner to get access to the tables
    Items - data items are based on fields/columns in the underlying database
        Items are individual data values based on fields/columns in the underlying database tables
    Discoverer Folders - based on tables in the underlying database
        A folder can be created from a table directly through Insert/Folder/From Database in the Administrator menu
        A folder can be created by copying a query from TOAD or SQL*plus
        Items are individual based on fields/columns in the underlying database
        Complex Folders - include items from multiple folders (fields from multiple tables) related by joins
        Create folders -> New/Custom Folder

Discoverer (EUL5_US) Notes on Security and Access
    Administration Edition Security controls access to business areas
        Sign-on to Administrator Edition with the 'Oracle Applications User' checkbox checked to work with the Oracle EUL's
            You can change the default EUL after sign-on via Tools/Options in Administration Edition
        The Administration Account for the EUL5_US schema is EULAPPS (and the default password is EULAPPS)
        Use Admin/Tools/Security to grant users access to the end user layer definition and business area
        Use Admin/Tools/Privileges and query the user to set privileges then set privileges (everything under administration)
    Access and Privileges to BA's is govered by Administrator
        The Owner or any other with Admin privileges must assign access and check 'Admin Privileges in 'Tools -> Security'
        The assigned user must have Admin rights also via 'Tools -> Privileges'
    Desktop Edition Security controls access to workbooks and worksheets
        You must share workbooks you create with other users or with other responsibilibities owned by users before they can see them.
        Share your workbooks -> File/Manage Workbooks/Sharing.../User->Workbook/and choose the user or responsibility, then choose the workbooks to share.
    Specifically for GL
        Set profile option for the GL responsibility: FII: GL BIS Discoverer access
        Ensure that the Security Enabled flag is set to Yes for all enabled segments of the chart of accounts.
        For accounting segments with no security rule, define a flexfield value set security rule for each segment in the chart of accounts that INCLUDES all possible values.
        Assign the value set security rules to the appropriate responsibilities.
        Ensure that the profile option GL Set of Books Name has been set at responsibility level for the responsibility.

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Running a Workbook
    In Desktop Edition you are prompted to open a workbook in the account where it was saved or in the current db account
        Choose 'current db account' if your account has access to the underlying business area
        Otherwise choose 'account in which saved' and log back on as the owner of the workbook

Discoverer (EUL Schema) Notes on Schemas
    The EUL5_US schema is the base schema for the Discoverer application
    The EUL5_US schema stores all the metadata that define the business areas and folders

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Creating Joins
    Use Insert, Join to create new joins between tables in the end user layer
    Joins are displayed as items in the item list within a folder
    Creating Complex folders - use Folder, Insert, New and tile two windows vertically to drag items in

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Item Classes
    Item classes can be defined in Discoverer Administrator (separate tab) to establish drop down lists for parameter entry
    Item classes are assigned by default to the item that is referenced when they are defined
        They become the LOV class for the item automatically in Discoverer Desktop
        They can be added to additional items.
    Create an Item classes: establish LOV's (drop down lists for parameters), drill to detail, and alternative sorts
        After creating and assigning to a data item in Discoverer Administrator, check the data item properties to make sure it is assigned (a two-way check)
        An alternate order can be defined in the item class to sort the LOV differently to the default

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Headline Fields and Page Items
    Create the headline fields tool bar through the user edition - Sheet/Edit Sheet/Table Layout/Show Page Items (Checkbox)
    Page items move columns into the heading of a workbook and can improve performance

Discoverer Parameter Values and Filters
    Parameter values can be changed through Sheet/Edit Parameter Values
    Parameters can be defined for a sheet through Tools/Conditions
    Speed up parameter search by creating and assigning an item class

Discoverer (EUL5_US Schema) Notes on Crosstab Workbooks
    You can create a cross tab workbook by copying from another workbook
    You should avoid using decodes in workbooks that are pivoted because these may return nulls - DECODES can't be summarized
        See Metalink: Explanation Of Why Totals and Calculations Are Sometimes Blank or Null in Discoverer [ID 208366.1]

eCommerce Gateway Responsibilities:
    eCOMMERCE GATEWAY VISION ENTERPRISES (ECGVE)

eCommerce Gateway Notes:
    eCommerce Gateway (formally EDI Gateway) imports and exports standard EDI transactions and maintains mappings with trading partners
    A third party EDI translation program is needed to map the output of eCommerce gateway to the EDIFACT standard, and to map EDIFACT inbound messages for processing
    Trading partners are individual vendor or customer sites in eCommerce Gateway - they can be defined individually and then make members of a group. The group is the multi-site trading partner (customer or supplier)
    Define Groups and Members: ECGVE/Setup/Trading Partners, and define the group and attach the group members.

Engineering Notes:

Enterprise Asset Management (EAM) Notes:
    EAM is a maintenance system - it enables planning and scheduling of maintenance activities for asset-intensive organizations
    EAM maintains preventive maintenance schedules, tracks inspections and readings, tracks asset availability and schedules maintenance resources
    Properties can be tracked for each asset, and assets can be assigned to groups of assets with similar characteristics and attributes
    Asset bills of materials can be defined to identify components of an asset, and asset groups can be assigned a default BOM
    Work orders and work order history are tracked against assets and asset components, together with the costs of the maintenance
    Rebuildable spares are tracked every time they are used, rebuilt, stored or reused
    A self service interface is designed for supervisors and tradespeople to provide information and tracking for common maintenance activities

Enterprise Asset Management (EAM) Notes on Key Tables:
    WIP_DISCRETE_JOBS - All details of the work order except Failure_Code_Required flag.
    WIP_ENTITIES - Contains Job type (EAM, DISCRETE, FLOW etc), Job/WO
    EAM_WORK_ORDER_DETAILS - Contains only Failure_Code_Required flag, which determines whether failure entry is required for the work order or not.
    APPS.EAM_WORK_ORDERS_V - Contains all work orders where the work order number is WIP_ENTITY_NAME

Field Service Responsibilities:
    FIELD SERVICEE DISPATCHER

Field Service User Exercises:
    Find Tasks -> FIELD SERVICE DISPATCHER/Dispatch Center/.. and choose the 'view by' option to filter the displayed tasks, or click the flashlight icon to display the standard 'Find Tasks' dialog

Financial Analyzer (OFA) Notes:
    OFA supports it's own chart of accounts,  for budgeting, forecasting, analyzing and reporting corporate financial data
    OFA is based on the Oracle Express multi-dimensional modelling technology.
    OFA is populated by exports of data from the GL, including the chart of accounts and the actual segment values - this transfer must be repeated periodically to refresh the Express database
    OFA maps the AFF segments into dimensions and dimension values, aka metadata.
    OFA supports hierarchies on each dimension to summarize values, similarly to parent values on the COA AFF segment values
    OFA receives data from the GL as follows: balances, average balances, encumbrances, statistical amounts, and budgets
    OFA uses 'Budget Writeback' to send modified budgets back to the GL after they are modified within OFA

Financial Statement Generator (RG Schema) Tips and Tricks

    You need to use the original responsibility or user to see FSG sets otherwise they won't appear
    'Enable Security' on the Report Definition page limits access to the definition of the report to the person who created it

Financial Statement Generator (RG Schema) Responsibilities:
    GENERAL LEDGER SUPER USER (GLSU)

Financial Statement Generator (RG Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Financial Statement Generator (FSG) is the report writer for the general ledger
    FSG's are used to define balance sheet, income statement and cash flow reports that are specific to each organization's account structures
    FSG reports account balances by period within the General Ledger but not detailed transactions such as individual journal entries
    FSG's can be exported to ADI for formatting and further summarizations and calculations
    FSG's consist of reusable components: Row Sets, Column Sets, Content Sets, Row Orders and Display Sets
        Row Sets and Column Sets are the primary entities needed to build FSG Reports and are required
    Rows sets are Account Segments or Segment combinations and based on the Accounting Flexfield values
        Row Sets have many values (rows) and can include calculations
        Defining rows in a rowset - leave account segments blank to choose all values
        Alternatively specify a range of account values to limit a rowset to specific accounts
        Name each range to allow printing a text description at the beginning of each row set
           Assign an order value to each range of row sets to sequence the order of printing.
        Display types on each range of rows drive the display of line detail (expand), totals for the group (total), or both (both)
        Define a single rowset for each family of reports, such as balance sheets, income statements etc.
            Don't duplicate row sets and increase maintenance
   Column sets are based on balance types and periods and can have many values (columns) including calculations
        There are 14 seeded column set definitions with FSG
        Balance Types include: actual, budget, encumbrance, statistical
        Periods include: current month, YTD, Last YTD, Prior Month etc
        The Column Set also defines the formating of the numbers for the column (e.g. leading '$')
        A column set is defined in the 'Column Set Builder' window
    Content Sets group and limit the information presented in the body of the FSG
        This grouping and limiting is based on Segments such as Departments or Companies
        They do this by over-riding the row-set definitions on the report
            e.g. A content set can be companies - the FSG prints separate report pages for each company value in the company segment
            e.g. A cost center can be added to a content set to print separate report pages for each content set values
        Multiple reports with different Content Sets can be printed in the same submitted process
    Segment Override on the Report Definition Form restrict output to a specific segment value
        You can use it to restrict output to a specific value in a specific segment or segments
        Segment Override is a more restrictive option that Content Set limits because they only allow one value
    Display Groups limit information that appears on the report by excluding rows and columns based on their sequence number
        The define ranges of rows or columns from Row Sets or Column Sets
        These groups are assigned to Reports through Display Sets
    Display Sets are collections of Display Groups and used to include/exclude specific columns and rows on a report
        Display Sets are directly assigned to report definitions
        They allow Row Sets and Column Sets to be used for multiple purposes
        They implement exceptions to Row and Column Sets as a final filtering process
    Add hoc FSG's can be run from the FSG submission window by choosing 'Add Hoc'
        Selecting a row set and column set directly
    FSG's can be defined or run to produce tab-delimited output to export to a spreasheet for formatting
    FSG's can be transferred between instances through database links
        They do not have to be re-keyed into each instance during a project
    FSG standard reports on FSG structures are all prefixed by 'FSG - ' in the concurrent manager

Financial Statement Generator (RG Schema) Notes on Definition Security
    Security can be enabled on the Report Definition Form with the 'Enable Security' flag
        Checking this flag restricts access to the report definition to the owner
        This security control does not limit access to running the report (see profile options for this)

Financial Statement Generator (RG Schema) Notes on XML Publisher:
    FSG's can be published in XML Publisher for spreadsheet and PDF formatted output.
    You cannot use content sets with the 'Parallel Processing' option to generate XML Publisher content

Financial Statement Generator (RG Schema) Notes on Alternative Output Formats:
    FSG's can be printed to tab-delimited values for spreadsheet import
    FSG's also support XBRL (Extensible Business Reporting Language) report formatting
        XBRL includes a standard naming convention of XML Tags for naming accounting report values and elements

Financial Statement Generator (RG Schema) Exercises:
    Run an FSG report -> General Ledger Super User/Reports/Requests/Financial
        (or concurrent req "Program - Run Financial Statement Generator")
    Define a report -> Reports/Define/Report: name the report and attach a rowset, columnset
    Define a rowset -> Reports/Define/Row Set: define any number of rows for a single rowset
    Define a columnset -> Reports/Define/Column Set:
    Define an FSG report set (multiple FSG's run in order) -> Reports/Define/Report Set
    Run FSG Definition Listings -> Concurrent Manager, Query on FSG% report listings

Financial Statement Generator (RG Schema) Notes on Profile Options:
    FSG: Enforce Segment Value Security - limits printable output to values allowed by Security Rules
    FSG: Allow Portrait Print Style
    FSG: Expand Parent Values
    FSG: Message Detail - enables maximum run details to the log file for the concurrent manager job to assist debugging
    FSG: Enable Search Optimization - improves performance for large reports with many row sets

Financial Statement Generator (RG Schema) Notes on Reports
    All FSG reports start with 'FSG - ' in Concurrent Manager report lists
    FSG - Where Used, details where specific Accounting Key Flexfield segments values are referenced in FSG's
        This will to assist in maintenance during COA changes

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Tips and Tricks:
    You must specify a Book and 'tab out' to see and change asset details from the Asset Workbench
        In the Books form, choose a book and tab through the header to default or display asset details
        This form displays blank values until a book is chosen for the asset (and you tab out of the header fields)
    You can see the value of an asset in both books via the Financial Summary form
    Asset Number auto-assignment is specified by a range in Setup/Asset System/System Controls  (not a profile option)
        You can manually enter a number outside this range when entering assets
        Entered asset numbers can be alpha-numeric
    Assets documentation is often classified under Financials and not under it's own heading
    Asset Key Flexfield must be defined buy is optional for entry
        Define a single segment KFF with no validation to avoid the KFF window opening in forms
    Assets are generated in Functional Currency - mass additions from AP sends transactions in the functional currency to FA
        This is regardless of the currency in which the invoice was entered into AP
        FA only creates journal entries in the Functional Currency - not the entered currency and functional currency
    Asset 'Cost Summary Report' (FACOSTS) and Asset 'Cost Detail Report' (FASCOSTD) reports can be out of balance for transfers, reassignments if depreciation is not run
        Rolling back depreciation before running these reports will also create an out of balance condition
    You can run the 'Generate Asset Trace' report to see all activity on an asset from its point of creation
    You can use unplanned depreciation to simulate a simple impairment
