Oracle Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Best Practices
    Periodically run the 'Mass Additions Delete' process to clear out posted, split/posted and deleted mass addition records
        This makes it easy to see what mass additions are not posted via the online forms
        It is run from the main menu and not from SRS

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Terminology:
    Asset Key - an optional key flexfield that can be used to group or categorize assets
    Assignment - the person, GL account and physical location assigned to the asset
    Book - a set of assets and accounting rules - depreciation is run on a book by book basis
        Journal entries must balance within the context of a book
    Depreciation Limit - the maximum amount of depreciation that can be expensed
    MACRS - Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (table based depreciation for different classes)
    Original Cost - the original cost of the asset which includes and cost adjustments made during the addition period
        Original Cost is fixed once the first depreciation is run
    Prorate Convention - the rule which decides when in the month an asset starts (and stops) depreciating
        See Metalink Note 115323.1 The Wonderful World of Prorate Conventions Whitepaper
    Recoverable Cost - the difference between cost and salvage value (i.e. what can be depreciated)
    Reference Number - a unique identifier for an asset transaction (not the asset itself)
    Reserved - fully depreciated
    Source Lines - the project or payable entry that created the asset
        Can be start of month, middle of month, or end of month (for the month placed in service)
    Transfer - change the assignment (location, depreciation account, employee) on an asset
    Reclassify - change the asset category on an asset

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Profile Options:
    Implement Asset Organization Security -> FA:Security Profile - assigns a Security Group Definition
        The Security Group Definition references an Organization Hierarchy and starting point
    Turn auto-numbering on for Asset ID's -> is not a profile option - see System Controls setups
    FA: Use Workflow Account Generation -- determines if FA Account Generator Workflow is used for account generation

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Assets are organized into Books in the Fixed Assets System
        Books can be corporate, tax or budget types
        Each asset book is associated with a Set of Books on the GL
            An Asset Book is confined to posting within a single GL Set of Books
    Fixed Assets key features include:
        Multiple depreciation methods
        Asset inventory
        User defined accounting rules
        Self service inquiry
        Standard Reports and User Defined Reports
        Tax calculations
    Fixed Asset information is primarily in three categories:
        Physical information - tag, serial number, description, identifying asset number
        Financial information - cost, depreciaton method
        Assignments - person, depreciation account and physical location
            Location is a Key Flexfield structure specific to Fixed Assets
            Exercise: Assign the Key Flexfield for Location -> <Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/System Controls
    The Fixed Asset lifecycle includes:
        Additions - creating new assets
        Adjustments - changing asset costs, lives and depreciation methods
        Transfers - changing locations, accounts and people (assignments)XX GL Cost Detail Report Set - by Refinery
            The account is the GL account where depreciation is charged
            The location and person are used for tax and responsibility reporting only
            Changing the location or person assignment has no financial impact
        Reclassifications - changing asset categories
        Retirements - full and partial asset retirements
        Changes in Physical Information - tags, descriptions, etc

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Corporate Books and Tax Books
    Assets can belong to any number of books but must belong to one corporate book
        Assets must first be assigned to a corporate book before being assigned to tax books
        Assets can only be assigned to a book where the asset's category is also defined
        Corporate Books can have independent accounts, depreciation rules and calendars
        You specify for which GL Set of Books an Asset Book will create journal entries
    An asset can have different financial values in each book (cost, accumulated depreciation)
    Tax Books exist alongside Corporate Books
        There can be multiple Tax Books for a single Corporate Book
        Assets are mass copied from the Corporate Books to the Tax Books
            The Corporate Book must be closed for the period to perform Mass Copy
            Different options for the Mass Copy include:
                Additions, Adjustments, Retirements/Reinstatements, and Salvage
            The concurrent process for Mass Copy is "Periodic Mass Copy"
        Tax reports include:
            Annual Additions by Date Placed in Service
            Capital Spending
            Property Tax Report - by Location
            Tax Preference Report - Compare Tax and Corporate Books
            Recoverable Cost Report
            Reserve Adjustments Report
            Tax Additions Report
            Tax Reserve Ledger Report
            Tax Retirements Report

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Book Security
    Unless optional security is setup in Fixed Assets, any responsibility has access to all books
    Optional Book Security is implemented by attaching each book to a Fixed Asset Organization
        One Fixed Asset Organization can hold many Asset Books
    See Metalink Note 111129.1 "Oracle Fixed Assets Security by Book" Whitepaper
    Book Security is driven by Assets Responsibility
        Each Assets Responsibility is assigned a Security Profile
            This is done with the profile option "FA: Security Profile"
        The Security Profile definition includes an Organization Hieararchy and "topmost" organization
            It limits the user to the Asset Organization Hierarchy defined in a Security Profile
        One or more Asset Books can be attached to an Asset Organization in Organization Definition
            This is done through the attributes of a Fixed Asset Organization
            When you check the attributes, a Book Definition form appears
                Existing Books can be queried and saved (associated with an Organization)
                    Modify the Book and resave to "trigger" the association to the Organization
                New Books can be entered and they automatically associate with the Organization when saved
        Tax books inherit the same security as their associated Corporate Books
    Steps to define asset security are:
        Define an asset organization and attach one or more books to it
        Define an asset profile listing the organization hierarchy and home organization
        Assign the asset profile to the responsibility
        Run Security List Maintenance to populate LOV's with their corresponding books
        Check access by logging in
    The organization is associated to the asset book in the Organization Definition form (organization classification)
        Use the Assets Superuser or any responsiblity with ASSETS_MAIN menu items
        Query the Operating Unit
        Query the book using QBE exactly, by name
        Modify something on the book so there is a 'change to save' - e.g. the description
        The book is now associated with the organization

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Key Forms:
    There are two inquiry forms: Transaction History and Financial Information
        The most options for finding an asset are provided under "Financial Information"
        You can inquire based on: Asset, Book, Source Details, Assignment, or Lease
    Inquiry is also supported through the i-Assets self service application
        See iAssets Notes in this document for more information on querying assets using this function
    Exercise: Inquire on Asset's transaction history -> <Responsibility>/Inquiry/Transaction History
        Enter a Transaction Reference OR an Asset Number to find the Asset's transactions
    Exercise: Inquire into an Asset's Financial Information -> <Responsibility>/Inquiry/Financial Information
        This provides Source Line, Book and Assignment information on an asset
        It includes book depreciation history
    The primary functions of the "Assets Workbench" are:
        general searches for existing assets
        adding new assets (quick additions and detailed additons),
        performing asset retirements,
        making transfers and adjustments
        inquiring into source (AP, Projects) lines and making source line changes
        Exercise: open the Assets Workbench Form -> <Assets Responsibility>/Assets/Assets Workbench
    All non "mass" asset activities are performed throught the Assets Workbench
    The Tax Workbench" form is used to assign Investment Tax Credits and do Reserve Adjustments
        Reserve Adjustments are manual changes in Depreciation Amounts on a Tax Book
        Exercise: Open the Tax Workbench -> <Assets Responsibility>/Tax/Tax Workbench

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Asset Attributes
    Asset Numbers can be entered manually or assigned automatically to identify an asset
        Leave this field blank for automatic assignment
        Automatic Asset Number assignment is part of System Controls in Fixed Assets
            Automatic Asset Numbering cannot be disabled - it is needed for the internal Asset ID field
            Exercise: View Asset Number autonumbering: <Reponsibility>/Setup/Asset System/System Controls
        Manual numbers must be unique and outside the reserved range of automatic numbers
        Access can be controlled to the Asset Number field to prevent manual entry
        Asset Number is used on many standard reports in Fixed Assets
    Descriptions can be LOV quick codes or manually entered text
    Tag Numbers are unique asset identifiers, attached to the asset for internal tracking purposes.
        Tags can be barcoded on the asset for inventory scanning
    Asset ID - an internal number not displayed on forms or reports
        Set equal to the Asset Number if automatic numbering is used
    Categories are used by Oracle to default depreciation rules
        These defaults are done in conjunction with book and date placed in service
        Exercise: Assign the Key Flexfield for Category -> <Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/System Controls
    Serial Numbers - are numbers assigned by the manufacturer
    Asset Key is an optional key flexfield for grouping assets
        Asset Key values operates independent of categories
        Exercise: Assign the Key Flexfield for Asset Key -> <Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/System Controls
        If not wanted or used, define as a single segment KFF without validation so a value is not required
    Asset type has three values:
        Capitalized
        CIP (Construction In Progress)
        Expensed - items that do not depreciate but are charged in a single period.
    Units - the count of an asset that comprised more than one identical asset
    Warranty number - the reference to a previously entered product warranty
    In Use - a reporting flag attribute
    In Physical Inventory - an exception reporting flag attribute

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Asset Additions (excluding Mass Additions):
    There are multiple methods to add assets:
        Detailed Additons - through the Assets Workbench (Additions button)
        Quick Additions - through the Assets Workbench (QuickAdditions button)
        Mass Additions using multiple options
            Import from Projects or Payables
            Upload from ADI - not recommended for large volumes of data
                ADI is spreadsheet based and helpful for editing and cleanup of data to reload
            Special Addition ADI (via PL/SQL)
            Custom posting to the Assets API table (FA_MASS_ADDITIONS)
    Manual Asset Addition Procedure
        Enter an asset through the Additions page
            Leave the Asset Number blank if you are using auto-numbering in System Controls
            Exercise: Check the auto numbering range -> <Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/System Controls
        Choose "Books" for the Asset from the Workbench
            Enter a book for the asset and tab through the header to default book values
                Assets should first be added to a Corporate Book before adding to a Tax Book
            The depreciation method will default from the Asset Category assigned to the asset
                Exercise: Set Depreciation Method on Asset Category
                    -> <Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/Asset Categories
        Choose "Assignment" to assign the asset a depreciation account, custodian and location
        Once the Assignment is complete, an Asset Number will be assigned
            This is if auto-numbering is on in System Controls Setup and a manual number was not entered
        The In Service Date must be in the current open period or a prior period in Assets
    Quick Additions Procedure
        Enter an asset through the Quick Addtions form
            Exercise: Open Quick Additions -> <Responsibility>/Assets Workbench/Quick Additions
        Rules for Quick Additions
            No Salvage Value
            Single Source Line (either AP or PA)
            Category Defaults are valid (i.e. existing combinations)
            There is no parent asset
            There is no lease or leasehold improvement

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Assets Integrator (WebADI)
    Additional References
        BEE Spreadsheet Interface: Spreadsheet Template Hangs at 'Processing: Create Document' (Doc ID 1459183.1)

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Mass Additions:
    Mass Additions creates assets in Fixed Assets from Accounts Payable and Project Accounting
    These assets are purchased assets or projects for constructed assets
        A mass addition can be an invoice charged to Asset Clearing or CIP Clearing
            An invoice charged to CIP clearing is added to a CIP asset which is recorded in Assets but not depreciated
                A CIP asset is depreciated once it is placed in Service
            An invoice charged to CIP Clearing and a Project/Task is transfered to CIP in Projects
                No mass addition is created
    It is also an API that can be used to import external data
        Mass Additions is useful for legacy system data conversion and for company acquisitions
        The interface process usesg the FA_MASS_ADDITIONS interface table
    The stages of processing mass additions includes:
        Create Mass Additions for Oracle Assets either in Oracle AP or Oracle PA
            creates mass addition lines for potential assets
            Mass Additions in Oracle Payables are invoice distribution lines that you transfer to Oracle
                Invoice lines distributed to Asset Accounting Flexfields are automatically marked for asset tracking.
            Oracle Projects only creates mass additions on invoice distributions marked for asset tracking.
        Review and modify these mass addition lines in the "Prepare Mass Additions" window
        Mass Additions via AP Clearing
            Get an asset clearing account from an asset category
                e.g. Asset Clearing Account for Materials and Equipment.Agitators category
                    110GB.201.10210.221099999.0000.000.00000.00000000.0000.0000
                Note - all asset categories can share the same asset clearing account in PRML
            Enter an invoice - enter a description for the distribution line - this will become the asset description
            Verify the 'Track as Asset' check box is enabled (show via folder fields)
            Submit 'Payables Transfer to General Ledger'
            Submit 'Mass Additions Create' in Payables to send mass addition lines to Assets
                Check the log file for records created - there is no output report
            In Assets, choose 'Prepare Mass Additions' to assign a category, depreciation account etc
                Change the queue to 'Post' from New
            In Assets, choose 'Post Mass Additions' to create the assets
        You must review and complete all of the required information about the asset
            Exercise: Review Mass Additions -> <Responsibility/Mass Additions/Prepare Mass Additions/New>
            The primary functions of the Mass Additions preparation process are to:
                find and review pending additions
                merge or split assets (where there are multiple assets of the same kind), and
                remove mass additions
            Queues are used to manage transactions in the "Prepare" stage of Mass Additions:
                New (entered into the Mass Additions table directly or by upload/PL/SQL)
                    This is the default queue assigned to additions entered manually through the forms
                On Hold and User Defined
                Split (already split)
                Merged (already merged)
                Cost Adjustment (already added to an existing asset)
                Post (ready to become an asset by importing through the interface)
                    This is the default queue from PA and AP if the data is valid and complete
                Posted (already an asset)
                Delete (marked for deletion and will not be sent into Fixed Assets)
            Entering assets in "Prepare Mass Addtions" requires knowledge of valid categories in the book
                Run the report "Asset Category Listing" for the required book to get this information
        Run the "Post Mass Additions" process and actually create assets from the mass addition lines
            You must have assets in the "POST" queue for a book or it will not show in the run parameters
            Oracle Assets does not automatically convert the mass additions to assets
            Then you post them them explicitly in Oracle Assets
            Exercise: Post Mass Additions -> <Responsibility>/Mass Additions/Post Mass Additions/Submit
                This submits the "Post Mass Additions" Request Set through the SRS window
        Periodically run the Mass Additions Delete process for unprocessed and unwanted interface transactions
            It is run from the main menu (Mass Additions -> Delete) and not from SRS
            The 'Mass Additions Delete' (FAMADEL) process purges transactions matching the following rules:
                SPLIT queue additions already posted
                POSTED queue additions
                DELETE queue additions
                    Lines in the DELETE queue are saved off to FA_DELETED_MASS_ADDITIONS for audit purposes since they were never capitalized
                    These lines can be removed by running the Purge Mass Additions
                    The Purge Mass Additions job is only accessible via the Fixed Assets Administrator seeded responsibility
            The 'Mass Additions Delete' process automatically starts the 'Mass Additions Delete Report' to list all deleted addition records
    There is a Mass Additions Workbench form to conduct tasks related to Mass Additions
        Exercise: Open Mass Additions Workbench -> <Responsibility/Mass Additions/Prepare Mass Additions/New>
    Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Accounts Payable Interfaced Additions:
        Oracle Payables sends invoices charged to an Asset Clearing Account to Assets
            This clearing account would replace the normal expense charge accounts used in AP
        These "Source Lines" are inserted into the Mass Additions table (FA_MASS_ADDITIONS)
    Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Project Accounting Interfaced Additions:
        See Metalink Note 103217.1 Interfacing from Oracle Projects to Oracle Assets Basics
            The final process in Oracle Projects is "PRC: Interface Assets" but several prep steps are needed
        Oracle Project Accounting tracks CIP assets - there is no need to interface them to Fixed Assets
        However Fixed Assets can track CIP for non-Oracle Project Accounting systems
            Optionally PA can be configured to feed CIP assets to Oracle Assets also
        Many fields in Mass Additions are defaulted from Oracle Projects:
            Asset Category (which determines default depreciation rule)
            Asset Cost
            DPIS (Date Placed in Service)
            Depreciation Expense Account
            Location
        Project CIP assets must meet several criteria to be picked up by Mass Addtions
            Date Placed In Service must fall in the current or prior asset period
            CIP costs in Projects must be interfaced to GL
            CIP costs for supplier invoices must be interfaced to AP
            CIP assets must be associated with an asset line

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Prorate Conventions
    Prorate Conventions determine the depreciation taken in the first and last year of an asset's live
        The basis of prorate convention is Date Placed in Service on the asset
        The Date Placed in Service is used with the Prorate Convention to determine the Prorate Date
        The Prorate Date is used to lookup the first Prorate Period on the Prorate Calendar for depreciation in the first or last year
    Setups include Prorate Calendar and Prorate Conventions (before assets are added)
        Prorate Calendar must be assiged to a book
            The Prorate Calendar determines the number of prorate periods in the fiscal year
            The Depreciation process uses the Prorate Calendar for asset depreciation in the first and final year
            The Prorate Calendar must be setup to include every day in each fiscal year
            Common Prorate Conventions are: Current Month, Following Month, Mid Month
                The mid-month convention takes half a month depreciation in the first month of the addition
        Depreciation Calendar must also be established for a book
            The Depreciation Calendar and 'Divide Depreciation' Flag on the book determine the depreciation in each period
            The Depreciation Calender period names must match the Set of Books period names to post journals
    Retiring assets before they are fully reserved also uses prorate conventions
    Navigations:
        Depreciation Calendar: Setup -> Assets System -> Calendars
        Prorate Calendar: Setup -> Assets System -> Calendars

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on the Month-End (Period-End) Close Processing
    Reference: What Is The Period Close Process For Oracle Assets In Release 12? [ID 557948.1]
        The close process for R12 does not require roll-back in order to make corrections
    http://it.toolbox.com/wiki/index.php/Period-End_Processing_in_Oracle_Assets_(Release_11i)
    Period Close in Fixed Assets (Detail)
        Complete All Transactions for the Period Being Closed
            Adjustments, Retirements
        Assign All Assets to Distribution Lines - make sure they are assigned a depreciation account
        Run Calculate Gains and Losses (Optional)
            You can run this process from Standard Request Submission or from the menu
        Run Depreciation
            Navigation: Depreciation -> Run Depreciation -> Uncheck 'Close Period'
            Note that you must subsequently roll back this depreciation run before doing a 'closing' run
                When you run the closing depreciation run it is final - the period cannot be reopened
            This process starts a request set comprising:
                Generate Accounts (parameter: book) - builds accounting combinations for all entries
                Calculate Gains and Losses (paramters: book, period) - resulting from retirements
                Depreciation Run (paramters: book, period) - calculates depreciation expense
                Journal Entry Reserve Ledger Report - runs either the Journal Entry Reserve Report or Tax Reserve Ledger Report
                    It depends on the book chosen as to which report is run (Journal or Tax)
                    This report shows the period, year to date and reserve depreciation (accumulated depreciation)
            View Requests -> Find -> and find the Depreciation Run Request Set
                Review the Depreciation Reserve Report and confirm the calculations
        Submit Depreciation Journal Entries (normally you do this on the 'closing' run although you can do it on any run)
            Navigation: Journal Entries -> Standard
                Enter the book to create journal entries - this starts the 'Create Journal Entries' job
                Enter the period to create the journal entries
            View the unposted asset journals in the USD Book
               Source will be 'Assets'
               Categories will be 'Addition', 'Adjustment', 'Depreciation', 'Retirement' and 'Transfer'
               Don't post these journals - leave them unposted
        Rollback the Depreciation
            You rollback in the reverse order of creating depreciation
                First rollback the journals created in GL
                    Navigation: Journal Entries -> Rollback Journal Entries
                    This deletes the unposted batches in the General Ledger and unwinds the accounting entries in Fixed Assets
                Second rollback the depreciation calculated in Fixed Assets
                    Navigation: Depreication -> Rollback Depreciation
                    This reverses the period depreciation and unwinds the change to depreciation reserve in Fixed Assets
        Rollback Depreciation and/or Rollback Journal Entries (Optional)
        Create Deferred Depreciation Journal Entries (Optional)
        Depreciation Projections(Optional)
        Review and Post Journal Entries
        Reconcile Oracle Assets to Oracle General Ledger Using Reports
            Reconcile the Cost Accounts on General Ledger
                Run the Asset Summary Report - compare balances to GL for opening and closing cost account totals
                Run the Asset Additions Report
                Run the Asset Retirements Report
                Run the Asset Adjustments Report and Compare.
        Run Responsibility Reports (Optional)
        Archive and Purge Transactions (Optional)
    Issues with Fixed Assets at Coryton (Detail)
        Special Year End Procedures including Roll Forward
        The Oracle User Guides need to be added to the class material and distributed
        There is confusion about the business areas deployed in Discoverer - they appear to overlap and some don't work as expected
            This may be unfamiliarity with the business areas - detailed documentation is needed and the old business areas need to be deleted
        How do you rollback if the journal is posted - workaround

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Accounting and Journal Entries
    Tips
        You can run 'Create Journal Entries' any number of times in a period but only after you run depreciation
            Runing 'Create Joural Entries' without first running Depreciation will throw an error
        You can roll back journal entries if they are not posted - from the same menu root where you submit 'Create Journal Entries'
        Once final depreciation is run, you can only 'Create Journal Entries one more time
    Journal entries are created for: additions, depreciation, adjustments, transfers, gain/loss and retirements
        Journal entries are created within a single GL Set of Books
        Each asset book is associated with a single GL Set of Books
        Journals can post to any company within the GL Set of Books, based on accounting rules
    The GL Period must be open to post depreciation
    Period Names in Fixed Assets must match Period Names in the GL
        Exercise: View Periods -> <Assets Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/Calendars (query all, page down)
    Journals are created and sent to GL using the "Create Journal Entries" process in Concurrent Manager
        Navigation -> can be via SRS or via the menu 'Journal Entries -> Standard'
        Parameters include a single book and period
        Only books that can create journals are selectable
        Important - You must run Depreciation first or this job will error out
    Fixed Assets versions 11.5.10 and above create journal entries in the GL_INTERFACE table
        They must be reviewed and imported as unposted journals within GL
        Fixed Assets versions prior to 11.5.10 do not insert records into GL_INTERFACE which is unlike all other subledgers
            They create journals directly in the General Ledger when 'Create Journal Entries' is run
    Depreciation Journals can be rolled back if they are not posted in the GL or if the posted journals are reversed
        Use "Rollback Journal Entries" concurrent process and enter the book and period
        Navigation can be via SRS or via the menu 'Journal Entries -> Rollback Journal Entries'
        The Fixed Assets period cannot be closed or Rollback will not be allowed
    Journal sources and categories are taken from Assets setups
        Defaults are defined at the Book level on the Book Controls Form
            Click the Journal Categories tab to see the Source/Category defaults
    Account Generator creates account values in Fixed Assets based on setups
        Account Generator Rules are implemented through Workflow and Assigned to the Account Key Flexfield
            Navigation: FA Setup (or any setup) > Financial > Flexfields > Key > Accounts > (Choose Accounting KFF) > Search on 'FA Account Generator' item type
            The Account Generator for item type 'FA Account Generator' can be copied, customized and assigned
            Additional References
                http://docs.oracle.com/cd/A60725_05/html/comnls/us/fa/fafb01.htm -- Decide how to use Account Generator
        Account Generator Rules for deriving depreciation expenses are:
            Use the assignment distribution account for depreciation
        Account Generator Rules for deriving other journals are:
            Use the Company from the assignment
                Specifically, the company segment on the account assignment for the asset
            Derive the Account from the Book or Category
            Derive all other segments fromt the Book default accounts
         The 
    Book Level Accounts include:
        Cost of Removal (Clearing, Gain, Loss)
        Deferred Depreciation (Expense and Reserve)
        Depreciation Adjustment
        Intercompany AP and AR
        NBV Retired (Gain and Loss)
        Proceeds of Sales (Clearing, Gain, Loss)
        Revaluation Reserve Retired (Gain, Loss)
    Category Level Accounts include:
        Asset Clearing and Cost
        Bonus Depreciation Expense, Reserve
        CIP Clearing and Cost
        Depreciation Reserve
        Revaluation Amortization, Reserve
    Account Generator Exceptions include:
        Asset Clearing or CIP Clearing (feed from Projects)
        Reclassification - uses expense account of the new category
    Reports for Fixed Assets Journals include:
        Journals Report (for unposted journals)
        Drill-Down Report in Assets - shows all journal lines for each journal posted to GL
            Separate journals are created for each category: reclass, transfer, adjustment, depreciation
        Account Drill-Down Report
        Reserve Summary and Detail Reports
        Asset Additions Report
        Cost Adjustments Report
        Asset Retirements Report
        Asset Reclassification Reconciliation Report
        Asset Transfer Reconciliation Report

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Depreciation Methods
    Depreciation Methods include:
        150DB - 1.5 Times Declining Balance with Straight Line Switch
        200DB - Double Declining Balance with Straight Line Switch
        ACRS - Accelerated Cost Recovery System
        ACRS Personal
        MACRS 30B HY - Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System
        MACRS HY
        MACRS HQ
        MACRS STL HY
        MACRS STL MM
        Several hundred seeded methods
    For table based depreciation calculations individual percentages can be entered by period
    DB Depreciation calcuates double the equivalent straight line depreciation each year
        For successive years, it repeats the calculation using current asset value (not initial value)
        Once the depreciation drops below the equivalent straight line amount, it is switched to straight line
    ACRS replaced Straight Line depreciation in the US in 1981
        It established asset lives based on Property Classes
            These are known as the General Depreciation System (GDS) Classes
        It assumes a salvage value of zero
        It is table based and similar in results to Double Declining calculation methods
    MACRS is a modification to ACRS that adds more Property Classes and introduces a mid-year convention
        MACRS is also table based and Property Class based
    Depreciation Methods are defined on the Depreciation Methods form
        Exercise: View Depreciation Methods -> <Assets Responsibility>/Setup/Depreciation/Methods
    Methods can be one of several types: table based, formula based, calculated, fixed or flat

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Depreciation Processing:
    Depreciation is run by book for a single period and provides the option of closing the period
    The depreciation process includes several steps (within a single book)
        Run "trial" depreciation and review results including error logs
            Exercise: Run Depreciation -> <Responsibility>/Depreciation/Run Depreciation
                Do not check "Close Period" because you may need to rollback
            Trial depreciation is the normal depreciation process w/out selecting the "Close Period" option
            Trial depreciation can be run any number of times before period close
            Rerunning depreciation is accomplished by rolling back the prior depreciation run and rerunning
            Four processes are run when depreciation is calculated:
                Generate Accounts
                Calculate Gains and Losses
                Calculate Depreciation
                Generate Reserve Ledger Report (or Tax Reserve Ledger Report for tax books)
        Once trial depreciation is rolled back, asset transactions can be performed and depreciation rerun
        Rollback if needed and make corrections before rerunning on a trial basis
            Exercise: Rollback Depreciation -> <Responsibility>/Deprecation/Rollback Depreciation
            It can only be done for the most recent period if the period has not been closed
        Run final depreciation by checking "Close Period" to close the period during the run
            This also opens the next period
    The Depreciation Flag on individual assets can be unchecked to suspend depreciation calculation
        If set to "No" then changed to "Yes" depreciation will be caught up
        If set to "Yes" then changed to "No" depreciation will be caught up in the final period of life
        Suspending depreciation does not change the life of the asset
    Depreciation Override is a new feature introduced in 11i
        It allows user defined depreciation amounts to override calculations on specific assets
        It is enabled through a profile option (FA: Enable Depreciation Override)
        Values for Book, Asset and Period are entered in a table
        The Depreciation process uses these amounts and ignores the calculation steps
        Exercise: Choose assets to override depreciation -> <Responsibility>/Depreciation/Override
            Query a range of assets and enter overriding depreciation values
        Key reports for the Depreciation Process include:
            Assets not assigned to book or cost center
            Expensed Property Report (expensed assets)
            Fully Reserved Asset Listing
            Non Depreciating Property Report
            Depreciation Projection Report
    Asset elements affecting Depreciation include:
        Date Placed in Service
        Prorate Convention
        Prorate Date and Period
        Life
        Depreciation Method
        Depreciation Calendar, Divide Depreciation flag, and Depreciate When Placed in Service flag
        Number of Active Assignments
        Cost and Salvage Value
    Depreciation Methods include:
        Life: Straight Line or Table based
            Double Declining Balance doubles the straight line depreciation and subtracts it
                The remaining asset value is recomputed for the next period calculation and the calc repeated
        Flat Rate (Diminishing value)
        Calculated based on a formula
    Depreciation Projections estimate depreciation for multiple books and periods
        Includes: All existing assets and current period adds, reclasses and transfers
        Excludes: Retroactive transfers and adds, fully reserved and retired assets
        The Projection includes two processes - one to populate table data and a second to run the report
        Exercise: Run the depreciation projection -> <Responsbility>/Depreciation/Projection
    What-If Analsis calculates depreciation on changed assumptions such as financial values, methods or lives
        You can also enter Hypothetical Assets and run what-if scenarios
        Exercise: Run What-If analysis -> <Responsibility>/Depreciation/What-If

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Changes and Mass Changes
    Changes to asset key book-level attributes can be made on single assets or groups of assets (mass changes)
    Changes are book specific and do not cross books or apply globally to assets
    Attributes that can be changed include:
        Prorate Convention
        Depreciation Method
        Life Years and Months
        Bonus Rule
        Group Depreciation
        Group Asset
    Mass changes are done through the menu using Navigation: Mass Transactions -> Changes
    Individual changes are done throgh the Book option of the Asset workbench
    Mass Changes allow updates to a key attributes range of assets based on selection criteria
         Enter the Depreciation Method to enable the 'Life Years' field
             Life Years are limited to specific valid values based on Depreciation Methods
    You can change the Depreciation Life of an Asset
        Change the life of the asset within the book
        You must check 'Amortize Adjustment' to depreciation the remaining value over the remaining life of the asset
        Then rerun depreciation to see the result
            See metalink note ID 233909.1

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Reclassifications:
    Asset reclassification involves changing the asset category assigned to an asset
        You cannot reclassify an asset in a prior period
        Asset cost and accumulated depreciation accounts are tied to category
        Reclassification changes these accounts and moves the balance sheet amounts to new accounts
            It does not change the depreciation method, life or prorate rule
        Journal entries are created to move the cost and accumulated depreciation values
    Reclassification can be done by changing the category on a single asset via the workbench
        Simply change the category on an existing asset to effect the reclassification
        You must choose a new category that is valid for the current book (or an error will prompt)
    When reclassed, the Asset Cost and Accumulated Depreciaton account balances are shifted to the new category account values
        These are the balance sheet accounts and don't affect the income statement account
        Income statement depreciation (current) is based on the assignment value, not the category
        To shift these amounts, you should make a backdated change in the current fiscal year to the asset assignment
           i.e. do an asset tranfer
    Mass Reclassification is also supported
        This is new functionality in Oracle 11i and provides a range of criteria for selecting assets
        Exercise: Select assets to mass reclassify -> <Responsibility>/Mass Transactions/Reclassifications
            Run the reclassification in Preview Mode after entering the new category (and other options)
            Run the Mass Reclassification Preview Report to view the results of the preview
                Use the Mass Transaction Number from the Preview as a reporting parameter
    Reports used in reclassification include:
        Assets by Category
        Asset Reclassification Report
        Asset Reclassification Reconciliation Report
        Asset Category Listing

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Asset Transfers and Mass Transfers:
    Transfers change one of the components of an asset assignment:
        Depreciation charge account - impacts the GL
        Location - the physical location for the asset
        Person - the custodian assigned to the asset
    Transfers can be backdated to prior periods within the current financial year
        This can be done on single transfers or mass transfers
    They cannot be done if depreciation is fully taken
    Assets are transfered individually on the Asset Assignment form through the Assets Workbench
        Enter a "-1" in the "Unit Change" column and create a new line with a "1" with the changed assignment
        Exercise: Transfer an asset -> <Responsibility>/Assets Workbench (lookup asset)/Assignments/
        After making a single transfer you can re-query the assignment to see the new values
    Mass Transfers allow multiple assets to be transfered in a single process
        Navigation: Mass Transaction -> Transfers
        A preview is supported to view the expected results prior to making the transfer
        Exercise: Mass transfer assets -> <Responsibility>/Mass Transactions/Transfers/
        Transfers allow to/from values for location, person and charge account
        To run the final transfer process, use the same form and enter the Mass Transaction Number

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Source Line Tranfers
    Amortization Rules
        Source line transfers between assets with the transfer amortized apply to the from and to asset
            The amortization date also applies to the from and to asset

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Asset Unit Adjustments:
    You can change the number of units of an asset in the main asset form (from the Workbench)
    The Assignment Form will open and show "Units to Assign"
    Enter the Units to Assign in the "Unit Change" column and save
    Exercise: Adjust the Units on an Asset -> <Responsibility>/Assets/Asset Workbench(inquire on asset)/
        Change units and enter the incrementally added units in the Assignments  form in "Unit Change"
    Changing the units may violate tag number assignments on assets since they should be unique

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Financial Adjustments and Mass Adjustments:
    Financial Adjustments are changes to the monetary values and associated methods for an asset
    They are performed by querying the asset and then the appropriate book for the asset
        Exercise: Adjust asset financial amounts -> <Responsibility>/Assets/Asset Workbench (query asset)/
            Books (enter valid book and tab to body of form)/view and change financial amounts
    Adjustments can include to:
        Cost
        Salvage
        Life
        Method
        Prorate Convention
    The decision must be made to expense or amortize the change in depreciation caused by the adjustment
        Check the "Amortize Adjustment" box to amortize the difference over the asset's remaining life
        Amortization must be allowable for the book
        All future financial adjustments to the asset must be amortized
    Adjustments can be made to fully retired assets
    No journal entry for the adjustment is made if the change is made to a current period addition
    Mass Changes are also supported through the Mass Changes form
        Exercise: Perform a mass financial adjustment -> <Responsibility>/Mass Transactions/Changes
        Set rules for assets to choose (within a book) and financial changes to make
        Note the option to amortize the adjustments is also provided on this form

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Asset Physical Inventory:
    Physical inventory allows for comparison of assets on the books and assets physically counted
    Key data elements for a physical inventory are:
        The asset identifier: Asset, Tag or Serial Number
        The asset assignment: Count and location
    Physicals can be entered into Assets several ways: ADI, Manual or through an Open Interface
    Once entered, a physical inventory comparison program can be run
    After running the comparison, assets may need assignment changes or retirement
    After all assignment changes are made, the Missing Assets Report is run to determine remaining retirements
        Exercise: query a physical inventory -> <Responsibility>/Physical Inventory/Enter/
            Enter a title for the physical inventory and save before proceeding
        Exercise: compare physical to book -> <Responsibility>/Physical Inventory/Comparison/View

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Impairments and Unplanned Depreciation
    Oracle Fixed Assets has specific functionality for impairments
    You can use unplanned depreciation to simulate an impairment
    Enter unplanned depreciation from the Assets Workbench for a specific book (Unplanned Depreciation Button)
        Create a new Type if needed via Quick Codes (Setup -> Assets System -> Quickcodes)
        Negative amounts are allowed (upward unplanned depreciation)
        Unplanned Depreciation appears as an Adjustment amount and can be viewed in Financial Amounts and Depreciation History
            Exception - unplanned depreciation in the period the asset is added is not tracked as an adjustment
                It is reflecte in Net Book Value and Accumulated Depreciation
        Once entered you can view the results immediately in Financial Amounts - the depreciation is applied immediatelywhen it is saved
    Restrictions on Unplanned Depreciation
        It cannot be split into separate depreciation accounts - enter separate amounts for this
        Unplanned depreciation is not allowed for assets using table-based methods
        Unplanned depreciation cannot be entered for an asset depreciating on Units of Production in the period the asset is added
            It must have historical reserves
        You cannot make expensed adjustments on assets where you have amortized previous unplanned depreciation

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Asset Retirements and Mass Retirements:
    General Rules for retirements include:
        You can undo a retirement transaction if you have not run gain/loss calculation
            A new retirement has a status of Pending which changes to Processed after Gain/Loss or Depreciation is run
            Once the gain/loss is run you must reinstate
            The Undo/Reinstate button on the retirement form is set based on this status of the retirement
                Reinstating a retirement before gain/loss/depreciation simply deletes the retirement transaction
                Reinstating a retirement after gain/loss/depreciation changes the status to reinstated
                    You must run gain/loss/depreciation on 'reinstated' status asset to recalculate financial amounts
        You can do mass retirments or single retirements
        You can retire a number of asset units or an asset cost
            Cost retirments are taken of each asset ratably and do not change the number of units
            The ratable cost is spread across all unit/assignment/distribution lines
    Retirements can be full or partial for individual assets
        Partial retirements are based on portion of cost or number of units
        Exercise: enter a retirement -> <Responsibility>/Assets Workbench (query asset)/Retirements (button)/
            and enter retirment details (current additions must be deleted and not retired)
        The cost of removal or any disposal proceeds can be entered in the retirement record
        Retirement types are optional and have no financial impact (e.g. sale, casualty, theft)
    Mass retirements are supported and require criteria to choose the assets to retire
        Exercise: Enter mass retirements -> <Responsibility>/Mass Transactions/Retirements/
            Create and Reinstate
        Preview mode is supported and the resulting transaction number used to subsequently execute
        Pending retirements are created and posted after running Gain/Loss processing
    Retirement transactions can be imported through an API interface
        Exercise: View imported retirements -> <Responsibility>/Mass Transactions/Retirements/Prepare
            and query on the book with the imported retirements
            The Queue must be "Post" in order for the retirements to be picked up
    Retired assets may be reinstated if they were retired in the current year
        Partial retirements can only be reinstated if no following transactions have occured
    Retirements can be backdated to prior periods in the same financial year
        If retirements are performed in a prior period, depreciation expense is backed out
    Retirements can be mass-copied to Tax Books (optional)
    Current period asset additions must be deleted and cannot be retired
    If untaken depreciaton exists, retirements create accounting entries
        Avoid this by making a cost adjustment to zero in a prior period before retiring

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Key Flexfields:
    Fixed Assets has three Key Flexfields
        Category Flexfield - depreciation rules are defaulted from category values
        Location Flexfield - specific to Fixed Assets and not part of HR Locatins
        Asset Key Flexfield - an additional grouping and reporting code that is optional
    Exercise: Assign the Asset Key Flexfield Structures -> <Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/System Controls
    Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Flexfields:
        Look up flexfields under the "Assets" application name (not "Fixed Assets")
        "Asset Key Flexfield" - a grouping key flexfield for asset classification (optional and unrelated to categories)
        "Category Flexfield" - a grouping key flexfield that defaults the depreciation method on assets
        "Location Flexfield" - a descriptive flexfield that is specific to assets (not related to HR Locations)

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Exercises:
    Exercise: Setup Fixed Asset Books -> Setup/Asset System/Book Controls
    Exercise: Add a CIP or Capital Asset -> Assets/Asset Workbench and choose 'New', then enter asset details.
        Set Asset Type to CIP if needed.
            Note: Add costs to a new asset through 'source lines' in the workbench
    Exercise: Capitalize a CIP Asset -> Assets/Capitalize CIP Assets,
        and choose the assets to capitalize and enter the 'Date Placed in Service'
    Exercise: Prepare Mass Additions -> Mass Additions/Prepare Mass Additions and find Mass Addition invoices.
        Dependencies: Create invoices for fixed asset purchases in AP,
            charge to asset clearing account and run 'Mass Additions Create' in AP.
            Note: Combine invoices lines into single assets,
                and change invoice queue to post to stage for next step - post mass additions
    Exercise: Post Mass Additions -> Mass Additions/Post Mass Additions, to run a concurrent process
    Exercise: Cleanup Posted Mass Additions -> Mass Additions/Delete,
        to remove them from the 'posted', 'delete' or 'cost adjustment' queues
    Exercise: Calculate Gains and Losses -> Depreciation/Calculate Gains and Losses,
    Exercise: Transaction History -> Inquiry/Transaction History,
        to view all transactions for an asset or group of assets.
        Note: Either Reference Number or Asset Number Range are required in the find form, but not both
    Exercise: Mass Transfer Assets - Mass Transactions/Transfers to change expense account for depr,
        location or employee assignment.
        Caution: Changing the depreciation account does not change the asset contra account.
    Exercise: Mass Change Assets -> Mass Transactions/Changes to change an asset prorate convention,
        depreciation method, life, or bonus rule
    Exercise: Mass Revalue Assets -> Mass Transactions/Revaluations
    Exercise: Mass Reclassify Assets -> Mass Transactions/Reclassify and specify assets to reclassify,
        then new asset category
    Exercise: Rollback Depreciation -> Depreciation/Rollback Depreciation and choose the book to depreciate.
    Exercise: Copy Book to Tax Book (Initial) -> Tax/Initial Mass Copy kicks off concurrent job 'Initial Mass Copy'.
        Dependencies: Check Copy Additions, Copy Retirements, Copy Adjustments and Salvage Value in Book Controls
    Exercise: Copy Book to Tax Book (Periodic) -> Tax/Periodic Mass Copy kicks off concurrent job 'Periodic Mass Copy'.
        Dependency -> Run 'Initial Mass Copy' first but only once
    Exercise: Retire an Asset -> Assets/Asset Workbench/Retirements,
    Exercise: Mass Retire Assets -> Mass Transactions/Retirements/Create and Reinstate,
        and specify retirement details, and choose assets to retire

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Report Exchange Designer (RXi)

        Exercise: Show the RXi form -> <Report eXchange Designer>/Setup RXi

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Key Tables:
    FA_ADDITIONS - holds all assets and their descriptions
    FA_ADJUSTMENTS - carries the subledger journal reference information for all financial asset transactions
    FA_MASS_ADDITIONS - holds all interfaced asset additions from AP, PA or ADI
    FA_BOOK_TYPES - holds the actual books (names as 'book types' with PK = BOOK_TYPE_CODE)
    FA_BOOKS - holds the actual asset item values (ASSET_ID identifies asset, and FK = BOOK_TYPE_CODE identifies books)
        Also holds transaction detail lines referenced by FA_TRANSACTION_HEADERS
        Foreign Key to FA_BOOK_CONTROLS for book definitions
    FA_BOOK_CONTROLS - holds 'books' definitions
    FA_CATEGORIES_B - holds category flexfield segment values
    FA_DEPRN_SUMMARY
    FA_DEPRN_DETAIL
    FA_JOURNAL_ENTRIES contains information about your posted batches to General Ledger.
        Oracle Assets uses this table to determine the names of the batches that were posted to General Ledger and the periods the batches were posted
    FA_TRANSACTION_HEADERS - carries a short header record for every asset transaction - addition or change to an asset
    FA_MASS_ADDITIONS - import table for mass additions

        Using Organization Security, you can attach an Asset Book to an Asset Organization for tighter control

Fixed Assets (FA Schema) Notes on Setup Steps:
    Additional Referneces
        See Metalink Note 116607.1 Financials 11i Assets Setup (for CRL Assets depreciated in groups)
    Important setups include:
        GL Set of Books
            Exercise: Assign Set of Books to Asset Book ->
                <Assets Responsibility>/Setup/Assets System/Book Controls
        Asset Key Flexfield - including structure and values (used for reporting, optional)
        Asset Category Flexfield - including structure and values
            Once established, each Asset Category must be assigned a collection of default values
            Categories should be defined based on depreciation rules (prorate convention, depreciation method, life)
        Location Flexfield including structure and values - aliases are optional
            Each of these three setups are attached to Fixed Assets in the System Controls Form
            Exercise: Attach Key Flexfields to System Controls ->
            <Assets Responsibility/Setup/Assets System/
                System Controls
        System Controls includes:
            Key Flexfield associations, oldest DPIS date and asset auto-numbering range
        Fiscal Years - define collections of years and ending dates
            The standard years are calendar years ending in December each year
                Exercise: View Fiscal Years ->
                    <Assets Responsibility>/Setup/Assets System/Fiscal Years
            The fiscal years should at least go back to the oldest DPIS defined in System Controls
        Calendars - define periods within a year based on accounting conventions
            See Metalink Note 139937.1 Calendar Usage and Setup
            Each book requires a Depreciation Calendar and a Prorate Calendar
                The Depreciation Calendar defines the number of accounting periods in the fiscal year
                The Prorate Calendar defines the number of prorate periods in the fiscal year
                The same calendar can be used for Depreciation and Proration in multiple books
                Exercise: View Calendar -> <Assets Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/Calendars
        Prorate and Retirement Conventions
            Exercise: View Prorate Conventions ->
                <Assets Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/Prorate Conventions
        Asset Category Defaults
            Exercise: Assign Asset Category Defaults ->
                <Assets Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/Asset Categories
        Book Controls
            Exercise: Assign Book Controls ->
                <Assets Responsibility>/Setup/Asset System/Book Controls
    Several Setups are Required but Defaulted
        Account Generator Workflow
        JE Sources and Categories
        Quickcodes are extendable lists of values for fields that appear throught Fixed Assets
            Quickcodes can be ignored in some cases - users can type in values on the fly
            An example is Asset Description where a user can look up a predefined value or create one
            Exercise: View Quickcodes -> <Assets Responsibility>/Setup/Assets System/Quickcodes
            Quickcodes can be modified in some cases and extended in others
                Some Quickcodes can be modified by changing the description but not the code values
                Some Quickcodes can be completely user defined and extensible
                Some Quickcodes cannot be modified and cannot be supplemented
                Some Quickcodes come with seeded values which can be deleted or over-written
                You cannot create new sets of Quickcodes - they are system controlled and defined
            Quickcodes sets include:
                Asset Descriptions - can be extended, modified and created on the fly
                Journal Entries - only the descriptions can be changed
                Lease Periods - are user defined
                Property Type - can be extended, modified and created on the fly
                Queue Names - Values DELETE, ON HOLD and POST cannot be changed
                RX Parameters - Report Exchange (RXi) parameters can be extended and modified
                Retirement - are user defined (examples are SALE, CASUALTY)
                Secured Program - are pre-seeded and can be extended
                Source Line Type - are user defined and pre-seeded (MATERIAL, NON-MATERIAL)
                Subcategory - asset subcategories are user defined and not pre-seeded
                Unplanned Depreciation Type - used to describe different types of unplanned depreciation
        Depreciation Methods - straight line and some seeded types are pre-established
        Profile Options
    Optional Setups include:
        Units of Measure (for Units of Production depreciation methods)
        Employees (for asset assignments - done through HR forms)
        Descriptive Flexfields
        Asset Number Mechanism
        Suppliers (through AP and PO)
        Locations
        Asset Key Combinations
        Security by Book
        Depreciation Ceilings
        Price Indexes - typically not used in the US or Canada
        Distribution Sets - to assign assets across multiple accounts
        Investment Tax Credits (ITC's)
        Leases
        Warranties
        Insurance

Flexfield and Value Set (FND Schema) Tips and Tricks:
    To find flexfields use the Oracle Applications as a search criteria
    Assign all "required" segment qualifiers to KFF segments or compiliation will fail
