Flexfield and Value Set (FND Schema) Notes on Terminology:
    Value Set - container for segment values
    Structure - a specific configuration of segments in a Flexfield
    Qualifier - a special meaning assigned to a KFF segment (some are required)

Flexfields and Value Sets (FND Schema) Notes on Responsibilities:
    System Administration
    System Administrator
        Use System Administrator to create and maintain flexfields

Flexfield and Value Set (FND Schema) Best Practices:
    Add extra characters or length to short segments in flexfields to allow for future growth
    Define value sets as queries on other tables where appropriate to reduce maintenance
        This will eliminate manual maintenance of independent and dependent value set values
    Plan flexfields carefully in advance - they cannot be easily changed once defined and used
    Limit KFF segment lengths to avoid exceeding reporting column widths

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on General Features:
    There is a Descriptive Flexfield Register form (Form FNDFFIDF) which allows lookup by table name
        Navigation: Inventory > Setup > Descriptive Flexfield Register
        Navigation: Application Developer
    The term Flexfield is derived from "Flexible Fields"
    Flexfields provide user-defined fields in Oracle applications
    There are two kinds of Flexfields:
        Key Flexfields (KFF's) which are record key fields comprising multi-segments parts
        Descriptive Flexfields (DFF's) which are multi-field user-defined data attributes
        When opened in a form, the key or descriptive flexfields display in a separate window
            This window has their individual named segments as separate fields
            Each field displays a user-defined prompt and value
        Both Key and Descriptive Flexfields allow user defined rules for valid values (domains)
        Examples of Key Flexfields are:
            GL Account Code Combinations
            Asset Categories, Asset Keys, Asset Locations
            Inventory Item Numbers
            Sales Territories
            Sales Taxes
            HR Jobs and Postions
        The seeded Key FlexFields are
            Accounting Flexfield GL GL_CODE_COMBINATIONS CHART_OF_ACCOUNTS_ID
            Assets KFF FA FA_ASSET_KEYWORDS
            Category Flexfield FA FA_CATEGORIES_B
            Location Flexfield FA FA_LOCATIONS
            Sales Tax Location Flexfield AR AR_LOCATION_COMBINATIONS LOCATION_STRUCTURE_ID
            Territory Flexfield AR RA_TERRITORIES
            Item Catalogs INV MTL_ITEM_CATALOG_GROUPS
            Item Categories INV MTL_CATEGORIES_B  STRUCTURE_ID
            Stock Locators INV MTL_ITEM_LOCATIONS ORGANIZATION_ID
            System Items INV MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS_B  ORGANIZATION_ID
        Details of all seeded KFF's for all applications are in the Flexfields User Guide
    A flexfield structure is a specific configuration of segments.
        Both key and descriptive flexfields support more than one structure.
            In Inventory the system item key flexfield has only one structure.
            In the General Ledger the account code key flexfield has multiple structures
        The "Structure Column" field on the Flexfield Registration form sets this value
            For DFF's it is normally the ATTRIBUTE_CATEGORY field (i.e. the context)
                The value of the ATTRIBUTE_CATEGORY is set on the "Flexfield Segments" form
                It must point to another column on the same table where the DFF ATTRIBUTES exist
            For KFF's it is the field the application uses to switch structures
                e.g. For the account code KFF, it is the "Chart of Accounts" field
                    This Chart of Accounts is actually the KFF assigned in the Set of Books Defn.
            So for DFF's the structure used is determined by another column on the same table
                For KFF's it is driven by a setup in the application that may be on another table

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Descriptive Flexfields:
    Descriptive flexfields are found on Oracle Forms within [ ] brackets
        If they have values, you can partially see them inside the [ ] brackets
        They are implemented on database tables in ATTRIBUTE'1-15' fields
    DFF's also have Global Attributes stored in GLOBAL_ATTRIBUTE'1-15'
        Global Attributes don't change based on context values (i.e. ATTRIBUTE_CATEGORY)
        They are displayed alongside any context-sensitive flexfield segments on forms
    Descriptive flexfields are text flexfields that carry additional descriptive information
        They are used where no field is specifically available for it
    Descriptive flexfields are optional space for user-defined information
    There are thousands of pre-registered DFF's in the Oracle Applications
        Key Flexfields support dynamic insertion of new values in some cases but not all
            Dynamic insertion allows new combinations to be added on the fly
            Dynamic insertion adds values to a flexfield structure as transactions are created
                They do not have to be added through definition or setup forms
            Dynamic insertion must satisfy combination rules (cross validation rules)
                This is controlled in a checkbox in the flexfield structure definition form
    Descriptive Flexfields are intended for extra information to be stored
        Descriptive flexfields are implemented as ATTRIBUTE1..ATTRIBUTE15 on a table that supports them
            e.g. PO Headers supports descriptive flexfield values that allow user-defined fields on PO's
    DFF's can have contexts defined - each context changes the DFF segment definition and valid values
        So the structure and values in the DFF will be different depending on the context value
        Contexts are predefined or can include $PROFILES$.ORG_ID for operating unit organization
            You can also include the following
                $PROFILES$.MFG_ORGANIZATION_ID
                $PROFILES$.login_ID
                $PROFILES$.USER_ID
                $PROFILES$.USER_NAME
                $PROFILES$.CONCURRENT_REQUEST_ID
                $PROFILES$.GL_SET_OF_BKS_ID
                $PROFILES$.SO_ORGANIZATION_ID
                $PROFILES$.APPL_SHORT_NAME
                $PROFILES$.RESP_NAME
                $PROFILES$.RESP_ID
            These are the equivalent of embedding fnd_profile.value(.....) in a query
        If no context is predefined any environment variable will always work
    DFF Contexts can be assigned validation value sets but these value sets must observe restrictions in order to be selectable
        Reference
            https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18727_01/doc.121/e12892/T354897T361276.htm
        Format Type must be Character (Char)
        Numbers Only must not be checked (alphabetic characters are allowed)
        Uppercase Only must not be checked (mixed case is allowed)
        Right-justify and Zero-fill Numbers must not be checked
        If the validation type is Independent: the value set maximum size must be less than or equal to 30
    Default values can be assigned to Descriptive Flexfield segments
        Flexfield defaults can be defined as values or as SQL select statements
        SQL statements are similar to the select statement that might be used to define the corresponding value set
        Descriptive flexfields appear on forms as 'beer mugs' i.e. brackets '[ ]'
            They can be viewed and edited by clicking on them, or
            Choose Edit to display (Ctrl-E) the contents of the DFF
        Descriptive flexfield values are concatenated when displayed in the beer mug field
        Descriptive flexfields can be controlled and changed based on context
            They are only relevent or possible for certain types of records or value of other fields
    Each segment of a key flexfield and attribute of a descriptive flexfield are named
        They can have valid values as well as description fields for those values
        A single complete valid set of values for each segment in a flexfield is a 'combination'
    Exercise: Inquire on existing descriptive flexfields -> SA/Application/Descriptive/Segments
        and choose View/Find from the menu to list all applications and flexfield values
    Key Tables
        References
            http://www.appsbi.com/about/key-erp-tables
        FND_DESCRIPTIVE_FLEXS
        FND_DESCR_FLEX_COLUMN_USAGES
        DESCRIPTIVE_FLEX_CONTEXT_CODE
        FND_COMPILED_DESCRIPTIVE_FLEXS

Flexfields and Value Sets (FND Schema) Notes on Concurrent Program Parameters
    The report parameters form used to enter report parameters is a descriptive flexfield form
        Report parameters are descriptive flexfield segments
        Segments are defined via Concurrent Program Definition and not via the Descriptive Flexfield Segments Window
        Valuess entered in concurrent requests are stored in the DFF segment of the FND_CONCURRENT_REQUESTS table
    $PROFILES$ or SQL Queries using FND_PROFILE.VALUE(Parameter) in SQL statements can be used in parameters
        Use ':$PROFILES$.ORG_ID' to reference the ORG_ID in SQL in table-validated value sets (the bind variable colon prefix is required)
        An example is $PROFILES$.ORG_ID (or FND_PROFILE.VALUE('ORG_ID') in SQL
            The full list of possible values for this environment variable are
                $PROFILES$.MFG_ORGANIZATION_ID
                $PROFILES$.login_ID
                $PROFILES$.USER_ID
                $PROFILES$.USER_NAME
                $PROFILES$.CONCURRENT_REQUEST_ID
                $PROFILES$.GL_SET_OF_BKS_ID
                $PROFILES$.SO_ORGANIZATION_ID
                $PROFILES$.APPL_SHORT_NAME
                $PROFILES$.RESP_NAME
                $PROFILES$.RESP_ID
    $FLEX$.ValueSet or $FLEX$.ParameterName can be used to refer to value settings for other parameters
        References
            https://docs.oracle.com/cd/A60725_05/html/comnls/us/fnd/values20.htm
            https://oracleappsnotes.wordpress.com/2012/04/24/dynamically-enabling-and-disabling-concurrent-program-parameters/
                Make program parameters dependent on prior values
        $FLEX$ is an environment variable which references selected values in flexfield value sets
        It can be used to create a dependent choice in a a list of parameters
        Until it is defined, it is null and the dependent parameters are greyed out
    Tips and Tricks
        Select from FND_FLEX_VALIDATION_TABLES for examples of WHERE clauses in table-validated value sets

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Key and Descriptive Flexfield Security
    Release 12.2 Flexfield Value Set Security Documentation Update for Patch 17305947:R12.FND.C (Document 1589204.1)
    R12.2 TOI: Implement and Use Application Object Library (AOL) - Flexfields Security and Separation of Duties for Value Sets (recorded training)

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Key Flexfields:
    Key flexfields are multi-segment values displayed as a combined single field on a form
        Key flexfields also have a popup display form allowing values to be shown separately
        They are implemented in SEGMENT'1-20' fields on tables
    Key flexfields are partitioned into multi-segment parts: from 1 to 20 segments
        The combined parts represent record keys: part numbers, account numbers etc
        Several applications require key flexfields to be configured for values
            These include account combinations, part numbers, location codes etc.
        Key flexfield segments are separated by a 'separator' character
            This character is user-defined in the flexfield definition
        Key flexfields are implemented in separate value tables as SEGMENT1..SEGMENT20
    Views are built when a KFF is compiled that store the concatenated fields
        These views shown in the "KFF Register" form and end in "_KFV"
        The name of the view table is created automatically when registry entry is made
    Key flexfields are segmented identifiers
        Each segment has a different meaning and rules for entry and range of values
    Flexfield qualifiers are names or tags for individual segments
        They tell an application where to look for needed information
            (e.g. natural account, or balancing segment, in the required GL accounting flexfield)
        Many qualifiers are required and must be assigned on segments prior to compilation
            Otherwise compilation will fail and generate an error message
        Access qualifiers of the segment definition form of a key flexfield structure
            You can only select qualifiers if the key flexfield supports them
    Key flexfields are required and unique identifiers
    Dynamic insertion allows key flexfield combinations to be added on the fly
    Key Flexfields can have Cross-Validation Rules (CVR) for value combinations that are valid
        Concurrent Program: 'Cross Validation Violation Report' ferrets out combinations which violate CVR's
        Cross-validation rules are active with dynamic insertion
        Cross-validation rules can be set up as EXCLUDE or INCLUDE rules
        Exercise: Create CVR's -> <Responsibility>/Flexfield/Key/CrossValidation
        Oracle recommends one all-inclusive rule followed by a number of exclude rules
            This avoid 'gaps' in the rules and avoids unintended excludes
        Adding a segment after flexfield cross-validation rules are defined will invalidate the rules
    Unique internal ID numbers are stored on the Oracle tables for each key flexfield combination
        The internal ID is used as the foreign key by other tables for a key flexfield combination
        So the flexfield is the outfacing value of the internal ID
    Every key flexfield has a combinations table that stores the segment values and corresponding internal ID
        For example the General Ledger/Accounting Key Flexfield uses GL_CODE_COMBINATIONS
        It stores all valid combinations for the GL code block (account combinations)
    Shorthand aliases can represent combinations of key flexfield values
        They are entered in the Alias window of the Flexfield definition
        The flexfield must be recompiled after aliases are defined
        All flexfield segment values must be established before aliases can be defined for valid combinations
    Changing a Key Flexfield once it has been setup and populated is difficult
        This is because Key Flexfields are embedded in tables as foreign key references.
        Changing these can involve complex conversion and risk, so planning is important
    You can search/query on key flexfields directly using wildcards and separators
        Use wildcards within separator patterns (e.g. "%.%.%.%" for a 4 segment flex query)
        You can also search by displaying the flexfield popup form and choosing 'Combinations'
    Flexfield segments have maximum length and display length parameters:
        if the display length is less than the maximum length, the field will scroll for data entry
    Dependent segments can be defined where ...
        The allowable values in one segment are dependent on the value in another segment
        This approach drives extra maintenance setting and updating valid segment relationships
    Segment names must be unique for key flexfields
        This is because KFF"s permit multiple structures
            Otherwise the flexfield will not compile properly
    Segment numbers in segment definitions indicate the relative position of the segment in the display forms
        Numbers can be 1, 2, 3 or 10, 20, 30 etc.
        Dependent segments should be numbered higher that the segments they depend upon
            This way they will appear after the segment that determines their scope of values
    Range values in a segment indicate if the segment value must be 'higher' or 'lower' than another segment ...
        in the flexfield with the same value set (eg from date and to date would be set up this way)
    Exercise: View an existing key flexfield registration -> Application Developer/Flexfield/Key/Register
    Exercise: Find an existing key flexfield -> System Admin/Application/Key/Flexfield/Segments and query the application
    Exercise: Create a key flexfield -> SA/Application/Key/Flexield/Segments
        and query by entering an application name
        Optionally add a flexfield name to the query to avoid paging through all flexfields for the application
        Or query back all values and page down at the header level to step through the applications and flexfields
    Exercise: Define segments for a key flexfield -> SA/Application/Key/Flexield/Segments
        and query a flexfield structure
        Then click the 'Open' button with a segment row highlighted
    Exercise: Define shorthand aliases for key flexfields -> SA/Application/Flexfields/Key/Aliases
        and query the flexfield to establish the alias, such as an account alias

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Defining a Key FlexField Structure
    The setup required for a KFF is normally limited to creating structures for existing KFF's
        Registration of the KFF is not required when additional structures are being added
    Establish Values Sets for the segments in the KFF
        Exercise: Create a Value Set -> <Responsibility>/Application/Validation/Set
        Exercise: Create values for the Value Set -> <Responsibility>/Validation/Values
    Define the segment structure for the Key Flexfield
        Exercise: Define a structure for an existing KFF -> <Application Developer>/Flexfield/Key/Segments
            Query the existing application and KFF values (e.g. "General Ledger" and "Accounting Flexfield)"
            Assign Value Sets to the Segments
            Assign all required segment qualifiers (otherwise compilation will fail)
        Freeze the flexfield structure definition and compile the flexfield
    Add cross-validation rules to the new KFF structure definition
    Assign aliases for the valid keyflexfield combinations
        Exercise: Create CVR's -> <Responsibility>/Flexfield/Key/CrossValidation

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Key Flexfield Security Rules
    References
        General Ledger FAQ for Segment Security Rules (Doc ID 138143.1)
    Navigation: GL Superuser > Setup > Financials > Flexfields > Key > Security > Define
    Navigation: GL Superuser > Setup > Financials > Flexfields > Key > Security > Assign
        to assign a security rule to a responsibility
    Flexfield security rules are sets of exclusion rules assigned to responsibilities
        Each set of rules is bundled into a named rule group.
        The rule group is attached to the responsibility definition
            So a user with the responsibility cannot enter or see the excluded combinations
    Security rules can be defined for flexfield values to limit what a user can enter
        It also limits what query results for existing records
    An example of flexfield security rules is General Ledger security
        GL responsibilities are tied to Sets of Books to limit access to these Sets of Books
        GL responsibilities are also tied to Security Rules to limit access to accounts
            This is used to limit which companies a user can see in a single set of books
        In R12 Data Access Set security overlaps Security Rules
            Security Rules limit access based on the Balancing Segment or Management Segment only

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Important Key Flexfields:
    Oracle General Ledger - Accounting Key Flexfield
    Fixed Assets - Asset Category, Asset Key, Asset Location
    Inventory - Item Key
    Human Resources - Positions and Jobs

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Value Sets:
    Value Sets are lists of values that can be applied to flexfield segments
        Note that for KFF's dynamic insertion will allow new values at the time of entry
    A Value Set is a set of valid values that can be attached to a report parameter
        It can also be attached to a field for validation and selection
    Value Sets can be independent or dependent
        A dependent Value Set is based on a prior segment value in flexfield
    Value Sets are otherwise known as QuickPick values.
    The display mode for Value Sets can be LOV, long list of values, and POP list.
        This is set through the "List Type" on the Value Set definition form
    Value Sets can be lists of values, or they can be defined as SELECT clauses on other tables
    Value Sets can also be used to store custom values
        This avoids developing custom tables or custom forms to maintain custom values
        The value sets are preserved through upgrades without special measures.
    Value Sets and values are stored in FND_FLEX_VALUE_SETS, FND_FLEX_VALUES.
    The Value Set tables are joined by a flex_value_set_id and flex_value_id.
    One Value Set can be assigned any number of times in the applications
        Value Set assignments can be to one or more segments in one or more flexfields in any applications
    A Value Set can contain a set of values and corresponding set of descriptions
        The values and descriptions are searchable in a lookup list
    Values in these sets have descriptions corresponding to values to better define them
        These name/value pairs are maintained through the 'Values' form
    Value Sets have validation types:
        independent- a user-maintained list of values (independent of other segment data)
        dependent - a user-maintainied list dependent on a value in a prior segment
        special- a range of values within another list of values
        none - only length and format restrictions are provided
        table - a query against values in another table is defined
        pair - used for request submission parameters
        translatable-independent - same as an independent value set, but with language translation
        translatable-dependent - same as a dependent value set, but with language translation
    A Value Set's length must be no longer than the length of the flexfield segment it is assigned to.
    The individual values in a Value Set cannot be changed once they are used
        However their descriptions can be changed.
    To edit values: hide old values (which may already be in use) and add new values
    Table validations can be set up for any existing table (or by creating and registering a new table
        Define the Value Set and choose Table Validation to get access to the table validation form
    Value Sets can have their own descriptive flexfields that are context sensitive
        You can define flexfields to value set values and associate additional value sets to these flexfields
    To see context sensitive descriptive flex field values in the Value Set flexfield
        (i.e.) look at the DFF's on value sets -
        query DFF's for the "Application Object Library" application
            using the description "Flexfield Segment Values"
    Value Set setup forms are accessible from many responsibilities across all applications
    Exercise: Create a Value Set for a flexfield -> <Responsibility>/Application/Validation/Set
    Exercise: Create values for a valueset -> <Responsibility>/Application/Validation/Values
        find the Value Set already defined ('find values by Value Set')
    Exercise: Create a table definition for a valueset -> <Responsibility>/Application/Validation/Set
        set the validation type to 'Table', then choose 'edit information'

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Value Set Setup Steps:
    Define Value Sets and values using almost any setup responsibility
    Exercise: Open the Value Set Definition -> <Responsibility>/Application/Validation/Set
        List Type: Can be Poplist (< 10 values), List (11 - 200 values), Long List (> 200 values)
        Maximum Size: This is the number of characters for the chosen format type (eg Char)
    Exercise: Create values for the Value Set -> <Responsibility>/Validation/Values
        Enter values and descriptions

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Profile Options:
    "Flexfields:Open Desc Window" - defaults to open a DFF automatically when focus is set
    "Flexfields:Shorthand Entry" - turns on short hand alias entries for key flexfields
    "Flexfields:Autoskip" - skips focus to the next field on complete entry, without tabbing
    "Flexfields:Show Full Value" - displays the key flexfield edit window after the alias window closes

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Key Tables:
    FND_ID_FLEXS - is a registry of key flex fields
    FND_ID_FLEX_SEGMENTS - defines the segments within each key flexfield
    FND_ID_FLEX_STRUCTURES - defines the structures for each key flexfield
    FND_FLEX_VALIDATION_RULES - cross-validation rules
    FND_FLEX_VALUES (and _TL) - contains the actual values and their hierarchy level
    FND_FLEX_VALUE_SETS - stores the values set headers
    FND_FLEX_VALIDATION_TABLES - validation rules for table based validations
    FND_FLEX_VALUES (and _TL) - stores the actual values within each value set
        This table supports language translation
    GL_CODE_COMBINATIONS - stores actual combinations for the General Ledger Account codes
    FND_FLEX_VALUE_HIERARCHIES - stores the parent values and all ranges detail level ranges for those parent
        You can query on a detailed account within a range and return all parents at all levels
        This table is denormalized to show all detail level ranges (at most detail level) for all parents at all levels
    FND_FLEX_VALUE_NORM_HIERARCHY - stores each parent and it's range in fully normalized format
        Each record appears as you enter it online - one record for each parent at each level with it's immediate children

Flexfields and Value Sets (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Frequently Asked Questions
    How is it possible to have multiple structures for the same Key Flexfield title?
        Applications such as General Ledger support them
        e.g. Each Set of Books can have a different accounting key flexfield
        e.g. Each Item Inventory Organization can have a different Item Key Flexfield
        So multiple key flexfield structures can be defined under the same flexfield title
    How is it possible to have multiple structures for the same Descriptive Flexfield?
        Descriptive Flexfields have a context field which acts as a switch between structures
        Different applications support using different contexts
        e.g. Invoice Source in AP can be linked to a Context Field
            Different Invoice Sources utilize different DFF structures on invoices
        This allows overloading of DFF fields with multiple definitions
        It extends the ability of a DFF to store values relevant to different transactions
    How can two different flexfield structures use common segment columns on the same table?
        For Key Flexfields, the structure that is used depends on how the application is setup
            Only one KFF structure is used on a single transaction
        For Descriptive Flexfields, the structure that is used depends upon the context
            Only one DFF structure is used on a single transaction
    How do the applications know which FlexField Structure to use
        That's the role of the "Structure Column" field in the Flexfield Registration entry
        The "Structure Column" is a table column used to decide which structure to use
        See the "Register" form for this value
        For DFF's it is normally set to the ATTRIBUTE_CATEGORY field (the Context field)
        For KFF's it is normally set to the column in the code combinations table established for the purpose
            e.g. Account Code Combinations actually use the KFF Structure column
                This value is tied into the table through the Set of Books setup definition
    Where do flexfield qualifiers come from and how are they defined and assigned special behaviours?
        Flexfield Qualifiers are defined by the Applications
        Different functions within the applications operate on these qualifiers
        e.g. An Intercompany Segment qualifier is used by Inter Company accounting functions
    Why can't Key Flexfield definitions be changed?
        DFF's can ) but KFF's cannot if they have been used.
            Once a KFF is used, its primary key is a foreign key embedded in other tables

FNDLoad or "Generic Loader" (FNDLOAD in APPLSYS Schema) General Notes
    Reference information on FNDLOAD is in the Systems Administration Guide in the 'Loaders' section
    The FNDLOAD utility is a generic loader that can upload or download application objects
        The concurrent program is 'Generic Loader'
    FNDLOAD is a concurrent program run from inside Oracle
    Data is downloaded to a file (.ldt) using a configuration control file (.lct) and uploaded using a config control file (.lct)
    The loader operates in download mode (to a text file) or upload mode (from text file)
    The .ldt file is human readable and editable by any text editor - information normally stored as codes is translated to short-names
    Foundation Loader exports foundation functional security and user setup values to a text file or imports values from a text file
    The Foundation Loader text file is easily readable and can be edited between the export and import
    The import loader updates existing rows, inserts new rows and leaves existing rows unchanged (unless there are updates)
    FNDLOAD is also known as 'Generic Loader' in Oracle terminology
        'Generic Loader' is the description assigned to FNDLOAD in the executable
            description in Oracle Applications
    FNDLOAD is a concurrent program located at $FND_TOP/bin
    It can move data across application instances using data file representions
    It downloads data from the database using a control file .ct.
        It creates a data file .ldt which is a plain text file and portable across hosts
        The .lct file is predefined by Oracle and saved at $FND_TOP/patch/115/import.
        Custom configuration .lct files can be placed in the same location

FNDLoad or "Generic Loader" (FNDLOAD in APPLSYS Schema) Notes on FNDLOAD Syntax
    FNDLOAD [username/password] 0 Y [mode] [configuration file] [target data file] [object type key] [object Identifier]
        0 Y represent your concurrent program flags.
        [username/password] your apps username and password
        [mode] might be download or upload
        [configuration file] might be the .lct file like afcpprog.lct
        [target data file] this the .ldt file created while download(or used for upload)
            like someprg.ldt[object type key] this would represent you object type like CONCURRENT_PROGRAM
        [object Identifier] this would be your object name like CONCURRENT_PROGRAM_NAME='XXACMEPRT'
    Examples Using The Command Line Syntax (Menu and Responsibility)
        FNDLOAD apps/apps 0 Y DOWNLOAD $FND_TOP/patch/115/import/afsload.lct
            menus.ldt MENU MENU_NAME=XX%
        FNDLOAD apps/apps 0 Y DOWNLOAD $FND_TOP/patch/115/import/afscursp.lct
        responsibilities.ldt FND_RESPONSIBILITY RESP_KEY=XX%

FNDLoad or "Generic Loader" (FNDLOAD in APPLSYS Schema) Notes on FNDLOAD Examples for Form Personalizations
    Upload
        FNDLOAD apps/$CLIENT_APPS_PWD 0 Y DOWNLOAD $FND_TOP/patch/115/import/affrmcus.lct
            XX_PERWSHRG.ldt FND_FORM_CUSTOM_RULES function_name="PERWSHRG-404"
        FNDLOAD apps/$CLIENT_APPS_PWD 0 Y DOWNLOAD $FND_TOP/patch/115/import/affrmcus.lct
            XX_HZ_ARXCUDCI_STD.ldt FND_FORM_CUSTOM_RULES function_name="HZ_ARXCUDCI_STD"
        FNDLOAD apps/$CLIENT_APPS_PWD 0 Y DOWNLOAD $FND_TOP/patch/115/import/affrmcus.lct
        XX_AP_APXVDMVD.ldt FND_FORM_CUSTOM_RULES function_name="AP_APXVDMVD"
    Download
        FNDLOAD apps/$CLIENT_APPS_PWD 0 Y UPLOAD $FND_TOP/patch/115/import/affrmcus.lct XX_PERWSHRG.ldt
        FNDLOAD apps/$CLIENT_APPS_PWD 0 Y UPLOAD $FND_TOP/patch/115/import/affrmcus.lct XX_HZ_ARXCUDCI_STD.ldt
        FNDLOAD apps/$CLIENT_APPS_PWD 0 Y UPLOAD $FND_TOP/patch/115/import/affrmcus.lct XX_AP_APXVDMVD.ldt

Flow Page Notes
    Step 1 - Define a view under the apps schema
    Step 2 - Attribute -> Object -> Region -> Flowpage -> Flow
    Step 3 - AK Developer Responsibility
    Step 4 - Define Attributes
    Step 5 - Create Object - Object Workbench, Tie Object to View, Define and Select Attributes and tie to View Column
    Step 6 - Define Region - and tie to object, with only one object per region
    Step 7 - Flow page in "Flow Workbench", go to page region and assign, define flow first, then flowpage then region
    Step 8 - Tie to function in System Administration, define new function

Forms Personalization (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Forms Personalization allows changes to Oracle Forms including:
        Changing titles on fields
        Hiding fields and re-arranging fields
        Making fields non-editable
        Adding validations and error messages
        Adding local captions on forms
        Setting field defaults
        Adding links from a form to other forms
    Forms personalization was originally implemented through CUSTOM.PLL library coding
        CUSTOM.PLL handles triggers on a range of events generated by Oracle Forms
    Forms personalization applies to Oracle Forms and not J2EE webpages
        Web page customization is covered by the Oracle Applications Framework
    It works in front of CUSTOM.PLL so both methods of personalization can co-exist
    With 11.5.10 these same customizations are implemented as metadata that is admin-user configurable
    The configurations in Forms Personalization are protected through upgrades
    FNDLOAD scripts are provided to move these setups between different instances of applications
        See notes on FNDLOAD

Forms Personalization (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on the Procedure to Change a Form:
    Personalizations are configured through the help menu on any existing Oracle form
        Exercise: customize a form -> Open the Form in 11i10, and
            choose Help/Diagnostics/Custom Code/Personalize
    The steps to create a personalization are:
        Run the form to be personalized (i.e. display it)
        Invoke the Personalization Screen via Help/Diagnostics/Custom Code/Personalize
        Create rules that determine when the personalization will be triggered
            All forms have a standard event list that provide candidates for the trigger
            Conditional expressions can be attached to the trigger to limit invocation
        Define the context for the trigger to specify who the rule applies to
            Context can be Site, Responsibility, User or Industry
            The rule will be executed if the current running context matches the definition
        Create the actions that will be invoked
            One or more actions can be defined
            The action can be associated with a single language or run for all languages
    Personalizations comprise Conditions ("if-then-else" like conditions) and Actions
    There is a central form for turning off all personalizations
        This shuts down unidentified errors that may arise in personalizations

Forms Personalization (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Note on Procedure to Enable View Output
    General
        Function: FND_FNDCPQCR_SYS
        Form Name: FNDRSRUN
    Condition
        Trigger Event: WHEN-NEW-RECORD-INSTANCE
        Trigger: JOBS
        Processing Mode: Not in Enter-Query Mode
    Context
        Level: Responsibility
        Value: System Administrator
        Sequence: 1
        Description: Allow View Output
        Level: Function
    Actions
        Sequence: 1
        Type: Property
        Language: All
        Object Type: Item
        Target Object: JOBS.VIEW_REPORT
        Property Name: ENABLED
        Value: TRUE

Forms Personalization (AOL FND APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Hidden Form Events:
    There is an event ON_VALIDATE_ITEM that is not in the list of events
        This event does not allow selection of the item from the LOV for items
        As a workaround, click on the form field you want before opening the personalization form
        This sets focus to the item you want behind the scenes

    Utilities:Diagnostics - set to Yes to eliminate prompt for an APPS password
        This profile option is cached so you have to log off and close browser sessions then restart

General Ledger (GL) Best Practices:
    Dependent segments on the accounting KFF should be avoided
       This is due to ongoing maintenance
       Use parent segments, summary accounts, rollup groups and FSG calculations used instead
    Use a Group ID on all GL uploades from ADI and enforce it through the 'GLDI Create Group ID' profile option

Accounting Setup Manager (GL) Table of Contents
    Accounting Setup Manager is a central setup dashboard for configuring ledger, legal entities and companies
    It also supports configuration of processing options for the General Ledger and related functionality
    Navigation: AP Superuser > Setup > Accounting Setups > Ledger Setup > Define > Accounting Setups

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Account Segments, Account Structure and Account Combinations:
    Natural accounts are qualified by type: asset, liability, owner's equity, revenue or expense. These qualifiers apply to the segment in the AFF that is designated the natural account segment
    Segment qualifiers at the highest level are: natural account (required), balancing segment (required), cost center (optional) ,inter-company, and management (optional - R12)
    After modifying segments (e.g. end-dating) you need to run 'Program - Inherit Segment Value Attributes' to update settings on code combinations
        This program 'Program - Inherit Segment Value Attributes' updates all segments in gl.gl_code_combinations that have the updated segment value
            If you update an account segment, all entries for all books for this account value are updated, regardless of the set of books
            Only code combinations in the same chart of accounts are updated
    Exercise: Disable an account code combination -> GLVO/Setups/Accounts/Combinations, query the range of accounts code combinations to review, and uncheck the 'Enabled' checkbox against each account code combination. Save.
    Exercise: Set an Account Combination Effective Date Range -> GLVO/Setups/Accounts/Combinations, and query the range of account code combinations to review, and set the effective dates for each row of valid account code combinations. Save.
    Exercise: Disable an Specific Account Segment Value (for all combinations) -> GLVO/Setup/Financials/Flexfields/Key/Value, and find values by key flexfield (segment). Uncheck the 'Enabled' checkbox for the segment value, and save.

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on the Accounting Flexfield:
    Accounting Key Flexfield - establishes the structure of the chart of accounts segments
    The account code combination flexfield length determines the lowest level of reporting and balances in the GL
    A balancing segment is required in the account flexfield to balance the total for journals (total DR's = total CR's for each balancing value)
       The balancing segment is the segment against which a balance sheet is prepared
       It is also used to generate a trial balance
    A cost center segment is required if FA, PA or other modules are implemented
    The accounting flexfield is difficult to change once it has been compiled and used. Changes could create data inconsistancies    Can be up to 30 segments but typically 3 to 6 (min would be company/department or cost center/account)
    Min segments are 2 (one balancing segment and one natural account segment)
    The intercompany segment is a separate segment that is stamped with the company id for the 'other company' in an intercompany journal.
        This provided a control total since the DR's/CR's for all intercompany journal entries for all companies should balance within a period.
        It also allows a company to track the source of a journal posted from another company.
        Note the 'Balance Intercompany' flag must be set on the SOB Definition form to force balancing entries to be created
    The Management Segment (R12) is optional and is used to restrict access by users with Data Access Sets
        It can be assigned to any segment except the Balancing Segment or the Natural Account
    Flexfield segment examples are: COMPANY -> Operations, Distribution, Corporate, etc, DEPARTMENT -> East, West, Computing, etc, ACCOUNT -> Cash, AR, WIP, Assets, Cost of Sales, Expenses, etc, SUBACCOUNT: California, Kansas, Idaho etc, PRODUCT -> Keyboard, Monitor, Stand, etc,
    Exercise: Define flexfield values -> Setup/Flexfields/Key/Values and find 'Oracle General Ledger'

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Segment Value Inheritance
    Run 'Program - Inherit Segment Value Attributes' to update all code combinations with attributes of the account segment
       Values such as Active, Inactive, Start Date, End Date etc are propogated
       Account Type is not propagated by segment value inheritance and must be updated via script
    You can protect an existing code combination from inheriting updates by checking the 'Preserve' check box
    The process is fully documented in the GL User Guide

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Accounting Calendars and Periods:
    The intercompany balancing segment is new to 11i
        it automatically stamps intercompany journals with the partner company id so that each company can add up total intercompany debits and credits and balance with the other companies
        Note the 'Balance Intercompany' flag must be set on the SOB Definition form to force balancing entries to be created
    Periods are defined in calendars by names and non-overlapping date ranges.
    An adjustment period for year-end adjustments can overlap date ranges
        The adjustment period is typically the last day of the year and is opened when all other periods are closed, to post adjustments before year end close is completed
    Accounting periods are opened one at a time through a concurrent process - triggered from the Open/Close form in the setup menu
        Periods that are open for entry only mean there are no lines on GL_BALANCES and posting cannot occur
        When a period is opened the new period balance lines are created in GL_BALANCES
            Journals can be posted to the new period because the lines exist in GL_BALANCES to update
    Accounting periods should be opened 'earliest first' since opening the first period locks all prior periods out
        If prior periods are locked out historical data cannot be converted
    Multiple periods can remain open at the same time
        However periods should be closed when no longer used to avoid transactions being posted incorrectly
    Encumbrance periods are opened one year at a time through the same form as accounting periods - Open/Close form in setup
    Accounting periods can be reopened but will invalidate past financial statements - prior period adjustments in current journals are preferred
    Exercise: Open an accounting period -> GLVO/Setup/Open-Close.
        Click on 'Open Next Period' button - form shows most recent open period. Kicks off concurrent process
    Exercise: Close an accounting period -> GLVO/Setup/Open-Close.
        Choose period to close and select 'Closed' from LOV. Save the change. You can also choose 'Permanently Closed' from the same LOV
    Exercise: Define Period Types -> GL Superuser/Setup/Financial/Calendars/Types - to define period types like month, quarter, year
    Exercise: Define Calendars (Calendar Periods) ->
        GENERAL LEDGER/Setup/Financial/Calendars/Accounting
            to define a calendar and it's accounting periods
        Note that the 'NAME' column is generated by Oracle using the 'PREFIX' and year
            The year is taken from the year in the 'FROM' date
            This 'NAME' column is generated automatically after the 'FROM' year is entered
    Exercise: Open Periods -> Setup/Open-Close and set focus on the line and click 'Open Next Period'
        open the earliest needed period first during setup, for historical entries

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Security Rules
    Security Rules are applied to Key Flexfields and not limited to the General Ledger
    See 'Flexfields and Value Sets' for in this document for more information

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Data Access Sets (introduced in R12)
    Data Access Sets restrict access to GL data based on Balancing Segment and Management Segment rules
        Functionality overlaps Security Rules which limit access based on any segment in the Accounting Key Flexfield
    Reports (available under the General Ledger Super User)
        'Data Access Set Listing' lists all data access sets sharing the responsibility chart of accounts

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Definition Access Sets (introduced in R12):
    There are several features of Definition Access Sets that must be observed when defining them
        They operate cumulatively at the user level and not the responsibility level
            If a user has definition privilege access under any responsibility this access will be enabled under all responsibilities
            Definitions are not restricted by responsibility for a single user but enabled under all resposibilities
        You cannot enable security on an entity without assigning at least one Definition Access Set
        You cannot assign a definition access set to an entity unless it has already been assigned to a responsiblity
            Each definition access set must be assigned to at least one responsibility before it will appear in a drop down list
            So create definition access sets (without member entities) and assign them to a responsibility before beginning the entity assignment process
        You also cannot assign a Definition Entity to a Definition Access Set if you don't have the corresponding responsibility
            This is one of the responsibilities the Definition Access Set is assigned to
        You cannot assign a Definition Access Set to an underlying Entity with no permissions for viewing, using or updating
            i.e. you cannot remove all privileges from a Definition Access Set assignment to an underlying entity.
            Simply do not assign the Definition Access Set to the responsibility and the responsibility will have no privileges (or remove the assignment)
    You can setup a Definition Access Set with members and subsequently delete all the members but it can create a problem
        If the entity is already secured by a definition access set and the DAS members are deleted, the entity becomes unreachable
            i.e. it is 'secured' but has no Definition Access Sets assigned (this is a design flaw)
    Setup steps are:
        Create a Definition Access Set Without Member Assignments to Secured Entities
            Navigation: GL Superuser > Setup > Definition Access Sets > Define
                Enter a Definition Access Set Name and Description
            You cannot create secured member entities here unless entities have already been tagged as secured
            If entities have not been tagged as secured, the member entities are created later when the entities are defined and secured(see step below)
        Assign the Definition Access Set to Responsibilities
            This must be done to at least one responsibility before the Definition Access Set can be used
            Navigation: GL Superuser > Setup > Definition Access Sets > Assign
        Assign the Definition Access Set to the Entity Being Created by Navigating to the Definition form for the entity
            Navigation (e.g. Revaluation) GL Controller > Currency > Revaluation > (Query Revaluation Rule Set or Enter New)
            Check the 'Enable Security' box to enable the 'Assign Access' button on the screen
            Click 'Assign Access' and add the Definition Access Set to the list of assignees (and save to trigger compilation)
                The compilation program is 'Compile Definition Access Sets'
        Requery the Definition Access Set to Confirm the Assignments
    Definition Access Set Reports (under GL Superuser)
        'Other - Definition Access By User - shows cumulative access to all entities across all responsibilities for a single user
        'Other - Definition Access Set Listing' lists definition privileges for a single definition access set and entity type (e.g. revaluation)

Inter-company and Intra-company Balancing Rules
    References
        Unable to Validate Bank Account Transfer FUN_INTRA_RULE_NOT_ASSIGNED (Doc ID 434308.1)
        Setting Up Intracompany and Intercompany Accounting - an Example (Doc ID 604441.1)
        R12: How To Balance Intercompany Journals Using a Clearing Balancing Segment Value (BSV)? (Doc ID 1640618.1)
        How To Setup Intercompany Accounting For All Other to All Other [ID 467236.1]
        Intracompany Balancing in Release 12 FAQ [ID 463472.1]
        12: How To Balance Intercompany Journals Using Intracompany Rules or a Clearing Balancing Segment Value (BSV)? (Doc ID 1640618.1)
            Define profile option: FUN: Balance Using Intracompany Rules Only
        Setting Up Intracompany and Intercompany Accounting - an Example (Doc ID 604441.1) -- primary reference
        R12 SQL Queries For Ledgers And Legal Entities (Doc ID 740643.1)
        How Can One Operating Unit Be Associated with Multiple Legal Entities and the Correct Legal Entity be Defaulted in the Invoice Workbench? (Doc ID 1453785.1)
        What is Legal Entity and its Uptake in Receivables in Release 12 (Doc ID 414014.1)
        What Is the Default Legal Context' in the Operating Unit Parameter [ID 436869.1]
        Intracompany Balancing In Release 12 (Doc ID 579930.1)	To BottomTo Bottom	
    Setups
        Ledger Option 'Intracompany Balancing' is enabled
        Balancing Details
             Comrpises DR Bal Seg, CR Bal Seg, DR Account, CR Account
             If a DR is required to the DR Balancing Segment, the Debit Account is used
             If a CR is required (to the CR Balancing Segment) the Credit Account is used
                 e.g. Net DR account is less than Net DR so DR account requires a balancing entry - use CR account
             If you use All Other on either or both sides of the rule
                 the appropriate trading partner balancing segment value replaces the balancing segment of the account combination.
    Key Tables
        fun.fun_balance_options - intracompany balancing options including default segment
        fun.fun_balance_accounts - intracompany balancing accounts

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Month-End (Period-End) Processing:
    You can open and close individual Ledgers using the Open/Close form
    Close the period once all transactions are booked and adjustments made
        This must be done for each set of books in 11.5.10 but can be done for Ledger Sets in R12
    Close for Ledgers or Ledger Sets can be done with concurrent programs
        Periods - Close Periods
        Periods - Gapless Close Periods - can only be done by concurrent program
            This close stamps gapless reporting sequences on all transactions (see Reporting Sequences)
        Periods - Permanently Close Periods

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Year End Close Processing:
    Close Year-End by opening the first period of the new year
        resets income statement accounts to zero and books retained earnings to the ledger
    After Year-End Close journals posted to a prior year automatically adjust the retained earnings account balance
        The adjustment reflects the net change in income and expenses
    Accounting dates use the occurrance date and not the entry date for a transaction
        transactions are accounted in the periods when they actually occurred.
    Accounting periods and start and end dates are completely flexible
        However the number of periods must be the same from year to year for comparison reporting purposes
            This is enforced by Oracle

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Entering and Maintaining Currencies
    Exchange rates can be entered in several ways:
        through Currency Rates Manager by direct entry
        through Currency Rates Manager by spreadsheet upload
        through the Currency Rates Maintenance form
    Oracle automatically calculates inverse rates so inverse rates do not need to be entered in each line
    Exercise: Enter currency rates -> GL Superuser/Setup/Currencies/Rates/Daily
    Exercise: Upload currency rates -> GL Superuser/Setup/Currency Rates Manager/Daily Rates

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Multiple Reporting Currencies (MRC's):
    MRC is a feature in Oracle that allows reporting and records maintenance in more than one currency at the transactional level
    Multiple Reporting Currencies (MRC) are implemented through additional 'reporting' sets of books in the GL
        these books have alternate currency definitions (see form 'Assign Reporting Sets of Books' form)
        Navigation -> <General Ledger Super User>/Setup/Financial/Books/Assign
        A reporting set of books is defined by setting the 'Reporting' radio button on the SOB definition form (MRC Tab)
    When a journal is entered in a currency different to the SOB functional currency:
        The system uses the exchange rate specified in the journal header to convert to the functional currency
        The journal is posted to GL_BALANCES with updates for each currency (two records in GL_BALANCES for the same set of books)
        This includes updating the 'BEQ' suffix fields on the foreign currency line and
            updating the entered values on the line representing the functional currency
        The functional currency line in GL_BALANCES represents the cumulative balance of functional currency entries and foreign currency entries
            This means you can only get the functional currency entered amounts by backing out the BEQ amounts on the foreign currency lines.
            It also means that the functional currency lines on the GL_BALANCES table represent the total balances for all currencies.
        The foreign currency lines in GL_BALANCES only represent the foreign currency amounts and their corresponding functional currency values
        GL then checks for reporting sets of books (using triggers on the GL_BALANCES tabe) and if it finds them
            GL automatically converts entered journals to the alternate currencies and then posting to the alternate reporting set of books
                so every transaction in the primary set of books is mirrored in the reporting set of books in the different currency
    Reporting sets of books in the GL have the same calendar and chart of accounts as the primary set of books
        they simply have a different currency.
    A separate reporting responsibility must be defined to access the reporting set of books.
        This is done by associating two profile options to a responsibility:
            GL: Set of Books Name
            GL: Reporting Set of Books
    Subledger transactions track MRC values using MRC 'subtables' for all the subledger applications:
        Cash Management,
        Cost Management,
        Global Accounting Engine,
        Payables,
        Receivables,
        Purchasing and
        Projects (ie all the subledgers)
    In the subledgers, MRC is implemented with MRC subtables that are populated by a trigger on the main tables
        to calculate and store the converted currency transaction values
    The reporting set of books is a fully functional GL for:
        transacting,
        inquiring and reporting directly,
        recording of adjustments
    Currency conversion rates can be maintained for different types.
        Seeded currency types are Corporate, Spot and User
        The currency type 'Revaluation' is also supported for a special revaluation rate (optional)
    MRC requirements come from several sources:
        foreign currency transactions (import/export),
        currency gains and losses,
        operations in foreign countries,
        consolidating foreign operations, and
        Euro activities
    Functional currency is the currency for the majority of transactions and the currency for reporting
        foreign exchange transactions are converted to functional currency
    Oracle posts the converted (functional) currency and the foreign currency to the ledger in the joural entry.
        GL maintains both currencies for future revaluations, gain and loss calculations and reporting
    Exchange rates are maintained in the GL and can be one of several types: daily, average, usage and period end
        Daily rates are used to convert transactions at the time they are entered.
        Average rates are used to compare operating results over a time period.
        Period-end rates are used to convert balances for consolidation
    Gains and losses in foreign exchange for export sales arise
        This is due to a change in the conversion rate from the time of invoice to the time of payment.
    Revaluation changes balance sheet accounts that become misstated due to fluctuations in exchange rates
        (eg receivables, payables, assets).
        A gain or loss account is posted with the change in valuation, as an unrealized amount
    Revaluation journals are posted at month-end close and reversed for the opening of the next month.
        This more fairly states the closing accounts at month end.
        Actual gains and losses are posted when the accounts are settled (eg invoice paid)
    Balance translation is used to consolidate foreign entity books using one of two methods:
        equity translation and
        temporal translation.
        Only one method can be chosen in compliance with FAS 52 standards
    Equity translation treats the foreign subsidiary as an investment and the equity is valued at market rates for inclusion in local books
    Temporal translation converts each account on the balance sheet according to it's timing
        (cash at current rates, fixed assets at date of acquisition etc).
        There is a TRANSLATED_FLAG on GL.GL_BALANCES that indicates if the line has been translated
            If 'Y' it means the balance is translated, based on the functional currency balance
            If 'N' it means the balance is translated, but out of date and needs re-translation
    GL supports reporting in Euro currency denominations as well as local currencies concurrently,
        to support the dual currency transition period to the Euro
    Transacting in Euros and reporting in Euros are independent objectives within GL and supported differently,
        because their timing is different.
    Inflationary countries set up USD as an MRC reporting set of books
        This provides reporting in a meaningful currency denomination

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Summary Templates
    Warning - avoid defining templates that break security rules
        For example if you set the Balancing Segment to 'T' it will break security rules on the Balancing Segment
        Avoid this by setting the Balancing Segment to 'D' or creating a rollup group on the balancing segment value
            Then include the rollup group in the template definition - this will prevent Oracle attempting to roll up secured segments
    Warning - adding templates can take a long time - assign the process to a separate manager if needed
    Templates are representations of account ranges where some segments are summarized and others shown in detail
    Navigation: <General Ledger Superuser>/Setup/Accounts/Summary
    Use 'T' or 'D' for Total or Detail to rollup or leave detailed accounts for summarization
    Also use fixed values to create very specific templates (e.g. include the actual company code in the template for the balancing segment)
    Additional valid values are rollup groups within each segment
    Once created and saved, a concurrent process is spawned to build a definition of the template for use in GL inquiry and reporting
        The definition is built on GL.GL_BALANCES by creating summary balances with new summary code combinations
    To delete a template and recreate it, delete the summary template entry from the form and save.
        The template will show 'deleting' status and start a concurrent process when saved
    Templates are stored on GL.GL_SUMMARY_TEMPLATES

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Summary Accounts and Rollup Groups:
    Navigation: <General Ledger Superuser>/Setup/Finanicals/Flexfields/Key/Groups (to create rollup groups)
    Navigation: <General Ledger Superuser>/Setup/Financials/Flexfields/Values (to assign rollup group names to segment values)
    Navigation: <General Ledger Superuser>/Setup/Financials/Flexfields/Values (to create summary Summary Segments and hierarchies)
    Rollup Groups are summary level values that attach to segment summary values in value sets
        There is a separate form for defining rollup groups and another form (key flex segment values defn) for assigning rollup groups
        Rollup Groups can only be assigned to parent values in segment hierarchies - they cannot be assigned to child values
    Rollup groups be applied to the segment in an accounting key flexfield
    The overall structure can be viewed in the Hierarchy Manager window (a Java applet)
        Navigation: <General Ledger Superusr>/Setup/Accounts/Manager (to view the Account Hierarchy manager)
        To allow changes in Account Hierarchy Manager, set the profile option 'GL AHM: Allow Users to Modify Hierarchy' to Yes
        To allow changes to Rollup Groups in Account Hierarchy Manager, the Key Flex Structure must be unfrozen first
            Otherwise the needed action buttons will not display.
            You create new rollup groups or change existing rollup groups in the rollup group window
            You change the assignments of rollup groups to parent accounts by viewing the properties (right-click) of the account
            You cannot change properties directly in the spreadsheet displays.
    Segment Summaries are parent values in the LOV hierarchy for a segment LOV
        Segment Summaries are attached to ranges of child values
        Roll up Groups are not attached to child ranges - they attach to any values at any level across the entire hierarchy
    Both Rollup Groups and Segment Hiearchies are defined in the Segment Values and Child Ranges dialog of Key Flex Segment Definition
    Multiple rollup groups on GL account segments are used to produce management summaries.
        You can define a hierarchy of parents and children for each account flexfield segment
    Summary accounts cross all segments in the Accounting Flexfield
        They can total designated segments and provide detail values on other segments
    Summary accounts totalling is designated in a template using 'T' for total the segment, or 'D' meaning keep segment detail
    Summary accounts provide online account balances, regardless of the values of non-account flexfield segments.
        Summary accounts are defined in the Setup/Accounts/Summary form
        Also create a value in the value set for each segment as 'T' to avoid errors querying balances in accounts (the segment value 'T' must exist)
            Note: the value set on the segment must allow non-numeric values to do this.
        Once the summary account combinations are defined and the 'T' values defined in each segment where needed, query GL balances
            Enter the summary account pattern (e.g. T.D.D.D.D.D) and enter values or ranges for the 'D' segments and run the query
        Use the Optimizer
            References: How To Improve Overall Performance of General Ledger Application ? (Doc ID 143196.1)
            The optimizer concurrent program 'GL: Optimizer' creates indexes on segment values to improve posting performance
            The 'Maintain Summary Templates' program updates summary templates for new accounts that have been added to the chart
    Parent-child relationships group individual value set values into summary or parent values
        This is all within the single segment and as part of their value set (value set hierarchy)
    Parent segment values are part of the value set, and their children are linked in the Account Hierarchy Editor form via ADI
    Parents can have parents in a multi-level hierarchy, and one child can be linked under multiple different parents
    Parent totals are calculated as they are needed
        They are not updated continuously and are therefore not available for online inquiry
    Rollup groups work like summary accounts but they are not continously calculated
        they summarize values across multiple segments
    Roll-up groups are independent of value set parents in accounting flexfields and group value set parents for further summarization
    Roll-up groups do rollups across all segments of the accounting flexfield, whereas parents/children in value sets remain within a segment
    Account should be grouped into meaningful ranges to accomodate range parameters in reports such as FSG's
    Account Generator builds accounts for a limited list of feeder transactions only: Projects Supplier Invoices, Projects Employee Expense Lines, Purchase Orders, Requisitions, AR Finance Charges, Asset Depreciation and Asset Additions, Inventory/Order Management Cost of Goods Sold
    Account Generator workflows are associated with AFF flexfields in the AFF flexfield definition - see SYSTEM ADMINISTRATOR/Application/Flexfield/Key/Account for the Account Generator Processes form

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Account Generation in Subledgers:
    Sales accounts from Order Management are built by AutoAccounting in 11i, not Account Generator

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Journals and Recurring Journals:
    References: Metalink Note: 138199.1 Oracle General Ledger Journal Entry Setup and Usage
    Journal sources define where a journal comes from (feeder system, manual input in place of automated interface etc)
    Journal categories define the business purpose of the journal such as payroll costs, cash disbursements, depreciation etc
        Journal categories are not dependent on set of books - they apply to all sets of books when they are setup
    Journal balance types can be actual, budget or encumbrance
    Journal batches are sets of related journals that are posted at the same time
    A journal is a set of journal lines that balance such that total debits and credits are equal.
    Journals are entered and posted in separate steps, from multiple sources: manual entry into GL, journal import interface or ADI upload
    Recurring journals are journal definitions, that can be 'generated' multiple times for different accounting periods. The accounting period is specified when you generate the journal.
    Autopost will post journals automatically on a recurring schedule using journal selection criteria: source, category (purpose), period and balance type
    Journals can be entered out of balance if a balancing account is specified on the set of books to post the variance
    Journals can be imported through the standard GL import process for Oracle subledgers and third party systems. Suspense tranasactions can be corrected, or deleted, or reprocessed (eg. after opening a d period)
    Journals can be imported into 'Open' periods or 'Future Enterable' periods but cannot be posted for future enterable periods.
    Journals can be imported in summary mode (one line per unique AFF combination) or detail mode (one line for every source line)
    Suspense accounts can be defined for journals to post imbalances, rather than require journals to be balanced prior to posting.
        They can be defined for a journal category and journal source combination
    Consolidations between SOB's on different instances use GL import to post consolidation journals.
        GIS contains this functionality including approval by owners of each instance SOB
    Journal import can be used to load opening balances to the ledger as an opening journal import set
    Posting involved applying each journal line to update the corresponding journal balance and setting the POSTED field on GJ_JE_LINES to 'Yes'
    Posting actual journals update balances rolling forward to the end of the most recent open period
    Security rules attached to responsibilities further restrict account access beyond the Set of Books level
        part of accounting flexfield definition and responsibility definition
    Cross validation rules block out invalid AFF combinations. For asset/liability accounts, Department is typically zero.
    Segments in the AFF should be independent of each other, with valid and invalid combinations
    Existing account combinations can be disabled to prevent further posting of journals
    Every journal entry has a descriptive flexfield segment where additional detail about the journal line or entry can be stored (eg source document number)
    Global Consolidation System (GCS) can be used to interface legacy subledgers to the Oracle General Ledger, utilizing it's multiple SOB capability and account mapping functions
    Exercise: Find a journal -> GLVO/Journals/Enter, displays 'Find Journals' form. Enter find criteria and click 'find'.
        Use Posting Status to find unposted journals. Click 'Review Journal' from next form of returned values, to view detailed journal
    Exercise: Refine a search for a journal -> click flashlight on 'Find Journals' form
    Exercise: Review journal detail (1) -> 'Review Journal' from the 'Enter Journals' form
    Exercise: Review journal detail (2) -> Journals/Enter, then 'Review Batch' then 'Journals'
    Exercise: Review journal detail (3) -> Inquiry/Journal' then enter find criteria
    Exercise: Enter a journal -> GLVO/Journals/Enter, then 'New Journal' or 'New Batch'
    Exercise: Post a journal -> GLVO/Journals/Enter. Choose unposted journal from the 'Find' dialog, then 'Review Batch', 'More Actions', and 'Post' review the journal contents and subsequently post the journal. 'Requery' from the summary journals form refreshes the posting status for the journal.
    Exercise: Generate recurring journal (path 1)-> GLVO/Journals/Define/Recurring, to find an existing recurring batch for generation of actual journals, and click on 'Generate' to submit or schedule the generation process
    Exercise: Generate a recurring journal (path 2) -> GLVO/Journals/Generate/Recurring, to list all recurring journal sources, and set the period to generate the journal.

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Recurring Journals

        http://oraclefunctional.com/general-ledger/recurring-journals/
        http://erp.adpc.ae/OA_HTML/help/state/content/group.FND%3ALIBRARY%3AUS/locale.en_AE/navId.2/navSetId.iHelp/vtAnchor.t_recur_batch/vtTopicFile.iHelp%7CHelpServlet%7CUS%7CGL%7C@t_recur_batch/
