        http://oraclegl.blogspot.com/2007/12/recurring-journals.html

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Source References and Drill-Back
    If summary mode is used, detail audit trail references back to the feeder are maintained in GL_IMPORT_REFERENCES.
        This option is activated for each journal source in the Journal Sources form
        Drill back is possible directly if detail mode is used based on values placed in REFERENCE_1 through REFERENCE_10 on journal lines
    If detail mode is used, one or more of the RERFERENCE_X columns carries enough information to drill back to the source
        For Project Accounting
            REFERENCE_1 - Source Expenditure Batch Name
            REFERENCE_2 - Source Expenditure DR Code Combination
            REFERENCE_3 - Source Cost or Liability
        For Accounts Payable
            REFERENCE_1 - Vendor Name
            REFERENCE_2 - Invoice ID
            REFERENCE_3 - Invoice or Check Line
            REFERENCE_4 - Payment Document
            REFERENCE_5 - Invoice No
            REFERENCE_6 - Accounting Type
            REFERENCE_7 - Source ID
            REFERENCE_8 - Not used
            REFERENCE_9 - Document ID
            REFERENCE_10 - Line Type

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on AutoPosting
    Autoposting is performed by running the Autoposting concurrent process with a criteria set as the parameter
        Criteria sets can define multiple criteria rows with ranked priorities
        Criteria sets include: source, category, balance type and period
            For each value you have the option of entering 'ALL' to pick up all sources, categories, balance types and periods
            You can enable or disable an autoposting set through the 'Enabled' checkbox
    You can submit or schedule the Autopost process directly from the Autopost Criteria Set form
    The process produces an Autopost Execution Report
    If MRC is enabled an Autoposting set must be created in the reporting set of books to post those journals also

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Automatic Journal Reversals
    Automatic reversals are setup by Category in General Ledger
    A Profile Option must be set to trigger the 'Program - Automatic Reversal' after a period is opened
        Profile Option -> GL: Launch AutoReverse After Open Period

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Accounting Sequences and Sequence Numbers
    You can set a sequence number assignment automatically on a journal entry
    Sequences assigned to journals are based on category but not on source or any other attribute like balancing segment
        This means you may have to split companies by set of books if regulation requires that each company have their own sequence numbering rules
    Make sure the profile option 'Sequential Numbering' is set to 'Always Used' for the Site or Responsibility
        Otherwise you will get an error when entering the journal
    You first define a Sequence and then Assign it
    You have to set up an assignment as Manual on one line and Automatic on the second line if you need it to work both ways

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Reporting Sequences and Sequence Numbers
    See - R12 What are the Differences Between Accounting Sequencing and Reporting Sequencing? [ID 756774.1]
    GLXJEENT Document Number Is Not Generated On Journal Entries Header (Doc ID 1333891.1)
    Reporting Sequences are generated at period end by the close process to stamp a reporting sequence number on each journal
    The process is triggered in the Close
    Reporting sequences are used on regulatory reports for 'gapless' auditing

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Account Aliases
    Reference: Oracle Flexfields Guide, Chapter 5, 'Using Additional Flexfield Features'
    Account aliases can be defined to speed up entry of account values by naming combinations of accounts
    Aliases are flexfield functions and not specific to GL
    Navigation: <General Ledger Superuser>/Setup/Financials/Flexfields/Key/Aliases - and query back the correct key flexfield before to create a new alias
    Account aliases can be setup with null segments and these can be filled in on the fly during journal entry

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Journal Reversals
    Reversing journals are automated in 11i by setting up reversing rules
        They can be used to reverse accruals or depreciation after management reports are generated
    Exercise: Setup reversal rules -> 'General Ledger Super User'/Setup/Journal/AutoReverse

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Journal Upload via ADI (Application Desktop Integrator)
    You can default the Group ID on ADI uploads with the profile option GLDI: Create Group ID

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Account Analysis and Drilldown
    Exercise: Review an account -> General Ledger Superuser/Inquiry/Account -> and enter value in Accounts block.
        Then 'Show Balances'
    A new web front end for Account Analysis and Drilldown was introduced in 11.5.10 (Family Pack G)
        References: See Metalink Note 290012.1 May 2007
    The 'Summary Templates' feature cannot be used - see Oracle Note 414403.1
        There is an enhancement request to fix this bug
        The workaround is to drill up from the detail account to the summary after querying the detail account combinations
    The view XLA_PA_EI_AEL_GL_V provides drill back to Project Expenditure lines from GL Journal Batches with source 'Projects'

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Suspense Accounts
    Suspense accounts are defined for imported journals that are out of balance
    They can be defined by category and source

Genera Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Journal Approvals
    General Ledger uses workflow to implement a journal approval process - optional in GL
    It is not integrated with Approvals Management Enging (AME) and AME cannot be used
    The setup for Journal Approval is documented in the GL User Guide (separate chapter)
    There is a profile option "Journals:Find Approver Method" to use a custom approval hierarchy instead of employee/supervisor
    Approval is based on the value of the largest value journal line (on the basis each line has an approval limit)

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Opening Balance Loads for Balance Conversions
    See metalink note: 141069.1 How To Load Initial (Beginning) Balances Into General Ledger
    You must load opening balances as journals in the prior non-adjustment period
    Then the loaded values will appear as opening balances in the period needed

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Budgeting and Budget Upload:
    Budgeting and cost allocation supports management or cost accounting
        Other types of accounting are financial, tax, and non-profit or fund accounting
    Budget journals are entered to establish a budget.
    Budgets can also be uploaded from a spreadsheet as 'amounts' (replace existing) or journals (add to existing)
        A journal must specify the budget name since multiple budgets are possible
        A journal must also specify a budget organization
            The budget organization restricts which accounts in the budget will be maintained
            It also establishes the controls on those accounts
            Budget organizations are defined and associated with ranges of accounts
            This decentralizes budget entry through the business, such as the operating unit level.
            Budgets can be secured at the Budget Organziation level by password.
            You can have any number of budgets. Budget organizations apply across all budgets
            Account ranges in budget organizations cannot overlap between different budgets for the same set of books
            Budget range assignments (within ranges on budget organizations) allow adding or deleting individual accounts to a budget within a defined range
    Cost accounting is supported by incorporating a product and department (cost center) segment in the chart of accounts KFF structure
    Budget periods can be month, quarter, half year, or year and should coincide with the periods in the set of books for financial reporting
    Budgetary control in non-profit organizations limits expenditures to prevent exceeding budget amounts
        This is mandated by law for government and non-profit organizations
    Funds checking verifies available funds in a budget before accepting the transaction.
        Funds checking is advisory or absolute, and is implemented in the ledger and in subledger systems also
    Funds checking takes total budget and subtracts actual expenditures and encumbrances to calculate available funds
    Budgets can be entered via journals using 'budget' for the journal type
    An unlimited number of budget versions can be stored
    Budget Wizard
        References
            How to use Budget Wizard functionality in WebAdi (step-by-step) (Doc ID 471044.1)
        Profile Option 'GL: Default Desktop Viewer' must be set to Excel 2007 or another valid value
        Budgets can also be entered through the budget wizard within WebADI, or via OFA (Oracle Financial Analyzer)
            Budgeting through the webADI budget-specific wizard allows using formula
                This enables calculating new budgets based on old actuals, at the account balance level
    Massbudget is an allocation method for creating budgets
        It can take a high level budget and spread it across detailed accounts based on posted account balances
    Posting encumbrance or budget journals updates balances rolling forward to the end of the most recent open year.
    Budgets can be 'open' for entry, 'current' and active for a given period, or 'frozen' from further changes.
        A 'Frozen' budget cannot be changed
        An 'Open' budget can be updated or have no budgets loaded
        The 'Current' allows the same activities as an 'Open' budget and also defaults onto Budget-related maintenance forms
            You can only have one 'current' budget in a given period
            The option to  set a budget as current does not appear in the Status List of Values if an existing budget has the 'Current' status
    If accounts are added after a budget is defined, use the Maintain button on the budget organization form to update the budget ranges with these new accounts. A concurrent request is initiated
    Budget Upload is possible via webADI or by Uploading to GL_BUDGET_INTERFACE using SQL*Loader
        Budget Values are uploaded to GL_BUDGET_INTERFACE and replace existing budget amounts
        Budget Journals are uploaded to GL_INTERFACE and add to existing amounts
        Budgets are loaded into the GL_BUDGET_INTERFACE table and cannot be deleted if in error
            A SQL script must be used to delete budgets uploaded in error
            See: How To Delete Bad Data From The GL_BUDGET_INTERFACE Table (Doc ID 198481.1)
        Use ADI to load budgets via the responsibility: General Ledger SuperUser (or Manager)
            Navigate -> Journals -> Launch Journal Wiziard
        Configure the budget upload via the responsibility: General Ledger Desktop Integration (Web ADI)
            Navigate -> Define Mapping -> Choose Integrator = 'General Ledger - Budgets'
    Exercise: Define a budget -> GLVO/GLVO/Budgets/Define/Budget, to establish a budget and set the budget status,
        Open the budget for the next period
        Make the budget 'current' - not that only one budget can be current at any one time
        If the 'current' value does not appear, another budget is current and must be frozen to release the current status
    Exercise: Create a budget org -> GLVO/Budgets/Define/Organization, and set up an organization with account ranges, display sequence, password protection
    Exercise: Modify a budget org -> GLVO/Budgets/Define/Organization
    Exercise: Open budget periods -> GLVO/Budgets/Define/Organization/
       Change the end period (Last Date) to the end of a new year, then click 'Open Next Year'
    Exercise: Delete a budget org -> GLVO/Budgets/Define/Organization, and query the budget org, then click the Delete key to kick off the concurrent process
    Exercise: Enter a budget journal -> GLVO/Budgets/Enter/Journals, and specify the budget name and the budget organization for this journal. Enter the budget amounts and create the journal and batch (batch name required). Subsequently 'import' the journal to add it to the unposted journals file. View output from the import process to verify success. A subsequent posting step is required. This will create
    Exercise: Enter a budget amount -> GLVO/Budgets/Enter/Amounts (no audit trail), to enter a budget for a range of accounts, for each period in a budget year. Must specifify budget org and budget name.

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Encumbrances
    Encumbrances are used by non-profit organizations and are implemented in Oracle as a balance type.
    Encumbrances are reserves held against accounts to fund specific transactions such as purchase orders
    Recurring allocations can be setup to repeat every month
    Net allocations only allocate the net change in an account since the last allocation was performed
    Exercise: Enter an encumbrance -> GLVO/Journals/Encumbance

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Allocations:
    Allocations can be budget or actual using the MassBudget and MassAllocation tools
    Allocations can be applied to actual or encumbrance amounts through the MassAllocation tool also.
    Allocations can be setup and maintained through the autoallocations workbench in the GL: by defining an allocation set of several lines and defining if these lines are step down (sequential) or parallel
    Step down allocations cascade down, so the target of one allocation becomes the source for the second round of allocations
    Exercise: Generate an allocation journal -> GLVO/Journals/Generate/Allocation, and select an allocation journal to generate (only allocation journals are listed). It must subsequently be posted via normal journal entry/post

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Global Consolidation System (GCS)
    References
        https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18727_01/doc.121/e13627/T312864T314184.htm
    Navigation
        Responsibility -> General Ledger Super User
        Navigation -> <General Ledger Super User>/Consolidation/...
    Overview
        Consolidation is the period-end process of combining the financial results of separate subsidiaries with the parent company to form a single, combined statement of financial results. 
            The Global Consolidation System (GCS) provides the flexibility to help you manage your consolidation needs regardless of your company structure
        GCS is part of the General Ledger and is separate to Consolidation Hub which is a module within Enterprise Performance Foundation
            Consolidation Hub is a broader application than GCS with broader reporting and upload facilities
            GCS can be used for most consolidation tasks without the need to implement Consolidation Hub
        GCS combines the financial results of multiple subsidiaries with multiple sets of books at period-end into the parent set of books
            Companies with a common global set of books do not require GCS - they can use FSG to do their consolidations
                This is a 'reporting consolidation'
            Companies with different sets of books (different charts of accounts, currencies or calendars) should use GCS
                This is a 'data transfer consolidation'
        Includes preparing and posting consolidation data from subsidiaries to a Consolidation Chart of Accounts
        Elimination entries are prepared after posting to cancel out offsetting postings (e.g. purchases and sales)
        The accounting structures of the subsidiaries can vary widely
        Both budgets and actuals can be consolidated
        Source data for consolidation can include spreadsheets, non-Oracle applications and other Oracle General Ledgers
            An Open Consolidation Interface is available to import from non-Oracle Sources
    Mappings
        Mappings are defined from child entities to parent entities in GCS
        Mappings are built between Charts of Accounts (not ledgers) and are effective dated
        There are Segment Rules and Account Rules in mappings
        Account Rules override Segment Rules and directly map combination from the source to the parent ledger

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Enhanced Inter-Company Processing
    Enhanced intercompany processing was introduced in 11i with the concept of a Balancing Segment Qualifier
    It automatically creates balancing intercompany entries between two companies in the same Legal Entity and Set of Books
        It requires setting up of at least one clearing account
        Multiple clearing accounts can be setup based on source and category
        It also requires setting the 'Balance Intercompany Journals' flag on the set of books definition
    Additional sources of reference for enhanced intercompany transactions include:
        Metalink Note 151130.1 How Intercompany Journal Lines are Created in General Ledger 11i
        Metalink Note 72408.1  11i FAQ For General Ledger (includes section on Intercompany Balancing)

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Global Intercompany System (GIS/AGIS - previously CENTRA)
    Additional References: Metalink Note: 72408.1 11i FAQ for General Ledger
    GIS automates journal generation of intercompany (inter-balancing segment) jourals and approvals
        Inter-company can be inter-balancing segment or higher (i.e. between Legal Entities and between Sets of Books)
        It is most beneficial between Sets of Books because other methods can be used at lower levels
        For inter-company entries within the same set of books, manual or automated intercompany accounting can be used
        Automated intercompany accounting requires an inter-company segment in the chart of accounts
            Oracle generates intercompany entries using the inter-company account values
        For charts without an intercompany segment, GIS can be used at different levels ...
            For journals between balancing segments in the same legal entity, direct entry can be used
                Security rules must allow the user to post to the different balancing segments
                Amounts can be cleared through equity (CR account) for each company
            For journals between legal entities in the same set of books, direct entry can also be used
                A responsibility with the appropriate security rules must be used
                Clearing accounts (AR Clearing, AP clearing) must be used instead of equity
            For journals across sets of books, inter-company accounting using the inter-company segment cannot be used
                This is because the intercompany segment values don't exist on the set of books on either side
            GIS provides automatic exchange rate calculations and approvals
    GIS forces approvals of intercompany charges generated by the Oracle GL when different sets of books are used in a Journal
    Spreadsheet upload can be used to load large volumes of transactions
    Approval notifications are generated by workflows
        Users on both sides of the transaction must have access to Oracle Workflow to use it
        An email notification opens a workflow approval screen within Oracle for approvals
        However their GL's don't have to be Oracle on the other side of the transaction
        Oracle will create JE's in the GL_INTERFACE table which may be exported to the foreign GL
            Transactions are initially imported to the GL_IEA_INTERFACE table
            A process is run to validate the records and load them to GL_INTERFACE
            You can delete errored journal lines from GL_INTERFACE and resubmit
                Navigation -> <General Ledger Super User>/Journals/Import/Delete
    Receiver-side transactions can be generated automatically from GIS Sender entries
        The sender inputs the sender and receiver names and the type of transactions
            User-defined accounting rules for the sender/receiver/type derive receiver accounts based on sender entries.
            The intercompany clearing accounts are also tied to these types
            Note that clearing accounts are tied to the transaction type - the charge accounts are entered directly
            Each intercompany journal is specific to a sender/receiver/type
                This means larger 'distribution' journals from one sender to multiple receivers cannot be entered
        The receiver account distributions can be entered manually or derived automatically
            Automatic derivation is done through auto-accounting rules
    Currency conversion is automated - and performed after the transaction is approved on all sides
    GIS operates in two basic scenarios - common sets of books and dissimilar sets of books
        If the sets of books are different, a GIS Intercompany SOB must be defined for the dissimilar subsidiaries
        The Intercompany SOB is then mapped to the local set of books
    AGIS (Advanced Global Intercompany System)
        Responsibilities -> In Vision use Global Intercompany System - Vision Enterprises
        References - http://davidhaimes.wordpress.com/2008/02/13/intercompany-invoicing-in-agis/
        AGIS creates documents for inter-company accounting such as payable invoice and receivable invoices
            The intercompany documents include taxes
            The invoices are created in the AP and AR Invoice Import Interfaces for the respective counterparties
        Creation of documents is optional - journal entries can be created instead

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Statistical Amounts
    Statistical amounts are entered either with STAT currency or with units of measure (mixed)
        Either way they create STAT balances on GL_BALANCES when the journal is posted
        STAT Currency journals do not have a UOM - they have only a debit or credit amount as STAT currency
        You do not have to assign a UOM to an account to post a mixed journal and see the STAT balances in GL_BALANCES
    The profile option 'Journals: Mix Statistical and Monetary' must be enabled for mixed journal entry
    For mixed journals, each account has a default UOM assigned but this is optional
        Navigation: GL Superuser/Setup/Accounts/Units (saved in table GL_STAT_ACCOUNT_UOM)
        UOM's can be different for different accounts within the same chart of accounts
    Statistical amounts can be used to calculate allocation journals

General Ledger (GL Schema) Interfaces - including Journal Entries from Subledgers:
    FA: Asset Additions, Depreciation, Retirements
    PO: Encumbrances
    AP: Expense Invoices, Asset Invoices, Inventory Invoices, Supplier Payments
    AR: Sales Invoices, Cash Receipts, Adjustments, Cash Applications
    OM: Unbilled Receivables
    ADI: Journals, Budgets
    INV: Inventory Values, Cost of Sales
    GL: Consolidations Journals from on SOB to another SOB
    PAY: Payroll Expenses
    Journal Import Process- to import journals from Oracle subledger systems or from third party systems
        by populating GL_INTERFACE table and running the import process).
        Suspense can be corrected in the Correct Journal Import Data form
        Unwanted entries can be deleted using the Delete form (Navigatio -> <General Ledger Super User>/Journals/Import/Delete
    'Program - Import Journals' can be scheduled to import journals in SRS (added in 11.5.10)
        The program calls 'Journal Import'
        It is limited because it requires a Group ID (leaving blank will only import journals with no group id)
            Most subledgers put group id's on their journals so it cannot be used for this purpose

General Ledger (GL) Localizations:
    The chart of accounts in France is mandated to be a fixed structure
        the account numbers are mandated.
        A separate SOB can be established and GCS used to populate after month-end

General Ledger (GL Schema) Forms and Navigation:
    Journals -> GENERAL LEDGER/Journals/Enter - and query existing journals to display journal details
    Period Types -> GENERAL LEDGER/Setup/Calendar/Types - to establish period types before creating a calendar
    Calendars (Periods) -> GENERAL LEDGER/Setup/Calendar/Accounting - to create a calendar and each period within the calendar
    Set of Books -> GENERAL LEDGER/Setup/Financials/Books/Define - to associate a currency, calendar and chart of accounts and define a set of books
    Assign Reporting Sets of Books -> GENERAL LEDGER/Setup/Financials/Books/Assign - to associate multiple reporting sets of books to a primary set of books
    Import Journals -> General Ledger/Journals/Import/Run - to import transactions from the GL_INTERFACE table populated earlier by 'Transfer to GL' programs in feeder systems
    Correct Journal Import Data -> GENERAL LEDGER/Journals/Import/Correct - requires a Source to bring back errors to correct
    Journal Sources -> GENERAL LEDGER/Setup/Journals/Sources - to define sources and activate source references for drillback on summary imported journals
    Currency Conversion Rate Types -> GENERAL LEDGER/Setup/Currencies/Rates/Types - to view seeded types (Corporate/Spot/User) and define additional types
    Daily (Currency) Rates -> GENERAL LEDGER/Setup/Currencies/Rates/Daily - to enter daily currency exchange rates for any conversion type
    Summary Accounts -> GENERAL LEDGER/Setup/Accounts/Summary - to establish summary accounts based on rollup groups for online display
    Account Generator Processes -> SYSTEM ADMINISTRATOR/Applications/Flexfields/Key/Accounts - to associate account generator workflows with an AFF structure
    Account Hierarchy Editor -> via ADI
    Mass Maintenance Workbench -> ... to merge balances from multiple accounts to another, and otherwise maintain the chart of accounts structure

General Ledger (GL Schema) Concurrent Processes:
    Open Period - to open a new accounting period (also kicked off from Open/Close form in setup)
        This process creates new lines in GL_BALANCES to carry forward all the balances from the previous period
    Autopost - post journals on a repeating schedule based on criteria values: sources, categories, balance types and periods
    Program - Import Journals - can be scheduled in SRS to run journal import but it requires a group id - no group id will only import journals with a blank group id
    Inherit Segment Value Attributes - to synchronize changes in account segment attributes with GL Code Combinations

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Standard Reports and XML Publisher (BI Publisher) Reports:
    Trial Balance - list of account combinations for a single balancing segment (ie company), showing opening balance, activity and closing balance. A trial balance shows total debits for all accounts and for all accounts to prove that debits and credits across all accounts 'balance'. Trial balances are not company specific because they add up DR/CR's for all accounts
    Account Analysis - 132 char or 180 char showing account opening balance, period activity and closing balance
    Journals Execution Report - list of all failed transactions in the GL_INTERFACE table with reason codes why the transactions failed GL Journal import
    Three XML Publisher Reports were introduced in Family Pack G in May 2007 (Metalink Note 290012.1)
        Account Analysis
        Journals - General
        Trial Balance - Detail

General Ledger (GL Schema) Workflows:
    Account Generator - automatically builds valid account code combinations (a successor to Flexbuilder introduced in Rel 10)

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Key Tables:
    FND_CURRENCIES - defines each possible currency
    GL_BALANCES - balances for every code combination, currency and period
        There is one line in this table for each currency and previously opened period and there is always a line for the functional currency
        If the period has not been opened there are no lines
        The BEQ fields on each foreign currency line represent the 'Base Equivalent' values in the functional currency
        The functional currency line includes the total values for actual functional currency entries and all foreign currency BEQ values in the same period.
    GL_BUDGET_INTERFACE - loads budgets into GL directly
    GL_BUDGET_ASSIGNMENT_RANGES Budget assignments to budgeting organizations
    GL_BUDGET_INTERFACE Budget Import API Table
    GL_BUDGET_VERSIONS Budget versions
    GL_BUDGETS GL budgets
    GL_CODE_COMBINATIONS - stores the key flexfield combinations of valid account codes (in segments based on flexfield definitions)
    GL_DAILY_RATES Currency Conversion Rates
    GL_DAILY_RATES_INTERFACE Exchanges rates interface table
    GL_IMPORT_REFERENCES for link references to source transactions in subledgers if summary posting mode is used for any source
    GL_INTERCOMPANY_ACCOUNTS Intercompany (due to/from) accounts (for specific sources/categories)
    GL_INTERFACE - staging table for importing journal transactions into GL. The import process reads this table for transactions
    GL_INTERFACE_CONTROL Interface control
    GL_INTERFACE_HISTORY Historical references for previous journal imports (enabled by profile option 'GL: Archive Journal Import Data')
    GL_JE_BATCHES - journal batches
    GL_JE_HEADERS - journal headers (ie journals)
    GL_JE_LINES - journal lines
    GL_JE_SOURCES (and _TL) Journal Sources
    GL_LOOKUPS Lookup values
    GL_PERIODS - contains the calendar periods
    GL_PERIOD_SETS Period Sets or Period Types
    GL_PERIOD_STATUSES General Ledger period statuses open and closed periods
    GL_PERIODS General Ledger periods
    GL_REVAL_ACCOUNT_RANGES - account ranges in revaluation set
    GL_REVALUATIONS - revaluation set headers
    GL_SETS_OF_BOOKS - contains one row for each set of books
    GL_STAT_ACCOUNT_UOM - holds mappings between UOM's and accounts in each set of books
    GL_SUMMARY_TEMPLATES Summary templates
    GL_SUSPENSE_ACCOUNTS Suspense accounts (for specific sources and categories)
    HR_ORGANIZATION_UNITS - defines organizations at all levels from business group down to inventory organization
    FUN.FUN_BALANCE_OPTIONS - intracompany balancing options including default segment
    FUN.FUN_BALANCE_ACCOUNTS - intracompany balancing accounts

General Ledger (GL Schema) Notes on Key Views:
    XLA_PA_EI_AEL_GL_V - drill back to Projects Expenditure Items from GL Batches

Global Accounting Engine (AX) Notes:
    The Global Accounting Engine is used in countries with different accounting rules to GAAP in the US
    It replaces the journal transfers from subledgers to GL with an intermediate subledger system
    The Global Accounting Engine holds all journals from subledgers as draft entries
        The draft entries must be finalized before they can be posted to the GL
    Adjustments can be entered to the Global Accounting Engine directly, prior to finalization and GL posting

Hyperion Enterprise Notes on General Functionality:
    Oracle purchased Hyperion on 01 March 2007 for $3.3 Billion USD
        It is classified as EPM or Enterprise Performance Management Software
    Hyperion Enterprise is a financial collection, consolidation and reporting tool
        It supports adjustments and formatting processes in addition to collection
        Processes include:
            Foreign currency conversion
            Allocations
            Adjustments
            Intercompany Eliminations for consolidation (with full audit trail)
            Legal Ownership Rollup Reporting
        It supports US GAAP, International Accounting Standards (IAS) and local/regional standards
        It eliminates the collection and rekeying of data or spreadsheet manipulations
    A primary benefit of Hyperion Enterprise is shortening the financial close
    Hyperion Enterprise maintains date-effective rollup hierarchies to support backdated adjustments
    Access to Hyperion can be centralized via the web, or distributed to multiple clients and countries
    Hyperion integrates with Excel on the desktop
    Hyperion Enterprise has a Financial Data Quality Management add-on for additional data loading controls

Human Resources (HR and PER Schemas) Notes on Profile Options
    Profile option: HR User Type' must be set on the responsibility to 'HR' to access the the Employee Maintenance form
        This is often needed to enter an employee to create a buyer or approver
        The HR application must also be a shared install for this to work.

Human Resources (HR and PER) Responsibilities:
    Global HRMS Superuser HRSU

Human Resources (HR or PER) Notes on General Functionality:
    Jobs standardize qualifications and requirements and pay grades for similar functions across different parts of the organization
    Positions are instances of jobs within an organization hierarchy and are used to calculate headcount and salary budgets
    A role is a supertype of a position or a person and roles are used in workflows for approvals
        They can point back to either a person or a position (ie employee/supervisor hierarchy or position hierarchy)
    Contingent workers are non-employees who can be setup as people and tied to user id's but do not have to be entered on a payroll
    HR generates budgets that can be posted to the GL as budget journals for employee costs
    HR supports statutory reports: COBRA, OSHA, ADA, EEO, AAP and Vets-100 in the US
    Exercise: Create organizations -> GHRSU/Work Structures/Organizations/Description - to create an organization

Human Resources Notes on Creating New Employees:
    You must choose an action type on the new employee form before saving a new employee. Use action type = 'Create Employee'
    Create an assignment and attach the new employee to the correct organization/operating unit so they are visible in drop down lists
    Exercise: Add a new employee -> Human Resources Superuser/People/Enter and Maintain, and click 'New' on the Find window

Human Resources (HR or PER) Notes on Security, Security Groups, Security Profiles and Business Groups
    Tips and Trick
        Security List Maintenance must be run after defining and assigning security profiles
        In general, a user can only view the records for one business group at a time. 
        However, depending on the value of the HR:Cross Business Group Profile option, you can view specific information across business groups
    References
        How To Restrict Supplier Records By Operating Unit with HR Security Profile (Doc ID 1271666.1)
        Understanding and Using HRMS Security in Oracle HRMS [ID 394083.1]
    HR: Security Profile controls access in HR (i.e. business groups) whereas MO: Security Profile controls access in financial subledgers and operating units
        Since an org can be a business group and operating unit, HR Security Profile takes precedence over MO: Security Profile
    HR Security Profiles can be defined for each business group to limit what users can access within the HR/Payroll applications
    Security Groups determine the Business Groups a user can access
    Security Profiles determine the organizations a user can access within a Security Group
    A Security Profile represents a distinct client or business entity (or organization unit) within a single installation of HR
    A Security Profile can be attached to a responsibility to limit user access to HR data using the standard security model
    HR has a security model that can be the Standard Security Model or the Multiple Security Groups model
    Under the Multiple Security Groups model, one responsibility can be used for all security profiles - the system prompts for the security group separately
    Under the Standard Security Model, a separate responsibility was needed for each security profile established (ie HR Security Profile)
    Security profiles also enable the cross-business group security model in HRMS where one responsibility has access to data in multiple business groups
    Security profiles include qualifiers such as employee type (employee, contingent, recruit), organization top level of access, included or excluded sub organizations and associated business group
    Security profiles are specific to HR and not used in the other applications - they partition an HR implementation to limit access to individual clients
    Security profiles are assigned to responsibilities in HR. If only one seeded Security Group is defined, users will not be asked which security group to use, when they choose a responsibility
    In the Applications Utilities Lookups form, a 'Global Security Group' checkbox has been introduced with the Multiple Security Group model to make lists of values local to their business group
    If the profile option "HR:Business Group" is set to a different group that the one included in the "HR:Security Profile" profile option, HR Security will prevent access to data
    Profile Option -> HR:Security Profile - lists the Security Profiles created through the 'Define Security Profile' form and limits access to HR data (including organization definitions)
    Profile Option -> HR:Security Group is used to set the security group for a user and is attached to a responsibility
    Profile Option -> Enable Security Groups - is set to 'No' by default and should be set to 'Yes' before running the concurrent process 'Enable Multiple Security Groups'
    Do -> Create Security Profile: Global HRMS Super User/ and search for 'Define Security Profile'

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Getting Started
    Use an Internet Procurement responsibility to bring up the self-service webpage (like 'Internet Procurement')
        The responsibility must be a 'Self Service Web Applications' application to display the self service web page
    Verify the securing attributes ICX_HR_PERSON_ID and TO_PERSON_ID are set on the user record
        Both values must be set to the 'Person' employee number from the HR system
        Without this setup, the message "<responsibility> is not a valid responsibility for the current user"
            Try reassigning the person values to the securing attributes and logging out/logging in again.
        The Internet procurement application require a person on a user record before entering the application
            This is done because iProc needs to access an approval hierarchy in HR for approvals)

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Best Practices:
    Internet procurement is a best practice
        by putting requisitioning and receiving into the hands of the requestors,
        generalizing requisitions in an organization and
        eliminating centralized requisitioning
    Centralized purchasing combined with decentralized requisitioning and receiving

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Tips and Tricks:
    Before creating requisitions, create personal profile defaults for charge accounts or add a default charge account to the assignment purchasing region in Human Resources
    Use Power Checkout to delete multiple selected rows from a cart, to update accounting on selected rows and to add supplier/site sourcing details on unsourced catalog items
    You can find the purchase order number of an approved requisition on the details page of the requisition status in iprocurement
    Requistions that are incomplete can be viewed in the shopping cart but cannot be viewed in the core applications
    The basic iProcurement process is: shop catalog, checkout (delivery info, billing info, notes, approvers, review and submit)
    An iProcurement installation without Core Apps includes shared HR and Purchasing tables
    The default charge account which is changeable during checkout is set as the default charge account for purchase orders for the requestor
    A single item can be split across multiple accounts on a percentage basis by clicking the charge account link in checkout and choosing the option to enter multiple accounts
    Project accounting can be manually recorded on requisition lines including project number, task and expenditure type
    Requisitions can be copied to create new requisitions
    As of 2001 it was not possible to requisition items for internal sourcing from inventory in iProcurement.
    Make or buy is an attribute on the item master that decides if an item is to be received into expense or inventory
    The profile option 'POR: Enable Requisition Line Customization' controls customizations on requisitions and can be turned off for troubleshooting

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Troubleshooting:
    The main "Requisitions" form in Oracle Forms won't find an iProc Requisition (or any requisition)
        Use the "Requisitions Summary" form to find iProc requisitions in Oracle Purchasing

Internet Procurement (iProc, ICX and POR) Personalization and Customization
    You can customize the menus under iProcurement responsibility to exclude sub-menus and functions from appearing on the web forms

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on 'My Profile' Settings (Requisition Preferences)
    My Profile allows setups/defaults for delivery, billing (including projects), favorite charge accounts, display preferences and password changes
    Delivery defaults include: need by date, requestor, deliver to (address and subinventory)
    Billing defaults include project details: project number, task, award, expenditure type, expenditure org and expenditure item date
    Favorite charge accounts allow users to setup short-name combinations of charge accounts and select them during checkout
    Display preferences in iProcurement are the same as display preferences in Self Service through the portal 'Preferences' menu item.
        Changing preferences in one place changes them for both
    If the error displays when looking at this page
        "You have encountered an unexpected error. Please contact the System Administrator for assistance"
        a likely cause is "when the location for the requester is not setup and the profile "POR: Preferences-Deliver to location"
        See metalink note: 444479.1
        a second cause is the profile option "POR Preferences - Expenditure Org" which should be set to a valid org_id (not an org name)
    Preferences Profile Options include:
        POR: Preferences - Award
        POR: Preferences - Deliver-to Location
        POR: Preferences - Project
        POR: Preferences - Expenditure Type
        POR: Preferences - Project
        POR: Preferences - Expenditure Org
        POR: Preferences - Requester
        POR: Preferences - Selected Items Default to Inventory
        POR: Preferences - SubInventory
        POR: Preferences - Task
        POR: Preferences - Expenditure Item Date Offset
        POR: Preferences - Expenditure Org
        POR: Days Needed By

Internet Procurement (iProc, ICX and POR) Setup Steps:

    Catalog attributes, catalog groups and catalog items

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on the Web Applications Dictionary (WAD):
    The Web Applications Dictionary is repository of metadata that is used to build webpages
        It is customizable and can be edited to change the appearance of web pages
        It can be used to customize iProcurement web pages
    The WAD allows hiding and showing of base descriptors in the catalog
    Oracle uses PL/SQL to generate web pages from the Web Applications Dictionary
    The responsibility "Self Service Web Applications Manager" is used to customize these webpages
    Display Manager is a middle tier java program that reads the repository and renders the pages
        It uses the region definition and and XML User Interface Template
    Custom webpages can be built in addition to modifying existing pages
        Create or change attributes via the "Self Service Web Applications Manager" responsibility
        Choose "Attributes/Define Attributes"
        Also define new objects via the "Object Workbench"
        Attach attributes to the object
        Create unique keys to sort the display
        Set the primary key on the object definition
        assign new attributes to PO_DUMMY_O object
        associate foreign keys to PO_DUMMY_O
    Choose the Regions Menu to define a single row or multi-row region
        also tag which items belong to a specific region
    Terminology
        Object -> a database view upon which a web form is built
        Attributes -> reusable fields on a web page
        Object Attribute -> an attribute that is tied to an object or database value
        Region -> an area on a webpage
        Region Item -> an attribute that is associated with a specific region
        Flow -> a series of web pages

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on the Catalog and eContent Manager (ECM):
    The internet procurement internal unified catalog is in the ICX schema. This catalog is separate from the Oracle Purchasing catalog
    The catalog structure for the unified iprocurement catalog is typically flat, with base and local descriptors to aid searching
    Base descriptors are common attributes such as names, uoms, prices, apply to all items in the catalog. They can be hidden or visible. Seeded base descriptors cannot be changed
    Local descriptors apply to all items in a specific category. Examples are shape, color, and size. Local descriptors can be hidden and are always optional
    Descriptors in the Oracle Purchasing Catalog are called 'Descriptive Elements' and are defined at the category level
    Purchasing categories must be loaded into iProcurement before items are loaded - by using Loader Values in Oracle Purchasing
    The two methods of loading are 'extract and load' from Purchasing, or Bulk Load from external catalogs
    ECM (eContent Manager) supports schema editing: adding, deleting and renaming categories, base descriptors and local descriptors.
    ECM allows for mapping purchasing categories to iProcurement categories - through the ECM Category Mapper utility
    Each iProcurement category must map to only one purchasing category so that requisitioned items inherit the purchasing category attributes
    Several iProcurement categories can map to the same purchasing category
    ECM provides a reverse mapper to map iProc classifications back to Purchasing Categories - Special Order Mapping Utility in ECM
    The ECM Classifier assigns items to categories and definition of categories on the fly. XML category files can also be uploaded
    Only purchasing categories in the purchasing category set are mappable - the purchasing category set is the default set for purchasing items
    ECM allows definition of a table of contents: master, intermediate (contains genus categories) and genus (contains base items) categories
    Titles are groupings of categories at the highest level and comprise the table of contents on the iProcurement home page (ie catalog level)
    Items that can be loaded are: items from the item master, requisition templates, blanket PO's, catalog quotes, approved supplier lists
    One item in a catalog can be assigned to multiple categories - updating the item information and the change will be reflected in all assigned categories
    Requisition templates are extracted from Purchasing to iProcurement using the same method as purchasing categories
    Catalog quotations created in the purchasing catalog and downloaded to the iProc catalog contain supplier price quotes and supplier part references
    Bulk Loaded catalog items do not exist in the purchasing catalog (no part number) and are loaded directly into the iProcurement catalog
    The catalog search engine is based on Oracle ConText server and Intermedia - it was previously based on 'BugsEye' technology
    Catalogs can be loaded from XML using the Java Loader or using spreadsheet .csv files via eContent Manager
    TPN Register is a major third party catalog for supplies with Oracle integration
    Requisite and TPN Register are content providers that provide compatible catalogs to load into the iProcurement unified catalog
    Exercise: Setup loader values and do adhoc loads from Purchasing -> SSIPSU/Setup/E-Catalog Admin/Loader Values .....to transfer classification data and item data from purchasing
    Exercise: Edit Attribute 10 of the Inventory DFF  'Item Categories' -> SSIPSU/Setup/Flexfields/Descriptive and query the DFF for the Inventory Application
    Exercise: Rebuild the ConText index after changing the catalog -> IPCA/Requests/New/Rebuild Catalog Item Context, to rebuild the indices for searching using the intermedia index
    Bug: Two or more catalog load responsibilities assigned to the same user may prevent access to eContent Manager functions

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Building a Catalog Schema and Table of Contents
    You cannot edit an empty category to add subcategories - you must have at least one subcategory to add additional categories later
    To add subcategories to an empty category, delete the category in the schema editor and re-add it with a sub category in the hierarchy manager

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Bulk Loading Categories and Items to the iProc Catalog
    Bulk loading categories and catalog items and price lists is done from the eContent Manager, Bulk Load section
    There are several tools available in Content Manager: Download Resources, Bulk Load Catalog Structure, Bulk Load Items and Price Lists, and View Bulk Load Status
    'Download Resources' downloads a template spreadsheet and a set of instructions for performing all types of bulk load
    Bulk Load Catalog Structure uploads a completed spreadsheet of catalog categories to insert into the iProcurement Catalog
    Any new categories in the Items and Prices upload spreadsheet will not load unless the profile option POR: Load Auto Category is set to 'YES'. The default is 'NO'
    For debugging, the profile option POR: set debug loader should be 'ON' to create exception lines in POR_BATCH_JOBS and ICX_POR_FAILED_LINES_MESSAGES
    Exercise: Review the POR: Load Auto Category profile option -> Sysadmin/Profile/System and query the profile option 'POR: Load Auto Category'
    Exercise: Run the bulk loader -> IPCA/eContent Manager/Bulk Load Item and Price Lists/ .... and specify the file to upload

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Catalog Loading Methods:
    There are four ways to load the catalog: java loader, manual loading, extract from Purchasing, and .csv spreadsheet upload via eContent Manager
    The Java loader loads an XML file and allows category/item/descriptor adds, changes and deletes. It is the method used by Oracle Exchange
    Categories and local descriptors can be dynamically added with Java Loader for new items if the categories don't already exist
    The Java loader is run from the command line with the xml file and several run options as command line options
    A .csv file can be loaded from within the applications by choosing Catalog Authoring page and the Data Load button
    A .csv file that is targeted in an upload can be saved back as an xml file for uploading through the Java loader
    The order of columns containing descriptors in the .csv file must match the order that descriptors are chosen for loading in ECM
    Exercise: Load a .csv file to the catalog -> IPCA/Catalog Authoring/Bulk Load Items and Price Lists, and point to the .csv file to upload.

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Loading the Catalog from Purchasing
    References
        What Are The Steps For Enabling Items In The Procurement Catalog? [ID 751324.1] -- for inventory items in R12
        FAQ - Rel 12 iProcurement [ID 396243.1] -- describes R12 real time integration of the Inventory Item Catalog and iProcurement
        How to Flag a Category or Item to be Accessible in iProcurement (Doc ID 281368.1)
        Web Enabled Categories are not Extracted from Purchasing to iProcurement (Doc ID 230054.1)
        How To Diagnose A Problem In The Item Catalog 11i (Doc ID 382592.1)
        Item Attributes (Chapter 6: R12 Inventory User's Guide in a Note) (Doc ID 733859.1)
    For the first extract from purchasing, you must use the Define Catalog Server Loader values window - following times can be done by running the concurrent processes directlty
    You must run the concurrent process: Catalog Data Extract - Classifications to extract categories from Purchasing into iProcurement
    The run date is used to determine what incremental changes to migrate - set the date to an earlier date to pick up all items in the transfer
    Since descriptive elements are attached to the catalog groups in core purchasing, they do not migrate to local descriptors in iProcurement
        since only item categories and not catalog categories are loaded across
    You must run the concurrent process: Catalog Data Extract - Items to extract from the purchasing catalog
    Attribute 10 of the Inventory DFF 'Item Category' must be set to 'Y' for all categories to load from Purchasing to iProcurement through the extract
    The Catalog Data Extract can be scheduled to run at regular intervals (daily, weekly and so on)
    The concurrent process 'Catalog Data Purge' must be run to delete inactive catalog quotes, blanket agreements, items and requistion templates from the catalog
    Catalog purge only deletes expired quote/template/blanket items in the iProcurement catalog that were loaded through the purchasing interface
    A system directory must be defined for the file extracted from Purchasing to load to iProcurement - set as a utl_file_dir = /home/Oracle/outbound
    The profile options ECE: Output and ECE: Inbound must point to the utl_file_dir
    Rejected lines in the export are stored in ICX_POR_FAILED_LINES,and ICX_POR_FAILED_LINE_MESSAGES
    ICX_POR_PRICE_LISTS and ICX_POR_PRICE_LIST_LINES are populated by the loader process also
    Add-hoc loads can be done through the 'Define Catalog Server Loader Values' window in the core applications (SSIPSU responsibility)
    After loading the catalog, you must rebuild the search indices in Oracle ConText. Run the concurrent program: Rebuild Catalog Item Context
    Exercise: Run the catalog load -> PSU/E-Catalog Admin/Loader Values, brings up the 'Define Catalog Server Loader Values' window to load categories and items, ASL's, templates
    Exercise: Run the category load concurrent process -> PSU/Requests/New Requests/Catalog Data Extract - Classifications
    Exercise: Run the item load concurrent process -> PSU/Requests/New Requests/Catalog Data Extract - Items
    Exercise: Run the catalog purge -> PSU/Requests/New Requests/Catalog Data Purge

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Requisite Technologies:
    Requisite Technology is a catalog content aggregator. They supply content from others: Grainger (parts), Corporate Express (office supplies), and Ikon (office equipment) are examples
    The Requisite catalog structure is proprietary but based on the UNSPSC structure

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Catalog Units of Measure:
    Units of measure in iProc are defined in ECM and are not the same as the UOM's defined in purchasing and inventory core applications
    UOM's in iProcurement are not inventory org specific
    The UOM names defined in ECM and loaded into iProc must exactly match the names of the UOM's in the core applications

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Punchout:
    A punchout to an external catalog is identified as a separate item source
    Punchout is setup through eContent Manager
    A site level profile option must be set to point to the punchout digital certificate for https authentication

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Images in the Catalog
    Images can be loaded into the OA_MEDIA directory (eg /u987/appsofd2/ofd2comn/java/oracle/apps/media) which is under the java top
    The reference to the file can be loaded into a catalog quote in Core Applications, and extract/loaded across
    The file name is entered into the descriptive flexfield of the catalog quote line
        use a file name relative to the OA_MEDIA directory (eg file.ext only if loaded into the OA_MEDIA top)
    The profile option POR: Hosted Images Directory must be set to /media/ which is the default subdirectory where images are placed.
    Profile options POR: Thumbnail Height and POR
        Thumbnail Width allow setting the size of thumbnails on search results but do not control the size of the full images displayed on the detail pages

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Public and Personal Shopping Lists:
    Shopping lists speed up common orders by listing commonly purchased items. Lists can be made public and shared with other users
    Public lists and personal favorites shopping lists are not updated when catalog items are updated
    Public lists can be copied to the shopping cart at the heading level of from within the list lines view
    If you copy a public list from the header level to the shopping cart, it copies the default quantities and accounts. From the line level it does not copy these values.

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Information Templates
    Information templates are supported in the iProc catalog and define additional information that accompanies an item on a requisition.
    Information templates contain attributes that have LOV's and default values - they can be attached to a single item or to a purchasing category to apply to multiple items
    It is not necessary to reimport items to the iProc catalog after defining an information template and attaching it to the item or category
    Although information templates are setup in core purchasing (iProc responsibility) they are only used in iProcurement
    A requisitioner will be prompted to enter template information during the checkout process if an information template is associated with the item or category chosen
    The LOV column on info template definitions is not used by iProcurement - LOV lists are not attachable to information templates in 11.5.8 - not yet implemented
    Attribute names defined in information templates become the field prompts in iProcurement when the template is displayed
    Exercise: Create information templates -> SSISPU/Setup/Information Templates

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Realms
    Realms are sets of access privileges to internal catalogs, internal catalog categories, and external catalogs
    Realms can be defined based on an internal catalog category or an item source.
    Sources are broad restrictions and include: internal catalog, external (punchout) catalog.
    Realms are implemented as securing attributes for responsibilities and user profiles
    Realms are inclusive rules and not exclusionary - you cannot exclude selected items from an included realm. This is an issue with realm implementation
    You cannot enforce restrictions within a realm - all items within a realm are available to the person who is assigned the realm.
        Separate categories are required to work around this restriction
    You cannot use realms to enforce content restrictions on punchouts to external catalogs
    Exercise: Define a realm -> SSIPSU/Setup/E-Catalog Admin/Realms and select item source or item category as the definging attribute
    Exercise: Attach a realm to a responsibility and user -> Sysadmin/Security/Responsibilities/Securing Attributes, and add ICX_POR_REALM_ID as an attribute

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Taxes:
    A Tax code is defaulted to the billing checkout screen of a requisition if the purchasing tax hierarchy is activated in Purchasing
    Tax codes default onto requisitions, purchase orders and blanket releases if the purchasing tax hierarchy is established
    The purchasing tax hierarchy allows ordered defaulting of tax codes from: ship-to location, item, supplier, supplier site, financial options

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Shopping, Checkout and Requisitions:
    A requisition number is assigned to a the contents of a shopping cart when it is first saved
    A requisition created in iProcurement can be viewed in the Oracle Purchasing application
        Use the "Requisition Summary" form to find these requisitions - not the "Requisitions" form
            Searching for a requisition through the "Requisitions" form doesn't return anything
    There are three methods of checkout: normal checkout, express checkout and power checkout
    Express checkout and power checkout require default options to be set at the user profile level
    Express checkout defaults the deliver-to, sub-inventory, name and days to receive from the user profile
        The deliver-to defaults from the users assignment location on their HR employee record
        A one-time address can be entered for the deliver-to address if needed
            This can be done during checkout on a catalog or non-catalog request
            Oracle does not create a new location for this one time address
            It is passed to the purchase order as a one-time deliver-to address
        The location record has a Ship-To location which becomes the ship-to on the purchase order
    Power checkout includes the Express Checkout defaults and also adds approvals, allows line splitting of distributions
    Attachments can be added to requisitions in the final stages of checkout
    There are several attachment types: internal, miscellaneous, to approver, to buyer, to receiver and to supplier
        Attachments which are internal or miscellaneous go on the requisition only and do not appear to others
        Attachments to the approver appear in the approver's window for the requisition
        Attachments to the buyer appear in the autogenerate window for the buyer creating the purchase orders
        Attachments to the supplier are printed on the purchase order and appear in the iSupplier portal
    The inventory organization on a requisition line defaults from the inventory organization assigned to the location
    If there is no inventory organization assigned to the location, the inventory organization is defaulted from the financial options for the operating unit assiged to the responsibility
                The inventory organization for a requisition line cannot be changed in iProcurement - however it can be changed in the core applications

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Contractor Requests
    Contractor request lines cannot be combined with non-contractor request lines in the same shopping cart or requisition
        Oracle will start a new shopping cart or contractor requisition if mixed shopping is performed.

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Automatically Generating PO's from iProcurement Requisitions
    See this topic under Purchasing for information on how to automatically create purchase orders from requisitions
        Profile option settings are required together with a blanket purchase order

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Cancelling Requisitions:
    You can cancel a requisition if it has not created an open purchase order, otherwise the purchase order must be cancelled first
    If you select a requisition to cancel in iProcurement and it has an active purchase order, the check box to choose each line to cancel does not appear.

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Accounting Distributions:
    Account Generator generates charge account distributions from the project (custom), item (for inventory destinations), from the user assignment (for expense destinations, including projects) and user profile favorites list
    Account Generator rules are based on destination type:
        inventory or expense or shop floor.
        Expense destinations can be inventory (expense items) or non-inventory
    All bulk loaded items are expense destination types by default.
        If an inventory destination is required, the items must be defined in core purchasing and extracted and loaded.
    If an item is bulk loaded rather than defined in core purchasing and inventory ...
        there is insufficient information on the item to allow a destination type of inventory.
    For items extracted and loaded from core purchasing ...
        the destination type is defaulted from the item attribute 'Inventory Asset Value' in the costing region of the master item window
    If the 'Inventory Asset Value' checkbox is blank, the item is a non-inventoried expense item and is assigned a destination type of 'expense'.
        If it is checked, the destination type is Inventory
    For destination type of 'Inventory' ...
        the 'Asset Subinventory' checkbox on the subinventory record is checked
            to see if it is an expense subinventory (destination type = expense) or asset subinventory
    The order of precedence for obtaining a charge account for an expense destination type item is:
        Item default charge account,
        item category charge account,
        employee default charge account
    A user can define and name and save overriding charge account distributions
        This is done in 'My Profile' in iProcurement
        The user can choose one of these distributions through power checkout
    However if the item is a bulk loaded item and not defined in core purchasing, the order of precedence is: Item Category charge account, employee assignment default charge account
    The default charge account for an employee is set in the employee assignment record, in the 'Purchase Order Information' alternate region.
    A requisitioner can split the charge account distributions on a requisition in checkout by clicking on 'Multiple Account Distributions' in the accounting checkout window
    Exercise: Setup default charge account for expenses for item -> Purchasing Superuser/Items/Master Items/Purchasing Region
    Exercise: Setup accounts for categories -> ProcuretoPay/Purchasing Setup/Financials/Accounts/Expense Account Rules, and enter the expense account for each category
    Exercise: Setup default charge accounts for employees (HR installed) -> HRVE/People/Enter and Maintain/ and find an employee, then navigate to Assignments/Purchase Order Info (alternate region)
    Exercise: Setup favorite charge accounts for employees in iProcurement -> IPSU/iProcurement/Home Page/My Profile, and edit/add favorite account code combinations

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Receiving
Items are eligible for receiving in iProcurement if the PO shipment line is "Open for Receiving" and the receipt routing is "Direct"
    Items eligible for receiving can be restricted to a single inventory organization by setting the profile option POR_ORGANIZATION_ID at the user level
        This limits viewing receipts to a single inventory organization
    The direct routing allows the user to create a receiving and delivery transaction in a single entry
    Inspection and receiving can be recorded by an employee in iProcurement directly, rather than in purchasing/receiving.
    The default receipt routing must be set to 'Direct' in iProcurement for receiving - this is set in receiving options
    The default receipt routing can be overridden at the item level receiving options, for master items and for organizational items
    The actual receipt routing on a purchase order can be viewed through the Receiving Controls tab on the PO shipment line
    Return items can be recorded if a supplier sends and RMA transaction via iSupplier Portal
    Users can receive a workflow notification of overdue receipts and respond: fully received, not received, partially or over-received, or reassign
    Temporary reassignments can be set on the 'Notification Reassignments' form for 'Requisition Approvals' and for 'Confirm Receipts' - from the notification
    Profile Option: POR: Enable Blind Receiving - when set to 'No' defaults the quantity available and displays the quantity received and quantity ordered columns
    Profile Option: POR: Support Review for Express Receive - when set to 'No' takes the receiver past the 'Receive Items:
        Review and Submit' page directly to the 'Receive Items: Confirmation' page
    Exercise: Receive Items - SSIPSU/Requisition Status/Receiving
    Exercise: Return Items - SSIPSU/Requistions Status/Receiving/Return Items

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on P-Cards:
    P-Cards in iProcurement apply to all lines on a requisition and cannot be different on each line
    A default P-Card number is setup in the user default profile for iProcurement
    Oracle Payables must be setup to allow P-Cards (several steps) and the supplier site P-Card Allowed check box must be set

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Projects Integration:
    Use My Profile to set the default project, task and expenditure type to default onto the checkout details of a requisition

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Notes on Inventory Integration
    Use My Profile to set the default receiving inventory location and subinventory location for receiving into inventory directly

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) User Exercises:
    Update Profile and Preferences -> INTERNET PROCUREMENT/Home Page/...My Profile Link (at base of homepage)..,
        to edit receiving location/subinventory, search starting subinventory, display date, return row count and password
    Create non-catalog requisition -> INTERNET PROCUREMENT/Home Page/... Non-Catalog Request link (left of homepage)... to create a non-catalog requisition
    Create information templates for items -> IPSU/Setup/Information Templates

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Profile Options:
    The profile option 'PO:Allow Requisition Approval Forward Action' enables requistion and po approval workflows to forward to the next approver if the current approver times out
    The profile option 'POR_ORGANIZATION_ID' limits what can be received in iProcurement to a single inventory organization
    The profile option 'POR: Enable Requisition Line Customization' controls customizations on requisitions and can be turned off for troubleshooting

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Concurrent Requests
    Workflow Background Process - for both the PO Approval Workflow, and for the PO Requisition Approval Workflow (ie start both processes)
    Workflow Notification Mailer
    Confirm Receipts Workflow
    Catalog Extract Data: Classifications - extracts the categories from the Purchasing catalog and loads into iProcurement
    Catalog Extract Data: Items - extracts the items from the Purchasing catalog and loads into iProcurement
    Rebuild Catalog Item Context - rebuilds the ConText search indices to make new additions to the iProc catalog searchable
    PO Document Approval Manager
    Receiving transaction Manager
    Catalog Data Purge - to delete items and catalog quotes in iProc that have been deleted from the core supplier item catalog
    Catalog Data Extract - classifications, .. extracts classifications from the core purchasing module and puts them into the iProcurement catalog
    Catalog Data Extract - items (extracts items from the core purchasing module to the iProcurement catalog

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Workflows:
    Workflows for internet procurement are setup in core purchasing.
        The profile option 'PO: Allow Requisition Approval Forward Action' enables forwarding if an approver times out
    PO Requistions Approval  - submits requistions to approvers
    PO Approval - submits purchase orders to approvers
    PO Document Creation - initiated if automatic sourcing rules are defined using:
        ASL's, blanket PO's, catalog quotes, and from the Create Release concurrent process
        This workflow is used to manage the autocreation of purchasing documents.
        PO Document Creation Workflow is initiated when you define automatic sourcing rules
            using an ASL, blanket purchase orders or catalog quotes and the Create Release concurrent process.
            Oracle Self-Service Purchasing 5 references contract purchase agreement with a supplier site as a part of sourcing.
            An automatic workflow process creates a standard purchase order referencing the contract purchase agreement.
            This workflow has been enhanced for automating the creation of standard purchase orders even if quotations with specific item information do not exist.
            Based on the supplier and supplier site on the requisition line, the workflow looks for a valid contract purchase agreement in Oracle Purchasing.
            If a valid contract purchase agreement is found, the requisition line is automatically placed on a standard purchase order
                with a reference to the contract purchase agreement on the purchase order line.
            This functionality can be enabled by setting the workflow attribute CONTRACT_ID.
            If this attribute is set to  Y , Contract Purchasing Agreements can be used to create standard POs.

    Change Order (sub process)
    PO Send Notifications for Purchasing Documents
        notifies approvers or originators of requisitions and PO's that are incomplete, rejected or requiring reapproval.
    PO Account Generator - builds charge, budget, accrual and variance accounts for for releases, requisitions and purchase orders
    PO Confirm Receipts - notifies requestors and buyers to confirm receipts where the need by date or promise date has passed
    PO Catalog Price Tolerance Exceeded - triggered when a catalog item is loaded and exceeds the price tolerance set for the item

Internet Procurement (iProc ICX and POR) Key Tables:
    All iProcurment tables are owned by the ICX (Internet Commerce) Schema and have an ICX_POR prefix
    ICX_POR_ITEMS (and _TL) - catalog items
    ICX_POR_CATEGORIES - catalog categories
    ICX_POR_CATEGORY_ITEMS - intersection of catalogs and items
    ICX_POR_DESCRIPTORS - descriptors associated with each category
    ICX_POR_ORACLE_ITEM_SUBTABLE - contains item details of blanket agreement numbers, templates and organizations
    PO_RULE_EXPENSE_ACCOUNTS -- Expense Account Rules
