Internet Sourcing (PON) Responsibilities
    Sourcing Buyer (SB)
    Sourcing Super User (SBU)
    Sourcing Supplier (SS) - used by Supplier contacts to respond to RFP/RFI/Auctions

Internet Sourcing (PON) Tips and Tricks:
    You cannot do supplier self registration through the Sourcing Supersuser responsibility - must go to separate URL for self registration
    You can register any supplier in Oracle as an iSupplier by creating and associating an iSupplier user through Supply Base in Purchasing Superuser (Register Supplier User)
    Standard PO's or blanket PO's can be automatically generated from the results of an sourcing auction or RFx or offer activity
    Registration of user contacts populates the TCA tables whereas normal supplier contact maintenance in core does not - must use self registration forms

Internet Sourcing (PON) Notes:
    There are three types of sourcing negotiations: RFX, Auction/Bid and Offer/Counteroffer
    RFX (involves RFI to qualify suppliers and RFQ to get quotations) are for complex configure-to-order items - takes days or weeks to complete
        An RFI is a Request for Information - a request for basic background information on an potential supplier
        An RFI is processed before an RFQ is sent in order to qualify the supplier for minimum commercial standards before issuing an invitation to bid.
    Auction/Bid are for standard items that can be competitively bid - takes only hours to complete
    Offers and counteroffers are between a single buyer and single seller for unique items where price needs to be negotiated/discovered between buyer and seller
    Negotiation styles can be: Open (auction), blind (auction, RFQ and Offer), and Sealed (Auction, RFQ)
    Sourcing can result in a purchase order or blanket agreement but not a catalog quotation, because a catalog quotation is not a commitment to buy
    Events are collections of auctions that occur at the same time - a group of related auctions or RFQ's. They help to monitor multiple RFQ's at once, as related activities
    Price elements are components of negotiation items. Price elements can include training, installation, consulting and related services. They can be negotiated as part of the RFQ
    Scores between 1 and 100 are based on attributes and weighted scores are the sum of scores multiplied by their individual weights
    Do Register Supplier User -> Purchasing Superuser/Supply Base/Supplier User Management/Register Supplier User

Internet Sourcing (PON) Notes on Supplier and Supplier User Registration
    Run the 'get org hash' key process in Unix to create a hash key web page to register a supplier and supplier user
    Alternatively, set up a supplier through forms and then register a user against the supplier
    Exercise: Register Supplier User -> Purchasing Superuser/Supply Base/Supplier User Management/Supplier User Creation/Register Supplier User (note - click 'search' w/out trying to enter a match string)

Internet Sourcing (PON) Notes on RFQ's in Core vs Sourcing
    RFQ's can be generated from requisitions in the Core Applications for a core RFQ or a Sourcing RFQ
    To choose sourcing RFQ in the Autocreate process for core requisitions, set the profile option PO: Allow Autocreation of Oracle Sourcing Docments = "Yes"

Internet Sourcing (PON) Notes on Collaboration Teams:
    Each person identified on a collaboration team as an approver must approve an RFI or RFQ before it can be published.

Internet Sourcing (PON) Notes on Events:
    You must future date the start of an even when you create it, or the event will be deemed to have started and will not show up in the event list on the RFQ/RFI definition page
    If an RFx or auction is attached to an event, it cannot be opened any earlier than the event open date, and the 'open immediately' option for the RFx is disabled

Internet iSupplier Portal (POS) Tips and Tricks:
    You must enable self registration for every organization in 11.5.9 to allow suppliers to register themselves

Internet Supplier Portal (POS) Profile Options:
    POS: External Responsibility Flag - assign to responsibilities
        to allow those responsbilities to be assigned to external users
        through the Administration page for external supplier userss

Internet Supplier Portal (POS) Notes:
    The scope of iSupplier Portal includes the complete procure to pay process:
        Registration - suppliers can enter their own details
            email preferences can be used to set HTML mail delivery method for notifications.
        RFQ's - suppliers can download requests and submit quotations
        Forecast and Planning Schedules - suppliers can view forecast demand
        Purchase Orders - suppliers can view and amend purchase orders
        ASN's - suppliers can advise shipments
        Receipts and Invoices - suppliers can view receipts and enter invoice
        RMA's - suppliers can enter RMA's requested by the receiver or buyer
    Self registration allows suppliers to apply for access
        Workflow routes the approval of the registration request
    Suppliers can download RFQ's and complete and send back RFQ responses
        Responses can be imported via Oracle EDI Gateway
    Forecast schedule information is viewable by the supplier
        They can see the buyer's forecast requirements scheduled needs for an item.
    Suppliers can view purchase orders on the portal and enter ASN's
        This eliminates the discrepencies of matching PO's to receipts
            (short ships, back orders and substitutions)
        Delivery promise dates can be entered and modified via by the supplier
    Self billing invoices (ERS invoices) can be accessed by suppliers on the portal
        It allows suppliers to see payment amounts
    Forecasts are plans, arranged by MRP schedules, over time horizons,
        They communicate future needs.
        You can click any schedule number link and see more detailed information
    Suppliers can post their capacity constraints online
        Buyers use the information to reallocate sourcing percentages for ASL's
    Suppliers can view inventory levels at the buying organizations warehouses
        This includes directly managing VMI subinventories.
        They can manage reorder points and initiate VMI resupply
    Return Merchandise Authorities can be entered on the portal by suppliers to support returns

Internet Supplier Portal (POS) Notes on Planning:
    The planning tab will not appear unless the manufacturing applications are installed
    You can export a schedule from the planning window
        Use the 'export' button underneath the table of planning schedules

Internet Support (iSupport) Notes:
    Includes knowledgebases for customer issues resolution, as well as self submission of tickets

Internet Time (iTime) Notes:

        This includes project, task and expenditure type (ie character of expense or commodity)
    Time cards can be copied from previous weeks and edited, modified, to speed up time entry
    Time cards can be self approved in workflow or routed to approvers for explicit review and approval

    Setup approval hierarchy for workflow approval, or default self approval.

        Not much can be done without performing this step

        ADADMIN disappears from the screen after it is first run

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Troubleshooting
    Message "No Organizations are currently defined" requires inventory organization security access
        The current responsibility must be granted access to the inventory organization in inventory
        Navigation -> Inventory/Setups/Organizations/Organization Access/
            and choose the applications and responsibilities that should have access to the organization
    If an inventory organization is not assigned to a responsibility, it is available globally
        Once it is assigned to a responsibility, no other responsibilities have access unless they are specifically assigned also

Inventory (INV Schema) Best Practices:
    Set all but one segments of the system item key flex field to value set validation
        Only one segment needs to be non-validated to make the item number unique
    Centralize the process of item numbering and category and catalog assignment within the organization
        This ensures consistancy in the numbering scheme
        It also ensures master level attributes are established fully when the item is created
        Oracle Inventory does not support mass changes and mass updates
    Define a single master inventory organization for each set of books throughout the business group.
        Without this control duplicate items may be created.
    Test inventory item template definitions before using them
        to identify any inconsistancies in the template definitions
    Use templates to create new items instead of copying existing items and their attributes
        Items may have errors that will be propogated throuh the system
    Put template names in one attribute of the item created by the template
        Tis way it is possible to track back to the creating template for an item
    Prefix item template names with an organization abbreviation
        to differentiate them from seeded templates.
    Define a separate name for each group of possible inventory status codes
        Use this name during item data conversion to automatically set each individual status
    Define a category set for each subledger area rather than reuse one or two sets for multiple purposes
        This will provide a context field for additional DFF information on items
        It is specific to each application area (eg name of price manager)
    Cycle count physical inventory for a few hours per day when shipping and receiving activity is low
        This will maintain a continuous inventory counting program
        It does not interfer with normal operations
        It allows using experienced warehouse staff
    Use alerts to warn of excessive transactions held in the standard interface import tables
    Set 'Transfer Detail go the GL' in the organization parameters during testing
        to tie back cost transactions. Disable this parameter in production

Inventory (INV Schema) Tips and Tricks:
    Check the UOM when creating an item.
        Once an item is saved the UOM field cannot be changed (easily).
        The primary UOM is on the main region of the item window.
    Update the price and buyer information on the purchasing region of the inventory item
        if you create the item by copying another item
    The list price on an inventory item can be used on a purchase order
        if there is no price in Purchasing
            no catalog quote,
            no blanket agreement,
            no requisition template priced lines
            no external price catalog uploads for the item
    Always review these attributes after creating an item:
        Asset Number,
        Description,
        Unit of Measure,
        User Item Type,
        Item Status,
        Category
    Accounting periods must be opened in inventory before transactions can be posted
        This includes transactions such as Costs or Receipts

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Terminology
    QuickCodes (or Quick Codes) - static lists of values for form fields
        The value name is separate to the underlying value field or code
        The value name can be changed without impacting the underlying field

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Inventory Organizations represent geographical facilities with multiple warehouses
        One inventory organization can be associated with many locations
            But one location or address can be assigned to EITHER just one inventory organization (as explained above)
                OR all orgs (by leaving the above field blank).
            Navigation: Inventory > Setup > Organizations > Locations Query the location(s) and go to Other Details tab.
                Enter the name of the org that you want to assign this location to.
        Inventory Organizations are specific to an operating unit.
        An inventory organization cannot be used by two operating units
        Attributes of inventory items can be differently defined for each inventory organization
            Even though there is one master inventory organization for an operating unit.
            Inventory Organization attributes are defined on the MTL_ORGANIZATION_PARAMETERS table
            Related tables that store additional attributes are:
                GL_CODE_COMBINATIONS - for accounting defaults
                HR_ALL_ORGANIZATION_UNITS - for operating units, organization names
                MTL_PICKING_RULES
                BOM_CALENDARS - for manufacturing calendars
                MTL_ATP_RULES - for ATP processing rules
        Most Master Inventory attributes can be overridden at the Inventory Organization level.
    Sub-Inventories are warehouses or storage areas within an inventory organization
        Sub inventories are defined in MTL_SECONDARY_INVENTORIES
        Items are associated with subinventories in MTL_ITEM_SUB_INVENTORIES
        They can be areas of a warehouse that serve a specific purpose
        Use of Sub-Inventories is optional
        Navigation <Inventory Superuser>/Setup/Organizations/Subinventories
        Sub-Inventory attributes help define the purpose of their contained items:
            available to promise,
            nettable against demand,
            reservable against orders,
            assets or expensed items,
        Major Sub-Inventories would include:
            sellable items, manufactured items etc.
        Other Sub-Inventory examples include:
            returned items waiting inspection,
            materials in transit,
            goods consigned from the supplier
        Sub-Inventory definitions are difficult to change once they have been defined or converted
    Locators or stock locators are areas within a warehouse or Sub-Inventory
        A stock locator is a Key Flexfield typically defined in four segments
            warehouse (facility or outside area),
            aisle (horizontal dimension),
            rack (segment of the aisle) and
            bin (vertical dimension for stacked bins)
        A stock locator can also be defined as a one segment KFF for ease of use
            The intelligence of aisle, rack, and bin can be built into the value set of the KFF
        Stock locators must be unique within an organization
            Oracle does not differentiate locators between different Sub-Inventories
        Additional detail inventory tracking within stock locator can be lot control and serial control

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on the Master Inventory Organization:
    There is one master inventory organization for an operating unit
        One Master Inventory Organization can be shared across multiple operating units as well
        The Master Inventory Organization maintains a master record of all items
            The master records are shared across multiple inventory organizations
    Every inventory organization referencing a master organization must share the same set of books
        This is because default accounts are determined at the master organization level
            Default accounts include: expense, encumbrance sales, cost of goods sold
    Subledger applications can operate with multiple inventory organizations within an operating unit
        Examples are purchasing and order management.
    Manufacturing applications operate within a single inventory organization
        Applications in Receiving (within purchasing)
    Inventory Organizations are most typically modelled to represent a distribution point
        multiple warehouses at the Distribution Center are set up as Sub-Inventories
    Supplier part numbers can be cross referenced to the system item key flexfield number
        Part numbers are then referenced on requisitions and purchase orders
    Movements between inventory organizations can be designated as intransit or direct
    Internal orders allow movements of items between inventory organizations in different operating units
        They are not required for movements between inventory orgs in the same OPU.
        They are initiated by internal requisitions in one operating unit
        They create internal sales orders in the shipping organization
        The Sales Order type is defined in Purchasing Options for the OU, which links to the AR Transaction Type
            The AR Transaction Type can have its 'Default Tax Classification' flag unset to disable tax calculation
            Additional References
                R12: What Are The Steps Required To Setup An Internal Requisition In Purchasing? (Doc ID 1384716.1)
    Shipping networks define movement options between organizations
        References
            Why Is It Not Possible For The Internal Location To Be Assigned To More Than One Customer Site ? (Doc ID 1498050.1)
            Note 1384716.1 - R12: What Are The Steps Required To Setup An Internal Requisition In Purchasing?
        Shipping networks can be direct or intransit - direct provide for immediate transfers
            Intransit move the inventory based on inter-org ship times
        They also establish accounting codes to charge transfers, in transits and losses
        Shipping networks allow movements/transfers of inventory between organizations
            However transit times must be setup otherwise the movements are immediate
            Additionally, Sourcing rules must be setup to enable scheduling and planning for internal orders
            Without internal requests/orders, all delivery requests are deemed to be needed immediately
                i.e. they become simple inter-org transfers
    Intercompany Relations
        Sets the buying and selling parties for inter-org transactions
            References
                INV: Intercompany Invoice for Internal Orders
                FG inter/intra must all be internal requisitions
                RM intraco can be interorg transfers
                https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18727_01/doc.121/e13450/T291651T292529.htm
                Intercompany Transaction Flows Between Multiple Inventory Organizations Are Same (Doc ID 1669234.1)
                R12: What Are The Steps Required To Setup An Internal Requisition In Purchasing? (Doc ID 1384716.1)
                AP Invoices Are Not Created With Proper Distributions For Intercompany Transactions (Doc ID 1669155.1)
                https://support.oracle.com/epmos/faces/SearchDocDisplay?_adf.ctrl-state=696ndtvpm_565&_afrLoop=469286940580611
                https://community.oracle.com/thread/556567 -- create invoice for internal sales order
                Create a Intercompany Invoice AR and AP Overviews (Doc ID 784679.1)
                http://oraclevalues.blogspot.com/2010_09_01_archive.html -- setup internal requistions
                http://oraclevalues.blogspot.com/2010/10/internal-order-process-step-by-step.html - internal AR and AP invoice process step by step
Processes
    Create Intercompany AR Invoice
    Create Intercompany AP Invoice (INCIAP)



    Status codes drive the different ways items can be used in the Oracle applications
        Status codes are highly interdependent
            There are a small subset of combinations that are actually appropriate
        Status codes are:
            Stockable - the item can be held in stock (can only be enabled if 'Inventory Item' is enabled)
            Build in WIP,
            Transactable - allows inventory transactions (item must be stockable to enable this flag)
            Purchasable,
            Internal Orders Enabled,
            Customer Orders Enabled,
            Invoice Enabled, and
            BOM Allowed
    Deleting an inventory item requires definition of a 'delete group'
        The item is moved to the delete group prior to deletion
        Items must be deleted from child organizations first
        Only then can the items be deleted from the master organization
    Deletion of an item is intended for deleting where the item is an error
        It is not intended to delete items with transaction history.
    Balance inquiry can be done in the:
        "View Item Quantities" form,
        "View Sub-Inventory Quantities" form, and
        "View Locator Quantities" form
    Supply and demand balances can be viewed in the "View Supply-Demand" form
    Inventory item revision levels can be changed directly in Inventory, however ...
        They are normally updated through Engineering with an ECO and change to the BOM
    Inventory allows for issues, receipts and inventory tracking within a warehouse by project
        This supports project costing and the interface to the Oracle Projects system
    Move Orders are generated are by subledger systems such as Order Management (picking moves)
        Move orders are nominations to move inventory between subinventories in an organization
        They can be input directly into inventory too.
        If planner approval is required, the move order will enter the planner approval queue.
        Autoapproval will execute the move order immediately
        Move orders provide two step processing of inventory moves - request and approve
            Moves can be requested by one person, but controlled and transacted by another.
    Attachments can be made to items in inventory
        Attachments can be notes or drawings or other electronic documents
    There is no change control or security associated with document attachments
        So attachments are a convenience but not a control point.

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Transaction Types
    Transaction Types identify a transaction action and transaction source type
        The combination defines a transaction type
        E.g.
            Action: Issue from Stores
            Source Type: Job or Schedule
            Transaction Type: WIP Component Issue
    Transaction Actions are seeded in FND_LOOKUP_VALUES with LOOKUP_TYPE = MTL_TRANSACTION_ACTION
    Transaction Source Types are in INV.MTL_TXN_SOURCE_TYPES
    See http://download.oracle.com/docs/cd/A60725_05/html/comnls/us/inv/trntype.htm for a list of transaction types

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Inter-Organization Transactions
    References
        http://www.oracleappshub.com/om/understanding-data-flow-for-internal-orders/
        http://appscentric.blogspot.com/2012/03/intercompany-setups.html
    Inter-organization transfers are transfers between inventory organizations
    They can be direct or in-transit
        Direct transfers occur immediately upon entry
            They do not require receiving at the destination
            Both the shipment and receipt occur at the same time and date
        In-transit transfers take time - defined by inter-org transit times
            The in-transit method is used when transportation delays are significant
            In-transit transfers post to in-transit inventory accounts
                If the transfer is FOB then the receiving organization owns the in-transit inventory
                If the transfer is 'Delivered' the shipping organization owns the inventory
            They must be received by the receiving organization to be completed
    Shipping Methods must be defined for Interorganization Transfers
    You can set up a shipping network to support inter-org transfers of items
        This is the minimum setup required to enable inter-org transfer transactions
        Shipping networks include shipping methods and ledger accounts
            The accounts for the from/to orgs default from the Inventory Org Parameters setups
            They can be over-ridden at the shipping network level
            Accounts include:
                Transfer Credit - transfer charges booked to the shipping organization expense account
                Purchase Price Variance - an expense account if standard costing is used
                Payable - the GL liability account charged to the receiving organization
                Receivable - the GL asset account charged to the shipping organization
                Intransit Inventory - the intransit asset account to hold instransit values
    You need to set up inter-org transit times to additionally calculate shipping delays in transfers
    You need to set up sourcing rules if internal requisitions/orders are created using supplier scheduling
        Internal requisitions allow 'need-by'dates and support internal invoicing if needed
        Need by dates in turn support MRP and MPS planning - otherwise transfers are all 'immediate'
    Key tables for inter-organization transfers are:
        MTL_INTERORG_SHIP_METHODS - associate shipping methods with carriers and transit times
        MTL_INTERORG_PARAMETERS - attach accounting rules for transfers between orgs
        WSH_SHIP_METHODS - hold the master shipping method entries
        MTL_MATERIAL_TRANSACTIONS - stores the actual movement transactions

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Available to Promise (ATP)
    ATP rules comprise computation, time fence and supply/demand sources
    Tables used in ATP are:
        MTL_ATP_RULES
        The ETRM for Inventory contains a sub-schema for all the ATP tables

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Material Transactions
    Inventory transactions can be created directly in Inventory or from feeder systems:
        Order Management
        Purchasing
        Work in Process
    All inventory transactions are store in the MTL_MATERIAL_TRANSACTIONS table
        There is a subschema diagram in the ETRM for Miscellaneous Transactions
    Material Transaction Distributions are Created by the Cost Manager
        If the cost manager is not running, they are not created
        Check Inventory Superuser > Setup > Transactions > Interface Managers (Tools > Launch) if inactive

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Demand and Reservations
    Material Demand tracks demand placed on inventory for ATP and Planning purposes
        MTL_DEMAND contains three different row types
            Summary Demand - total of unreserved and reserved demand
            Open Demand - unreserved demand
            Reservations - representing a firm promise
    Inventory writes a unique sales order identifier into MTL_SALES_ORDERS
        after entry of demand from the new sales order into MTL_DEMAND or MTL_DEMAND_INTERFACE
    Demand and reservations from sales orders are either automatically entered by Oracle Order Entry
        (if the reservation is placed online)
        or loaded from MTL_DEMAND_INTERFACE, where external demand may be defined.
    Inventory adjusts reservation information in MTL_DEMAND after execution of material transactions.
    Primary tables for Demand and Reservations include:
        MTL_DEMAND - links sales orders to inventories and holds reservations
            Holds sales orders demand and reservations
        MTL_DEMAND_INTERFACE - interface table for demand from outside resources
            This is a temporary storage area for external demand sources

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Practical Exercises
    Exercise: Define Organization Parameters -> IVO/Setup/Organization/Parameters
        To set all parameters and accounts and negative inventory flags for each inventory organization
    Exercise: View Material Transactions -> <Inventory>/Transactions/Material Transactions
    Exercise: View transactions in the Inventory Transactions Open Interface ->
        <Inventory>/Transactions/Transaction Open Interface
    Exercise: Purge Material Transactions -> <Inventory>/Transactions/Purge
        Transactions may only be purged from closed periods
            Installations often 'never close' Inventory to keep transactions accessible
        Once purged, material transactions are lost to reconciliation reporting and item geneology
            Accounting information is purged along with the movement information
        Tables purged include MTL_MATERIAL_TRANSACTIONS and MTL_TRANSACTION_ACCOUNTS
    Exercise: Make a subinventory transfer -> IVO/Transactions/Subinventory Transfer
        To move inventory between subinventories, or from one locator to another.
        Choose type = 'Subinventory Transfer'
    Exercise: Record a miscellaneous transaction -> IVO/Transactions/Miscellaneous Transactions
        To make a miscellaneous receipt or issue or scrap.
        You can choose to do the transaction by alias (name for account) or enter the actual accounts
        Enter the accounts to offset the inventory account tied to the subinventory - eg expense account
    Exercise: Enter a move order -> IVO/Move Orders/Move Orders
        Record the move order and account to charge (eg expenses for an issue)
    Exercise: Transact a move order -> IVO/Move Orders/Transact Move Orders,
        find the move orders, select using the checkbox and then click 'Transact'
    Exercise: Correct a receipt or delivery transaction -> IVO/Transactions/Receiving/Corrections
        Enter a negative quantity after finding the original transaction to undo the error
    Exercise: View On-Hand Quantities -> IVO/On-hand,Availability/On-Hand Quantity
        Enter the items to view, click subinventory to see quantites at the subinventory level
    Exercise: View Supply/Demand Quantities -> IVO/On-Hand,Availability/Supply,Demand
        To view quantities on hand, due from PO, due in from mfg, and reserved for shipment out
    Exercise: Attach a document to a master item -> IVO/Items/Master Items,
        Query an item to attach documents. Click on the paperclip

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Organization and Hierarchy Security
    Inventory Organization hierarchies are established through organization definition form
    Inventory organizations can be restricted through organization security
        A user with a responsibility can only see inventory organizations assigned to the responsiblity
    Exercise: Assign Inventory Orgs to parent Inventory Orgs ->
        <Inventory>/Setup/Organizations/Organizations
        Query Organization, choose Inventory Org Classification
            Click 'Others', 'Inventory Information'
    Exercise: Assign inventory organization security to responsibilities ->
        <Inventory>/Setup/Organizations/Organization Access
        Assign inventory organizations to application responsibilities
            to limit access and lookup lists
    Inventory Organization Security is also possible using Security Groups in HR
        The Global Super HRMS Manager Responsibility must be used
        Navigation: Global Super HRMS Manager > Security > Global Profile
            Create Security Groups with entries of Organizations with classifications 'Inventory Organization'
            Assign the Security Groups to responsibilities

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Item Templates:
    Items can be created by cloning from other items or using Item Templates
        in the Master Inventory Organization
    Templates are predefined sets of attributes
        that can be reused to reliably create items.
    Templates make initial definition easier
        Seeded Oracle templates have one template and one matching user item type defined.
    Item Templates can default attributes for items during item creation.
    Templates can be defined for the master organization or for a child organization.
        Leave the Org blank on a template to make it a master template available to all organizations
    Items attributes set on templates can have 'Item Level' control
        Those attributes are controlled at the item level across all organizations.
    Items set with item/org level control can be modified within each inventory organization
    Oracle dictates certain selected items must be maintained at the item master org level
        Others are maintained at the Item/Org level.
            The control level for other attributes are driven by setup during the implementation
    The standard approach to creating an item from a template is to name the item
        then select a template (from the options menu ... copy)
        It is possible to select and apply multiple templates for a single item
            Overlay each template successively.
        Any overlapping attributes will be overlaid in the process
    For each item, a template is needed at the master inventory organization level
        This creates the master item
        Another template is needed at the child inventory organization level
            This creates/overlays the child organization level item and attributes
    Multiple templates can be applied to a single item cumulatively.
        The most recent template takes precedence if it overlaps another template value
    The template form has an alternate region switch
        The template values must be set for each alternate region starting with 'main'
            These regions correspond with the alternate regions on the item definition form
    Exercise: Create an item template ->
        <Inventory>/Setup/Items/Templates, and create a named template.
        Leave Org blank if it is a master org template
        Set the control level for each attribute to the master level.
            Attributes won't show for applications not yet installed
    You can also create an item by copying another item and applying templates
        Oracle will copy the item first and apply the template second.
    Fields to update on the purchasing region after copying an item are:
        list price
        receipt required
        purchased flag
        purchasable flag
        default buyer
        receipt close tolerance
        taxable flag
        expense account

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Importing Items
    Run Import Items to import items through the Open Item Interface from any source
        This can be run from an inventory responsibility via Items -> Import -> Import Items
    Tables used are:
        MTL_SYSTEMS_ITEM_INTERFACE
        MTL_ITEM_REVISIONS_INTERFACE - to import revisions to existing items
        MTL_INTERFACE_ERRORS - tracks errors that arise during the import

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Setups:
    System Item Key Flexfield Definition (primary item key)
    Item Attributes cannot be changed once the items are transacted
        item attribute setups are key to how they are processed.
        This is a special risk for phased implementations
            where design decisions may create the need for attribute changes down the road

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Item Types and Items:
    Inventory items can have attributes defined and controlled at the master level or the organization level.
        Master level centralizes control of these attributes
    Items can be tangible goods or intangibles
        Intangibles include magazine subscriptions or labor services sold as items
    Items can be defined in a parent/master organization and inherited down to child organizations.
        Item attributes can be overridden at the child level
    Items can be assigned to all child organizations
        An Organization Assignment Form button 'Assign All' does this
    Items can be phantom assemblies which are never stocked
        They represent a common 'build' of components referenced in multiple Bills Of Material
    Item numbers can be prefixed or suffixed (more common) with a lot number if lots are tracked.
    The Inventory Item Id Key Flexfield must be defined to cover all items in all inventories
    You must create items in the inventory master organization
        Choosing a responsibility with access to the master organization
    Exercise: Create a master item by copying another item or template -> use the Tools/Copy menu
    Exercise: Create an Item Type -> <Inventory>/Setup/Items/Item Types
        Create item types to associate with items (finished goods, suppliers etc).
        Material overhead costs are charged to items at the item type level.
        Item types cannot be changed or deleted once used.
    Exercise: Create a Master Item and assign to Inventory Organizations ->
        <Inventory>/Items/Master Items (ensure responsibility has access to the master organization)
            Enter the Item ID, then choose "Tools/Copy From" to use a template or other item
                Then choose Tools/Organization assignment, to assign orgs that will have this item
    Exercise: Enter an Inventory Item -> <Inventory>/Items/Master Items/Menu/Tools/Copy From,
        Choose the template to copy and give the item a new number/code and description
        Choose "Menu/Tools/Organization Assigment" and choose organizations to assign
        Choose "Menu/Tools/Categories" and assign to a Category Set or Category
    Exercise: Delete an item -> Inventory/Items/Delete Items
        Define a Delete Group (type items) and add items to the Delete Group.
        Run 'Check Groups' to see what items cannot be deleted and why
        e.g. an item has an inventory balance or pending sales order

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Purchasing Alternate Region in Items:
    The 'Purchased' attribute is an item-defining attribute that defines an item as 'existing' for purchasing.
        It also allows the 'purchasable' attribute to be turned on
    The 'Purchasable' attribute allows temporary disabling of an item from being purchased
        This attribute can be turned off for this purpose.
        It must be turned on to allow purchasing (including in purchase orders)

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Locations:
    Exercise: Define a location -> <Inventory>/Setup/Organization/Location
        Define locations and define activities allowable at each location.

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Accounting:
    Inventory requires numerous account setups which should be fully tested prior to go-live
    Accounting for inventory receipts involves three steps:
        Purchase Order (encumber budget and PO with commitment and relieve when received)
            This step is optional and the encumbrance is one-sided without accounting impact
        Receive Goods (Accrue Purchase and Debit Inventory with receipt
            The encumbrance is removed
            Inventory is debited with the cost of goods received at the time received
        Receive Supplier Invoice (relieve purchase accrual and record payable liability)
        Pay invoice (relieve payable and reduce cash)
    Variance accounts post the difference in prices that occurs in each step of the purchasing chain.
        Accounts are:
            Purchase Price Variance (variance between purchase order and receipt cost)
            Invoice Price Variance (variance between receipt cost and invoice cost)
            Both variance accounts are liability accounts offset by final payment
    Variances are relieved by posting to inventory periodically
        Standard costs are adjusted to eliminate systematic variances for future transactions.
    Average costing modifies the cost of each item with each receipt
        This is done when the cost is debited to the inventory account at the time of receipt
    Standard costing keeps items costs fixed (inventory is charged the same cost)
        The difference is posted to a Purchase Price Variance (PPV) Account
    Exercise: Open or view inventory accounting periods ->
        <Inventory>/Accounting Close Cycle/Inventory Accounting Periods

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Month-End (Period-End) Close Processing:
    ...

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Lot and Serial Control:
    Lots are sets of the same item that are tracked with a common expiration date.
        They are usually manufactured at the same time and have the same quality characteristics
    Lots are identified by Lot Number and tagged with an Expiration Date.
        They are useful in tracking goods with a limited shelf life
    Lot numbers also provide tracking for quality analysis
        Purchasing can receive lot numbers,
        Inventory can store against lots
        Discrete Manufacturing (not flow) can pull lot numbered items
    Actions that can be performed with Lots include:
        viewing,
        reviewing their material transactions
        lots can be disabled,
        and their expiration dates can be changed
            all through the Oracle Forms
        Exercise: View Lots -> <Inventory>/On-hand,Availability/Lots
            and find by Lot# or by Item# (all lots with the item will be displayed).
            Update expiration dates, view transactions and disable lots.
            You can also view lot geneology in BOM format
    Serial provide unique identification of individual units of the item
        They can be generated sequentially
    Serial numbers can be generated for any item
        This includes finished assemblies, parts within assemblies and non- assembly items
    Serial numbers can be predefined with a sequence and prefix for an individual item
        They can be pre-generated to create a list of valid values for subsequent use
        To generate serial numbers, the item must be setup at the org level for serial control
            This is an attribute (look on the Inventory Alternate Region of the Item Attribute)
        Exercise: Generate Serial Numbers -> Inventory/On-hand,Availability/Generate Serial Numbers
    Serial numbering of assemblies and components is tracked with barcoding or serial number
        Serial numbers can be entered into Oracle Forms
    Serial numbers are used in other Oracle apps:
        Service with warranty terms, inspection, customer RMA's.
    Serial numbers are also maintained for items in Purchasing and WIP modules

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Units of Measure:
    Unit of Measure classes group similar units of measure
        Units in a class can be converted to other units in the same class
            Examples classes are volume, weight, temperature, length, capacity
    Every unit of measure class has a base unit of measure.
        Once set and used, the base unit of measure cannot be changed
        You should normally choose the Unit of Issue used by OM as the Base Unit
            This will simplify system usage
    Unit of measure conversion factors can be defined as universal item specific
    The default UOM for Order Management is the Unit of Issue
    Key tables in Units of Measure include:
        MTL_UNITS_OF_MEASURE (and _TL)
        MTL_UOM_CLASSES (and _TL)
        MTL_UOM_CONVERSIONS
        MTL_UOM_CLASS_CONVERSIONS
        MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS_B

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Replenishment:
    Inventory supports several replenishment and safety stock replenishment methods
        These algorithms take manufacturing and sales demand into account.
        One method is Re-Order Point (ROP)
            ROP uses safety stock and economic order quantity concepts (EOQ)
            It calculate replenishment orders, and it also factors in expected demand.
            Time buckets are established in the ROP method
            Inside each time bucket the supply and demand are balanced to ensure proper matching
            MRP keeps Inventory updated with the status of material requirements
            It factors in expected demand for BOM components through the INV_SUPPLY table
            Inventory takes these into account when calculating reorder quantities
        Another method is Min-Max
            This method places an order when minimum inventory is reached
            It sized the order to restore inventory to the maximum value
            Min-Max planning is 'point in time' and does not factor in demand

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Category Sets:
    References:
        Metalink Note: 423551.1 How To Create Category Sets and Assign Items to Categories
        http://docs.oracle.com/cd/A60725_05/html/comnls/us/inv/categasn.htm#t_asgncateg - different methods of assigning items to categories
    Category sets (Inventory Item Category Setups) are named collections of category values for a specific category KFF structure
        A category structure will have assigned categories
        A category set is a named collection of categories within the structure (a subset of the full category list)
        Oracle supports more that one list of categories (i.e. sets) and each supported list is defined in a named (separate) set
        Items fall under categories under category sets and multiple sets are allowed.
        In other words ...
            Define an inventory category structure
            Define a list of category values for the structure - this creates all possible values for the structure
            Define a category set for the structure, and populate it with a subset of the categories
            Define additional category sets as needed
    Category Sets allow multiple category structures for internal reporting and data entry
        Category Sets comprise lists of Categories
        Each Category Set specifies a Category Key Flexfield
            Different Category Key Flexfields can be defined and assigned to different Category Sets
    Category Sets group categories for different purposes:
        engineering,
        purchasing, etc.
    Oracle seeds seven inventory category sets to support sub-ledger applications:
        Inventory,
        Purchasing,
        Order Management,
        Service, Engineering,
        Costing
        Planning
    The Purchasing Category Set groups items under purchasing categories such as commodity lines.
        Buyers can be grouped to Categories within this Category Set
    The Order Management Category Set is used to set sales discounts by category, run sales reports, and to report sales backlog.
    A Default Category set must be assigned to each of the seven key subledger areas within Oracle:
        Inventory,
        Purchasing,
        Order Management
        Service,
        Engineering,
        Costing
        Planning
    Every Category Set must identify a default category.
        The Open Item Interface assigns default categories to items as they are loaded
            This happens if specific categories are not named in the interface data.
    Category Sets can utilize a different flexfield structure for item catalogs for each definition of the set.
    Category Sets and categories should be assigned to items in the master organization (where the item assigment is controlled)
        They cascade down to the child organizations if wanted
    Items are assigned to Category Sets in one of two ways:
        Query the item in the master organization and choose tools from the menu - and assign the item to categories
        Open the Category Set from within the Master Inventory Organization and choose Assignments
            If you are not in the correct inventory organization (the master organization) the Assignment options are read-only
    Key tables in the inventory schema for categories are:
            MTL_ITEM_CATEGORIES - assign items to categories for all flex structures (category sets)
            MTL_CATEGORY_SET_VALID_CATS
            MTL_CATEGORIES_B
            MTL_CATEGORY_SETS_B
            MTL_DEFAULT_CATEGORY_SETS
            FND_ID_FLEX_STRUCTURES
    Exercise: Create a key flexfield structure -> <System Administrator>/Setup/Flexfields/Key/Segments and search for the 'Item Categories' Flexfield
    Exercise: Create category set -> <Purchasing Super User>/Setup/Items/Categories/Category Sets...
    Exercise: View Categories in a Category Set -> <Responsibility>/Inventory/Setup/Categories/Category Codes
        Enter a structure (the KFF "structure" that is associated with a Category Set) to return all values in the Category Set
    Exercise: Add categories to a category set -> <Purchasing Super User>/Setup/Items/Categories/Category Codes
    Exercise: Create a List of Values to assign to a Category Set -> <System Administrator>/Setup/Flexfields/Validation/Sets/
    Exercise: Add values to a value set -> <System Administrator>/Setup/Flexfields/Validation/Values

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Catalogs
    Catalogs are outward serving customer/user-oriented references
        Categories are internal reporting and control references to items.
        Category Groups are used internally by Inventory for reporting purposes
        Descriptors attached to the items make catalogs searchable
    Catalogs provide searchable indexes into items for purchasing and sales
    Catalogs consist of attributes or descriptors (descriptive elements) and catalog groups
        Each Catalog Group can have a different collection of descriptors
    Catalog Groups define the catalog schema and valid item descriptors
        They also define the navigation hierarchy
    Catalogs are helpful for finding items
    Primary tables for Inventory Catalogs are:
        MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS_B
        MTL_ITEM_CATALOG_GROUPS
        MTL_ICG_ALIASES - item catalog group aliases
        MTL_ICG_CATEGORIES - item catalog group categories or supergroups
        MTL_DESCRIPTIVE_ELEMENTS - assign descriptive elements to catalog groups
        MTL_DESCR_ELEMENT_VALUES - define element values for items within a group
    Exercise: Setup Catalog Groups and item descriptive elements ->
        <Inventory>/Setup/Items/Catalog Groups
            Enter a catalog group and "Show Detail" to add descriptive elements
    Exercise: Search for Catalog Items -> ,Inventory>/Items/Item Search
        Choose Show = "Item Catalog" to search on Catalog Groups and item attributes/descriptors

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Physical Inventory and Cycle Counting ABC Analysis:
    Physical inventory involves an actual count of items in inventory
        It records the physicals against book calculated amounts
    The physical inventory process involves taking a snapshot of inventory
        Physical count tags are printed and actual amounts recorded
        Recounts are issued based on recorded differences
    ABC is setup by defining the Classes (A, B, C etc)
        Compiles are created to build groups of items based on a value definition
        Groups are defined and a compiled list of items is associated to a group
        Finally breakpoints are set for which items belong to each class in the ABC group
    Cycle counting uses the ABC classes to decide how often items get counted
    Tolerances are established for accepting inventory counts that vary from book totals
        They can be different to counts of book value
        A Recount Request is generated if the discrepancy exceeds the tolerance
    Exercise: Create ABC Compiles - <Inventory>/ABC Codes/ABC Compiles
        to define a collection of items based on scope and value criteria
    Exercise: Create ABC Classes -> to establish the number of classes (A, B, C, ....X)
        These will be used for inventory counting
    Exercise: Create ABC Groups and Associate a Compiled List of Inventory Items ->
        <Inventory>/ABC Codes/ABC Assignment Groups
        to create groups of inventory items that will be cycle counted
        cyles will use ABC value analysis within the group
        a group may cover several subinventories
        You associate the Group with the ABC Compile name here
            This defines the total membership of the group
    Exercise: Assign ranges of items to ABC Classes in the Group ->
        <Inventory>/ABC Codes/Assign Items to define the items within the group as members of each value tier (A, B, C)
        This is done by entering the sequence number of the last item in the group as the 'breakpoint' for the group.
        The form shows the total count of items in the group and the percentag of value in each assignment

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Functional Gaps:
    The Return Material Authorization (RMA) process
        Disassembly and restocking of configured Assemble-to-Order items are not supported

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Standard Reports:
    ABC Descending Values - sorts items in descending order of ABC critical value for tight control
    ABC Assignments Report - shows current assignments of items to ABC inventory value categories

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Interfaces:
    The Interface Managers form sets the frequency of background workers importing interface transactions.
    Set interface processing frequency -> <Inventory>/..../Launch Interface Managers
        to set the frequency of import for major interface processes (from say, RF devices).
        Processes include: Cost Manager, Lot Move, Material Transaction, Move Transaction.
    Open Items Import -> by loading the MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS_INTERFACE table
        Run a process to load the items into MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS.
        The process to load the items from the interface table
        It checks the settings on item attributes to validate their consistancy.
        Import in two passes starting with the master organization items
        This is followed by the child organization items.
        Specify a template for each import to stamp the appropriate attribute values
    Open Transactions Import -> in the MTL_TRANSACTIONS_INTERFACE
        to bring in transactions and opening balances for inventories
        Opening Balances are imported as Miscellaneous Receipts
        These are loaded into MTL_MATERIAL_TRANSACTIONS for processing.

Inventory (INV Schema) Notes on Key Tables:
    APPS.ORG_ACCESS_V -- organization access view
    BOM_CALENDARS - BOM or inventory calendars for an inventory organization
    MTL_ATP_RULES - rules for Available to Promise for each inventory organization
    MTL_CATEGORIES
    MTL_CATEGORIES_B (and _TL)
    MTL_CATEGORY_SETS (and _TL)
    MTL_CST_LAYER_ACT_COST_DETAILS - cost layers for each inventory organization
    MTL_DEMAND - maintains records of expected issues from inventory
        including manufacturing and sales
    MTL_ITEM_CATEGORIES
    MTL_ITEM_REVISIONS
    MTL_ITEM_QUANTITIES_VIEW - counts all available quantities in an inventory
        counts across lots and serial numbers
    MTL_ITEM_LOCATIONS - master table for inventory locators within subinventories
        Locators only exist for subinventories with locator control active
    MTL_MATERIAL_TRANSACTIONS - stores a record of every material transaction
        Also stores lines for any cost updates in inventory
        Records are inserted by the transaction processor or standard cost update
        Joined to MTL_TRANSACTION_ACCOUNTS for accounting/costing information
        Transfers are represented by two transactions in this table
            They are joined on TRANSFER_TRANSACTION_ID
    MTL_MATERIAL_TRANSACTIONS_TEMP - the gateway for all material transactions
        All inventory transaction forms write directly to this table
        Record are processed from this table to Inventory through the Transaction Processor
        The transactions interface table also writes to this table upon import
    MTL_PARAMETERS - inventory organization parameters
    MTL_PHYSICAL_INVENTORIES - physical inventory definitions
        contains user-defined options for a physical inventory, including:
            approvals required, subinventory scope, tolerances, tag generation options
    MTL_PHYSICAL_SUBINVENTORIES - subinventories defined within a physical inventory
    MTL_ONHAND_QUANTITIES - current balances to the subinventory and locator level
        Multiple entries must be summed to get the on-hand balance
        See Metalink Note 92031.1 MTL_ONHAND_QUANTITIES Table - An Overview
        This table creates one record for each receipt
        Disbursements deplete the receipt rows or eliminate them
    MTL_ONHAND_QUANTITIES_TEMP
        Holds records for validation prior to posting to MTL_ONHAND_QUANTITIES
    MTL_SECONDARY_INVENTORIES - master table for subinventories
        Includes an indicator LOCATOR_TYPE for Stock Locator Control
    MTL_SECONDARY_LOCATORS - stock locators in subinventories
    MTL_SUBINV_QUANTITIES_VIEW - counts all available quantities in a subinventory
        counts across lots and serial numbers
    MTL_SUPPLY - maintains records of expected receipts into inventory and disbursements
        supports a rolling inventory of projected future balances on the Supply/Demand Detail form
        balances are projected forward from the current availability total
        Exercise: View Supply/Demand Detail - <Inventory>/On-hand,Availability/Item Supply//Demand
        Exercise: View Current Availability - <Inventory>/On-hand,Availability/On-hand Quantity
    MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS - holds all item definitions
        It is one of the 'widest' tables in Oracle for number of columns
        It is now a view on MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS_B
    MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS_B - new underlying table view of MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS
    MTL_TRANSACTION_ACCOUNTS - stores accounting transactions for items posted to GL
        (using MTA as the link table in gl_import_references)
        Joined to MTL_MATERIAL_TRANSACTIONS by TRANSACTION_ID
    MTL_TRANSACTION_REASONS
    MTL_TRANSACTION_TYPES
    MTL_TXN_SOURCE_TYPES
    MTL_TRANSACTIONS_INTERFACE
    MTL_TXN_REQUEST_HEADERS - move order headers
        contains information defining a move order including:
            move order type, move order status, and the request number
    MTL_TXN_REQUEST_LINES - move order lines
        these are requests to move some quantity in inventory from source to destination
        creates transactions in MTL_MATERIAL_TRANSACTIONS_TEMP when detailed or pick-released
    MTL_UNITS_OF_MEASURE - units of measure for all items
    MTL_UOM_CONVERSIONS - all conversions between different units of measure

    Browser compatibility is in Metalink Note: 285218.1:
    The Oracle JInitiator plug-in is required to run Oracle Forms as Java applets on the Client.
        jInitiator is a set of class files written in Java to implement Forms functions in a browser
    Starting with R12 jInitiator is no longer needed - the standard Sun JVM is used and installed from the Sun site.
    jInitiator is an ActiveX object running within Microsoft Internet Explorer
        It is a plugin within Netscape Navigator and Mozilla Firefox
            In Firefox you need to place the jinit dll in the Plugins Directory under the Firefox file system.
        Browser security must allow plugins for ActiveX or Oracle Forms will not work
    jInitiator allows running Oracle Developer Server applications within a browser
        It allows the browser to run an Oracle certified version of the JVM instead of the standard JVM
    The Oracle JInitiator plug-in is required to run Oracle Forms as Java applets on the Client.
    jInitiator recent versions include:
        jInitiator 1.1.8.16 available through patch 5300474
        jInitiator 1.3.1.12 availabel through patch 4392066
    See Metalink Note 162488.1 for Jinit 1.1.8 Troubleshooting
    Download jInitiator from Metalink note: 124606.1 or patch Patch 5300474
    Launch the install .exe from under the C: drive or desktop.
        It won't launch from deep in the file system because it cannot handle long file paths
    The path for jInitiator is C:\Program Files\Oracle\JInitiator<version>\
        There are readme files in these directories with instructions on managing jInitiator setups
    For version 1.1.18.16 there is a cache directory at C:\Program Files\Oracle\JInitiator 1.1.8.16\jcache
        There is another cache for 1.3.1.21 at C:\Documents and Settings\gjarman\Oracle Jar Cache
        Use the control panel utility for jInitiator to clear the jar cache
    There is a control panel entry for jInitiator (Programs\Settings\Control Panel and look for the jInitiator Entry)
        This utility can be used to turn off caching or clear the cache
        There is also an entry in the Windows Programs menu to run this control panel utility
    jInitiator may place a text trace file in C:\Documents and Settings\gjarman\ as jinitiator13121.trace
        This trace file is the same as the text log entries in the java console
        The java console can be enabled through the jInitiator Control Panel utility

    The Address assigned to the Legal Entity must be in the country/domain where the entity is legally registered
        References
            How to Setup a Legal Address Using HR Address Formats in R12 Legal Entity Configurator (Doc ID 1104887.1)  end-to-end description of defining, choosing or modifying a style to meet local needs. Also describes creating a custom validation set against HZ_GEOGRAPHIES  so that the list of valid values  setting up an address is the same list used to validate it for tax purposes.
            Can you use the US Address Style in a Shared HR Environment? (Doc ID 1610796.1) recommends disabling the US style so that Oracle uses US_GLB instead (since the US style is intended for a full implementation of HR and a full load of the Vertex HR geography patch
            Can the US Address Style be Disabled? (Doc ID 1394466.1) also recommends disabling the US style if on Shared HRMS and not the full HRMS/Payroll system
            What is the Difference Between The Two Address Forms PERACADR (North American Address) and PERWSADR (Generic Address) (Doc ID 954512.1)  a somewhat related note describing the purpose of the two styles  US is for HR/Payroll.
            No Values In City/County LOV When Creating Legal Address In Legal Entity Manager (Doc ID 1259396.1) recommends removing the validation sets on the US address style but continuing to use the US address style instead of disabling it.
        The LE Address style cannot be chosen at entry - Oracle finds the first valid address style on the 'Location Address' flexfield definition
            Oracle stores the LE Address in the HR_LOCATIONS_ALL table
        eBusiness Tax uses this county in the 'Determine Applicable Regimes' process
        You cannot choose an address style entering and LE address - Oracle picks the first valid style if finds
        If there are two styles it will pick 'US' and not 'US_GLB' (Global/International)
            The 'US' style is defined for HR employee addresses (a domestic US address style) and will throw errors if HR is not fully installed
            The tables used in the validation sets query PAY tables which are loaded with Vertex location codes but only for a full HR install
                PAY_US_CITY_NAMES
                PAY_US_COUNTIES
                PAY_US_STATES
                PAY_US_CITY_GEOCODES
                PAY_US_COUNTIES
                PAY_US_ZIP_CODES
                PAY_US_CITY_SCHOOL_DSTS
                PAY_US_COUNTY_SCHOOL_DSTS
            On a shared HR install these tables are empty so the validations on the 'US' address style need to be removed
                Or unfreeze the flexfield definition and disable the 'US' contect on the 'Location Address' flexfield, then refreeze
                Oracle will choose the next available valid address style 'US_GLB' in Legal Entity Manager

Marketing Notes:
    Marketing is a CRM application that defines marketing programs with potential customers down to the specific product/item opportunity
    Marketing covers presales, leads, identifying prospects, and tracking contacts.
    It is designed for disconnected users and uploading/synchronization when network access is available
    Literature, kits and trial package requests are fulfilled with customers by originating orders for these items and passing through to Order Management
    Relationships between contacts and prospects are also managed as part of the prospect database
    Forecasts based on pipeline likelihood are generated to feed demand forecasting for manufacturing demand planning

Master Scheduling/Material Resource Planning (MRP Schema) Notes on Troubleshooting
    In setup, Message "No Organizations are currently defined" requires inventory organization security access
        The MRP responsibility being used must be granted access to the inventory organization(s) in inventory
        Navigation -> Inventory/Setups/Organizations/Organization Access/
            and choose the applications and responsibilities that should have access to the organization

Master Scheduling/Material Resource Planning (MRP Schema) Notes on Additional References
    MRP Tutorial -> http://www.erplite.com/InstantMRP_Introduction.htm
    MRP Metalink Notes: 99166.1 Memory Based Planning Process - Whitepaper
    MRP Online documentation -> http://download.oracle.com/docs/cd/A60725_05/html/comnls/us/mrp/mrptop.htm

Master Scheduling/Material Resource Planning (MRP Schema) Notes:
    MRP plans material requirements in time buckets to the end of a fixed planning horizon
        It generates manufacturing work orders for sub-assemblies and completed products
        It evaluates lead times for purchasing, setup and assembly.
    MRP recommends when to start making items to meet lead time requirements for demand
    MRP translates demands from multiple sources including:
        order management,
        manufacturing schedules,
        inventory restocking etc
    Demands are converted into materials requirements at multiple levels:
        purchased parts,
        finished assemblies and
        intermediate assemblies
    MRP takes into account current inventory levels in meeting future demands
        unless those inventories are designated non-nettable at the subinventory level
    MRP generates planning workorders to manufacturing for assemblies to meet expected demand
        This is done for all stocking strategies
        It issues requisitions to purchasing to supply bought-in parts.
            MRP does not create purchase orders
    MRP Steps are:
        Generate forecasts,
        generate MDS's from Forecasts and Sales Orders,
        generate MPS's from MDS's and inventory,
        generate MRP from MPS.
    Independent demand is demand from forecasts and sales orders
    Dependent demand is calculated from explosion of the bill of materials for an item
    Net Requirements are gross requirements less stock on hand
    The 'Planning Manager' concurrent process performs the following steps:
        consumes forecasts against orders,
        imports forecasts,
        relieves master schedules
    Master Demand Schedules or Master Planning Schedules can be 'loaded' manually
        More often they are loaded from forecasts and orders
    MRP calculates use-up dates as the dates when items will run out
        They can be tied to ECO's to schedule component change-outs
    Kanban means  'card' or 'sign' or 'signal'.
        Create Kanbans by specifying names and demand forecast sources
            Then launch and review results in the workbench
    'Feedback' on an MRP plan definition allows the MRP to evaluate the status of planned orders
        (for deleting planned, not actual orders?)
    Overwrite on MRP options allows firm orders generated by previous plans to be deleted
        This does not delete actual orders
    Orders with compression time in MRP are required to start earlier than the current date
        This is based on lead time and must be compressed
    Order modifiers are min and max order quantities
        They modify the plan generated orders to suppliers or to work order mfg/wIP

Master Scheduling/Material Requirements Planning Profile Options:
    MRP: Cutoff Date Offset Months - establishes the span of months included in the MRP.
        Added to the current date to calc the planning end-date
    MRP: Firm Planned Order Time Fence
        - moves the end date of the 'off-limits' MRP time fence to the date of the most recent firm order
    MRP: Snapshot Workers - number of parallel workers supporting the snapshot MRP multi-threaded process

Master Scheduling/Material Requirements Planning (MRP) Notes on Responsibilities:
    Distribution Planner
    Material Planner
    Supply Chain Planner

Master Scheduling/Material Requirements Planning Dependencies:
    An MPS or MDS must be defined and built before running an MRP
        (an MPS will require an MDS) since MRP calculates from and MDS or MPS

Master Scheduling/Material Requirements Planning (MRP) Forms:
    MDS-Entries: MATERIAL PLANNER/MDS/Entries
    MPS-Entries: MATERIAL PLANNER/MPS/Entries
    MRP-Material Requirements Plan -> MATERIAL PLANNER/MRP/Names
    MPS-Master Production Schedule -> MATERIAL PLANNER/MPS/MPS Names
    MDS-Material Demand Schedule -> MATERIAL PLANNER/MDS/MDS Names
    Forecast Sets -> MATERIAL PLANNER/Forecast/Sets
    Planning Manager -> MATERIAL PLANNER/Setup/Planning Manager
    Planning Parameters -> MATERIAL PLANNER/Setup/Parameters
    Kanban Names -> MATERIAL PLANNER/Kanban/Names
    MRP Workbench -> MATERIAL PLANNER/MRP/Workbench
    Supply/Demand -> MATERIAL PLANNER/MRP/Workbench/SupplyDemand Button
        shows demand as negative rows and supply as positive rows, in date order

Master Scheduling/Material Requirements Planning (MRP) Reports:
    Master Scheduled Detail Report - main report to display the outcome of an MRP run
    Planning Detail Report - second major report to display the outcome of an MRP run

Master Scheduling/Material Requirements Plan (MRP) Exercises:
    Build an MRP -> MATERIAL PLANNER/MRP/Names and create an MRP plan name
        then click Options button and complete options.
    Launch an MRP Calculation -> MATERIAL PLANNER/MRP/Launch
        or run 'Launch Planning Process' from the concurrent manager
    Review and modify MRP results online -> MATERIAL PLANNER/MRP/Workbench
    Copy an existing plan to do simulations -> MATERIAL PLANNER/MRP/Copy Plan

Master Scheduling/Material Resource Planning (MRP) Interfaces:
    Open Forecasts Interface: imports forecasts via MRP_FORECAST_INTERFACE
    Forecast Entries API: table of entries and designators for importing as a forecast - call mrp_forecast_interface to import
    Open Master Schedule Interface: import master demand or production schedules via MRP_SCHEDULE_INTERFACE

Master Scheduling/Material Resource Planning (MRP) Concurrent Processes:
    Planning Manager - accessed via Planning Manager form
