Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Project Statuses
    The primary project statuses are:
        Unapproved
        Submitted
        Approved
        Rejected
        Pending Closed
        Closed
        Pending Purge - can apply to previously Open or Closed projects
        Partially Purged - transactions purged but master and summary data retained (must have been Closed initially)
        Purged - transactions and summary data purged but master data retained (must have been Closed initially)
        Each of these statuses is defined as allowing transitions to the other statuses
    Reference: Oracle Projects Implementation Guide > Project Definition > Defining Statuses and Status Profile Options
    Navigation: Project Superuser -> Setup > System > Statuses > Status Type = 'Project'
        There are two tabs: 'Functions' and 'Workflow'
    There are several project status types: Project, Task, Assignment, Progress Status (of a task), Candidate, Control Item, Deliverable, Deliverable Action, Funding
        Each status type applies to a different series of statuses with different purpposes: e.g. project level vs. task level
    Statuses are user defined or seeded and inclued a user status and internal system status - any new user status must be assigned to an internal system status
        This way Oracle knows from the System Status how to treat the new status and what rules to apply
    For the 'Project' Status Type, typical project user statuses (which are predefined by Oracle) are: Unapproved, Submitted for Approval, Approved, Pending Close, Closed
    You can create new user project statuses or use the seeded ones and modify their attributes
    Attributes of statuses include:
        Description - user entered description (not used by Oracle on seeded statuses)
        Effective From - effective to date
        Effective To - effective end date
        Starting Flag - indicates if the status can be used as a starting status for the object to which it applies
    Each user status (you can define additional ones) must map to a predefined internal 'System Status' on this form
        Each system status determines the available Status Controls (actions) that are allowed for the user status
        Check or uncheck the Status Controls  to make then available or unavailable for a specific status
            The 'Default' check box is display-only and shows the original setting seeded by Oracle
    Transitions between these status can be managed by a Project Status Workflow (optional)
        Workflow approval can be implemented globally or for specific projects only (e.g. large projects)
        Workflow approval can also be implemented for specific transitions (e.g. from 'Submitted' to 'Approved')
            You enable workflow for a specific status with the 'Enable Workflow' checkbox on the Workflow Tab of the Status Maintenance form

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Periods and Period Statuses
    Projects has two period types: PA Periods and GL Periods
        PA Periods are used for reporting
            PA Periods can be more frequent or the same as GL Periods
            These must be open in order to choose a period on Project Status Inquiry
        GL Periods are used for accounting
            GL Period Maintenance is controlled by the Implementation Option 'Maintain Common PA and GL Periods'
                If this option is set in Projects Implementation Options, period statuses can only be updated to GL Period Statuses
                    Click 'Copy from GL' in 'Maintain PA Period Statuses' to update period statuses to match GL
                If this option is not set, period statuses can be maintained in Projects directly
                    Edit period statuses directly in 'Maintain PA Period Statuses' to update period statuses
    Period Statuses are
        Never Opened - the initial project status. You can enter budgets and forecasts but you cannot post transactions
        Future - has the same privileges as 'Open' and is intended for use in accepting transactions from other modules which are open earlier than Projects for the same period
        Open - allows posting of transactions and interfacing to the general ledger. Open is normally set when transactions are entered directly into Projects even though the period may have been 'Future Open' to allow interfaced transactions earlier
        Pending Close - prevents entry of new transactions but allows corrections to existing transactions
        Closed - used to prevent the posting of transactions
        Permanently Closed - cannot be reopened

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Creating Expenditure Items
    Navigation: Expenditures -> Pre-Approved Batches -> Enter
        Enter a batch, and expenditure lines
        Note that all expenditures can be imported through the standard interface for expenditure item import (e.g. Maximo)
    Transactions can be uploaded via WebADI
        See Oracle Costing User Guide 'Uploading Expenditures from Microsoft Excel'
        Transactions are loaded into PA_TRANSACTION_INTERFACE_ALL initially
        The Integrator for this function is 'Projects - Transaction Import'
        You have the option of automatically importing transactions from the ADI Template
            The template submits 'PRC: Transaction Import' to import the transactions
        You must use a valid Expenditure Item Ending Date
            Check the correct value in Setup -> System -> Implementation Options -> Expenditure Cycle Start Day
    Once an expenditure batch is entered, click 'Submit' to submit for review and approval
        Batches will remain in working status until submitted
        While in working status they can be modified and deleted
    Click 'Release' to release submitted batches for distribution
        Once a batch is released it can no longer be reworked or deleted - it must be reversed

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Transferring Costs Between Projects
    You can transfer costs between projects by querying the cost
    Find the expenditure items in Expenditure Item Inquiry and choose 'Transfer' from the menu
    Enter the new project and task and click OK
    Run the cost distribution process to create accounting.

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Transaction Import
    Transactions are loaded into the PA_TRANSACTION_INTERFACE_ALL and imported by runnning the 'PRC: Transaction Import' concurrent process
    All transactions in a single batch are rejected if a single transaction is in error
        You must page through all the good transactions in a batch to find the one or two bad transactions
        A quicker way is to query transactions in PA_TRANSACTION_INTERFACE_ALL to find the items with error reasons
    The are loaded with Released Status so cannot be reworked and deleted, they must be reversed.
    You can delete items from a batch in the interface table
        Navigation: Expenditures > Transaction Import > Review Transactions
        The transaction Review form does not support selecting multiple transactions

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Transaction Controls
    Transaction Controls limit what can be charged to a project
        They also allow rules about what items are capitalizable vs. non-capitalizable
    Transaction controls are setup within each project by adding the attribute to the Project Template
    Transaction Controls can be inclusive or exclusive (they are exclusive by default)
        This is controled by the check box 'Limit to Transaction Controls' on the Transaction Controls Setup Form

Project Costing and Billing (PA) Notes on Project Costing Processes
    Costing is the processing of expenditures to determine their full costs and to determine their charge accounts
    Expenditures processed by Project Costing include:
        Pre-approved expenditures: labor(timesheets), expenses (expense reports), usages (purchase order), usages and miscellaneous transactions
        Burden costs
        Expenses submitted via Oracle Internet Expenses
        Supplier invoices from AP
        Imported expenditures
        Adjusted expenditures requiring re-costing
    The primary processes in Project Costing are:
        Enter transactions or import transactions
        Distribute Costs (calculate raw and standard costs, calculate burdens, calculate curency conversions, assign accounting distributions)
        Perform Accounting
        Interface transactions to AP (Project Expense Reports) and GL (costs not already accounted)

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Auto Accounting
    Tricks and Tips
        Always specify a warehouse on an invoice line to pick up the revenue account for an item
            Otherwise it will pull the revenue account from the master org for the item
        References:
            How is Revenue Account Derived For Manual Invoices Based On Standard Lines (Doc ID 1340582.1)
    Autoaccounting is used within projects to assign GL accounts to transactions entered directly into Projects
    Account Generator on the other hand is used to derive project accounts in requisitions, purchase orders and payables invoices
        Primary accounting includes:
            liability accounts for costs,
            accounts for unbilled receivables and unearned revenue
            accounts for costs entered directly into Projects and not from interfaced systems
        This applies to transactions that were not coded by feeder systems such as purchasing
            (i.e.  where the source is not tagged as 'pre-accounted')
        Autoaccounting also assigns accounts for transactions originating within Projects
    Autoaccounting is primarily used to build the distribution for labor costs not pre-accounted by feeder systems.
        Other transactions are mostly pre-accounted in the feeder systems to Projects
    How it works
        AutoAccounting consists of predefined accounting functions that are called by processes that create accounting values (e.g.'Distribute' processes)
            These functions are predefined and cannot be extended by setup or configuration - you choose which ones you need to use
        Each function is a assigned an autoaccounting rule that has the logic to derive the account values
            Within each autoaccounting function are function transactions that provide additional granularity - different function transactions can be assigned different rules
            Oracle defines the transactions within each autoaccounting function - you cannot extend them by configuration or setup
            Individual function transactions can be enabled or disabled under each autoaccounting function
            Enabled function transactions must be assigned autoaccounting rules
            If Oracle needs a rule on a function transaction and it is not defined and enabled, it uses a fallback transaction for the function
            Within each accounting function there is an 'all transaction'transaction that is the highest level fallback segment rule
            Note that autoaccounting rules can be set up once for a given chart of accounts but the assignment of those rules to function transactions is operating unit specific
        Each autoaccounting rule can be further defined by lookup sets
        When the autoaccounting function is called by a distribution process, it looks up the assigned rule and uses it to derive the account
        Each autoaccounting rule supplies only one segment value (called segment/rule pairings) so you need to assign a rule for each segment and assign it to an accounting function
        An autoaccounting rule first derives an 'intermediate value' which can be a constant, a parameter or a SQL statement result
        Autoaccounting uses this value as the segment value if no Lookup Set is defined. If a lookup set is defined, it uses the value as a lookup of the final segment value
            If the intermediate value is one of several predefined parameters (e.g. Project Organization) the lookup set can be defined to return a different segment value for different project organization values
            If the intermediate value is a SQL Statement, the returned value can be based on more than one 'parameter' by coding this logic in the SQL Statement
                The purpose of a SQL statement is to support rules based on mor than one parameter - not to supplement the existing list of parameters (SQL Statements have a performance hit)
                Use the rule parameters region on the AutoAccounting rule definition form to define inputs to the SQL (referenced in the SQL statement as binds, e.g. ':1', ':2' etc)
        You can define the intermediate value to be the actual segment value on the form by setting the Segment Value Source to 'Intermediate Value'
            Otherwise define a lookup set before defining the AutoAccounting rule and assign the lookup set as the segment value
        A lookup set is defined from the Lookup Set button in the Segment Value region of the AutoAccounting Rules definition form
            A lookup set is a set of name/value pairs hwere the name is the intermediate value and the resulting value is the segment value that is used for the account
    Autoaccounting is used by cost processes to determine account distributions for:
        Distribute Labor Costs,
        Interface Expense Reports to Payables,
        Interface Labor Costs to GL,
        Distribute Usage Costs,
        Interface Total Burdened Costs to GL,
        Distribute total Burdened Costs, and
        Distribute Expense Reports
    Autoaccounting is used by revenue processes to determine accounts for:
        Generate Draft Revenue
    Autoaccounting FAQ's are in Metalink Note 223031.1
    Cost Functions and Transactions in AutoAccounting
        Borrowed and Lent Credit Account - Determines borrowed account, which is the credit side of the borrowed and lent transaction
        Burden Cost Account - Determines cost account for burden costs
        Burden Cost Clearing Account - Determines clearing account for burden costs
        Expense Report Cost Account -  Determines cost account for expense report items
        Intercompany Invoice Accounts - Determines receivables and rounding accounts for cross-charged transactions requiring intercompany billing processing
        Labor Cost Account - Determines cost account for all labor items, including straight time and overtime
        Labor Cost Clearing Account - Determines clearing account for labor costs
        Borrowed and Lent Account Debit Account - Determines lent account, which is the debit side of the borrowed and lent transaction
        Miscellaneous Transaction Clearing Account - Determines clearing account for miscellaneous transactions
        Miscellaneous Transaction Cost Account - Determines cost account for miscellaneous transactions
        Provider Cost Reclass Cr - Determines credit amount for cross-charged costs reclassified by the provider operating unit
        Provider Cost Reclass Dr - Determines debit amount for cross-charged costs reclassified by the provider operating unit
        Supplier Invoice Cost Account - Determines cost account for adjusted supplier cost items
        Total Burdened Cost Credit - Determines credit account for total burdened costs for all items on burdened projects
        Total Burdened Cost Debit - Determines debit account for total burdened costs for all items on burdened projects
        Usage Cost Account - Determines cost account for usage items
        Usage Cost Clearing Account - Determines clearing account for usage cost
    Intermediate Rule Attributes Include
        Class Code  AutoAccounting class code on the project.
            Note: Since you can define many project classification categories, the Class Code parameter always corresponds to the one classification category that you specified as the AutoAccounting classification category.
        Labor Costing Rule  Labor Costing rule of the employee who incurs the expenditure
        Customer ID  Internal ID of the internal customer you define for the receiver operating unit
        Customer Name  Internal customer you define for the receiver operating unit
        Employee Number  Employee number of the employee who incurs the expenditure
        Event Num  Event number of the event
        Event Organization  Organization for the event
        Event Organization ID  Internal identifier of the organization for the Event
        Event Type  The classification of the event
        Expenditure Category  Expenditure category of the expenditure item
        Expenditure Item ID  Internal identifier that identifies each expenditure item
        Expenditure Operating Unit  Operating unit that incurs the expenditure
        Expenditure Operating Unit ID  Internal identifier of the operating unit that incurs the expenditure
        Expenditure Organization  Organization that incurs the expenditure
        Expenditure Organization ID  Internal identifier of the organization that incurs the expenditure
        Expenditure Type  Expenditure type of the expenditure item
        Labor Cost Multiplier  Labor cost multiplier of the task charged
        Non-Labor Resource  Non-labor resource utilized for the expenditure
        Non-Labor Resource Org.  Non-labor resource-owning organization
        Non-Labor Resource Org. ID  Internal identifier of the non-labor resource-owning organization
        Person ID  Internal identifier of the person who incurs the expenditure
        Person Type  Identifies whether a person is an employee or a contingent worke
            Note: If transactions have no Person Type parameter, use a SQL statement to derive your AutoAccounting rules.
        Project ID  Internal identifier of the project being charged
        Project Number  The number of the project being charged
        Project Operating Unit  Project-managing operating unit
        Project Operating Unit ID  Internal identifier of the project-managing operating unit
        Project Organization  Project-managing organization
        Project Organization ID  Internal identifier of the project-managing organization
        Project Type  Project type of the project charged
        Provider Organization  Organization incurring the cross-charged transaction
        Provider Organization ID  Internal identifier of the organization incurring the cross-charged transaction
        Receiver Organization  Organization whose project receives the cross-charged transaction
        Receiver Organization ID  Internal identifier of the organization whose project receives the cross-charged transaction
        Revenue Category  Revenue category of the expenditure item
        Task ID  Internal identifier of the task charged
        Task Number  Task number of task charged
        Task Organization  Task-managing organization
        Task Organization ID  Internal identifier of the task-managing organization
        Task Service Type  Service type of the task charged
        Top Task ID  Internal identifier of the highest level parent task of the task charged
        Top Task Number  Task number of the highest level parent task of the task charged
        Supplier Type  Supplier type of the supplier on the invoice

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Multiple Reporting Currencies (MRC)
    You must export journal entries to the primary set of books before the secondary set of books if MRC is enabled

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Major Setups:
    Primary Setups include:
        Project Types - include a default service type for a Project
        Service Types - at the task level
        Template Projects

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Creating New Projects:
    You can only create a new project by copying from an existing project or template
        Oracle will force you to select a template or existing project first (i.e. 'Find' dialog)
    You can also upload a project via WebADI

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Project Cost Budgets
    Budgets are created as Draft and in Working or Submitted status (submitted for baselining)
    Each baseline has an incremented budget version number
    Successive baselines can be copied to create a new draft and the version number of the draft is always 1
        This applies to working and submitted drafts
        When the submitted budget is baselined, the version becomes the next higher available version number
        The original draft version number 1 is always retained after baselining
        If you copy a baseline budget to a new draft, the existing draft is overwritten
    PA_BUDGET_VERSIONS stores all the budget versions
    Budget Entry Methods
        Time-phased - allows entry by GL Period, PA Period or Date Range
        Inception to Completion

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Project Status Inquiry (PSI):
    Project Status Inquiry (PSI) is a set of forms that displays summary project info and drilldowns as of a specified date
        The information is only as current as the last time the 'PRC: Update Project Summary Amounts' job was run
        The period also defaults to the current reporting period set in PA Periods
            You can change the current reporting period in PA Periods to any period value
            Navigation: PA Periods > PA Periods > Ctrl-F11 (Blind Query) > Set Reporting Period (button) > Enter New Reporting Period > OK
        The PSI forms are configurable through a column setup (Projects/Setups/Project Status Columns)
    A concurrent process 'Update Project Summary Accounts' populates accumulation tables which support the Project Status Inquiry form
        So the status is current as of the last run for this process
    The PA Period 'Reporting Period' flag controls the period shown at the top of the Project Status Inquiry main form
        If the PA Period 'Reporting Period' has not been advanced during the month-end close you can do it at any time
         Navigation: PA Periods > PA Periods > Ctrl-F11 (Blind Query) > Set Reporting Period (button) > Enter New Reporting Period > OK
    PSI displays commitments (all project related purchase orders whether or not interfaced to Projects)
    The full list of PSI processes includes:
        PRC: Refresh Transaction Summary Amounts (PAXACRPT)
        PRC: Refresh Project Summary Amounts (PAXACRTA)
        PRC: Update Project Summary Amounts for a Single Project (PAXACMPT_SINGLE)
        PRC: Update Project Summary Amounts (for a Range of Projects) (PAXACMPT)
        PRC: Update Project Summary Amounts after a Resource List Change (PAXACRLT)
    Accumulation of project status is done in four periods:
        inception to date,
        year to date,
        prior period and
        period to date, for budget and actual numbers for costs and revenues
    Project Status Inquiry (PSI) supports drilldown from summary totals through the task structure
        It drills into resources and as far as idividual transactions
    There are three views supporting the PSI forms
        PA_STATUS_PROJ_V
        PA_STATUS_TASK_V
        PA_STATUS_RSRC_V
    The base tables underlying PSI that hold accumulated values for projects are:
        PA_TXN_ACCUM - updated but not period dependent
        PA_RESOURCE_ACCUM_DETAILS - updated but not period dependent
        PA_PROJECT_ACCUM_HEADERS - updated for the current period
        PA_PROJECT_ACCUM_ACTUALS - updated for the current period
        PA_PROJECT_ACCUM_BUDGETS - updated for the current period
        PA_PROJECT_ACCUM_COMMITMENTS - updated for the current period
    Technical notes include:
        PSI Frequently Asked Questions Note: 222320.1
        PSI Troubleshooting Guide Note 222659.1
    Exercise: Inquire Project Status -> PBSU/Project Status/Project Status Inquiry, and use the find button to locate the project.
        Inquire on multiple project attributes, costs, commitments, events, invoices through a dashboard for the project

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Allocations and Burdening:
    Burdening uses a cost group (of items in a project) and burden multiplier to gross up the costs by the burden amount to cover overhead
    Allocations is new to 11i and allocates actual costs from another project
        (or parts of another project - 'Project Sources')
        or from GL accounts ('GL Sources')
        and charges these costs directly to a project
    Allocations are rule-based. They define the source of the costs, the targets and the method for spreading the costs to the target items
    Allocation rules can be grouped with Autoallocation sets to run as a request set (together with GL allocations) for parallel or step-down allocations
    Define an allocation rule -> PBSU/Allocations/Allocation Rules, and enter the rule and sources for the allocation and the project and line targets
    Establish a burden base -> PBSU/Setup/Costing/Burden, ...

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Billing and Revenue Accruals:
    Contract projects (class = contract) allow for accrual of revenue directly to the GL, or billing as a draft invoice into receivables
    Revenue can be accrued on a project as it is earned, then billed on the project according to the customer agreement.
        This allows revenue recognition on the ledger ahead of actual revenue
    Revenue accrual debits unbilled AR, and credits Revenue. Billing credits unbilled AR, and debits AR.
    Invoices are sent to Receivables through the AR Invoice Open Interface and processed by Autoinvoice.
        GL is updated from AR and not from Projects
    A contract project must be funded before revenue can be accrued or billed.
        If existing funding is fully used, no further revenue or billing will take place
    Revenue and billing can be done using one of several 'distribution rules' in the project setup:
        on a cost (actual vs budgeted costs determine revenue percent),
        event (specific milestone events) or
        work basis
    Interproject billing (within the same operating unit) is done by billing from one project and running a 'tie-back' process
        It creates a payables invoice to the other project.
        AP sends the payables distribution to projects
    Intercompany billing is used to transfer costs between companies (operating units) for the same project.
        This uses the 'borrowed and lent' process to transfer costs from a project in one org to a project in another.
        Then a cross charge GL journal is used to move the GL entries as well
    If a project is split across legal entities, the sub project in one entity must create an invoice and bill to the other legal entity.
        Invoice tieback is used to create the purchase invoice for the second entity from the receivable invoice in the first entity

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Business Intelligence and Project Analysis Collection Pack (PACP):
    Financials Intelligence includes three pre-built Discoverer workbooks for projects:
        Projects Cost Analysis, Projects Revenue Analysis and Projects Margin Analysis
    PACP is a series of programs that populate a separate star schema for data warehouse inquiry.
        It reports on broader time period options than the PSI form and underlying collection packs
    Database triggers on the base tables set flags to include individual transactions in the next data collection run to export to the star schema
    The PACP schema can be customized and any Oracle reporting tools can be used against it.

Project Costing (PA Schema) Notes on Organizations and Organization Hierarchies Notes:
    Each project is owned by a single operating unit - the Project Operating Unit Owner
    Project numbers and project templates are uniquely numbered across all operating units in an installation
    Customers and suppliers are uniquely numbered across all operating units in an installation
        Customer sites and supplier sites are unique to each operating unit
    Customer agreements are owned by individual operating units
    You can charge expenditures from any organization to any project ...
        as long as the project's "Project Operating Unit" and "Expenditure Operating Units" are eligible for cross-charging
            These are system options within the Projects Responsibility
        and ... as long as the charging organization is classified as a Project Expenditure Operating Unit.
    Project Expenditure Operating Units process all expenditures on a project within their own operating units
        You enter and process expenditures in the "Expenditure Operating Unit"
            These can be expense reports, timecards and non labor resources (e.g. purchases)
        Costs are calculated in the Expenditure Operating Unit at the rates setup for the Expenditure OPU
        Cost burdens are also calculated in the Expenditure Operating Unit
        Journal entries are created in the Expenditure Operating Unit
            The AutoAccounting or Account Generator processes and configs from the Expenditure OPU are used
        Supplier invoices are transfered to Payables within the same Expenditure Operating Unit
        Labor costs are transfered to the GL in the set of books corresponding to the Expenditure Operating Unit
        Expense reports are tranferred to AP within the same Expenditure Operating Unit
            If an expense report is entered into Payables first, it is entered int the Expenditure Operating Unit
            The costs are transferred to Projects in the same Expenditure Operating Unit
        You can view expenditures in projects in either Project Mode, or Cross Project Mode
            Project mode is based on the Project Owning Operating Unit
            Cross-Project mode is based on the Expenditure Operating Units that charged to the project
    Project Owning Operating Units process all revenue and generates invoices from costs processed in Expenditure Units
        AutoAccounting defaults on Project Owning Organizations can drive revenue accounting and reporting
        You enter and process revenues in the "Project Owning Operating Unit"
        The Project Operating Unit calculates draft revenues and draft invoices using bill rates, overrides and multipliers
            It will only pick up costs for billing if the Expenditure Operating Unit has processed them
        The Project Operating Unit uses auto-accounting to create journal entries for billing transactions
        The Project Operating Unit also uses auto-accounting to transfer revenue to GL and transfer invoices to AR
        Project Owning Operating Units can submit reports on a project that cross all Expenditure Operating Units
        Assets created from the project are posted to the Corporate Asset book for the Project Operating Unit
    There are project specific organizations: "project/task owning", "Expenditure", "and "Invoice/Collection"
        A single "project owning" or "project expenditure" organization can roll up to multiple OPU's
        This is because the relationship is maintained in PA_ALL_ORGANIZATIONS which has one row for each rollup
        Projects tracks both the OPU and the Project Org when stamping transactions with Org ID's
    Project/task owning organizations (classification 'PA_PROJECT_ORG' on the HR_ORGANIZATION_INFORMATION table)
        these organizations can be assigned to projects and tasks and 'own'the project
        these project organizations 'receive' from expenditure organizations (see below)
        they are also marked as 'PROJECT' in the PA_ORG_USE_TYPE column on the denormalized PA_ALL_PROJECTS table
        Project owning organizations can be used by Auto-accounting to look up accounting segments for GL coding
        For cross-charge purposes they are the receiving organizations
    Project/Expenditure Event Orgs (classification 'PA_EXPENDITURE_ORG')
        expenditure orgs can charge to projects, track expenditures and hold budgets
        typically many organizations within a company are classifed as expenditure organizations
            This is so that they can charge projects
            It applies to operating unit organizations and lower
            Expenditure Orgs are also normally classified as HR_ORGS so they can have employees (who charge to projects)
        these organizations can be assigned to transactions in projects so these orgs are recorded on project charges
        they 'provide' resources and costs to the project
        they can include HR organizations (i.e. departments) employees are assigned to, for time and expense entry
        they can include operating units where purchases are made and charged to projects
        Thea are also marked as 'EXPENDITURE' in the PA_ORG_USE_TYPE column on the denormalized PA_ALL_PROJECTS table
        expenditure orgs can track expenditures and be assigned/hold expenditure budgets
        they must be in the expenditure hierarchy in order to be charged to a project
    project/invoice collection and (classifiction 'PA_INVOICE_ORG')
    Organization hierarchy setups can be changed in Oracle Projects
    Projects specific org hierarchies begin at the Operating Unit level in the overall Oracle Organization structure
    The main type of project organization is the "project/task" organization type
        A single project/task "typed" project organization is attached to each project as the "owning" organization
            This organization assignemnt is viewable on the main projects maintenance form
            The organization must be a projec/task org type rolling up to an operating unit`
            This means a project can be at the OPU level or lower in a project/task hieararchy
            Individual projects are attached to these organizations
    The allowed reporting hierarchies and starting points for an OPU can be viewed in Project Setups
        Navigation: Projects/Setups/System/Implementation Options (System, Project Setup, Expnd/Costing)
        These hierarchies can be viewed in Org setups
            Navigation: PSU/Resources and Organizations/HR Foundation/Work Structures/Organization/Hierarchy
    Project Organization Hierarchies can be analyzed by getting a list of all operating units and then:
        Looking at the Implementation Options in Projects for each Operating Unit
        Noting the hierarchy types and names and starting points
        Switching over to the HR Hierarchy setups and displaying the hieararchiesd
    Project organization information is stored in a denormalized table PA_ALL_ORGANIZATIONS
        Most Organziation Lists of Values in Projects are based on this table
        This table is not always updated when org definitions change - a source of many bugs
        To force an update, temporarily change the start org for the expenditure or project hierarchy and change it back
            This triggers an update to the PA_ALL_ORGANIZATIONS table
        This table carries the ORGANIZATION_ID, ORG_ID (of the owning OPU), PA_ORG_USE_TYPE (either Project or Expenditure)
    Projects in different business groups can be visible if the profile option "HR:Cross Business Group" is set
    Exercise: Establish project organization hierarchies for an operating unit: Projects Superuser/Setup/System/Implementation Options
        These setups are stored in PA_IMPLEMENTATIONS_ALL

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Cross Charging (Borrowed and Lent, and Inter-Company Billing)
    Cross charging allows expenditure organizations to charge to a project owned by a different organization
        The project owning organization can be a different "project owning" organization, operating unit or legal entity
    It allows a single project to be setup and different organizations to incur expenses and recover their costs
    All the costs are ultimately transferred to the owning organization to capitalize, expense or move to inventory
    Cross charging is accomplished in one of two ways - Borrowed and Lent, or Inter-Company Billing:
        Borrowed and Lent - journal entries are created to relieve the CIP/WIP of the expenditure organization
            There are no invoices created with "Borrowed and Lent" so Project Billing is not required
                This limits Borrowed and Lent activity to projects within a legal entity (otherwise invoices are needed)
            The WIP/CIP account of the project owning organization is charged and the WIP/CIP of the expenditure org is relieved
            Oracle Projects determines the appropriate costs based on transfer pricing rules of the provider and receiver
            It is calculated by the Project Costing process "PRC - Distribute Borrowed and Lent Amounts"
        Intercompany Billing - invoices are created in AR to relieve the CIP/WIP of the expenditure organization
            Companies choose this method for legal and statutory reasons because it creates an invoice payable and receivable
            A physical invoice is created in AP for the owning organization to shift the charge
            Accounting entries are created at legal transfer prices based on the invoices created, through normal AP and AR
        In both cases the owning organization is charged the costs to their CIP/WIP accounts
    Cross charging controls specifically enable and limit cross charging to specific projects and tasks
        Cross charging is only allowed if the Expenditure and Owner Operating Units are enabled for Cross charges
        Cross charge controls can be specified at the operating unit, project and task level
        There are no intra-operating unit cross charge controls
            they are allowed if the project and task are 'owned' by the expenditure operating unit
            i.e. the owner and expenditure organizations on the project are the same
            Transaction controls should be used to limit what can be charged on intra-company charges
        There are several controls for inter-company (operating unit) cross charging
            For the provider, cross charge implementation options on each operating unit allow/disallow cross charging
                They also determine if Borrowed and Lent, or intercompany billing will be used
                If intercompany billing is used, they also specify the billing project that will create the invoice
            For the receiver, they specify whether the OPU will accept cross charges
                The also specify the name of each OPU that will be allowed to cross charge to the receiver
                They also require the specific project to be turned on to accept cross charges
        There are several controls for inter-company (legal entity) cross charging (similar to inter-operating unit controls)
            For the provider legal entity's operating unit, an option is activated to allow inter-company billing
            Specify each receiver operating unit that can be sent cross-charge transactions
        For the receiver, they specify whether the receiving OPU will accept cross charges
            The also specify the name of each OPU that will be allowed to cross charge to the receiver
            They also require the specific project to be turned on to accept cross charges
    Cross Charge Transfer Pricing Rules control calculation of tranfer prices for labor and non-labor cross charges
        Transfer pricing rules are setup between organizations
        Lines can be created at the "project organization/operating unit/legal entity/business group" levels
        Projects will find and use the rules at the lowest applicable organization level
    Additional Controls for Cross Charges
        Cross charges can also be limited by project, task, expenditure type and transaction source
        Client extension rules may also be defined to customize cross charge controls
    Transfer Prices for Cross Charging (Borrowed and Lent vs Inter-Company Billing)
        Transfer prices can be "Legal Transfer Prices" or "Transfer Prices"
            "Legal Transfer Prices" are the prices charged at arm's length between legal entities
            "Transfer Prices" are internally agreed prices charged between organizations within a legal entity
        The transfer price basis may be raw cost, burdened cost or revenue
        The transfer price calculation method defines the calculation rule (including upcharge ratios)
        Currency conversion is done between operating units using the currency options defined for each operating unit
    Transfer price schedules associate rules with provider and receiver organizations
        The simplest schedule would be a single rule used by all organizations
    Processing Flow for Borrowed and Lent Amounts
        The "Provider" operating unit enters expenditure transactions just like any other expenditure transactions
        The "Provider" OPU runs charge distributions in their own company
            Oracle identifies cross charges based on the cross-charge setups
        The "Provider" runs PRC: Distribute Borrowed and Lent Amounts"
            This calculates transfer prices and generates accounting entries
        The "Provider" runs PRC: Interface Cross Charge Distributions to GL
    Logic Used to Determine Cross Charges by Oracle Projects and Related Accounting
        Oracle determines the cross charge organizations for a transaction (provider and receiver)
            This is used to determine intra-company, inter-operating unit or inter-legal entity charge
        Oracle also determines the cross charge method between the entities: borrowed and lent or billed
    Accounting Entries Generated by Cross Charge
        Cross charging debits the receiver's charge account and credits the provider's charge account
        This is actually done by two entries (if the balancing segment of the provider and receiver are the same)
            A "Lent" (Asset) account is debited for the "Provider" cost center
            A "Borrowed" (Liability) account is credited for the "Receiver" cost center
        If the Borrowed and Lent amounts are booked to different balancing segments,
            an inter-company revenue account would be used for offsetting entries
            i.e. Provider DR "Lent" asset/receivable, CR "Inter-Company Revenue" income account
                 Receiver DR "Inter-Company Revenue" income account, CR "Borrowed" liability account
    Setups for Cross Charging
        Set Cross Charge and Internal Billing Options -> /Project Administrator/System/Implementation Options/
        Setup Provider/Receiver Controls -> /Project Administrator/Setup/Costs
        Enable a Project for Cross charge -> Project Responsibility/Projects (Find)/Options/Cross-Charge/Allow Cross Charge from Other Operating Units
            Appears only if cross-charging is enabled
    Profile Options
        Get access to projects in all business groups -> HR: Cross Business Group

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Capitalization and Assets:
    References
        Information Center: Capital Projects and Asset Capitalization in Oracle Projects R12 (Doc ID 1405456.2)
    Assets can only be created for Capital Projects
        New assets can only be defined and created if the Project Type is has a Project Class of 'Capital'
            Navigation: Projects Superuser -> Setup -> Projects -> Project Types -> (inquire on a Project Type)
        Retirement assets can be created to collect the costs of retiring assets - taking them out of service
            Retirement assets can be created in the same project as new assets, or placed in separate projects
    Assets must have an "In-Service" date attribute populated in order to be sent to Oracle Fixed Assets
        The in-service date must be in the current open FA period or prior period - future dates will not be exported
        The Asset must be changed to 'As-Built' from 'Estimated' to activate the 'In Service Date' field
    Enter or inquire on assets via the project screen -> Options -> Assets
        There may be multiple assets on this screen - displayed one at a time (page through)
    Asset attributes are defined in Projects to allow capitalization of their costs in Fixed Assets
    Assets are assigned to a project or task once they are defined
        Inquire on asset assignments at the project level through "Projects/Options/Asset Information/Asset Assignments"
        Inquire on asset assignments at the task level through "Projects/Tasks/Options/Asset Assignment"
    References:
        Creating Assets in Oracle Projects, Oracle Project Costing User Guide
        Asset Grouping Levels, Oracle Project Costing User Guide
        Metalink Note 866310.1 What Are The Steps to Generate Asset Lines and Interface Them to Oracle Fixed Assets?
    Process Outline for Capitalizing Assets on a Project
        This process applies to one or more assets on a single project
            Each asset can be capitalized at a different time for different amounts even if there is only one task for all assets
        Create an active Project with a Project Type that is Capital
            i.e. the Project Type has a Project Class of 'Capital'
        Post Expenditures to the Project (either Invoices or Non-Invoiced Expenditures)
        Define one or more assets on the Project
            You must fill out all required fields and the Location Flexfield if the option 'Require Complete Asset Definition' is enabled
                Check the value of this option on the Project Type definition
                    Navigation: Project Superuser -> Setup -> Projects -> Project Types -> (query capital project type) -> Capitalization Information
        Assign the assets to the Project or to Tasks on the Project
            If you assign assets to a task then only the costs for that task are capitalizable to the Asset
            You can assign an asset to a summary task or detail task
            You can assign multiple assets to the same task without restricting how and when each asset is capitalized
        Change the Project Asset Type from 'Estimated' to 'As-Built' and assign an Actual Date in Service
            The process that collects Asset Costs for Capitalization is based on the Asset Actual In Service Date
            Navigation: Projects Superuser -> Capitalization -> Capital Projects -> (Find Project) -> Assets (button)
                Change the Project Asset Type from 'Estimated' to 'As-Built' and enter an Actual Date In Service
                The actual in-service date must be in the current or a prior period in order to export
            You do not have to change every asset to 'As-Built' - leave any incomplete assets as 'Estimated' for later capitalization
                Any assets that are 'Estimated' will not be assigned asset lines and exported to Fixed Assets
                Their costs can be left unassigned for later regeneration and assignment
        Create Asset Lines
            This process can be run manually in SRS or through the forms
            Run 'PRC: Generate Asset Lines'
                This process creates asset lines to pass to FA Mass Additions
                    It attempts to assign project costs to Assets but if it cannot, 'unassigned' asset lines are created for manual assignment
                Navigation: Projects Superuser -> Capitalization -> Capital Projects -> (Find Project) -> Generate
            Conditions Required to Meet the Criteria for Capitalizing Costs
                Expenditures must be costed and interfaced to the general ledger before they can be grouped onto asset lines
                The Net Zero flag on the expenditure line must not be checked - net zero lines (accruals reversed later) are not capitalized
                The Grouped CIP flag on the asset line must not be checked - if it is checked then the charge has already been capitalized
                    Note - if the capital amount has not been transfered to assets, it may be regenerated on the next run
                The Capitalizable flag on the expenditure line must be checked
                The Costs Distributed flag on the expenditure lines must be checked - costs must have been previously distributed
                The 'Expenditure Through Date' Through on the 'PRC: Generate Asset Lines' must be on or after the end of the month
                    This is the case if the CIP Grouping Rule is based on the GL or PA period being monthly
                    The log file for each run shows the PA Date Entered and the PA Date used to confirm this
                Assets must be assigned to the tasks where the costs lie
                The project status must allow for capitalization
                The Asset In Service date and Expenditure Date parameters on 'PRC: Generate Asset Lines' must cover the actual dates for these items
                If the project capitalization method for the Project Type includes capitalizing burdened costs the 'Distribute Total Burdened Costs' must be run first
            Bugs in Capitalization
                Lines will not capitalize if the PA_PROJECT_ASSETS.CAPITALIZED_COST values don't match PA_PROJECT_ASSET_LINES.CURRENT_ASSET_COST
                Unpublished Note 386597.1
            The Generated Asset Lines are Grouped in three ways
                1. WBS Grouping -> Costs on a Task are Grouped to An Asset Assigned to the Task (if there is only one asset)
                2. CIP Grouping -> Costs are also grouped based on the Grouping Rules defined for the Project Type
                    A common grouping rule is 'Expenditure Type' where all costs are grouped for the same expenditure type (within the task)
                    This grouping rule is controlled on the Project Type Definition in Setup
                        Navigation: Projects Superuser -> Setup -> Projects -> Project Types -> (Query a Capital Project Type) -> Capitalization Information -> Grouping Method
                    There is a flag on the Project Types/Capitalization region for grouping invoices - if it is unchecked then invoice line charges are not grouped.
                    If invoice line charges are not grouped, the description on the asset line is 'Invoice' '+' <Invoice ID> '+' <Invoice Distribution ID>
                3. Account Grouping -> Costs are grouped based on their CIP Account but not across multiple CIP accounts
                    This is done because Projects sends the CIP account on the Asset Line to Assets to relieve when the Asset is capitalized
            This process can be rerun any number of times - rerunning deletes any asset lines created previously unless the lines have been exported to Fixed Assets
                Both assigned lines (lines actually assigned to a project asset) and unassigned lines are all deleted and regenerated
                If you don't want to lose earlier assignments, export the lines to Fixed Assets before rerunning the process (see below)
        Review the Generated Asset Lines
            Navigation: Projects Superuser -> Capitalization -> Capital Projects -> Lines
            Each line will be assigned to an asset if the assignment rule is unambiguous (e.g. only one asset assigned to a task)
                Unassigned lines may be assigned manually be entering the asset name on each asset line
                Unassigned lines can also be split before assigning to assets
                Assignments can be manually changed
                Asset line descriptions can be manually changed
            You do not have to assign all lines to all assets and place all assets in service at the same time
            Assign only those costs you want to capitalize to the Assets with an Actual In Service Date that will be capitalized
                Any unassigned lines will be over-written and regenerated the next time the 'Generate Asset Lines' process is run
        Run 'PRC: Interface Assets to Oracle Assets' from Standard Request Submission
            This will create Mass Additions in Fixed Assets for the assigned asset lines and in-service assets
            It will build one parent Addition Line in the 'Post' Queue of Mass Additions for each asset
                It will merge all asset lines and their costs under the parent and assign a 'Merged' status in Mass Additions
                If you only have one Asset Line for each Asset in Projects, you will have two lines for each asset in Mass Additions
                     There will be one Parent Asset and one Merged Asset Line from Projects
        Check the Mass Addition Lines in Fixed Assets and Make any Changes
            Inquire on all Mass Additions for the single Project in Fixed Assets
            Navigation: Fixed Assets -> Mass Additions -> Prepare Mass Additions
        Post Mass Additions to create assets for the Mass Addition Lines
            The Post process will pick up all eligible Mass Additions in the 'POST' queue
            Navigation: Fixed Assets -> Mass Additions -> Post Mass Additions
            You cannot limit the posting to mass additions for a single project
    Exercises - inquire into assets on a project
        Project User -> Projects -> (Query Project) -> Options -> Assets -> Asset Information
            Any assets setup on the project will display without requiring a blind query
    You can reverse capitalize an asset and recapitalize it
        The asset must be created in Assets and can be depreciated
        The reversal process generates cost adjustments in Assets to bring the Asset Value to Zero
            Any accumulated depreciation will be reversed in the period the asset costs are adjusted
        Find the Asset from the Capital Projects form (click the Assets button)
            Click Reverse to start the reversal process
            Run Generate Asset Lines to create the asset reversing lines

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Workflows:
    Two standard PA workflows are:
        Project Status Change (project creation approval to active),
            Item Type: PAPROWF, User Item Type: PA Project Workflow
        Project Budget Baselining (from status 'working' to 'baselined')
            Item Type: PABUDWF, User Item Type: PA Budget Workflow
        Timecard Approval
            Item Type: PATCARD, User Item Type: PA Timecard Approval
        Supplier Invoice Account Generator
            Item Type: PAAPINVW, User Item Type: Project Supplier Invoice Account Generation
            This workflow must be customized to work
        Expense Report Account Generator
            Item Type: PAAPWEBX, User Item Type: Project Expense Report Account Generator
        Allocations
            Item Type: PASDALOC, User Item Type: PA Stepdown Allocations
        Workflow Library
            Item Type: PAWFLOW, User Item Type: PA Oracle Projects Library

Project Costing and Billing (PA Schema) Notes on Interfaces:
    Journal Entries to General Ledger
        Important Notes
            Journal entries are inserted into PA_GL_INTERFACE and not GL_INTERFACE
            Running journal import for Projects source journals pulls the values from PA_GL_INTERFACE directly
            You must run a couple of jobs to insert records into PA_GL_INTERFACE after entering, submitting and releasing a miscellaneous expenditure batch
                PRC: Distribute Miscellaneous Costs
                PRC: Interface Miscellaneous Costs
        Implementation Options control this interface:
            Interface Labor Costs to GL
            Interface Usage Costs to GL
            Interface Revenue to GL
        All data flowing from Projects to General Ledger use a seeded source and categories
            Source = Projects
            Categories = Labor Cost, Usage Cost, Total Burdened Cost, Borrowed and Lent, Provider Cost Reclassification, Revenue
        Run the streamline process to export from projects, import to General Ledger and tie-back journals
            The process is PRC: Submit Interface Streamline Process
                This process runs sub-processes:
                    PRC: Distribute Usage and Miscellaneous Costs
                    PRC: Interface Usage and Miscellaneous Costs to General Ledger
                    Journal Import
                    Journal Post
                    PRC: Tieback Usage Costs from General Ledger
            Tie back makes previously exported distributions from Projects eligible for re-export because they failed import to GL
                It marks the transactions as 'Failed' so they can be re-exported
            Journals include cost, revenue and cross-charge transactions
        The Projects Export process gathers all eligible distribution lines and places them in PA_GL_INTERFACE
            The GL Date assigned to the transactions is the end-date of the earliest open or future open period in GL
    Activity Management Gateway (AMG) - to import projects and tasks from a project management tool for setup of projects
        (via PA_TRANSACTIONS_INTERFACE table) and PA:Cost Transactions Import concurrent process
    AMG is a separate product and separately licenced.
        It requires custom wrappers to call and provides calls to PL/SQL packages that load projects
            It also updates and delete projects, and create, update and delete tasks.
    Project Connect - is a subset of AMG API's to import projects and tasks from Microsoft Project.
        It can send percent completes to Oracle and return project definitions and setups to Microsoft during a project.
    Cost Transaction import interface (transaction interface)
        via PA_TRANSACTIONS_INTERFACE_ALL to import costs calculated in purchasing and payables and all other source systems.
            This interface loads transactions to project/task/expenditure type/expenditure org.
    Interface Usage and Miscellaneous Costs to GL -
    Interface Revenue to GL -

    Period Close Steps in Projects
       Change the Current Oracle Projects Period Status from Open to Pending Close
           Navigation: Setup -> System -> GL Periods
           Common PA and GL Periods are enforced through Implementation Options
       Open the Next Oracle Projects Period
       Complete All Maintenance Activities
       Run Maintenance Processes
       Complete All Transaction Entry for the Period Being Closed
       Run the Final Cost Distribution Processes
       Interface Transactions to Other Applications (AP, GL, FA)
       Generate Draft Revenue for All Projects
       Generate Invoices
       Run Final Project Costing and Revenue Management Reports
       Transfer Invoices to Oracle Receivables
       Interface Revenue to General ledger (Project Billing Only)
       Run Period Close Exception and Tieback Reports
       Change the Current Period Oracle Projects Status from Pending Close to Closed
       Advance the PA Reporting Period (Optional)
       Update Project Summary Amounts
       Restore Access to User Maintenance Activities
       Permanently Close the Oracle Projects Period (Optional)
       Reconcile Cost Distribution Lines with General Ledger (Optional)

Property Manager (PN) Responsbilities:
    PROPERTY MANAGER, VISION OPERATIONS (PMVO)

Property Manager (PN) Best Practices:
    Setup property as a GL subaccount/account in Oracle Cash Management, then use CE functionality to track cash flow and profitability for the property as well as forecasting future cash flows

Property Manager (PN) Notes:
    Property Manager is a new application for Oracle 11i and is a subledger application to the GL
    Manages land based property, records leases, pays rents and makes rent collections
    Allocates the cost of owned or rented property to cost center expense accounts
    Property locations represent designated space within a property and can be defined at multiple levels from building down to office.
    Property locations are a KFF comprising Region or Office Park, Building, Floor, and Office segments. The values within each segment are referred to as aliases
    Floor space for the building is recorded at the building level. Rentable, usable and common space is recorded at the office level and floor level
    A master lease is a lease signed by a tenant for usage of a property. A lease is signed by the landlord to allow the tenant in. These are two terms for the same document
    A lease can include references to several locations
    Leases are recorded in the Edit Lease form.
    Lease classes drive expected rent payments vs rent receipts: rent payments are made on 'Direct' leases, and billing/rent receipts are expected on 'Third Party' and 'Sublease' leases
    Payments and billings are defined under the 'Billings' tab of the lease details, and exported to AR or AP for actual billing and collection, or payment
    Indexed rent is calculated by applying a CPI index escalator to scheduled rent payments
    Lease rent payments and receipts are generated by a concurrent program and transfered to AP and AR, and regenerated whenever the lease definition is changed
    Occupancy can be assigned at any level in the property hierarchy and space usage can be tracked by employee, cost center, or both.
    Integration with other applications includes: AR for scheduled rent receipts, AP for scheduled rent payments, HR for employees as occupants, and GL for normalized rent and accrued liabilities and assets
    Exercise: Enter or modify a lease: PMVO/Leases and Documents/Main Lease/Enter Leases and Documents

Property Manager (PN) Functional Gaps:
    The due date of an invoice for rent payments and receipts is built of the date the scheduled payment is transfered to AR or AP, and not the invoice date

Property Manager (PN) Interfaces:
    Export billing items to AR (PNEXPAR)
    Export payment items to AP (PNEXPAP)
    Purge open interface tables (PNVPURGE)

Property Manager (PN) Concurrent Processes:
    Create Rent Schedules (PNCPMTSC)
    Export or Import Property Locations and Space Allocations to Open Interface Tables (eg to/from CAD systems) (PNEXPCAD/PNIMPCAD)

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Best Practices:
    Global suppliers and Contract Purchasing Agreements (CPO's)
    Consolidated purchase orders - from pooled requisitions to lower admin costs
    Monitoring of contract leakage - value of purchase orders where a purchasing agreement could be used
    Supplier performance monitoring - via supplier scorecard for: quality, price, delivery, survey
    Lost discount monitoring - measurement of lost early payment discount to suppliers for payment terms
    Create alerts or reporting procedures to monitor old PO's which have not been fully closed because lines on the PO remain open
    Perform allocations in purchasing and not in the ledger, for purchased goods if needed.
        Otherwise, interfaces to Projects and Payables will carry incorrect accrual codes
    Clean up supplier records during data conversion and not afterwards
        Oracle restricts what can be deleted and old upper case text will continue to appear on purchasing documents unless otherwise cleaned up
    Responsibilities should be built to separate requisitioning, purchasing, receiving and payment activities to different people to maintain oversight
    Make all purchases on purchase order and enforce pay only on purchase order rules/policies, to stamp out non-PO and renegade purchasing practices
    Chief Purchasing Officer
    Purchasing Cards (or p-cards) for small and routine purchases

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Responsibilities:
    PURCHASING SUPER USER (PSU)

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Profile Options:
    PO: Automatic Document Sourcing - to allow automatic generation of purchase orders from requisitions and the most recent blanket purchase agreement
    PO: Allow Autocreation of Oracle Sourcing Docments = "Yes" - to allow creation of Sourcing RFQ's from the core 'Autocreate' function in requisitions
    POR: Goods Line Type - establishes the default line type on a purchase order
    PO: Change Supplier Site - allows changes to a purchase order to include supplier site
    PO: Enforce Buyer - prevents a change to the buyer if set to yes, by forcing the buyer to be the user preparing the purchase order

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Purchasing functions include: sourcing, requisitioning, purchasing and receiving and the system supports mainly operational decision-making
    Purchasing covers all goods and services: raw materials, capital equipment and fixed assets, expendable supplier (MRO), services.
    The destination type of an item (shop floor, inventory or expense) drives the default accounting treatment on the purchase order shipment/distribution lines
    Purchasing stores
        purchase orders,
        requisitions,
        supplier items and prices, and
        approval hierarchies for workflow approvals
    Most accounting information is derived by Account Generator
        based on the identity of the requestor and the nature of items ordered
    Complex purchases of services from a supplier may require implementation of Oracle Projects
    Part number cross references can be used to capture supplier part numbers and distributor part numbers
        as well as track legacy system part numbers for converted data
    Drop ship is supported, but the drop ship order originates in Order Management, and generates a purchase order in Purchasing.
    ASN's can be sent to customers based on notification from the supplier of a shipment
    Supplier acceptances are notifications from the supplier that they have accepted the PO and the delivery dates. These are also PO acknowledgments or PO-ack's.
    Purchasing provides Oracle Projects with cost updates for project/task/expenditure type as goods are requested, purchased and received and invoiced.
    Accruals for goods received but not purchased are not sent to projects at month end for the close process - a custom interface is required.
    Purchasing periods must be opened before accounting transactions can be created such as purchase accruals
    Exercise: Enter a release for a blanket PO -> PSU/Purchase Orders/Release, and specify the blanket PO to release against. Specify the shipping information.
    Exercise: Open Purchasing Periods -> Setup/Financials/Accounting/Control Purchasing Periods

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Cancelling Purchase Orders
    Cancelling Purchase Orders
        References
            Troubleshooting for Requisitions / Purchase Orders in Process or Pre-Approved Status (Doc ID 225017.1)
            How To Reset a Purchase Order or Requisition From In Process or Pre-Approved To Incomplete/Requires Reapproval For Isolated Cases (Doc ID 390023.1)
            Help With Purchase Order / Requisitions that are In Process or Pre-Approved Status with Cancelled Workflow or Missing Workflow (Doc ID 1273245.1)
        You cannot cancel a purchase order in 'In Process' or 'Pre-Approved'
        Cancel a PO from the PO menu: Actions > Control > Cancel
        You can control PO status with different actions: Cancel, Final Close, Close for Receiving, Close for Invoicing, Delete, Freeze, Hold, Firm
        Tip -> change document status through the tools menu on the PO form (don't open the PO, just inquire/search for return results, then use Tools/Control)
        Exercise: Cancel a purchase order -> PSU/Purchase Orders/Purchase Order Summary/Find Purchase Orders.. and find the purchase order to cancel, then choose Menu/Control to cancel.
        You can cancel an existing commitment to a supplier by cancelling a PO header, line, shipment or distribution
        By cancelling a PO or component of a PO, you cannot receive or match an invoice for payment against the cancelled component (header, line, shipment, distribution)
        Cancelling a component also cancels the components beneath that level: eg canceling a shipment line cancels all the distribution lines in the shipment.
        Documents that are cancelled at the header level can be purged. If encumbrance and budgetary accounting are used, the encumbrances for the cancelled commitments are reversed.
    Mass Cancel Purchase Orders
        Mass cancel allows canceling of groups of requisitions or purchase orders that are still active
        Mass cancel is in two steps: identify candidate PO's and Requ's to cancel, and then cancel them
        Creating a batch for mass cancellation creates a report of qualified candidates which are different for requisitions vs PO's
        Mass cancellation candidates for requisitions automatically excludes: requ's with PO's created, incomplete requ's, final closed requ's and cancelled requisitions.
        It only cancels requisitions that are approved, pre-approved, returned or returned
            A pre-approved requisition is one that is approved and forwarded for additional approval
            This is normally done by the final approver
        Exercise: Identify Mass cancel requisitions or purchase orders -> PSU/Accounting/Mass Cancel,
            and cancel for a specific supplier (PO's only) and for a range of account values, to produce a report of candidate requs and PO's
        Exercise: Mass Cancel requisitions or purchase orders -> PSU/Accounting/Run MassCancel, and specify the requ's and po's to cancel.
    Cancelling Requisitions
        Requisitions can be cancelled or closed to prevent them being placed on a purchase order
        Requisitions cannot be cancelled though Tools/Controls/Cancel Requisitions if there is an open purchase order against the requistion - cancel the PO first.
        The default Location on a requisition is taken from the Location on the requester's employee assignment record
        If PO's are canceled, their backing requisitions can also be canceled automatically. ***

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Integration With Other Systems:
    Oracle Accounts Payable - for suppliers, matching and tolerances, pay on receipt, budgetary control. receipt accrual and bank statement reconciliation
    Oracle Alerts - for seeded alerts on pending expirations on purchasing documents
    Oracle Bill of Materials - for complex item  definitions and their components
    Oracle EDI Gateway - EDI gateway supports multiple purchasing documents: quotes, response to RFQ, ASN's, ASBN's, Planning Schedules, Shipping Schedules, PO's and PO Changes
    Oracle General Ledger - Purchasing posts encumbrances to offset budget amounts, and receipt accrual entries to ledger accounts
    Oracle Inventory - shares item definitions and generates resupply requisitions for minimum stocking quantities
    Oracle Master Scheduling/MRP - MRP generates manufacturing requisitions
    Oracle Order Entry - generates sales orders to match internal requisitions supplied from inventory
    Oracle Human Resources - shares employee definitions and position definitions
    Oracle Project Accounting - to provide project accounting codes and validate purchase charges to Projects
    Oracle Quality - to capture quality information during receiving. Purchasing can make quality data capture mandatory
    Oracle Payables - for suppliers, matching and tolerances, pay on receipt, budgetary controls, receipt accrual and bank statement reconciliation
    Oracle Supplier Scheduling -
    Oracle Workflow - for account generator and seeded approval and late notification workflows
    Oracle General Ledger - via RCV_RECEIVING_SUB_LEDGER which holds all accounting entries
        This table links to entries in GL_IMPORT_REFERENCES or GL_JOURNAL_LINES via link references for link table type RSL in GL_IMPORT_REFERENCES

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Open Interfaces:
    Requisitions Open Interface is for requisition import
        It can be scheduled to run continuously to bring in requisitions from other applications
        (e.g. OSP Requisitions from WIP)
        Uses the Requisitions Open Interface
            The Requisitions Open Interface does not assign account distributions using account generator
            It expects the distributions to be on the incoming requisition records
    Purchase Documents Open Interface is used for importing purchase orders

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Integration with Payables:
    Purchasing shares tables for suppliers and supplier sites to provide much of the default information
    Defaulted information from supplies and sites includes: payments, terms and payment methods. These can be overriddeon on purchasing documents and invoices
    Matching levels are enforced in Payables: two way, three way and four way matching.
    Invoice matching tolerances are defined on the Invoice Tolerance form for: qty ordered, qty received, price tolerance - all as a percentage
    Pay on receipt generates payments to suppliers based on items received and based on ASN and ASBN transactions. Invoices are created in Purchasing and sent to Payables
    Budgetary contol ties PO encumbrance amounts and approved invoice amounts to available budgets in the GL. Matching PO's and invoices transfers the encumbrance from PO's to invoices
    Payables reverses purchase receipt accruals of purchases booked to the ledger when the corresponding invoice is approved for payment

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Period-End Close
    References
        EBS R12 Period Close Advisor: Purchasing [Article ID 1359462.1]

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Purchasing Setups:
    Ownership of supplier setup should be established in either AP or PO but not both
        This will help avoid double entry of suppliers
    A find should be conducted before entering a supplier
        This will identify if the supplier is already setup in the system
    There should be a document defining supplier naming conventions for all supplier setups to help ensure consistancy
    For multi-org implementations, suppliers are shared across all operating units so duplicate supplier checking is important before entering a new supplier
    Many inventory setup forms are shared with purchasing to allow item setups
    Create a template for purchase items before setting up individual items - use the template to default purchasing item defaults
    Employees must be defined as buyer before they can create purchase orders
    Global buyers can be setup as buyers across multiple business groups. Set the HR: Cross Business Groups profile at the site level to 'Yes'
        The buyer name LOV becomes global instead of limiting the buyer LOV to the current business group. The find window displays the buyer and business group
    Line type establishes the default line data structure on requisitions and PO's: seeded values are goods, services, and outside processing
    Line type must be choose a value basis of either units times rate, or fixed amount. The unit in unit x rate can be any unit of measure. Line type sets defaults for units, value, category.
    Line type is established with the profile option POR: goods line type at the operating unit level
    Exercise: Setup buyers -> PSU/Setup/Personnel/Buyers, to enter a buyer and their default purchasing category and default ship-to address for purchases
    Exercise: Setup locations -> PSU/Setup/Organizations/Locations, to define ship-to and receiving locations for requisitions and purchase orders
    Exercise: Enter requisition preferences -> PSU/Requisitions/Requisitions, and choose Tools, Preferences from the menu.

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Order of Setups:
    Units of Measure - shared with Oracle Inventory. Defines classes, units of measure, conversions and interclass conversions
    Items - owned by Inventory. Items are defined in the master org and inventory org levels. Includes item templates and attributes
    Oracle Workflow and Configuration - for document approvals, automatic document creation and general ledger account generation
    Account Generator - to define the rules for constructing accounts for purchasing variances and charge accounts
    Profile Options -
    Subinventory Locations - to establish physical areas such as individual warehouses or receiving docks. Owned by inventory
    Cross-Reference Types - as dictionaries to xref supplier item numbers, old (converted) item numbers to current item numbers
    Location Associations - for internally sourced requisitions. These associate purchasing locations to internal customer sites
    Approval Groups - to limit approvals by account range, location, item category range and item range for document total values
    Assignment of Approval Groups - to assign approval groups to document types and to positions in the approval hierarchy
    Fill Employee Hierarchy - to assign employees to the position approval hierarchy based on their current primary position assignments
    Document Types - purchase agreement, purchase order, quotation, release, request for quotation (RFQ), and requisition.
    For purchase agreements document type, there are: blanket and contract subtypes
    For purchase order document type, there are: planned and standard subtypes
    For quotation document type, there are: bid, catalog, and standard subtypes
    For Release document type, there are: blanket and scheduled subtypes
    For request for quotation document type, there are bid, catalog and standard subtypes (corresponding to quote subtypes)
    For requisition document types, there are: internal and purchase subtypes
        The Source Type on a Requisition Line can be 'Supplier' or 'Inventory'
    Lookup Codes - includes many seeded codes that can be added onto.
    Quality Inspection Codes - used to record the inspection quality of goods received. Requires a ranking value for reporting usage.
    Hazard Classes - classifies items as hazards and copies hazard information to purchase orders, requests for quote and receipt travellers
    UN Numbers - to define UN reference numbers for international trade. Hazard classes can be associated with UN numbers
    Standard Notes and Attachments - on requisitions, RFQ's, and purchase orders.
    Purchasing Item Category Flexfield by defining
        purchasing categories,
        value sets,
        flexfield segments,
        segment values and account aliases and account x-validation rules
    Buyers - to give privileges to create purchasing documents.
    Line Types - to distinguish items purchased by price and quantity, or by total amount. Line types have seeded values
    Transaction Managers - must be started, including the receiving transaction manager, and workflow transaction manager.
    Notification Process - by starting the 'send notifications of purchasing documents' workflow to notify users of incomplete documents
    Document Creation Options - in the PO Create Documents workflow. Options include automatic creation, creation of releases, and automatic approval
    Exercise: Setup hazard classes -> PSU/Setup/Purchasing/Hazard Classes
    Exercise: Setup UN numbers -> PSU/Setup/Purchasing/UN Numbers
    Exercise: Setup buyers -> PSU/Setup/Personnel, and associate an employee with a buyer designation and their allowable categories
    Exercise: Setup banks -> Payables/Setup/Payment/Banks

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Lookup Codes:
    Lookup codes are used throughout Purchasing to populate lists of values that drive processing within the applications (unlike data values in value sets)
