    You cannot receive an unordered receipt in the self service procurement functions - the option is not available (as of version 11.5.9)
    Unordered receipts can only be entered as standard 'receiving' destination type transactions and must be subsequently accepted and delivered to their final destination through additional receiving transactions
    Once matched, an unordered receipt needs to be received at its final destination to create the final receiving transaction.
    The supplier on the unordered receipt must match the supplier on the purchase order when it is subsequently matched.
    The item and purchasing category on the receipt must match the item and purchasing category on the purchase order
    The PO must have a receipt routing of Standard Recipt, Inspection Required, or None. Otherwise the profile option RCV: Allow Routing Override must be set
    Exercise: Enter an unordered receipt -> PURCHASING/Receiving/Receipts, and click the unordered button on the receiving header to show the unordered receiving form
        The Unordered button is at the bottom of the Find form if enabled in receiving options for the receiving organization
    Exercise: Match Unordered Receipts to a purchase order
        Purchasing Super User/Match Unordered Receipts ...
            and search for receipt entered previously as unordered,
            then enter the Purchase Order Number
    Profile Option -> RCV: Allow Routing Override allows receiving

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Receiving Transaction Processor
    The Receiving Transaction Processor imports ASN's and Receipts through the Receiving Open Interface Tables
    Pending transactions can be viewed through 'Receiving' > 'Transaction Status Summary'
        If no transactions are found via this form, then no transactions are pending

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Approvals, Approval Groups and Approval Position Hierarchies:
    Approvals can use two different paths: employee/supervisor, or position hierarchies.
    Employee/Supervisor hiearchies look at the supervisor link in a person's assignment record for their supervisor
    Position hierarchies find the position for the person, navigate to the position above and find the encumbent of that position
        Position hierarchies are high maintenance due to HR changes impacting position hierarchy integrity
        Most implementations avoid position hierarchies due to maintenance and the inability to preserve their integrity
    The approval can be sent to the position with sufficient approval directly (direct method) through each position (hierarchy method) even though they lack final approval authority
    Since more than one person can be assigned to a position
        the alphabetical first person is chosen if multiple encumbants are found
    Position Hierarchies are created through the Position Hierarchy form
            The form has peculiar behaviours to query existing hierarchies and create new hierarchies
                To query an existing hierarchy, first query the top region of the form and then separately query the bottom region after clicking 'Exists in Hierarchy'
                If you don't click 'Exists in Hierarchy' before querying the bottom half of the form, it will query back the full list of possible positions.
                To create a new position hierarchy, you need to create a hierarchy name, then save, then query the top position
                    (eg F11 query on 'PRESIDENT%' to bring in the top position)
                After adding each person to the bottom half of the form, save before proceeding.
                Position hierarchies must defined from the top most position down - start at the top of the hierarchy. You cannot add a  top position later
            The position hierarchy is used for two purposes: document approval routing and document security control
                The position hierarchy is assigned as the security hierarchy for document security in the Purchasing Options: Control alternate region
                The position hierarchy is assigned as the approval hierarchy for each document type in the document types window
        Position approval hierarchies are turned on in the financial options (HR tab) - in the checkbox 'Use Approval Hierarchies'
        Position hierarchies can be defined multiple times for multiple purposes and have names associated with each position in the hierarchy.
        The person who is alphabetically first in order in a position hierarchy is routed the approval request first
        Position hierarchies require job and position definitions in HR
            Jobs are sets of responsibilities like Buyer, Receiver, Cost Accountant, VP or Manager.
            Positions are specific slots in an org chart such as Buyer-East Coast
            Positions are related together in a position hierarchy.
    Approval groups include rules defined to set limits on approval authorities
        Approval rules are defined for each approval group
        Approval groups require (at a minimum) a document total line and an account range line
            All other line types are optional: Item Category Range, item range, location.
            Rules can cover: specific document types (eg PO), account ranges, item ranges, category ranges, and locations
            If two or more approval lines are created in an approval group, the most restrictive line is used to determine approval authority
            Approval Groups limit approvals by account range, location, item category range and item range for document total values
    Assignment of Approval Groups assigns approval groups to document types and to positions (or jobs) in the approval hierarchy
    Fill Employee Hierarchy - to assign employees to the position approval hierarchy based on their current primary position assignments
    Approval Groups -> click on low value to display account ranges for included accounts
    Approval Groups -> if position approval hierarchies are turned on in Financial Options, the Approval Groups form only allows searching on positions and not jobs
    Approval Groups -> if position approval hierarchies are turned off in Financial Options, the Approval Groups form only allows searching on jobs and not positions
    Navigations are:
        Create positions ->  ..../Positions
        Create a position hierarchy (if HR is not installed) s-> PSU/Setup/Personnel/Position Hierarchy
        Create a position hierarchy (if HR is installed) -> HRSU/Work Structures/Position/Hierarchy,
            and query both regions of the form (click 'Exists in Hierarchy' on in lower region query)
        Create approval groups -> Purchasing/Setup/Approvals/Approval Groups to create approval groups for doc totals,
        Assign approval groups -> PSU/Setup/Approvals/Approval Assignments, to assign an approval group to a position or job
        Assign position hierarchy as security hierarchy -> ..../Purchasing Options/
        Assign position hierarchy as the approval hierarchy (for each doctype) -> PSU/Setup/Purchasing/Document Types
    Exercise: Turn on approval hierarchies in financial options -> PSU/Setup/Organizations/Financial Options/Human Resources, and click 'Use Approval Hierarchies' on
    Exercise: Fill the position hierarchy -> Concurrent manager/Fill Employee Hierarchy
    Exercise: Approve PO's and Requ's -> PSU/Notifications and click on each approval notification to review and approve.

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Notification and Delegation Rules and Vacation Rule and Worklist Access
    Notifications for PO approvals can be redirected or delegated
    See Metalink Note: Note:221915.1 "How to Reassign Purchase Order Approval Notifications"
        This uses the navigation: "Workflow User Web Applications"
    See Metalink Note: 248076.1 "How to Setup Default Notification Rules in Workflow"
    In 11.5.10 and 12.0.0 Vacation Rules and Worklist Access options allow others to act on your notifications
        Navigation -> Workflow User Web Applications/Advanced Worklist/Tip - Worklist Access (and define rules)
        Worklist Access grants notification access to another user - in effect providing a delegation of authority
        The granted user can act as a proxy or delegate and act on the notifications
        The granted user can do most things that the original user can do to the notifications
           The granted user will get a 'Switch User' option on their notifications list to see other users' notifications
        Worklist Access is stored in the FND_GRANTS table in the APPLSYS schema

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Security:
    Security levels (visibility) and access levels (privileges) work together to restrict who can access a document and what they can do with that document
    A security level of public gives everyone visibility to the document ie the ability to open the document
    Security (visibility) levels are: public (open), private (owner and approvers), purchasing (owner, approvers and buyers) and hierarchy (owners, approvers and people above as defined by the approval hierarchy)
    An access level of Full means anyone with the ability to open the document has the privileges to make any changes to the document
    The person who creates a purchasing document is the owner. The owner can always change the document and has full access.
    Access levels are:
        view only (people with visibility can view only),
        modify (view, modify, freeze, close) and
        full (view, modify, freeze, close, final close, delete)

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on ERS and Payment on Receipt (aka Self-Billing)
    ERS or Payment on Receipt creates an invoice when goods are received, rather than waiting on an invoice from the supplier
    ERS is enabled on a standard purchase order by clicking the 'Terms' button and entering 'Receipt' in the 'Pay On' field
    ERS creates an unapproved invoice based on receipt of goods and purchase order information, triggered by an ASN or physical receipt.
    ASN's and ASBN's can also trigger payment on receipt because they are processed as receiving records
    ERS is also known as payment on receipt and self-billing
    ERS options allow different levels of invoice creation and grouping: packing slip, receipt, or supplier site
    To generate ERS draft invoices, the concurrent process 'Payment on Receipt' autoinvoice program must be run after receipts are posted in Purchasing and Receiving
    Profile Option -> PO: ERS Aging Period, defines the delay in days before an ERS invoice is created after the goods are received
    Profile Option -> PO: ERS Invoice Number Prefix, assigns a character prefix to all ERS invoice numbers

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on ERS and Payment on Receipt (aka Self Billing) Concurrent Processes:
    Pay on Receipt Autoinvoice concurrent process is scheduled to run constantly - automatically creates invoices based on received amounts
    Pay on receipt is setup as an option for a supplier, to be paid on shipment receipt or on final delivery
    Pay on Receipt grouping of invoices can be at the packing slip, receipt or supplier site level
    The Pay on Receipt Autoinvoice program generates invoices for receipts and matches the invoice to the corresponding purchase orders

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Procurement Cards or pCards - Overview:
    pCards can only be added to requisitions in iProcurement and not requisitions in core purchasing. Core purchasing pcard requs are not supported.
    pCards are credit cards that enable the purchaser to buy directly from the supplier and eliminate a large number of small value invoice transactions
    pCards can be assigned to requisitions in iProcurement directly, but not in Purchasing.
        This allows automatic creation and approval of purchase orders
    pCards bypass the need for requisitioning all together or can be used on requisitions to automate the payment process.
    pCard processing imports charge details from a pCard processor (corporte card) and
        verified directly through web-expenses by each employee (and charged to a project).
    Employees can override the default accounting treatment on web expenses and add project numbers and change cost centers
    pCards are useful for buying expensed items but not capital or inventory items, since there is no way of adding the inventory or asset information in iExpenses
    pCards can't buy asset items since AP processes pCards without matching to PO's. Normally AP sends Mass Addition assets to FA based on PO flags indicating an asset purchase
    pCards can't buy project capital items through self service because the project id can't be added in SSP at the time of purchase
    pCards can only be used with expense item purchases,
        cannot be used with encumbrance accounting,
        cannot be used for project purchases and
        do not accrue payables on receipt

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Procurement Cards (pCards) Business Process:
    Employees purchase items from suppliers using pCards
    The card issuer such as American Express sends the pCard transactions to the employer for payment
    The pCard transactions are imported directly into AP or through mapping software (such as Accounting Link - for Amex)
    The import process automatically generates accounting distributions for expenses
    The invoice to pay the card issuer is automatically built from the imported pCard transactions
    Self service applications can be setup to verify transactions and override accounting distributions by sending the purchases to the employee for review
    Transactions from the pCard company are loaded into AP_EXPENSE_FEED_LINES
    A process 'pCard Transactions Validation Report' is run after loading to identify invalid transactions and build default GL account distributions
    Next, the 'Distribute Employee Credit Transactions' process is started, which kicks off a workflow 'AP pCard Employee Verification'to send to employees via notifications
    The employee verifies and approves the notification details in self service
    The manager approval workflow 'Manager Approval for pCard' is started by another concurrent process for manager approvals of these expenses
    Adjustments including splits of accounting distributions can be made in the form 'Credit Card Transactions' in AP
    Invoices are created  by transfering lines after approval from AP_EXP_FEED_DISTRIBUTIONS to AP_HEADER and AP_LINES,  by running the Payables Open Interface
    Finally, Invoices are processed within AP normally for approval and payment

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Procurement Cards (pCards) Setups:
    Overall Setup involves establishing a pCard program, pCard profile, and actual pcards.  Each supplier site that can accept pCards must have it's 'pCard Allowed' flag set at the site level.
    Additional setups include creating Credit Card Code Sets, and Credit Card GL Sets to allow users to change accounts during credit card transaction approval.
    Setup credit card issuer as a supplier (and setup their bank info if payment is via EFT)
    Setup the pCard Program to establish a pCard and pCard issuer (supplier) and supplier site to pay the pcards. Also use to establish the default clearing account and excluded transactions
    Setup the pCard Account Set and Account Set members to establish accounts that will override the employee default expense account on import of credit card txns, based on the incoming 'card code'
    Setup a pCard GL Account Set to establish a list of accounts a user can change during workflow approval of transactions. This is associated to a pCard Profile
    Setup a pCard Profiles to apply to a single program. Each profile is a set of characteristics that default to cards in the program: over-ride clearing account, employee and manager approval notice levels, spending limits on ranges of card numbers
    Setup employees who are pCard holders, if required
    Setup each pCard and assign it to a pCard profile. Assign the card to an employee (optional) or supplier and the supplier's eligible sites
    Modify the supplier site general attributes to allow pCards for each supplier site where pCard is allowed. Set pCard Allowed = Yes in the General region of the supplier site

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Note on Procurement Cards (pCards) Accounting:
    pCards account distributions are defaulted to the employee's default expenses account on the employee profile
    Default account distributions are over-ridden by the GL default account distribution on the pCard profile
    pCard profile account distributions are over-ridden by credit card code sets that look up account values based on codes attached to the card transaction

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Procurement Cards (pCards) Profile Options:
    PO: Use P-Cards in Purchasing
    POR: Override Supplier p-Card (yes/no)

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Key Tables:
    Look here -> http://www.oracleappshub.com/oracle-purchasing/po-tips-and-useful-query/
    MTL_CATEGORIES - item categories
    MTL_TRANSACTION_ACCOUNTS - accounting distributions
    MTL_SYSTEM_ITEMS - inventory items
    FND_LOOKUP_VALUES - basis for view 'PO_LOOKUP_VALUES'
    PO_RULE_EXPENSE_ACCOUNTS -- expense account rules for defaulting distribution segments onto accounts
    PO_HEADERS_ALL - purchase order headers
    PO_LINES_ALL - purchase order lines
    PO_LINE_LOCATIONS_ALL - purchase order shipments or releases for each po line
    PO_RELEASES_ALL - actual releases
    PO_REQUISITION_HEADERS_ALL - requisition headers (key fields are: AUTHORIZATION_STATUS, CREATION_DATE, SEGMENT1 - which is the requisition number)
    PO_REQUISITION_LINES_ALL - requisition lines (joined to PO_REQUISITION_HEADERS_ALL by REQUISITION_HEADER_ID)
    PO_REQ_DISTRIBUTIONS_ALL - distributions for requisition lines
    PO_REQUISITIONS_INTERFACE_ALL - staging for requisition imports
    PO_DISTRIBUTIONS_ALL - purchase order distributions, includes foreign key REQ_DISTRIBUTION_ID to the PO_REQUISITION_LINES_ALL table linking requisitions and purchase orders
    PO_REQEXPRESS_HEADERS_ALL - requisition template headers
    PO_REQEXPRESS_LINES_ALL - requisition template lines
    RCV_SHIPMENT_HEADERS - receipt headers including receipt number
    RCV_SHIPMENT_LINES - a single receipt line under a receipt/shipment header
    RCV_TRANSACTIONS - low level receipt transactions within a receipt line
    RCV_RECEIVING_SUB_LEDGER - the 'RSL' table includes all accounting transactions created by purchasing
        GL_SL_LINK_ID links the GL Import References table lines
        GL_SL_LINK_ID is 'RSL' in GL_IMPORT_REFERENCES for all transactions linking back to the RSL table
    RCV_ACCOUNTING_EVENTS
    RCV_RECEIVING_SUB_LEDGER (see immediately above)
    RCV_SUB_LEDGER_DETAILS
    PO_APPROVED_SUPPLIER_LIST - approved supplier lists
    PO_ASL_ATTRIBUTES - supplier/item attributes on approved supplier list lines
    PO_REQUISITIONS_INTERFACE_ALL - requisition import headers
    PO_REQ_DIST_INTERFACE_ALL - requisition import lines

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Profile Options:
    Tax: Allow Override of Tax Codes - allows override on a requisition
    HR: Cross Business Groups - to allow buyers to be global
    PO: Change Supplier Site - allows a supplier site to change on an approved PO and a revision issued (otherwise the PO must be cancelled and reissued)
    PO: Legal Requisition Type - allows internal requisitions
    PO: Allow Rate Override for User Rate Type - allows override of exchange rate on PO's at receiving
    PO: Source Type - allows restriction of source type on requisition and req template to inventory, or purchase (ie internal or external)
    PO:Allow Requistion Approval Forward Action
        sets the requisition approval workflow to escalate a timed out approval
            to the next person in the Approval Chain

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Workflows:
    Workflow Background Process
        must be run from the Workflow Administrator responsibility to run any workflows
            see notes in Workflow on options.
    Purchasing uses workflow extensively for:
        requisition approval,
        PO creation,
        PO/Req Action Notifications,
        PO approval
    PO Account Generator
        build account code combinations on PO's for accrual, budget, charge and variance accounts
            accrued purchases are booked at time of goods receipt
                (using department, item category, supplier, project)
    PO Requisition Account Generator
        builds account code combinations on req's for accrual, budget, charge and variance accounts
    PO Requisition Approval Workflow
        approve requisitions based on the approval hierarchy of the preparer (not the requester)
            The workflow ID is based on the internal requistion ID and not the requisition number
                The workflow item ID is comprised of the Requisition ID and a sequence number
            The profile option: 'PO:Allow Requistion Approval Forward Action'
                forwards timed out approval notices to the next person in the approval chain
    PO Approval - approve purchase orders
    PO Send Notifications for Purchasing Documents
        sends notifications and reminders about incomplete purchasing documents such as purchase orders and requisitions.
    PO Create Documents - create requisitions and purchase orders automatically from approved requisition lines.
        The Overall Document Creation / Launch Approval process is initiated when requisition lines are approved,
        you've kept the item attribute Is Automatic Creation Allowed? set to Y for Yes,
        a source document is associated with the requisition line,
        and you have properly set up sourcing rules
    PO Confirm Receipt - for receipts past their due date and not confirmed
        Escalates unreceived goods using notifications to the receiver

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Reports:
    Purchase Order Report - prints purchase orders
    Vendor Price Performance Analysis Report - compares prices from suppliers for the same item
    Vendor Purchase Summary Report - totals the purchase orders for each supplier
    Vendor Quality Performance Report - percent accepted, rejected and returned to vendor
    Vendor Service Performance Analysis Report - late, early, incorrect and rejected shipments
    Vendor Volume Analysis Report - compares actual purchasing percentages with sourcing percentages

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Common Customizations:
    Adapting heavily used internal documents to meet specific needs: requisitions and receipt travellers
    Adding descriptive flexfield columns to reports to report on contractor priority ratings for orders with department of defense contracts
    Displaying vendor and manufacturer part numbers on reports alongside the internal Oracle item number

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Testing Practices:
    Test all possibilities of receiving exceptions including incorrect quantities, substitute items, unexpected receipts, unknown suppliers and damaged goods

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Predefined Alerts:
    Approved Standard Purchase Orders: number of approved PO's created by each buyer in the past 'N' days (periodic)
    Blanket Expiration Notification: blanket purchase orders about to expire (periodic)
    Blanket Notifications Not Released: blanket purchase orders where release amount is less than desired release amount (periodic)
    Blanket Notifications Released: blanket notifications with releases exceeding the desired release amount (periodic)
    Blanket Purchase Releases Over Threshhold: blankets with releases exceeding a threshhold value (periodic)
    Contract Expiration Notification: contract agreements about to expire (periodic)
    Contract Notification Not Released: contract agreements with no release purchase orders (periodic)
    Contract Notification Released: contract agreements with desired amounts released on PO's (periodic)
    No Receipt Required for Purchase Order Shipment: lists PO's with two way matching enabled and no receiving required (periodic)
    Planned Notification Expiration: planned purchase orders about to expire (periodic)
    Planned Notification Not Released: planned purchase orders with scheduled releases below threshhold (periodic)
    Small business suppliers: lists suppliers identified as small business (periodic)
    Standard Purchase Orders Over Threshhold: PO's created in the last 'N' days exceeding a threshhold value (periodic)
    Suppliers on Hold: shows suppliers who have been placed on hold (periodic)

Purchasing and Receiving (PO Schema) Notes on Contingent Workers
    References
        http://itsafeature.com/category/reviews/
    Contingent workers can perform multiple purchasing functions
        raise and approve requisitions
        create, maintain and approve purchase orders
        receive goods and services
    The profile option: "HR: Expand Role of Contingent Worker" established contingent worker provisions
        It allows contingent workers to perform purchasing functions
    How it Works
        Full Install of HR Required
        Define a Person as type 'Contingent Worker' in HR and add assignments
        Attach the worker to their corresponding supplier record

Purchasing Intelligence Notes:
    Purchasing Intelligence is part of the BIZ technology platform and BIZ must be installed
    Contract leakage tracking requires contracts to be established: blanket PO's, contract agreements and catalog quotations

Purchasing Intelligence Notes on Standard Reports:
    Standard Report: Purchases: by Supplier, Commodity, Items, Buyers, or Operating Unit
    Standard Report: Contract Leakage Trends: by Organization, Commodity, or Supplier
    Standard Report: Supplier Perf: price, quality, delivery, quantity, and total purchases
    Standard Report: Supplier Consolidation: to project savings by consolidating suppliers
    Standard Report: Purchase to Sales Ratio - Requires Order Management
    Standard Report: Contract Savings
    Standard Workbook: Contract Savings

Quality Management (QA) Notes:
    Quality Management plans and executes physical testing of items in the manufacturing and receiving processes and tracks the results
    Collection elements are attributes that are measured in a quality test
    Target measurments and the severity of departures from the target measurements can be specified for collection elements within a quality collection plan
    Collection procedures are instructions to collect quality data, including equipment usage and sampling methods
    Actions as a result of quality measurements can be defined, including notification alerts, holds on purchases of the item, shipment returns and payment holds

Quality Management (QA) Forms:
    Enter Quality Results
    Pareto Chart (definition)

Quality Management (QA) Interfaces:
    Collection Import - to read quality measurements from testing and measuring devices

Quality Management Tables:
    QA_CHARS - collection elements and element types
    QA_ACTIONS - action definitions
    QA_ACTION_LOG - quality action logs
    QA_SPECS - quality specifications
    QA_SPEC_CHARS - quality specification elements
    QA_PLAN_CHARS - collection plan elements
    QA_RESULTS_INTERFACE - imported quality measurements

Quality Management (QA) Profile Options:
    QA:Blind Results Entry - hides specifications from quality data entry

        Concurrent Programs - single programs
        Request Sets - groups of programs defined as sets
        Applications - includes all the programs assigned to a specific appliction
        Stage Functions (of Request Sets) - used to calculate the status of stages within a Request Set
    Navigation: Application Administrator -> Request Groups

Report Exchange Designer (RXi acronym) General Notes
    RXi is a reporting architecture separate to Oracle Reports
        It provides output in multiple formats: CSV, Tab, HTML and Text
    RXi has two components:
       A report formatting component
       A data extract component that uses a SQL package to extract data to a temporary table for reporting
       The report formatting component calls the data extract component, formats the report and deletes the temporary (extracted) data

Sales Compensation (???) Notes:
    Sales Compensation is a CRM product that calculates commissions payable to the sales force.
    Sales events are defined as commission events to trigger the accrual of sales commissions
    Sales compensation tags each order line with a revenue class category.
        Categories can be defined along lines of industry, market, service, product etc
    The commission is calculated from
        the value of the sale times the compensation factor of the revenue class within the assigned category
    Direct sales, agents and distributors can be paid commissions through Sales Compensation
    Credit for a sale can be shared among a salesforce, either by
        splitting the commissions or
        giving all the full commission
    Quota credits are calculated with different commission rates to achieve quota, and commission accelerators for quota bands over 100%
    Plans can clawback commissions for cancelled sales or uncollectable invoices from customers
    Sales are fed from Receivables rather than Order Management, for calculating commissions
        This ensures commissions are paid on final billed values.
        This ensures sales compensation ties out with revenue flows
    Commission data is originally captured by Order Management:
        sales person, commission class, price list, etc.

Sales Online (???) Notes:
    Sales online tracks:
        the pipeline of sales leads,
        assigned sales reps and
        the actual products and expected sales value of the lead or opportunity
    Sales Online is a Java/Web Based interface like iProcurement

Security (FND Schema) Notes on General Functionality

        Signon Password Case
        Signon Password Custom (use a custom java class name as the value for this option)
        Signon Password No Reuse (default is 0, recommended is 180 (days))
        Signon Password Length (default is 5, recommeded is 8)
        Signon Password Hard To Guess
        Signon Password Failure Limit
    An alert can be built on FND_UNSUCCESSFUL_LOGINS to warn of unsuccessful attempts to login
    Hard to Guess Passwords are defined as:
        At least one number and one letter
        No repeating characters
        Does not contain a username

Service (???) Notes:
    Service tracks:
        the installed base of products installed with customers,
        the support of those products delivered by phone,
        onsite calls or returns for factory repair
    Service contracts and warranties, and implied warranties on the sale are recorded as part of the service commitment
    Service attributes are carried on the inventory master items and on items at the Organization levels
        including flags to indicate if service is billable
    Order Management populates the installed base records in the shipping confirm process
    BOM can create an 'as-built' configuration to track changes to the product as it is upgraded and repaired
        (at the customer site or at the factory)
    For warranty replacement of parts,
        Service will track the serial number of the replacement parts for continued warranty support
    Terms and conditions in warranties and service agreements codify
        the length of service,
        days of week, hours of the day of service,
        whether repair parts are covered, and
        billable shipping costs
    Workflow is used in Service to escalate service requests from telephone to onsite to depot return or replacement,
        including warnings for overdue service issues
    Depot repair process includes:
        cost estimating, customer approval to repair,
        non-standard work order for repair work,
        return to inventory and shipment from inventory (OM interface to shipping execution)
    Depot repair creates WIP's in the WIP system to collect detailed cost estimating data.
        Engineering can inquire into service wIPS to measure component mortality rates and quality problems

SQL*Loader (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Oracle Loader (or SQL*Loader) loads data from a text file into one or more Oracle tables, with indexes, based on a set of control file parameters
    The control file has a .ctl extension (if there is no extension specified, Loader assumes it is .ctl) and contains parameters and data mappings between the input text file and the Oracle tables being loaded.
    Invalid records that are not loaded are logged into an error file in a location determined by the 'error=' parameter.
    Loader is run from the command line as 'sqlldr.exe' located in the \bin subdirectory of the Oracle home directory.
    Loader takes command line parameters either positionally (in the correct order) or as parameters (parm1=, parm2= etc) and most parameters are optional. A typical min set of parameters is -> sqlldr userid=username/pwd control=cfile.ctl
    A session log is written to control.log and bad records are written to control.bad (where control is the name of the control file)

SQL*Loader (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Control File Parameters
    parallel=true runs the loader in parallel mode by dividing the loader process into parallel segments. Indexes cannot be loaded in this mode. In this mode, several temporary tables are used, and merged as a final step.
    direct=true runs the loader in direct mode, where date is formatted in memory to match the database blocks on disk, and subsequently copied. This mode runs faster than conventional mode. It is compatible with parallel mode.
    skip=n a number that defaults to 0, and Loader will skip the first n lines and start loading at n+1. This is good for multi-step loads
    load=n will load n records and then stop.
    discard=filename sends all discarded records to filename, where discarding is determined by conditions set for loading each row. If not specified, no discard file is created

SQL*Loader (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on the Control File
    Use '--' for comments in the control file
    start the file (other than comments) with 'load data' (omit the quotes)
    'infile' identifies the data file to be loaded, eg 'infile.dat' with the single quotes
    into table tablename - identifies the table to be loaded (eg into table purchase_orders)
    field mapping specifications include the column name, position start and finish, format and format mapping (eg (first_name position(01:14) char...)
    The default mode is insert (into an empty table) and options on the 'into table' line are append, replace, and truncate. Replace and truncate do the same thing. If the target table is not empty, append must be used instead of insert
    Filters can be put on the load process in the control file, on a separate line eg (when first_name <> 'John' will discard all 'John' records)

SQL*Plus and SQLCL (SQL Command Line) Notes on Connections
    SQLCL Connection String (without TNS Names File)
        Command Line
            cd c:\SqlCl\bin
            cd C:\Oracle\Middleware\sqlcl-17.3.0.271.1943\bin -- included in $PATH shown by 'echo %PATH%'
            sql username/password@host:port/service
                Examples
                    sql apps/appscrp032014@10.83.40.35:1529/EBSDEV03 -- Darling DEV03
                    sql apps/ebsqa01D4rling@ocebsqa1db01.dii.local:1524/EBSQA01 -- Darling QA01
                    sql gjarman/Mpa4egu9@192.168.0.44:1521/orcl -- risingfast VM
        Non-Command Line (after starting SqlCL)
            Darling EBSDEV03
                User: apps@10.83.40.35:1529/EBSDEV03
                Password: appscrp032014
            Risingfast
                User: gjarman@192.168.0.44:1521/orcl
                Password: Mpa4egu9
    Usage
        help -- to see all commands with new commands highlighted
        supports all SQL*PLUS commands
        ddl <owner>.<table_name> -- shows DDL for the table
        clear screen -- clears the SQLCL screen
        set sqlformat ansiconsole -- to get clean column-oriented data in select statements
        set sqlformat csv -- formats csv
        set sqlformat json -- formats json
        set sqlformat -- clears any prior sqlformat settings
        / -- execute the buffer text
        set head off -- remove column headers
        set pagesize 100 -- set page depth to 100 rows
        set linesize 100 -- set line length to 100 characters
        user arrow keys to show previous commands
        history -- lists command history and line numbers
        history nn -- shows line nn from the history list
        info <owner><table_name> -- new describe with additional information
        alias <Name> = <SQL> to define an command alias (then run by typing 'Name' on the command line
        repeat <times> <delay> -- repeat the current buffer SQL multiple times with specific delay

    SQL*Plus Connection String (with TNS Names File)

            sqlplus
            Enter user-name: username (e.g. apps)
            Enter password: password@SID (e.g. appscrp032014@EBSDEV03
                SID is the TNS Names connection identifier

Subledger Accounting (XLA Schema) Notes on General Functionality
    Seeded setups in Subledger Accounting are owned by Oracle
        They must be copied and renamed to be modified and ownership automatically changes from 'Oracle' to 'User'
    SLA is event based - it turns transactions into events
        and applies accounting rules to the events to derive/override accounting
    Subledger Accounting is introduced in R12 along with Ledgers (rather than Sets of Books)
    This is done along with the change from SET_OF_BOOKS_ID to LEDGER_ID in the GL tables
    It was introduced to allow multiple accounting representations (timing and definition of accounting events) to be created to meet different reporting requirements
        Different accounting representations include: GAAP, IFRS, Cash etc
    Subledger Accounting is a service and not an application
        SLA forms and concurrent programs are accessible from within other applications (sub-ledgers) and not directly accessible
        SLA stores cross references between distributions in the subledgers and additional data but does not store source subledger distributions directly
        Accounting Methods Builder is an SLA service to create distributions in the subledger and replace the workflows for Account Generator
    Subledger Accounting implements the accounting concept of 'Day Books'
        In 'Day Books' details of the transaction are records for future accounting including key business attributes
    Subledger Accounting derives appropriate accounts based on business events for all subledgers
        The distributions are still derived in each subledger's and stored in their account distributions tables
        However, preliminary accounting distributions derived in each subledger act as default distributions in Subledger Accounting
            They can be modified by rules in Subledger Accounting or passed through to the General Ledger unmodified
            The seeded rules in SLA simply derive the accounting as 'take from subledger distribution' unless the rules are modified
            Subledger Accounting Rules triggered by Accounting Events modify these default distributions
            Any changes to accounting distributions made in SLA are not pushed back to the sub-ledger
                This is because (for example) the subledger can't store multiple representations of the same accounting even
        Any attribute captured with the accounting event can be used in the rule to derive the accounting distribution
    Subledger Accounting stores a complete and balanced journal entry for each financial transaction in the subledgers
    Subledger Accounting can be called by external systems via the Oracle Financial Services Accounting Hub
    Subledger Accounting includes a posting engine to summarize and post transactions to the GL
        The posting engine is a single process for posting all subledger entries to the GL
    In R12, Subledger Accounting succeeds and supercedes the Global Accounting Engine
        It also supplements AutoAccounting in Accounts Receivable by adding a back-end to override the AutoAccounting results or simply act as a pass-through
    Multiple accounting representations can be created from a single accounting event
        Multiple accounting representations allows the same transaction to be posted to different books (or ledgers within a ledger set)
        Each accounting representation can use different charts of accounts, calendars, currencies, and subledger accounting methods.
   Subledger Accounting is a single set of tables for reporting detail accounting distribution activity across all subledgers from a single point
        Reporting off the subledger is supported by XML Publisher

    Subledgers are registered in SLA to use SLA services
    Navigation: Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Subledger Applications

        Assets
        Cash Management

        Institutional Banking

        Loans
        Payables
        Process Manufacturing
        Projects
        Purchasing
        Receivables
        Trade Managementa

Subledger Accounting (XLA Schema) Notes on Hierarchy
    SLAM Subledger Accounting Methods (SLAM)
        Application Accounting Definitions (AAD)
            Event Classes
                Journal Line Definitions (JLD)
                    Account Derivation Rules (ADR)
                        Mapping Sets and Conditions

Subledger Accounting (XLA Schema) Notes on Key Entities
    Subledger Accounting Methods (SLAM)
        These are the different Valuation or Accounting Methods that can be used for financial reporting
            One SLAM includes Application Accounting Definitions for all Subledgers (Accounting Applications)
        There are very few valuation (accounting) methods and they are pre-defined:
        e.g. STANDARD_ACCRUAL, STANDARD_CASH, UNITED_STATES_FEDERAL, JA_CN_STANDARD_ACCRUAL, ENCUBRANCE_ACCRUAL, ENCUMBRANCE_CASH
        Everything defined under one of these methods are considered Accounting Methods definitions
            Navigation: AP Superuser > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Accounting Methods Builder > Methods and Definitions > Subledger Accounting Definitions > Find
        All the tools and forms used to create these methods are collectively the Accounting Methods Builder
        Accounting Event Classes and events are different and have different timing in different accounting methods
            e.g. cash accounting generates on AP Invoice Event (entry/payment)
            e.g. accrual accounting generates two events (entry, then payment)
    Application Accounting Definition (AAD) Assignments to SLAMs
        Navigation: AP Superuser > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setup > Accounting Methods Builder > Methods and Definitions > Application Accounting Definitions
        AAD Assignments link SLAM's and Application Accounting Definitions (Event Class Collections)
        The Event Class and Event Type Assignments in an AAD represent Journal Headers
            Journal Entry Descriptions can be attached via the 'Header Assignments' button on the AAD Maintenance page
    Application Accounting Definition (AAD)
        A named 'Collection' of Event Classes and Event Types for a single Application that can be assigned to a SLAM
            e.g. Invoices (ALL Events) and Expense Reports (ALL Events) for the Accounts Payable Application
            All the Event Classes for an Applicatoin are included in the Application Accounting Definition
        Application Accounting Definitions can be limited to a Chart of Accounts (Transaction or Accounting)
        Validation is required before an Application Accounting Definition can be used (via the 'Validate' button on the Definition form)
            The Validation Status is shown against each Event Class and Event Type in the Application Accounting Definition
        Journal Line Definitions are assigned to the Application Accounting Definition if they share the same Event Class and Event Type
            If the Event Type is set to ALL on the Class/Event Assignment Line, then all Journal Line Definitions with the same Event Class are available for assignment
        Application Accounting Definitions can be exported and imported to support testing across environments using concurrent programs
            Import Application Accounting Definitions and Export Application Accounting Definitions are concurrent programs
    Entities and Event Classes and Event Class Options
        Entities are the transaction supertypes and classes are the types within the subledger application
        For Receivables, the primary entities are: Transactions, Receipts, Adjustments and Bills Receivable
        For Assets, the primary entities are: Transactions, Depreciation, Inter-Asset Transactions, Deferred Depreciation
        For Payables, the primary entities are: Invoices and Payments
            For Invoices, the primary event classes include: Standard Invoices, Credit Memos, Debit Memos, Expense Reports (the Invoice Entity supertype)
            For the Payment Entity, the primary event classes are: Prepayments, Payments, Refunds (the Payment Entity supertype)
        Entities are defined in the Event Modeller 'Entities' form
            Navigation: Payables Manager > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Accounting Methods Builder > Events > Event Model
            The Gapless Event Processing option control accounting on a sequence of event numbers
                Accounting cannot occur on an event if the prior event is not accounted for an instance of an entity (e.g an invoice_id)
                The Identifers page shows the source table identifer from the subledger and the column where it is referenced in XLA_TRANSACTION_ENTITIES
        Entities correspond with object super-classes in programming
        Event Classes correspond with inherited object classes (subclasses) in object-oriented programming
        Event Classes are defined in the Event Modeller 'Event Classes and Types' form
            This is reached from  the 'Event Classes' button on the 'Entities' form
            Navigation: Payables Manager > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setup > Accounting Methods Builder > Events > Event Model > Event Classes (button)
            Each Event Class is assigned a code, name and description and can be enabled or disabled
            Each Event Class is also assigned multiple Event Types (methods)
                e.g. Types (or methods) for AP Event Class 'Invoices' include: Invoice Validated, Invoice Adjusted, and Invoice Cancelled
            Each Event Class can have predecessors defined
                Predecessors are event classes that must be accounted beforehand
                e.g An invoice must be accounted prior to a payment on the same invoice
                Navigation: AP Superuser > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Accounting Methods Builder > Events > Event Model (Entities) > Event Classes > Predecessors
        Not all event classes are capable of generating accounting events - e.g. Supplier Setup
        Accounting Events within an Event Class are the actual transactions or event object instances
        Transactions correspond with instances of a class in object-oriented programming
        Process Categories are groupings of Event Classes used by the 'Create Accounting' process (as an optional run parameter)
            Navigation: Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Accounting Methods Builder > Events > Process Categories
            Process Categories are seeded in Oracle and cannot be modified
            Process Categories allow the 'Create Accounting' process to be run for a subset of Event Classes within an application
                It also allows forcing the correct order for 'Create Accounting' where Event Classes have predecessors
            A Process Category is assigned to an Event Class in Accounting Event Class Options
                Navigation: Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Accounting Methods Builder > Events > Accounting Event Class Options
                e.g. Invoices, Payments, Third Party Merge
        Accounting Event Class Options are defined for each Accounting Event Class
            Navigation: Payables Manager > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setup > Accounting Methods Builder > Events > Accounting Event Class Options
            These setups are overridden by settings in Subledger Accounting Options
            The Journal Category is assigned to the Event Class in Event Class Options
            A Process Category is assigned to the Event Class also (see 'Process Categories' above)
            Informational Fields (Transaction Identifiers) are assigned to an Event Class in Event Class Options
                These are based on the Transaction View also defined on Accounting Event Class Options
                Each field in the view is mapped to a User Identifier Name which is exposed to the user in place of the column name
                These information fields are displayed in Tools > View Accounting Events > View Journal Entries from the subledger forms
        Sources
            Sources are generated after Accounting Event Classes are fully defined by running Create and Assign Sources 'Create and Assign Sources'
                This program validates all Accounting Event definitions and creates sources for all reference objects
                    It also assigns the generated sources to Event Classes within each application
                The results are viewed on the Sources page and Source Assignments page
                    Navigation: AP Superuser > Setups > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Accounting Methods Builder > Sources > Sources
                    Navigation: AP Superuser > Setups > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Accounting Methods Builder > Sources > Source Assignments
                Source Assignments are assigned to Accounting Attributes via Accounting Attribute Assignments
                    Navigation: AP Superuser > Setups > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Accounting Methods Builder > Sources > Accounting Attribute Assignments
                    Accounting Attributes are used to create subledger journal entries
                    One Accounting Attribute (e.g. Accounted Amount on Paybles Invoices) can have multiple sources assigned
                    These Accounting Attribute Assignments are defaults and can be overridden at the Joural Line Type level
    Event Types and Events
        Each class can have multiple event types (methods)
        e.g. for class STANDARD_INVOICES, there are types: STANDARD_CREATED, STANDARD_FULLY_REVERSED, STANDARD_DISTRIBUTE, STANDARD_OVERRIDE_TAX, etc
        Event Types correspond to class methods
        Each event class is subtyped from an event entity and has distinct Event Types (or methods)
        Each time an Event Type occurs on an Event Class Object, an Event Number is generated
        e.g. Invoice Created ('Invoice' event class object instance, with a Creation Event Type)
        Journals headers are defined at the level of Event Class and Event Type combination (in Application Accounting Definition)
            For each combination of Event Class and Event Type (i.e. Journal Header) a collection of Jouranl Lines are assigned (a Journal Line Definition)
        Events are stored in XLA_EVENTS with EVENT_TYPE_CODE and ENTITY_ID as foreign keys
     Journal Line Types
        Navigation: Payables Manager > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setup > Accounting Methods Builder > Journal Entry Setups > Journal Line Types
        Journal Line types are different structures of different journal lines (e.g. Freight Expense)
            They cannot be modified directly but they can be copied from Oracle owned to User owned and then renamed, changed and used to replace the original Line Types
        Journal Line Types are assembled into Journal Line Definitions which comprise all the journal lines an Event Class can create
        A Journal Line Type is a unique combination of Application, Event Class and Accounting Class
            Accounting Class is used by the Journal Posting program to group postings to the Ledger
            Accounting Classes are grouped into Post-Accounting Programs which are used to identify journal entries that must be created by specific processes
            Accounting Class is defined as subledger accounting lookups and can be added as needed
                e.g. Application: Payables, Event Class: Invoices, Accounting Class: Item Expense - conditions include Invoice Distribution Type 'Item' or 'Invoice Price Variance' or 'Exchange Rate Variance'
                Navigation: Payables Superuser > Setup > Lookups > Subledger Accounting Lookups (Type XLA_ACCOUNTING_CLASS)
        Conditions are defined for each Journal Line Type to decide when the Line Type is created and used
            Conditions can include references to Invoice Distribution Types and accounting options
    Journal Line Definition Assignments (JLD) to Event Classes
        Links event classes to a collection of Journal Line Definitions
        They determine the types of journal lines that can be generated by an event class
        e.g. For AP Invoices in Payables can generate: An Accrual Charge, Gain/Loss, Withholding Tax
    Journal Line Definition (JLD)
        Navigation: AP Superuser > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setup > Accounts Method Builder > Methods And Definitions > Journal Line Definitions
        Journal Line Definitions tie Event Class and Event Type combinations (journal headers) to Journal Line Types and their Account Derivation Rules
        They comprise a named 'Collection' of Journal Line Types that are assigned as a group to a single event class and event type
            e.g. Event Class ACCRUAL_INVICES_ALL, and Event Type ALL
        A Journal Line Definition is specific to an application event class and event type
        There is a separate Journal Line Definition for each Subledger Accounting Method (SLAM) which applies to an event class
            i.e. a different definition for the journal line for each different accounting convention or SLAM
        A Journal Line Definition can include multiple Journal Line Type records (e.g Withholding Tax, Gain/Loss, Accrual Charge)
            Each Journal Line Type can include one or more Account Derivation Rules (multiple if each segment has a separate rule)
            The Description for the Journal Line Type can be specified, or flagged as 'Inherit' to derive automatically from Journal Line Type Flow rules
                One Account Derivation Rule can be specified for all segments, and additional Account Derivation Rules assigned to override individual segments
            Each Journal Line Type is assigned Account Derivation Rules which can be one for all segments or separate rules for each segment
            Supporting references are added to the Journal Line Type also, if needed
        A Journal Line Definition can optionally have a Chart of Account specified (either 'Transaction' or 'Accounting')
            This will limit when the definition is used, as well as limit the Account Derivation Rules available
    Mapping Sets
        Mapping Sets are translation tables that map entity attributes onto account values to modify account segments
            Navigation: AP Superuser > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Journal Entry Setups > Mapping Sets
        Mapping Sets are used in Account Derivation Rules to derive account strings or segment values
            The choice of Mapping Sets is only available in Account Derivation Rules if a Chart of Accounts is specified in the Account Derivation Rule (either Transaction or Accounting)
        A Value Setup must be created first (or found) to establish the 'Input' Values in the Mapping Set
            Navigation: AP Superuser > Setup > Flexfields > Validation > Sets
        The 'Output' values are defined by segment values in the Chart of Accounts (or a combination of Segment Values)
            The Chart of Accounts field can be left blank if the same Output value set applies across multiple chart of accounts
            Specifying a Chart of Accounts limits the Mapping Set Usage to a single chart
    Account Derivation Rule (ADR)
        Navigation: Payables Manager > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setup > Accounts Method Builder > Journal Entry Setups > Account Derivation Rules
        Seeded and saved rules must be copied and renamed - they cannot be modfied once saved
            When copied the owner automatically changes from 'Oracle' to 'User'
        Account Derivation Rules can be used in any application with a common Reference Object defined in Accounting Event Class Options
        Account Derivation Rules are used to build account strings based on rules (which derive account values) and conditions (which determine when the rules is applied)
        They can comprise a set of rules for each segment or for all segments as a single combined rule
            They are assigned to Journal Line Types in Journal Line Definitions
            Each rule comprising one or more prioritized 'sub' rules
        Chart of Accounts values in ADR definition are 'Transaction' or 'Accounting' (or neither or both)
            The choice defines the type of rule and the choices of output type
            Choosing either a Transaction or Accounting Chart limits the Output Types of Flexfield and Segment
            Transaction means the chart of accounts used on the originating transaction - the primary books chart
            Accounting means the chart of accounts used in the Accounting Subledger (which can be the primary book or a secondary book)
                The balancing segment entity is only available as an Output Type if the Accounting Chart of Accounts is specified on its own
            Choosing a Chart of Accounts puts a restriction on where the Account Derivation Rule can be used (i.e. transactions using this chart)
                Choosing an Output Type without a Chart of Accounts is the least restrictive and the rule can be used anywhere
        Output Type in ADR definition determines the type of output for the rule (Flexfield combination, Segment or Value Set)
            'Flexfield' can only be specified if a Chart of Accounts is specified (either Transaction or Accounting)
            'Segment' refers to an individual account segment
        Using an output type of Segment without a Chart of Accounts will limit the Value Types available on rule lines to Account Derivation Rule and Source
            Specifying a Chart of Accounts (Transaction or Accounting or both) makes the Value Types 'Constant' and 'Mapping Set' available also
        Conditions
            The conditions for an Account Derivation Rule determine when the rule will apply
            All the conditions assigned to a specific Account Derivation Rule must be met for the rule to apply (if they are 'AND'ed together)
            If the condition source is a key flexfield, then a segment qualifier can be chosen.
    Supporting References
        References
            MOS Note 876190.1 FAQ's on Transfer to GL
            MOS Note 790978.1 FAQ's on Supporting References
            https://www.slideshare.net/prithis/supporting-references-in-oracle-ebs-r12
        Navigation: AP Superuser > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setup > Accounting Methods Builder > Journal Entry Setups > Supporting References
        Supporting References are additional attributes of transactions passed to Subledger Accounting for drill-back referencing
            They are not included in journal entries to the GL but are available in drillback to Subledger Accounting
        Supporting References are added to Journal Line Types in Journal Line Definitions
    Journal Entry Descriptions
        Navigation: AP Superuser > Setups > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Journal Entry Setups > Journal Entry Descriptions
        e.g. JE_INV_HEADER_DESC
        Journal Entry Descriptions control the content of descriptions on journal entry headers and lines
        Journal Entry Descriptions appear on the Subledger Journal Entry Inquiry Page and are built dynamically based on definitions
            These are viewed from the subledger via the link 'Tools > View Accounting Events'
            They are also viewed via drill back from the GL on Journal Entry Inquiry and Account Balance Inquiry
        Journal Entry Descriptions are assigned to Journal Entry Headers and Journal Entry Lines
            Navigation for Journal Entry Header: Application Accounting Definitions (Event Class and Event Type Assignment Region) > Header Assignments
            Navigation for Journal Entry Lines: Application Accounting Definition (Journal Lined Definition Assignments) > Journal Line Definition > Line Description (Line Assignments Region)

Subledger Accounting (XLA Schema) Notes on Form Maintenance Groupings
    Entity maintenance is grouped onto forms as:
        Subledger Accounting Methods and Application Accounting Definition (AAD) Assignments
        Application Accounting Definitions (AAD), Event Class Assignments and Journal Line Definition (JLD) Assignments
        Journal Line Definitions (JLD), Line Types and Account Derivation Rule (ADR) Assignments
        Account Derivation Rule Detail (ADR), Priorities, Mapping Sets, Conditions

Subledger Accounting (CLA Schema) Notes on Seeded Setups
    Each application must be registered in order to use SLA
        Seeded subleders are pre-registered (Navigation: System Administrator > Application > Register)
        Only custom applications need to be registered explicitly
        Registration of an application to SLA is allowed if the application is assigned to the responsibility
            Navigation: Payables Manager, Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setup > Subledger Application
            The 'Use Security' option enables Data Access Set protection of viewable transacions via drillback
    Accounting Methods
        Subledger Accounting Events - Accountable Transactions

Subledger Accounting (XLA Schema) Notes on Concurrent Programs
    Create Accounting - run in each subledger but calls code in SLA to generate distributions
        Generates account distributions in each subledger and any overrides in SLA
    Transfer Journal Entries to GL
        Can be run if the option to tranfer to GL is not chosen in Create Accounting
    Validate Accounting Application Definitions
        Does the same as the 'Validate' button on the Application Accounting Definitions Form
        Provides the additonal option of running across multiple applications at once
        It can be run with Debug set at Statement Level to get detailed information on issues found

Subledger Accounting (XLA Schema) Notes on Reports
    Reference: http://www.oracleappshub.com/release12/subledger-accounting/sub-ledger-accounting-technical-perspective/
    Journal Entries Report
    Account Analysis Report
    Third Party Balances
    Multiperiod Accounting
    Open Account Balances (Trial Balance) - shows balances created by SLA and transactions within these balances
        Applies to AP Trial Balance in R12
        Create an Open Account Balance Listing Definition
            Navigation: AP Superuser > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setups > Open Account Balances Listing Definitions
            These definitions are stored in XLA_TB_DEFINITIONS_B (and _TL) for headers, and XLA_TB_DEFN_DETAILS for detail/account ranges
        Compile the Definition using concurrent process "Open Account Balances Data Manager"
        Run the compiled definition using concurrent process "Open Account Balances Listing"
            This process is submitted automatically if any changes are made to a report definition
        This report is customizable with XML Publisher templates
        Reference: Oracle Subledger Accounting Implementation Guide Release 12.1 Part No. E13628-04, Page 10-2
    Period Close Exceptions Report

Subledger Accounting (XLA Schema) Notes on Account Derivation Rules (ADR's)
    Oracle ships with default rules for each subledger accounting event for accrual and cash accounting
        They can be modified through the Accounting Methods Builder (AMB) Forms
        Most of the rules are simple pass-through rules to build the subledger accounts by copying the account distributions from the subledger applications

Subledger Accounting (XLA Schema) Notes on Supporting References
    References
        http://navaneeth-oracleapps.blogspot.com/2012/12/an-insight-to-sla-supporting-reference.html
    Bacgbround
        Supporting references add attributes to journal lines in subledger accounting
        They do not pass to the General Ledger
    Navigation
        Setup
            Payables Manager > Setup > Accounting Setups > Subledger Accounting Setup > Accounting Methods Builder > Journal Entry Setups > Supporting References
        Analyze Account Activity by Supporting References
            Payables Manager > Accounting > Subledger Accounting > Supporting Reference Balances
    Key Tables
        XLA_AE_LINE_ACS - journal line detail of supporting references
        xla_ac_balances - balances for supporting references

Subledger Accounting (XLA Schema) Notes on Upgrading from 11i
    Patch 5233248 is a pre-upgrade SLA patch in 11i to run prior to the upgrade
        It allows you to upgrade more history than the current financial year and six months of the prior year
        GL Drilldowns are supported by running this patch for the required periods.
        It also allows cancelling and reversal of old transactions

Subledger Accounting (XLA) Notes on Key Tables
    GL.GL_LEDGERS - stores ledger definitions (currency, chart of accounts, calendar and convention)
    XLA.XLA_AAD_HEADER_AC_ASSGNS
    XLA.XLA_AAD_HEADER_ACCT_ATTRS
    XLA.XLA_AAD_LINE_DEFN_ASSGNS - Application Accounting Definition - lines showing Event Classes/Types assigned to AAD headers
    XLA.XLA_ACCTG_METHODS_B (and _TL) - main accounting methods
    XLA.XLA_ACCTG_METHOD_RULES - has the Application Accounting Definition Assignments
    XLA.XLA_AE_HEADERS_ALL - stores journal entry headers (FK AE_EVENT_ID)
    XLA.XLA_AE_LINES_ALL - stores journal entry live referenences (FK AE_HEADER_ID)
    XLA.XLA_DISTRIBUTION_LINKS - links AE_LINES back to subledger accounting entries - stores the journal entry values, debits and credits
    XLA.XLA_ENTITY_TYPES_B (and _TL) - entities within each application
    XLA.XLA_EVENT_CLASSES_B (and _TL) - event classes such as credit memos, chargebacks within each application and entity
    XLA.XLA_EVENT_TYPES_B (and _TL) - event class methods for each event class
    XLA.XLA_EVENTS - accounting events which are instances of event type occurances within an entity
    XLA.XLA_MAPPING_SETS_B (and _TL) - mapping set headers
    XLA.XLA_MAPPING_SET_VALUES - mapping set lines
    XLA.XLA_TB_DEFINITIONS_B (and _TL) for Open Account Balance Definition headers
    XLA.XLA_TB_DEFN_DETAILS for Open Account Balance Definition detail/account ranges
    The source_id_int_1 column of xla.xla_transaction_entities stores the primary_id value for the transactions.
        You can join the xla.xla_transaction_entities table with the corresponding transactions table for obtaining additional information of the transaction.
        e.g you join the xla.xla_transaction_entities table with ra_customer_trx_all for obtaining receivables transactions information or with mtl_material_transactions table for obtaining material transactions information.
    XLA.XLA_TRANSACTION_ENTITIES - maps each event back to the source system transaction

Subledger Accounting (XLA) Notes on Key Table Relationships
    GL_JE_BATCHES (je_batch_id)                                   => GL_JE_HEADERS (je_batch_id)
    GL_JE_HEADERS (je_header_id)                                  => GL_JE_LINES (je_header_id)
    GL_JE_LINES (je_header_id,  je_line_num)                      => GL_IMPORT_REFERENCES (je_header_id, je_line_num)
    GL_IMPORT_REFERENCES (gl_sl_link_table, gl_sl_link_id)        => XLA_AE_LINES (gl_sl_link_table, gl_sl_link_id)
    XLA_AE_LINES (application_id, ae_header_id)                   => XLA_AE_HEADERS (application_id, ae_header_id)
    XLA_AE_HEADERS (application_id, event_id)                     => XLA_EVENTS (application_id, event_id)
    XLA_EVENTS (application_id, entity_id)                        => XLA.XLA_TRANSACTION_ENTITIES (application_id, entity_id)
    The entity_id mappings can be obtained from the XLA_ENTITY_ID_MAPPINGS table

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Tips, Tricks and Troubleshooting
    References
        EBS AP, AR and EBTax Setup/Data Integrity Analyzer (Doc ID 1529429.1)
        R12.1.X: or R12.2.x: Tax Diagnostic Framework (Doc ID 1621617.1)
    Tax recovery rates on recoverable tax cannot be overridden on payables invoices until they are generated and saved by viewing All Distributions. 
        Generating and saving via All Distributions makes them accessible for override via drill-down from line distributions. 
    Tax distributions are created when you click on All Distributions or upon invoice validation
    The Bill-to address for AP invoices used by eBTax comes from the Operating Unit (not the legal entity or establishment address)
        Create a test invoice and examine ZX.ZX_LINES_DET_FACTORS to confirm this
        References
            http://blog.ebizanswers.net/2013/02/oracle-ebtax-payables-bill-to-country.html
    For employee expenses, the ship from and bill from are null on tax determining attributes
        So the registration rule can point to bill from to avoid self-assessment (since there is no 'enable self assessment flag there)
    There is a concurrent program 'Run Diagnostics Tests' under the System Administrator responsibility
        It can be run with the application name parameter: 'E-Business Tax'
        An alternative is to run the tax diagnostics under the 'Oracle Diagnostics Tool' responsibility
    If you change a tax to self-assess on the tax lines, you must requery the invoice to see the correct tax on the invoice lines summary tab
    The tab sequence is broken on several setup forms
        Tabbing out of Configuration Owner on the Tax setup form
        Tabbing out of Tax on the Tax Status form
        Tabbing out of Tax Status on the Tax Rates form
        Tabbing out of Configuration Owner on the Tax Rules form
    If Tax Groups are not defined in 11i no tax rules will be generated in R12
        This is because the conversion process uses the Tax Group Name as the Rule Name in R12
        It ties the STCC into this rule as the Determining Factor Set and creates a Direct Tax Determination Type Rule
    You must run Geography Name Referencing in TCA to get taxes to calculate automatically - even for direct determination
    You cannot disable a Configuration Tax Owner's subscription to an application and event class
        Taxes will continue to calculate after the effective end-date or if disabled or both
        You have to end-date and then create a new subscription for the same event with the Tax Applicability Checkbox disabled
        You cannot disable the Tax Applicability box on an existing subscription - it is frozen so a new subscription is required
    Set the Profile Option = Tax: Debug Flag at the user level to 'Yes' to get additional detail in the concurrent log
        Search for string in the output matching:
            Return_Status = E
            Return_Status = U
            ORA-
    If Direct Tax Determination is used, tax rules must be defined to avoid the default tax rate being invoked
        Condition sets and determining factor sets must be defined for the rules first
    The Bill-to for Payables Invoices is the default address of the legal establishment attached to the buying operating unit
        Any tax rules based on bill-to for payables will always evaluate to this one address.
        References
            Case Study: Setup R12 E-Business Tax (EBTax) for Canada: Includes 2010 HST Changes (Doc ID 577996.1) (search on 'Bill To')
            Bug 8909476 : BILL TO LOCATION TO BE PICKED BY LOOKING AT HEIRARACHY

Fusion Tax
    References
        http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E15586_01/fusionapps.1111/e20375/F569957AN2EDE8.htm
        https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZQ18R6jqumU
        http://www.ebizanswers.net/2015/05/oracle-fusoin-tax-the-good-the-bad-the-ugly/

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Regime and Jurisdiction-Specific Rules
    United States
        Texas
            Direct Pay status allows a purchaser to self-assess 100% of their taxes - vendors do not change tax on their invoices
    Mexico
        There are three Oracle bugs with deferred tax in Mexico
            Interim input tax on self-assessed tax amounts is not reclassed to input tax credits when the invoices are paid
            Self Assessed tax liability is not deferred but booked to the final liability account
            Discounts taken on invoices at time of payment do not generate tax credits for the amount of the discount
    Canada
        Business Numbers (BN's)
            References
                http://www.canadiancommunities.org/reg/bnInfo.asp?l=e
            Business Numbers are 9 digits (the Legal Entity Number) followed by one of several Program Identifier Codes, followed by a 4-digit reference
            Program Identifiers are:
                RC - Corp Income Tax
                RM - Import/Export
                RP - Payroll
                RT - Transaction Tax (eg. 123456789-RT0001)
         Reporting Payments
             No requirement for residents of CA
             T4A-NR - mandatory for payments to non-residents (similar to 1099 reporting in the US)

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Direct Tax Determination
    References
        http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E48434_01/fusionapps.1118/e20371/F1085094AN2F566.htm
        The following must occur for a Direct Tax Rate Determination rule to be applicable:
            The Direct Tax Rate Determination rule must evaluate to true
            The tax rate code must be defined for the product family
            The place of supply must evaluate successfully except in the case of migrated taxes when Allow multiple jurisdictions is selected

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Procedures
    Changing Existing Tax Lines
        You can't cancel a tax line and add a second line with the same Regime and Tax - it is considered a duplicate
            Canceling a tax line is final - you cannot recreate it for the same items
            The workaround is to discard the associated invoice lines and re-enter the line
        You can modify a tax line any number of times until it is validated, but after validation, the adjustment creates a new line upon saving
    Entering a Tax Control Amount on an AP Invoice
        You cannot 'undo' a tax control amount on an AP invoice - once entered the line is tagged as manual and treated as manual
        See: Changing Tax Control Amount to Null Does Not Modify the Existent Calculated Tax Amount [ID 780887.1]

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Steps to Analyze if Taxes Don't Calculate
    For AR transactions with no backing sales orders, there must be a warehouse specified if the situs rule is 'ship-from'
        See MOS Note 1082
    Make sure the supplier is enabled for tax ('Allow Tax Applicability' flag') at the 3rd Party and 3rd Party Site levels
        Reference: R12 Supplier Site Transaction Tax Not Set To Yes After Upgrade [ID 1139023.1]
        R12: What Is The Purpose Of The Allow Tax Applicability Checkbox In Customer Site? (Doc ID 1462080.1)
        "Allow tax Applicability" flag not working correctly (Doc ID 1362750.1)
            States this flag is only implemented for suppliers and supplier sites
        Check this on the tax party/site profile and the supplier/site setup
        Note: this flag applies only to suppliers - it is not evaluated for customers
        Search on 'Allow Tax Applicability' in MOS for specific rules
        It may be necessary to use a specific customer or supplier who is enabled for tax
    Make sure the Content Owner is subscribed to the transaction type
    Check the Legal Entity on the Transaction is subscribed to the Tax Regime
