Tax Engine (ZX Schema) Notes on Terminology
    Nexus - connection
        References
            http://biztaxlaw.about.com/od/glossaryn/g/nexusdef.htm
        A nexus in general means a connection. 
        The term nexus is used in tax law to describe a situation in which a business has a "nexus" or presence in a state
        If an entity has Nexus it is subject to state income taxes and to sales taxes for sales within that state. 
        Nexus describes the amount and degree of business activity that must be present before a state can tax an entity's income. 
        If a taxpayer has nexus in a particular state, the taxpayer must ay and collect/remit taxes in that state.
        Nexus Tests include:
            If the business has a physical location in the state
            If there are resident employees working in the state
            If the business has property (including intangible property) in the state
            if there are employees who regularly solicit business in the state.
    Situs - location (the Place of Supply)
    Zero-Rated - tax is charged at zero % but input taxes to the sales of zero-rated items can be claimed for input tax credit
        Input tax credit cannot be claimed on exempt sales

Tax Engine (ZX Schema) Notes on General Functionality
    The Tax Engine is refered to as e-Business Tax or EBT
    Tax related holds are applied on an invoice when it is validated
    Tax lines can be entered manually on an invoice if the setups allow it
        This includes setting the flags to allow taxes at Regime, Tax, Status and Rate levels
            Reference: How To Enter A Single Or Multiple Manual Tax Line In Payables [ID 818513.1]

Tax Engine (ZX Schema) Notes on Profile Options
    Tax: Debug Flag at the user level to 'Yes' (to get debug messages in the concurrent manager log)
    eBTax: Read/Write Access to GCO Data -- Global Consolidation Owner access switch


Tax Engine (ZX Schema) Notes on Seeded Responsibilities
    There are three seeded responsibilities in the Oracle Tax Engine
        Tax Manager - setup and maintain tax configuration data
        Tax Administrator - tax technical setup and support responsibilities
        Oracle Tax Simulator - to use the tax simulation feature

Tax Engine (ZX Schema) Notes on Tax Model Setup and Configuration
    Tax Engine entities must be setup for:
        Tax Regimes - is a country or group of countries with common registration settings
            A country defined in the TCA Geography Hieararchy is attached to a Regime when the regime is defined
            Defined as a set of taxes and regulations that establish tax requirements
            A regime is a common set of default information that applies to one or more taxes
                It designates the geography in which the taxes apply
                It defines the use of fiscal classifications
            Tax registrations are done once for each regime
            A Tax Regime must be associated with all First Parties (LE's or OPU's) using configuration options
        Configuration Options - define the relationship between a tax regime and a first party legal entity or operating unit
            They allow flexibility on how regime rules apply to different legal entities in the same regime
        Configuration Owners - parties (legal entities or operating units) which have specific configuration options
            Global Configuration Owner - the owner of all tax setups for a regime
            Specific Legal Entities or Operating Units - can have overriding content ownership to pre-empt the Global Configuration Owner setting
            Stored on the database tables as CONTENT_OWNER_ID
        Taxes - a tax classification such as Sales, Use, VAT, Excise
        Tax Status - are different rate classes for the same tax
            e.g. standard rate, zero rate, partially exempt rate
        Tax Rate - a rate specified for a tax status for an effective date
            Expressed as a percent, rate per unit, or fixed amount
        Tax Recovery Rate (optional) - a full or partial recovery rate
        First Party Legal Entity - an internal legal entity or operating unit
        Country Defaults - for a country
        Configuration Owner Defaults - for the First Party who is the configuration owner
        Application Tax Option Defaults - for installation level default values
    Manual entry of tax can be activated or deactivated at several levels
        Event Class Level (topmost level)
        Configuration Owner (more specific)
        Tax Level (most specific - applies to only one tax for the event class)
        The most specific levels override the higher levels
        Options made possible at these levels include:
            Manual entry of tax lines
            Over-ride of calculated lines
            Recalculate manual tax lines
        Manual tax lines can only be entered if they apply proportionally to all invoice lines

Tax Engine (ZX Schema) Notes on Address Validation
    References
        https://smartystreets.com/
    Address Styles
        Important Note
            The address style validations defined for address entry do not use the same tables and the geography validation process in several instances
                This can be changed so that the validation sets reference the HZ_GEOGRAPHY tables if needed.
            The reason is that in HR_LOCATIONS, the validations are based on the PAY ... payroll tables populated by Vertex Data with a full install of HR
        For HR_LOCATIONS_ALL (applies to Legal Entity Addresses and Internal Location Addresses)
            DFF is 'Location Address' and seeded styles (DFF contexts) 'US' (the seeded style for HR) and 'US_GLB' (the seeded Global/International Style)
            If HR is not fully installed, the validations on 'US' style will cause data entry failures because the tables are empty
                Tables referenced in validation sets for style 'US' are:
                    PAY_US_CITY_NAMES
                    PAY_US_COUNTIES
                    PAY_US_STATES
                    PAY_US_CITY_GEOCODES
                    PAY_US_COUNTIES
                    PAY_US_ZIP_CODES
                    PAY_US_CITY_SCHOOL_DSTS
                    PAY_US_COUNTY_SCHOOL_DSTS
            You cannot choose the style when entering a Legal Entity Address
                Oracle chooses the first valid style ('US')
                If HR is not fully installed you can disable this style in the DFF context, or remove the validation set references
                    or, replace the validation sets with newly defined sets which reference HZ_GEOGRAPHIES
                        which guarantees the LOV's used to enter addresses match the validation values used in geography validation
            References
                How to Setup a Legal Address Using HR Address Formats in R12 Legal Entity Configurator (Doc ID 1104887.1)  end-to-end description of defining, choosing or modifying a style to meet local needs. Also describes creating a custom validation set against HZ_GEOGRAPHIES  so that the list of valid values  setting up an address is the same list used to validate it for tax purposes.
                Can you use the US Address Style in a Shared HR Environment? (Doc ID 1610796.1) recommends disabling the US style so that Oracle uses US_GLB instead (since the US style is intended for a full implementation of HR and a full load of the Vertex HR geography patch
                Can the US Address Style be Disabled? (Doc ID 1394466.1) also recommends disabling the US style if on Shared HRMS and not the full HRMS/Payroll system
                What is the Difference Between The Two Address Forms PERACADR (North American Address) and PERWSADR (Generic Address) (Doc ID 954512.1)  a somewhat related note describing the purpose of the two styles  US is for HR/Payroll.
                No Values In City/County LOV When Creating Legal Address In Legal Entity Manager (Doc ID 1259396.1)  recommends removing the validation sets on the US address style but continuing to use the US address style instead of disabling it.
        For HZ_LOCATIONS (applies to suppliers, customers, bank branches and freight carriers etc)
            DFF is 'Address' and seeded style (dff context) 'POSTAL_ADDR_US'
                'POSTAL_ADDR_US' is similar in design to 'US' on the HR_LOCATIONS_ALL table but without country
                    This is because Country is the context used to link the style in AR setups (Receivables > Setups > System > Countries > (Query for 'United States')
    Tip: Message 'Skipped GNR - transaction exists for this location' validating HZ_LOCATIONS can occur
        This is governed by AR System Option (not profile option) 'Allow change to printed transaction'
            If this option is set, the GNR error will be suppressed but changes will be allowed to printed transactions
    Tip: You must set up a default address style before defining validations for additional address styles
        The default style will be applied to validate addresses for any address style, or no style
            This handles the situation where multiple address styles exist (e.g. conversion vs. new data)
        Optionally add validations for additional address styles but this is only needed if the structures differ from the default styles.
        This ensures that validation can be performed on any address in a chosen geography
        It applies to each table: HZ_LOCATIONS and HR_LOCATIONS_ALL
        Reference: Oracle Trading Community Architecture Administration Guide (pp 11-11)
    Reference: Setting Up Geography Hierarchy And Address Validation In Release 12 [ID 554492.1]
    Reference: Trading Community Architecture Administration Guide
    Profile Options: HZ: Address Validation Level for Application
    Address Styles
        Validations can be set for multiple address styles
        Each validation definition acts independently
        Each customer or supplier address is validated based on the rules for the entered address style
    Geography Validation
        Geography Validation only applies to the HZ_LOCATIONS table so the Geography Validation Control is only visible for this table
        Geography Validation is used to validate addresses when they are entered into the application
        The Geography Validation checkbox at each geography level determines if the field is required for entry
        The Geography Validation Control box selects the type of validation that is applied in Geography Validation
            Error - full validation is performed and all mandatory fields must have values
                Invalid values in non-mandatory fields will throw errors when geo name referencing is run
                The field heading in 'Geography Mapping and Validations' is set to 'Geography Validation' to indicate which fields are validated
            Mandatory Fields Only - only fields checked as mandatory must be filled in and they can be invalid
                Mandatory fields are determined by which address attributes are checked for 'Mandatory'
                The field heading in 'Geography Mapping and Validations' changes to 'Mandatory' to indicate the mandatory address levels
            No Validation - all addresses are accepted whether valid or not
            Warning - invalid addresses are saved after a warning
            When you change the Geography Validation Control from 'Error' to 'Mandatory', the column heading for validation changes from 'Geography Validation' to 'Mandatory'
    Tax Validation
        Tax Validation is applied to transactions
        Only transactions with valid addresses for tax purposes will be considered in Tax Calcuations
        Each field marked as part of tax validation is considered valid on transactions for tax
    Geography Name Referencing Program
        Tip: AR System Profile 'Allow Changes to Printed Transactions' may cause 'Skipped GNR' messages in the log file
            This option locks addresses from update if there are transactions on the location and the line type is 'TAX' on the AR invoice line
        Geography validation is not case sensitive for attributes like County and City
        Run this program to validate addresses in HR_LOCATIONS_ALL or HZ_LOCATIONS
            Set the parameter 'Run Type' to 'All Records', previous 'Errors' or 'New' records never previously validated
            Set the parameter 'Address Usage' to 'Tax' or 'Geography' to choose the applicable validation configuration a validation address style
        Tables involved in the procees are
            HZ_GEO_NAME_REFERENCE_LOG - lists 'S' Success or 'E' Error in the MAP_STATUS field after each run
            HZ_GEO_NAME_REFERENCES
        This program only inserts values under the new concurrent request id if there is a change of status
            Query the table based on location_id to see the current status ('S' or 'E') and the concurrent request under which this was originally set
            If tax and geography are being validated, expect two lines with different USAGE_CODES (TAX or GEOGRAPHY)

Tax Engine (ZX Schema) Notes on Accounts Payable Tax Configuration
    Payables Invoice Categories that trigger a tax event include:
        Standard Invoices
            Standard
            Mixed
            PO Price Adjustment
            Credit Memo
            Debit Memo
        Prepayment Invoices
        Expense Reports
    Each invoice category maps to an event class in EBT
    Tax Drivers on the invoice trigger tax rules for these events
        If a tax driver value is updated the taxes must be recalculated/revalidated
    Invoice Header tax driver attributes include:
        Invoice Date
        Supplier Name
        Supplier Number
        Supplier Site Invoice
        Currency Related Invoice
        Taxation Country
        Credited Invoice (Quick Credit)
        Exchange Rate
        Exchange Rate Type
        Exchange Rate Date
        Invoice Sub-Type
    Invoice Line tax driver attributes include:
        Type
        Quantity Invoiced
        Unit of Measure
        Unit Price Amount
        PO Number
        PO Release Number
        PO Shipment Number
        Receipt Number
        Default Account
        Inventory Item
        Business Category
        Primary Intended Use
        Fiscal Classification
        Product Fiscal Classification
        Product Type (entered manually or derived from Purchase Basis on PO's and Req's)
        Product Category
        Ship-To
        Country of Supply
        Assessable Value
        Control Amount
    Tax Calculation on Invoice Entry
        E-Business tax calculates total taxes on an invoice as:
            Invoice Header Taxes
                Total Tax
                Self-Assessed Tax (Use Tax)
            Invoice Lines
                exclusive taxes - separate invoice lines
                inclusive taxes - tagged as 'tax included' on each non-tax line
                    can be viewed as distributions below the non-tax line level
    Product Type Driver Attribute (seeded: Goods, or Services)
        Set manually on the inovice line or derived from PO/Req Purchase Basis
            PO/Req Purchase Basis is assigned to each PO/Req Line Type and can be: Goods, or Services
        The Product Type can be modified in tax attributes on PO's and Req's
        Tax Rules can be built on Product Type
        One application is imports of goods or services from a supplier
            Product Type rules can be built to zero rate the goods import and self assess the services

Tax Engine (ZX Schema) Notes on Accounts Payable Invoice Import Tax Configuration
    References
        R12: How to turn off EBtax calculation for invoices imported through Payables Open Interface Import process? (Doc ID 843367.1)
        Case Study: How Payables Open Interface Import works with EB Tax for importing Invoices (Doc ID 1381400.1)
        How to avoid tax on imported invoices (Doc ID 1386491.1)
        Fusion: Quick Invoice Using Spread Sheet- How it Works (Doc ID 1347982.1)
        R12: Imported Lines Are Getting Tax Lines Created On Validation (Doc ID 889253.1)
    Import Flags
        CALC_TAX_DURING_IMPORT_FLAG - controls if taxes are calculated on imported payables invoices
        ADD_TAX_TO_INV_AMT_FLAG - controls adding the tax calculated by eBTaxto the invoice header during import
            If manual tax lines are inserted in the interface, then CALC_TAX_DURING_IMPORT_FLAG should be set to 'N'
                The ADD_TAX_TO_INV_AMT_FLAG should be set to 'Y' to add the manual tax line amount to the header amount
    WebADI Import Constraints
        WebADI sets the import flags by default to:
            AP_INVOICES_INTERFACE.CALC_TAX_DURING_IMPORT_FLAG - Y 
            AP_INVOICES_INTERFACE.ADD_TAX_TO_INV_AMT_FLAG - N
        This means the tax amount Oracle calculates must be known in advance for a balanced import.
        The workaround for this is to set the Tax Control Amount field (AP_INVOICES_INTERFACE.CONTROL_AMOUNT) to the amount of tax (difference between the line and header amounts

Tax Engine (ZX Schema) Notes on Configuration Owner Tax Options
    Option 'Perform Additional Applicability for Imported Invoices' creates self-assessed tax lines for the difference between taxes imported and taxes calculated
        Disable this option to avoid self-assessment
        References
            Tax Calculation Error-Self Assessed Tax (Doc ID 1434808.1)
            AP Invoice Interface Ignores Tax Lines (Doc ID 1331107.1)
            Tax Users Guide
                This option determines whether E-Business Tax runs the tax applicability process
                to identify missing taxes on an imported document. Taxes not included in the imported document 
                are marked as Self Assessed, if self-assessment applies to the transaction.

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Key Entities
    Classifications
    Legal Entities/Operating Units
    Party Tax Profiles - tax information for each party
    Tax Jurisdictions - a geographic area where a taxing authority levies a tax
    Tax Parties (Payables suppliers)
    Tax Records
    Tax Reporting Codes
    Tax Regimes - a set of laws and regulations that determine the treatment of a group of taxes
    Tax Registrations - the withholding registration status of all parties involved in taxable transactions
        Includes the internal legal entities and external third parties
    Tax Status - the taxable status or nature of the transaction
        There is a separate status if the nature of the tax is different
        The default is typically 'Standard' status with override rules for other statuses
        Separate Tax Statuses are not required if the rate varies based on place of supply
    Tax Rates - the date-effective calculation rates for a tax
        Different tax rates are required over time, for separate reporting and for different place of supply
            Different Tax Rates should not be used if the nature of the taxable transaction is different
            This should be done via Tax Status - otherwise all the override rules for rate need to be copied if the tax policy changes
        A percentage applied to value, a rate per unit, or a fixed amount
    Tax Rules (multiple)
    Tax Zones
    Tax Classifications for Product and Services
    Transaction Classifications
    Default Values
    Third Party Tax Services and Vendors

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Lookup Values
    Lookups are maintained via AOL
        Navigation: Application Developer -> Application -> Lookups -> Application Object Library
    Reference: Metalink Note: 466578.1 Tax Lookup Codes
    Lookups include:
        ZX_INPUT_CLASSIFICATIONS - used to migrate AP/PO tax codes from R11 (additional values can be added)
        ZX_OUTPUT_CLASSIFICATIONS - used to migrate AR (and GL) tax codes from R11 (additional values can be added)
        ZX_EXEMPTION_REASON_CODE - used to track the reason for an exemption, or the status of processing one
        ZX_REGISTRATION_REASON - used for tax reporting to show why a tax registration was given
        ZX_REGISTRATION_TYPE - used to classify tax registrations for reporting. Includes several seeded values
        ZX_REGISTRATION_STATUS - include seeded values: Agent, Registered, Not Registered - can be used in tax determination
        ZX_TAX_TYPE_CATEGORY - contains seeded values including: EXCISE, SALES, VAT, CUSTOMS, ENVIRONMENTAL
        ZX_WEB_EXP_TAX_CLASSIFICATIONS - internet expense related transactions
        ZX_JEBE_VAT_TRANS_TYPE - tax transaction types
    Hiding and Showing Tax Classifications
        You can end-date and disable classifications to remove them from lists of values
        Simply disabling may not hide the values so also end-date (test this)

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Tax Inclusive Processing
    Taxes are not inclusive in the US for Sales Tax (i.e. they are charged as separate line items)
        For Excise taxes, the tax is inclusive and not separately charged.
    Tax inclusive handling is set at several levels in the model:
        1. Regime level
        2. Tax level
        3. Tax rate level (on rate details)
        4. Party level 1 - First Party Legal Entity
        5. Party level 2 - First Party Legal Establishment (within Tax Registration)
        6. Party level 3 - supplier/third party
        7. Party Site level - supplier site/third party site

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Accounts
    Reference: Oracle E-Business Tax Users Guide - Setting Up Tax Accounts
    Default Tax accounts can be set at the Tax Authority Registration level, Tax level, Tax Rate level and Jurisdiction level
    Overrides to defaults for project accounting or other needs are implemented in Sub Ledger Rules - not in the old 11i account generator workflows
    Accounts defined at the tax level default to the tax rate level and can be over-ridden at the tax rate level
        The primary account is the tax liability account, labeled 'Tax Recoverable/Liability'
            This is the main liability account where owed taxes are accrued for later payment
    General Tax accounts include:
        1. Tax Expense (not required)
        2. Interim Tax (not required)
        3. Tax Recoverable/Liability (required)
    There are additional accounts specific to AR

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Tax Distributions
    Tax distributions are created when you click on All Distributions or upon invoice validation
 
Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Recoverable Tax and Tax Recovery Rate Override
    Tax recovery rates on recoverable tax cannot be overridden on payables invoices until they are generated and saved by viewing All Distributions. 
        Generating and saving via All Distributions makes them accessible for override via drill-down from line distributions. 

Tax Engines (ZX) Schema Notes on Self Assessment
    Additional References
        ebTax User Guide: Setting up Parties for Self Assessment
        ebTax User Guide R12: Managing Tax Profiles and Registrations
        How to Configure a Tax to Self-Assess in R12 E-Business Tax (EBTax), Payables and Purchasing (Offset, Use Tax) [ID 948414.1]
        Self Assessed Tax Goes To AP Accrual Account Not PO Charge Account When Accrue on Receipt Is Yes [ID 1094713.1]
        Cannot Validate Self-Assessed Invoice [ID 605345.1]
    Basic Procedure (applies only to AP transactions - not purchasing or receivables which are unaffected by these setting)
        Default the Registration Rule to 'Bill From' - all taxes will not self assess
        Establish 'Not Registered' registrations for unregistered suppliers
        Enable the internal Legal Establishment for Self Assessment and Create a Registration to the Regime
        Create an overrding registration rule pointing to 'Bill To' is the supplier is unregistered
            Registrations must be jurisdiction-specific
    Basic Reverse Procedure (applies only to AP transactions - not purchasing or receivables)
        Default the Registration Rule to 'Bill To' (or 'Ship To/Bill To)
        Establish 'Registered' registrations for registered suppliers
        Enable the internal Legal Establishment for Self Assessment and create a Registration to the Regime
        Create an overriding registration rule pointing to 'Bill From' if the supplier is registered
            Registrations must be jurisdiction-specific
    Keep in mind
        Self assessment won't work if the Legal Establishment is not enabled for self assessment and has no registration to the regime
        Supplier registrations are not needed for suppliers to prevent self-assessment
            Self Assessment is driven by the registration rule looking to the Legal Establishment which is registered to the regime and enabled for self-assessment
            Taxes will calculate as non-self-assessed on suppliers with no registration records but there will be no registration number on the tax line record
        If the legal establishment is not registered to the regime the tax will not self assess regardless of other settings
    How it Works
        Self-Assessment only applies to purchases and not to sales so the configuration is purchasing/payables specific
        Oracle uses these things to determine self-assessment
            The 'Existance' of tax registration records on legal establishments (self-assessment will not set if there is no valid registration for the regime)
            The 'Set for Self Assessment/Reverse Charge' flag must be set on the First Party Legal Establishment
                This setting can be on the legal entity, legal establishment or individual registrations for each regime within the establishment
                The individual regime registration settings of this flag drive processsing - the other levels are defaults
            A default tax rule (registration type) or override rule that sets the registration party as the ship-to (e.g. if the supplier is not registered)
        The Self-Assessment flag must be enabled on the Legal Establishment Tax Profile and child registrations
            Note this flag can be set on the legal entity, legal establishment and individual tax registration records
                It needs to be enabled on the legal establishment tax registration record - other levels are default
        A registration record does not have to exist on the supplier to calculate tax
        The purpose of a supplier registration is to track their registration number info and to support a rule to point back to the Legal Establishment for self assessment
        However a registration record and corresponding registration rule are needed to override the default and point to the internal establishment
            Eg. Default Registration rule 'Bill From' - tax will calculate as not self assessed
                No supplier registrations unless the supplier is specifically 'not registered'
                For suppliers specifically 'not registered' a registration record and rule based on the record to point to the establishment as the registered party
            It doesn't matter how the Tax Registration Status value is set within the registration record (Registered, Not Registered, Agent, or Custom)
                What matters is the 'existance' of the registration record and the effective date range of the registration record
                The flag 'Set for Self Assessment/Reverse Charge' enables or disables self-assessment on the party pointed to by the tax rule
                    If the tax registration rule points to the supplier and the supplier has no registration but the supplier has the Self Assessment/Reverse Charge Flag set, it will self-assess
                    If the tax registration rule points to the first party legal establishment and the Self Assessment/Reverse Charge Flag is set, it will self-assess
    You enable self assessment by the check box 'Set for Self Assessment/Reverse Charge' on the First Party Legal Establishment Tax Profile
        You can enable self assessment at different levels based on the setup of the Registration Record
            You can limit the registration record to a Tax or Tax Jurisdiction Level
            Registration settings at lower levels override settings at higher levels
    There is a self-assessment flag on the Supplier also, at the Supplier level
        The Self-Assess flag at the supplier level is not needed to enable self-assessment
        If this is set then the transaction will be set to self-assessment if the rule is defined to use the supplier registration and not the first party
    Enable self assessment with the 'Set for Self Assessment/Reverse Charge' option by updating the First Party Legal Entity and Establishment Records
        Do this on the Party Tax Profile for the internal Legal Entity, Legal Establishment or Operating Unit (if the Operating Unit is subscribed to the regime directly)
        Navigation: Tax Manager/Party Tax Profiles/<Choose Legal Entity>/Create Tax Profile
    Each supplier has a flag at the supplier level 'Set for Self Assessment/Reverse Charge' which must be enabled
        If this option is not set, you cannot manually force self-assessment on the Tax Details of a transaction
        You can set the flag for it, but it won't save this way and will recalculate with tax on the invoice

Tax Engine (ZX) Schema Notes on Configuring Supplier Tax Profiles
    Supplier tax profiles are maintained in the Tax Engine and not in Payable
        Navigation: Tax Manager/Party Tax Profiles/<Choose Third Party or Site>/Create Tax Profile
        Options exist at the supplier level and the supplier registration level
        Supplier level Options include:
            Allow Tax Applicability - to automatically calculate taxes for this supplier
            Allow Offset Taxes - if offsets are used
            Default Tax Classification
            Rounding Level
            Set Invoice Values as Tax Inclusive - if taxes are included in line amounts
        Registration Level options include:
            Supplier
            Supplier Registration

Tax Engine (ZX) Schema Notes on Fiscal Classifications
    Reference: E-Business Tax User Guide
    Several fiscal classifications can be optionally defined as country-specific
        This limits their availability on transactions to matching 'Taxation Countries' on the transaction
    Fiscal Classifications include three 'types'
        Party Fiscal Classifications - such as special vendor classifications (e.g. not for profit)
        Product Fiscal Classifications - based on inventory item groups
        Product Categories - based on non-inventory classifications
        Intended Use Fiscal Classifications
        Business Categories
        Transaction Fiscal Classifications - for example a give-away or disposal sale - these are assigned to Business Categories
        User Defined Transaction Fiscal Classifications
    They are assigned at run-time to determine if tax rules apply
    Fiscal classifications are optional on transactions
    Party Fiscal Classifications - assigned to suppliers and their tax registrations
        Fiscal Classifications are assigned to Regimes and Countries
        Party Fiscal Classifications group parties into different tax status groups
        TCA Groups are used to set party fiscal classifications for tax handling purposes
        Examples are: Distributer, Consumer, Not for Profit
        Party Fiscal Classifications can be used to apply different tax treatment to suppliers or customers
    Product Fiscal Classifications are inventory based product classifications
        They are based on An Oracle Inventory Category Set
        The product fiscal classification is defaulted on the line based on the inventory item
        If no item is entered they can be recorded manually in the Product Fiscal Classification field
    Product Category (non-inventory based)
        These values must be entered on the transaction line (invoice or purchase order) in the Product Category field
        They can be multi-segment or single segment - fixed at implementation time
        They are created by adding to the existing seeded categories in: Tax Managers > Products > Product Classifications > Product Category > (add subcomponents)
    Intended Use (for inventory and non-inventory)
        Intended Use is tied to the inventory category or non-inventory category
        This assignment is set at implementation time and cannot be changed
        Intended use applies where the same item is taxed differently based on use
        An example is off-road/on-road dieses
        Another example is project management as intangible or tangible (constructing an asset)
        They are created in: Tax Managers > Products > Intended Use Classifications
    Business Categories are seeded values and include the following values:
            Expense Report
            Purchase Pre-Payment
            Purchase
            Sale
            Sales Adjustment
            Intercompany
        References:
            How To Setup and Troubleshoot a Tax Rule using Transaction Business Categories and Transaction Fiscal Classifications in R12 E-Business Tax (EBTax) (Doc ID 1114923.1)
        Custom business categories are only created as children of the seeded categories (new ones can't be created at the seeded level)
            Once created, they can be associated to Transaction Fiscal Classifications for use in tax rules
                They can be assigned to transactions at the header and line levels in the 'Business Category' field
                The value in the Business Category Field show the full hierarchical path for each value
                If Business Categories are defined as country-specific they will not appear in transaction lists of values if the transaction Taxation Country does not match
            See: How To Setup and Troubleshoot a Tax Rule using Transaction Business Categories and Transaction Fiscal Classifications in R12 E-Business Tax (EBTax) [ID 1114923.1]
        Business Categories are entered on AP invoices in the Business Category field at the header and line level
            You choose the complete path for the busines category in this field
            Only business categories set up with no country assignment or matching the 'Taxation Country' on the invoice header will appear in the list of values
    Transaction Fiscal Classification Codes
        References
            How To Setup and Troubleshoot a Tax Rule using Transaction Business Categories and Transaction Fiscal Classifications in R12 E-Business Tax (EBTax) (Doc ID 1114923.1)
        These are not the same as User Defined Fiscal Classification Codes - see below
        These values are defined and assigned to Business Categories (as subclassifications) and not entered on transactions directly
        Hierarchies are supported with multiple segment values
        You can define a Transaction Fiscal Classification and assign it to multiple Business Categories
            This allows a single rule which applies to multiple Business Categories
    Document Fiscal Classifications
        Document Fiscal Classifications are intended to classify transactions according to special tax documentation that must accompany transactions (e.g. export approvals)
        They are entered on the Document Sub Type field on PO's (in the Additional Tax Information page and on the AP Invoice on the invoice header as 'Invoice Subtype'
            The value on the PO does not default to the invoice because it is stored on the shipment level on PO's (in ZX.ZX_LINES_DET_FACTORS) and on the invoice header
        They are created in Tax Managers > Transactions > Document Classifications > New (under DOCUMENT_SUBTYPE)
        Question: where is this value entered on the transaction?
    User Defined Fiscal Classification Codes
        References
            How Can Users Be Allowed To Choose A Tax Classification That Applies A Different Rate? (Doc ID 1050423.1)
        These are not the same as Transaction Fiscal Classification Codes - see above
        These are created via Tax Manager > Transactions > User Defined Transaction Classifications
        They are entered on transactions at the header and line level in the 'Fiscal Classification' field (e.g. on AP Invoices)
        They are independent of Business Categories and Transaction Fiscal Classifications

Tax Engine (ZX) Schema Notes on Tax Registrations
    Reference: Setting Up a Tax Registration, Tax Users Guide pp 3-10
    Tax Registrations are assigned to first and third party tax profiles
    They define a parties obligation to pay taxes to a taxing authority (Nexus)
    Tax registrations are also used in tax reporting
        Navigation: Tax Manager/Party Tax Profiles/<Choose Third Party or Site>/Create Tax Registration
    Each tax registration on a party or party site is tagged with multiple attributes
        A tax regime
        A tax jurisdiction for the tax registration
        A tax for the tax registration indicating which tax (i.e. tax type) it applies to
        The supplier's 'Company Reporting Name'
        Tax Registration Type - is used for reporting purposes
            There are seeded values for Argentina only and are used to validate tax number
            Tax registration types define how the tax registration number is built and validated
        Tax Registration Number - assigned to the supplier by the tax authority
            The Tax Registration Number can be validated if it is based on build rules and types
        Legal Registration Address of the supplier
        Registration Status: Agent, Registered, Not Registered
            Registration Status is used as a determining factor in tax rules
        Explicit or Implicit Registration -
            An explicit registration is an officially issued registration
            An implicit registration deems a suppiler to be registered based on their level of business
        Tax Authority issuing the registration
        Registration Reason - used to further define implicit registrations
        Effective Dates
        Invoice Controls - these default from the party level and can be overridden here
        Bank Accounts of the registration for the supplier (if required on reports)
        Reporting and Collecting Tax Authorities
             These default from the jurisdiction but can be over-ridden here

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Tax Registration Processing
    Reference: EBusiness Tax User Guide R12 - p 6-10 Determine Tax Registration
    Registrations determine the registration number, dates and details applicable to a party
        They also drive self assessment, inclusive tax and tax rounding processing
    A registration is required for the first party legal entity
    A registration is optional for the third party entity (at the entity or site level)
    Tax registrations can be set as the default value on the registration attached to first party establishments
    They can also be set on suppliers and customers
    Two tax registrations are stamped onto each tax transaction
        1. The first party registration of the first party legal entity
        2. The tax registration derived from the 'Determine Tax Registration' rule
    The registration derived from the tax rule is used to drive tax reporting and handling
        It uses the information from the tax registration derived from the tax rule for the following attributes:
            1. Tax Inclusive Handling
            2. Self Assessment/Reverse Charge/Use Tax
            3. Tax amount rounding
    Tax rules drive the tax registration that is used to report tax on a transaction
        In the US SUTA regime, registrations should first check the supplier
        If the supplier is not registered than the first party establishment registration should be used (US SUTA only)
    When registrations are attached to parties, they can be attached with multiple optional attributes
        1. Regime
        2. Tax
        3. Jurisdiction
        If attached with these attributes, the registration is identifed first at the jurisdiction level, next at the tax level and lastly at the regime level
        If a registration is applied at the regime level it applies to all taxes and jurisdictions

Direct Payment Permits and Registrations (for self-assessment of taxes e.g. in texas)
    References
        http://www.revenue.state.il.us/businesses/DirectPay.htm
        http://salestaxguy.blogspot.com/2006/01/direct-pay-certificates.html
    In the US, businesses over a certain size can register for Direct Payment
    Direct Payment allows them to self-assess all their taxes


Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Purchasing Integration
    References
        Purchasing User Guide 12.0 pp 4-115 Tax Information in Purchasing
        How Does the AP-PO Integration Works From EBTAX Perspective [ID 1372895.1]
        How To Diagnose E-Business Tax Issues In Procurement [ID 728906.1]
        E-Business Tax For Oracle Purchasing [ID 464243.1]
    Taxes for Different Purchase Order Types
        Taxes are calculated on requisitions and standard purchase orders
        They are not calculated on Blanket Purchase Orders but they are calculated on Releases
            You cannot configure a Blanket Purchase Order for tax (there is no ship-to information)
    Tax information defaults onto PO's, Requisitions and Releases if eBTax is setup
        Taxes normally apply at the shipment level of a purchase order or release and the line level of a requisition
    You can view tax on purchase orders and requisitions or releases window once the PO or Requisition is saved
        This can also be done at the lines and distributions windows
        Navigation: Tools (or Actions) -> Manage Taxes
        A requisition or PO must be saved before tax calculation is fired
    You can view tax on iProcurement requisitions in the final step (Review and Submit) of requistion creation
        Open the details of the requisition and click on the Tax Details option
    You can change the tax on a purchase order shipment line via the Forms PO maintenance screen
        Navigation: Tools (or Actions) -> Manage Taxes > Tax > Additonal Tax Information > (Update and apply)
            Updates are made only in the 'Additional Tax Information' window
        The profile option: "eBTax: Allow Override of Tax Classification Code" must be enabled
        Taxes are calculated on requisition lines and po shipment level lines
        Changes to tax driving attributes on a PO recalculate tax when the PO is saved
            If the PO is incomplete you have to complete the PO and submit for approval to see the new tax
            Taxes are always calculated when a PO is submitted for approval
    You can override the recoverable vs. non-recoverable amount on a purchase order in the 'Recovery Rate' field on PO Distribution lines
        This field and all other tax-related fields are frozen if receipts have been recorded against the purchase order
    PO Taxes are applied to the invoice when it is matched to the PO
        If the option 'Enforce Tax from Reference Document' is enabled on Configuration Tax Options (for the Payables > Standard Invoice subscription)
            References
                What is the Meaning of the Enforce Tax From Reference Object Flag in AP? (Doc ID 1510891.1)
            The tax status and tax rate on the PO is placed on the Invoice and any changes are accounted as a second tax variance line
            Variances can be
                TERV - Tax Exchange Rate Variance
                TIPV - Tax Invoice Price Tax Rate Variance
                TRV - Tax Rate Variance
                TQV - Tax Quantity Variance (shown as a non-variance distribution)

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Payables Integration
    Reference: Payables User Guide 12.0 pp 3-182 Taxes on Invoices
    When you enter an invoice and click 'Calculate Taxes' in Payables, eBTax is invoked to calculate taxes
        The total tax is updated on the invoice header
        If the tax is self assessed, it appears on the 'Self Assessed Tax Amount' field on the invoice header
            This field is for reference only - it does not modify the amount due from the supplier
            Self assessed tax distributions are not visible through the invoice - only distributions that are part of the invoice amount are viewable
            If you update a tax line to be self assessed, it is included in the self assessed total and removed from distributions
            To report on self-assessed taxes, use the following Subledger Accounting reports:
                Account Analysis Report, Subledger Accounting Implementation Guide
                Open Account Balanced Listing, Oracle Subledger Accounting Implementation Guide
    Taxes that are not inclusive are generated as separate lines on the invoice (exclusive lines)
            The tax amounts are shown as a summarized line with separate distribution lines for each tax
        Inclusive taxes are generated as amounts in the inclusive tax amount field on the existing invoice line
    Taxes are recalculated during invoice validation and put on hold if tax related issues are found
    'Tax Only' lines are tax lines not related to any other line on the invoice
        They may be the only line on the invoice - created to process a tax transaction on its own.
    Manual tax lines can be entered on an invoice
    The tax engine does not provide tax services for withholding taxes or 1099 reporting
    Supplier tax profiles are maintained in the Tax Engine and not in Payable
        Navigation: Tax Manager/Party Tax Profiles/<Choose Third Party or Site>/Create Tax Profile
        Options exist at the supplier level and the supplier registration level
        Supplier level Options include:
            Allow Tax Applicability - to automatically calculate taxes for this supplier

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Order Management Integration
    References

    Key Tables
        OE_PRICE_ADJUSTMENTS - stores the tax lines for an order (they are not stored in ZX_LINES for orders)
        OE_ORDER_LINES_ALL - stores a running total of the tax amounts in the TAX_VALUE field
    Tax lines displayed in orders shows values from OE_PRICE_ADJUSTMENTS
    Tax amounts in the order header are grouped on the fly by the form from the TAX_VALUE field on OE_ORDER_LINES_ALL

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Offset Taxes
    Reference: 1312671.1 Offset Tax Codes Also Display in Tax Classification LOV
    Reference: 1104163.1 Oracle E-Business Suite 12.1 Financeials Pre-Upgrade, Setup, and Operational Tips (includes Offset Tax introduction)
    Reference: http://www.orastudy.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/OracleEBusinessSuiteR12.1FinancialsPreUpgradeSetupandOperationalTips.pdf
    Offset Taxes are used to undo taxes charged on supplier invoices and accrue them as self assessed taxes
        They differ from self assessed taxes (use taxes) because the create journal entries to transfer the taxes to an accrual account from the supplier tax journal
           Use taxes replace the original supplier tax charge rather than creating a second tax line
    With an offset tax, the original supplier tax is recorded from the invoice to reconcile to the invoice header
        A second negative amount offset tax is added automatically by Oracle and charged to an offset tax
    Offset Taxes will only calculate if the supplier is enabled for Offset Taxes in their Tax Profile
    Offset Taxes must also be enabled on the event class subscription and on the tax definition

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Tax Rules
    Tax rules have defaults and specific rules - the rules are tested first and the defaults applied last
    Rules are specific to a regime and tax - they must be repeated for every additional regime and tax
    Certain tax rule types or defaults are required (e.g. Determine Place of Supply)
    Tax rules have several different types that are evaluated in a specific order:
    1. Determine Place of Supply - where the goods transfered from seller to buyer for tax purposes (point of delivery or 'use' in the US)
    2. Determine Tax Applicability - determines if the tax under which this rule is written in applicable
    3. Determine Tax Registration - determines which tax registration will be used on the transaction (e.g. the supplier's?)
    4. Determine Taxable Basis - the underlying value or measure upon which the tax will be calculated
    5. Determine Tax Status - requird before determining tax rates since tax rate rules are specific to a single status
    6. Determine Tax Rate - each tax rate rule is specific to a tax and tax status determined earlier

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Formulas
    Formulas are used in a number of places including tax rules (e.g. STANDARD_TB is the rule for taxable basis)
    There are seeded formulas and user-defined formulas are allows
    Navigation: Tax Manager -> Advanced Setup Options -> Tax Formulas
    Change the tax basis using a formula and base rate modified
        Reference: Tax User Guide and search on 'Base Rate Modifier'
        Create a formula with type 'Taxable Basis' and basis type 'Line Amount' and enter a percentage base rate modifier
            e.g. -10 will reduce the taxable basis by 10%, +10 will increase the tax basis by 10%

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes Determining Factor Sets and Condition Sets
    Navigation: Tax Manager -> Advanced Setup Options -> Determining Factor Sets
    Determining factor sets are collections of factors used in rules and assigned a single (group) name
    Determining condition sets are specific to factor sets and have values for the determining factors
        It is not possible to use a condition set on a determining factor set other than the set to which is was originally defined
    A combination of a determining factor set and condition set represents a complete rule which can point to a result (tax rate)
    Only one determining factor set can be used on a single tax rule
        If more than one determining factor set is required on tax rules, additional rules should be defined

Tax Engine (eTax ZX Schema) Notes on Extensible Tax Rules

    Overview
        Try using 'Allow Extensible Tax Rules' feature in eBTax in COTO's


Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Tax Migration from 11i to R12
    Migration uses the Direct Tax Determination Method and the STCC (Standard Tax Classification Codes) in an upgrade
        Each Tax Code is migrated as a Tax Classification in R12
    One Tax Rule (type 'Direct Tax Determination Method) is created for each Tax Group in 11i
        If no Tax Groups are defined in 11i then no rules are created and they have to be built manually
    The Determining Factor Set is created as STCC (Standard Tax Classification Codes)
        One Condition Set is created with a condition for each Tax Classification
    A regime determination set "Standard Tax Classification Codes" is attached to each Event Subscription in Configuration Owner Tax Options
        If STCC is not to be used but the full tax model is to be used, the Regime Determination Set is set to 'Determine Applicable Regime'
    One new tax is created for every unique tax code in 11i (if multiple date effective records exist only one new tax is created)
        A new tax rate is created for every date-effective record in 11i
        If a tax code in 11i is end-dated and only one value exists, it is created as a single tax code with one date effective rate (end-dated)
    R12 Tax Names are converted from 11i Tax Names by removing the numbers and special characters and adding the Tax Type as a suffix
    R12 Tax Rates are created in R12 from the 11i Tax Name without any changes
    Tax Classification Codes on the Supplier Site in 11i are migrated to Tax Classification Codes on Party Tax Profiles for Third Party Sites in ebTax
        They are no longer maintained via the Supplier Site Maintenance page
    In a standard upgrade the flag 'Allow Tax Override' is not set by default (potentially) so you don't get a list of values in Tax Rate for manual entry

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes Tax Exceptions and Tax Exemptions
    References 
        How to Setup Tax on Freight in R12 E-Business Tax (EBTax) Order to Cash [ID 764297.1]
        Which one is more advantageous to setup, rules or tax exceptions to indicate that certain products (or prod. classifications) have a tax exception? (Doc ID 422689.1)
    Exemptions are party specific and exceptions are product specific
        Exemptions are for parties and allow you to exempt parties from tax on all transactions
            Exemptions require exemption certificates issued by the government authorities
            Exemptions must be defined at the party-specific owner level and not the global level - per regime subscription options
            Exemptions can be specific to an item and inventory organization or global for all items
            Exemptions setup at site level only apply to ship-to addresses on customers
                Exemptions setup at party/customer level apply to bill-to addresses
            Exemption Status of 'manual' requires the exemption to be entered on the transaction with a matching exemption reason
            Exemption Status of 'Primary' automatically applies to the transaction
            Navigation: Tax Manager > Parties > Party Tax Profiles > Third Party > Exemptions
        Exceptions allow you to setup a specific tax for a product and this rate applies globally
            They are setup on items and product fiscal classifications
            Use product tax exceptions for special rates based on product fiscal classifications rather than defining a Determine Tax Rate rule based on product fiscal classifications.
                For example, if three out of five product fiscal classifications use a special rate, define three product tax exceptions based on the three product fiscal classifications that need a special rate, and set the standard rate as the default rate. 
        References
            Bill To Site Tax Exemption Not Working (Doc ID 749684.1)
            R12: How to Setup Tax Exemption in Ebusiness Tax for Suppliers. [ID 602863.1]
            http://www.salestaxsupport.com/sales-tax-information/states-sales-tax-by-state/CA-California/sales-tax-exemption-certificate
            How To Setup a Tax Exemption for Customers in R12 E-Business Tax [ID 1389965.1]
            Using and Troubleshooting Tax Exemptions in R 12 E-Business Tax (EBTax) [ID 750064.1] -- detailed usage and troubleshooting on tax exemptions
            Oracle E-Business Tax User Guide Release 12.1 Part Number E13631-03 - Setting Up Tax Exemptions
            NOTE:738338.1 - R12: How to Set Up County or City Tax to Use the State Exemption in E-Business Tax (EBTAX)
            Using and Troubleshooting Tax Exemptions in R 12 E-Business Tax (EBTax) (Doc ID 750064.1)
        Exemptions can be setup for specific customers via Party Tax Maintenance
            They do not apply to suppliers
            Navigation: Parties > Party Tax Profiles > Update Party Tax Profiles >
        The event class subscription must be set to allow exemptions otherwise they will not apply
        The configuration owner on any exemption must be a specific operating unit or legal entity - it cannot be owned by the global configuration owner
            Exemptions cannot be shared across legal entities because they are issued to legal entities specifically
        Exemptions can also be setup as zero rates under alternative tax statuses
        For US SUTA, charitable organizations and law firms are not exempt from tax but their services are exempt
            This applies to an exempt tax status rather than a customer based exemption
        Attachment functionality is not enabled for exemptions (e.g. inline attachments to store registration scanned documents)
    Exceptions in Items and Categories
        Exceptions allow discounts or overrides on existing tax rates but they do not support choosing a different tax rate name
        References
            User Guide 6-20 -- Product Tax Exceptions.
        Troubleshooting
            Make sure the configuration owner is correctly set on exceptions (global configuration owner does not work if a legal entity or operating unit is the owner)
        Exceptions can be entered for a 
            tax, tax and status, tax and status and rate
            country or single jurisdiction
            item and inventory organization, or fiscal category or item category

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Application Tax Options
    Reference: E-Business Tax User Guide 2-41 'Using Application Tax Options'
    Application Tax Options are used to migrate legacy tax codes from 11i
    They set the precedence rules previously available in 11i for stamping a tax code on a transaction line
    They should not be setup in 12i unless the instance is an upgrade and the new features of 12i will not be used
    Tax rules are still required to drive tax handling based on the legacy tax codes if this feature is used.
    Disabling migrated hierarchy rules is permanent.

    Vertex O Series
        Versions
            Series 6
        References
            http://www.vertexinc.com/training/course-descriptions/vertex-indirect-tax-o-series-north-america-consumer-use-tax -- Vertex training agenda and tax assist rules
        Background
            Vertex remains privately owned and offers the Q-Series and O-Series applications.
            Vertex ORAMAST is a jurisdiction and rate load file into Oracle
                It does not handle capped taxes in Tennessee and Florida (max taxes)
                It does handle sellers use tax in Missouri (rate for interstate supplies is lower than in-state supplies)
            Both O and Q do the same thing but Q is older, simpler to implement and does not have rates for special districts
                Q is built on zip code level detail
                O is built on geocode level detail and handles special jurisdictions
            There is no automated upgrade patch from Q to O - the underlying architectures are different
            Vertex have sales tax, consumer use tax (use tax in-state) and seller use tax (use tax across state lines)
                There are some rate differences between sales, use and seller use tax due to out of state taxing rules (e.g. local taxes are excluded)
            O Series has many issues
                References
                    http://scn.sap.com/people/subra.manian2/blog/2011/09/19/vertex-q-series
        Overview
            Approach
                Everything is taxable unless otherwise exempted
            Taxability Categories
                Mapped from Oracle Attributes: GL Account, Expenditure Type, Item, Item Cateogory
            Taxability Drivers
                Taxability drivers are attributes of transactions (GL Expense Accounts, Cost Centers, Purchasing Categories, Expenditure Types)
                Source drivers (from EBS) map to Taxability Codes (a normalized list of taxability codes in Vertex)
                Taxability Codes are mapped to Taxability Category ID's (internal Vertex codes maintained by Vertex)
                Taxability Category ID's map to geographies for the correct tax rate
                Taxability Categories and geographies are maintained by Vertex
                Taxability Drivers and Taxability Codes are maintained by Oracle users
            Tax Assist
                Data Transformation and Mapping
                Hierarchy for each transaction type of taxability rules to apply
                Comprises
                    Precalculation - modifies data before tax rules are applied
                        Examples (set values for Purchase, PurchaseClass, Usage, UsageClass, EntityName, GeneralLedgerAccount, Division)
                        IF ((FLEX.input.MINOR=) AND (FLEX.input.SOURCE=)) AND (LOOKUP ( PO_GL_Exempt, generalLedgerAccount) = Y) SET purchase  TO "Y" -- no item category and account is exempt, so exempt
                        IF (FLEX.input.PO_NUM=) AND (LOOKUP ( GL_ExpenseExempt , generalLedgerAccount) = Y) SET purchase TO Y -- no PO number and account is exempt so exempt
                        IF (projectNumber=) AND (FLEX.input.PO_NUM=) SET purchase.purchaseClass TO generalledgerAccount -- not a project or purchase order so use account rule
                        IF (FLEX.input.MINOR<>) AND (FLEX.input.SOURCE<>) SET purchase.purchaseClass TO LOOKUP (Source_to_GL, FLEX.input.MINOR, FLEX.input.SOURCE) -- item category so use category exemptions
                        IF (projectNumber<>) AND (LOOKUP ( Exempt_Expenditure_Type , FLEX.input.EXPND_TYPE) = Y) SET purchase TO Y -- project with exempt expenditure type
                        IF (projectNumber<>) AND (FLEX.input.EXPND_TYPE<>) SET purchase TO LOOKUP (EXPENDITURE_MAPPINGS , FLEX.input.EXPND_TYPE) -- set expenditure type
                        IF costCenter<> SET usage TO LOOKUP (CostCenter_To_Usage, costCenter) -- non-null cost center to map cost center to usage
                        IF FLEX.input.LEGAL_ENT<> null SET FLEX.input.EntityName TO LOOKUP (Legal Entity Name Lookup, FLEX.input.LEGAL_ENT) -- set legal entity
                        IF (project.NUM<>) AND (FLEX.input.EXPND_TYPE<>) SET usage TO p -- set usage to Project
                        IF (projectNumber <>) AND (FLEX.input.EXPND_TYPE<>) SET generalLedgerAccount TO  LOOKUP ( EXPENDITURE_MAPPINGS , FLEX.input.EXPND_TYPE) -- map GL account for project
                        IF FLEX.input.LEGAL_ENT<> null SET buyer.division TO FLEX.input.LEGAL_ENT
                        IF buyer.division = 1100 SET buyer.division TO 1101
                    Postcalculation - modifies data before results of tax rules are returned to oracle
                    Lookup Tables - used by precalculation and postcalculation rules to map data
            Transaction Tester
                Sample transaction tester
                Tax Journal posting for non-tax eligible transactions
            Tax Journal

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Streamlined Tax Reporting (US)
    References
        http://www.salestaxsupport.com/sales-tax-information/SSTP-Introduction-Help-Guide.php
        http://www.salestaxsupport.com/sales-tax-information/Streamlined-SSTP/States-and-Sourcing-Rules.php
    Background
        Streamlined Sales Tax (SST) is a common method of registering to report sales tax collection
    Members
        There are 22 Full Member States
            Arkansas, Georgia, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, Nebraska, Nevada,
            New Jersey, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Utah, 
            Vermont, West Virginia, Washington, Wisconsin and Wyoming. 
        The 2 Associate Member States are:
            Ohio and Tennessee.

Tax Engine (ebTax ZX Schema) Notes on Tax Reporting
    References
        PATCH:9031051 - European Sales Listing Report - R12.1.1
        EMEA VAT: Oracle Financials Release 12 Setups for 2010 EU VAT Package - Solution based on Tax Rates (Doc ID 974979.1)
        NOTE:1107453.1 - EMEA VAT: Oracle Financials R12 Setups for 2010 EU VAT--Solution Based on Tax Rules
        Intra-EU Vat Audit Trail not Ordered By Country. (Doc ID 1359746.1)
        Intra EU Audit Trail Report Issues and Solutions (Doc ID 1485465.1) - for AP invoices that are intr-EU (requires configuration check)
        Tax Audit Trail Report, Intra-EU Audit Trail report Not Available in R12 (Doc ID 1262973.1) - lists old reports and their replacements
    Tax Reports in R12 are two types: Tax Reporting Ledger (TRL) Based and Non-TRL Based
    Tax Reporting Ledger (TRL-based) Reports
        Financial Tax Register (AR, AP, GL, RXi report, CSV output) - primary and central register of all tax transactions
    Non-Tax Reporting Ledger (non-TRL-based) Reports
        Tax Received Report (AR, XML Publisher Enabled) the amount of tax received for AR debit items for a GL date range with subtotals by geographic region.
        Tax Reconciliation Report (AR, XML Publisher Enabled) taxable and tax amounts for receivables transactions for a GL date range and liability account range.
        Tax Reconciliation by Taxable Account Report (AR, AP, XML Publisher Enabled) taxable transactions in payables, receivables and general ledger for VAT reporting
        Tax Register Report (AR, XML Publisher Enabled*) covers Accounts Receivable transactions and shows tax liabilities for current and deferred amounts
        Tax Audit Trail Report (ZXXTATAT, for AP, XML Publisher Enabled) tax distributions on posted and partially posted payables invoices
            Replaces Tax Audit Trail Report (APXTAVAR) from Payables in 11i
        Use Tax Liability Report (ZXXINUTR)
            Replaces Use Tax Liability report (APXINUTR) from Payables in 11i
        Tax-Only Open Invoices Report (AR, Text) receivables invoices where the tax amount is not paid but the items on the invoice are paid
        European Sales Listing (ESL) Report - R12.1.1 - requires patch 9031051 and extensive configuration per MOS Notes: 974979.1 and 1107453.1 - not a 'Standard' report - gives EU service sales invoices
        Intra EU Audit Trail Report (AP, XML Publisher enabled) - see Issues and Solutions (Doc ID 1485465.1) - for AP invoices that are intr-EU (requires configuration check)
            Replaces the Intra-EU Audit Trail report from Payables in 11i
        ECE Payables VAT Register (Eastern European Countries only - Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic only
        VAT Exception Report exceptions on receivables invoices including: item lines with no tax lines, item lines posted to tax accounts, tax discounts/adjustments charged to tax accounts, and adjustments of type Tax.
    Reports Not Registered to Run under Tax Manager Responsibility
        Payables Tax Report by Legal entity (ZXAPJAJL) - replaces 11i Intra-EU Audit Trail report (APXTAVAR)
        Payables Tax Report by Ledger/Operating Unit (ZXAPJAJL) - replaces 11i Tax Audit Trail report (APXTATAT)
            ZXAPJAJL - Payables Tax Report by Ledger/Operating Unit replaces APXTAVAR - Intra-EU Audit Trail report - cannot be run - not available to SRS and produces no output
        Instead, use ...
            Program : Tax audit trail report Short Name : ZXXTATAT
            Program : Intra EU audit trail report Short Name : ZXXTAVAR

The Use Tax Liability Report is ported from 11i but does not support R12 Tax reporting
        It only reports migrated Use Tax types from 11i
        There is no corresponding report available in R12 to report use tax liabilities at transaction level
    The Tax Register report covers AR transactions and is used to review tax liabilities
        Parameters allow a choice between current and deferred liabilities
    The Financial Tax Register Report shows the output of the Tax Reporting Ledger
    Both the Tax Register and Financial Tax Register populate the tax register view ZX_REP_EXTRACT_V
        The process 'Financial Tax Register' must be run to populate this view
    Financial Tax Register
        Components
            RX-Only: Financial Tax Register Report - this component generates the data
            Financial Tax Register - this component is submitted and subsequently formats returned data
        The Financial Tax Register covers GL, AP and AR transactions
        How the Tax Reporting Ledger works
            Job "Financial Tax Register" is submitted and calls "RX-Only: Financial Tax Register Report"
            Job "RX-Only: Financial Tax Register Report" selects data from the base tables and populates four temporary tables
            The Tax Reporting view ZX_REP_EXTRACT_V holds tax reporting data from GL/AP/PO for RXi based reports
            The view is populated from AP/PO from ZX_LINES via ZX_REP_TRX_DETAIL_T (a temp table)
            Intermediate tables populated prior to RXi output are:
                ZX_REP_CONTEXT_T
                ZX_REP_TRX_DETAIL_T
                ZX_REP_TRX_JX_EXT_T
                ZX_REP_ACTG_EXT_T
            These tables are not purged if FND DEBUG is enabled
            Query these tables for a specific request_id to see the lines applicable to the request
            It must be run with the Register Type: 'Tax Register' as the parameter set to see AP transactions
        Parameters
            Attribute Set
                TAXREG -  includes AR, AP and PO data but not discount amounts for AR and GL
                Default - contains all attributes from the extract view
                Use TAXREG for debugging initially since Default may not work
                Running the report with 'Default' as the parameter set will only show AR transactions
            Register Type:
                Tax Register - transactions from the Collected tax accounts
                    The Interim Tax option only reports taxes from receivables, not payables
                Interim Tax Register - transactions from the interim tax accounts
                Non-Recoverable - transactions from the non-recoverable tax accounts
        General Rules
            The following parameter values are required during report submission to display accounting information
                  Summary Level = Transaction Distribution
                  Include Accounting Segments = Yes
                  Accounting Status = Accounted or Both Accounted and Unaccounted
              See MOS Note 1305895.1 for supporting guidelines
        Troubleshooting
           Enable debug to freeze the contents of the temporary tables so results are not deleted
    Reporting is custom: XML Publisher, RXi (Assets) and Oracle Reports
        Standard templates are available for XML Publisher
            Tax Audit Trail Report
                This is a full listing of tax and invoice information
            Tax Received Report - AR only
            Tax Reconciliation Report - AR only
            Tax Reconciliation by Taxable Account Report (*) - includes AR and AP transactions
                This report also supports reconciliations at the posted account level
                It is XML template based for customization
            Tax Register
                Used to view tax liability
                Use Register Type 'Non Recoverable Tax Register' to see payables taxes
    Information includes both taxable and tax amounts as well as tax derivation codes
    Standard reports include:
        Tax Journals
        Tax Audits
        Tax Summaries
    Key Tables in Tax Reporting
        ZX_LINES - holds all tax lines
    Open Questions
        How is data purged from ZX_REP_EXTRACT_V by purging ZX_REP_TRX_DETAIL_T and other temp tables?
            To report on self-assessed taxes, use the following Subledger Accounting reports (from AP responsibility):
                Account Analysis Report (XLAAARPT) (*), see Subledger Accounting Implementation Guide pp 8-20
                    Drill down information on the activity on an account.
                    XLAAARPT is referenced to the Subledger Accounting application in foundation
                Open Account Balanced Listing (XLATBRPT)(*), see Oracle Subledger Accounting Implementation Guide pp 9-1
            This is a summary report only, by account
                    Identifies accounts with balances and the sources of those entries
                    XLATBRPT is references in the Subledger Accounting application in foundation
                    The Open Account Balances Listing is defined in AP (Setup/Accounting Setup/Subledger Setup/Open Account Balances Listing)
            This establishes the 'Report Definition' which is a parameter in the listing

Telesales (???) Notes:
    Telesales is an Oracle Forms format application to track telephone marketing prospects and their budget spends
    Telesales allows leads to be converted into orders based on the items tagged in the lead
    It tracks transition of opportunities to a lead to specify the stage of the sale and the items being sold

Trade Management (QZH Schema) Notes on General Functionality:
    Oracle Trade Management administers trade promotion programs for maximum return
    It integrates with Order Management for orders associated with promotions
    It integrates with Payables for claim settlement of trade promotion incentives
    It integrates with Receivables for discounts on customer invoices and collections
    It provides a real time view into customer commitments and payments under a single promotion
    Claims can also be associated with a 'Research' workflow to route claims for approval

Training Administration (OTA) Notes:
    Training events can be scheduled and course enrollments recorded for each event, including caps on enrollee counts
    Training results are posted to the employee's career management profile in HR

Transfer Pricing Notes
    Definitions
        Marginal Cost - cost of producing or manufacturing an additional unit
        Absorption Cost - the fully absorbed cost of producting a unit
        Standard Cost - a predefined 'budgeted' cost of production

    Pricing Approaches
        Cost Based - a markup over the cost (based on marginal, absorption or standard)
        Market Based - the price that could be obtained in the open market

    General Notes
        Transfer pricing must observe national laws for taxes on sales
            It cannot be set artificially low to avoid local taxes

Treasury (XTR) Responsibilities
    TREASURY, VISION OPERATIONS (TVO)
    TREASURY/CASH MANAGEMENT, VISION OPERATIONS (TCMVO)

Treasury (XTR) Notes:
    Oracle Treasury is a new application for Oracle 11i and is a subledger application to the GL
    The two purposes of Oracle Treasury are to raise long term capital, and provide short term funding or invest short term funds from operations to maximize interest income
    Treasury obtains information from AP on scheduled payments, AR on expected receipts, PAY on expected payments.
    A portfolio in Treasury is a collection of individual deals or trades.
    A position is a total commitment to a particular market, equal to the number or value of contracts bought, less the number of contracts sold
    The company profile is used to relate contracts to a set of books, legal entity, a bank account and employees responsible for opening and settling deals
    Counterparties to deals can be internal (subsidiaries) or external (banks and brokerages)
    Deals captured by Treasury include spot, forward, futures, swaps, short term money, intercompany funding, negotiable instruments, and derivatives
    Treasury maintains interest rates in XTR_MARKET_PRICES which is separate to the interest rates maintained
        GL_DAILY_RATES and Treasury uses its internal rates for tolerance checks and revaluations
    Treasury bank accounts are separate to AP bank accounts, and are maintained in XTR_BANK_ACCOUNTS
    Exercise: Setup company profile -> TVO/Setup/Parties/Company Profiles, and set up profiles for each company or operating unit
    Exercise: Setup counterparties -> TVO/Setup/Parties/Counterparty Profiles

Treasury (XTR) Interfaces:
    Market Data Feed, imports foreign exchange rates, interest rates, bond prices and option volatilities, via XTR_MARKET_DATA_INTERFACE

User Management (UMX) Notes on Procedures
