        Log in as SYSADMIN and update assigned roles on user name to include 'Security Administrator'
        Run Workflow Bacground Process
        Clear caches
    Create a custom role and assign to a user
        Create a Role Category (not required if an existing role category will be used)
            User Management > Role Categories > Update > Add Another Row
            Create a new Role Category (backdating is allowed)
        Create a new Role for a Role Category
            User Management > Roles and Role Inheritance > 
            It is not required to create a Grant
            Run Workflow Background Process and clear Java Caches
        Assign the Role to Users
            User Management > Users > Search on User Name > Update

Warehouse Management System (OWM or WMS) Notes:
    Warehouses are defined through the Organizations form as Orgs with type = Inventory Organization (subinventories are zones within a warehouse complex)
    OWM transactions include: receiving, putaway, backflush, kanban replenishment, cross-docking, completions, picking, loading, ship confirm, zone transfer
    UOM Classes group units of measure that can be converted into one another. Each UOM class has a base UOM.
    Examples are UOM classes are: quantity, volume, temperature
    Each item has a primary UOM - on-hand quantities are maintained in the primary UOM.
    You must define a conversion to the base UOM to use a UOM on an item
    Transaction Source Types - are transaction types of the source of material transactions (eg PO is the source type for a PO receipt)
    Transaction Actions - identify the nature of the material transaction (eg receipt into stores).
        Joined with transaction source type to define the transaction (eg PO/Receipt into Stores = PO Receipt)
    Transaction Types - represent the combination of tran source types and transaction actions.
    Transaction Reasons - are tagged to a transaction that cannot be performed, and may trigger an associated workflow (eg insufficient inventory to pick)
    Subinventory in OWM simply means zone - there is no implicit definition of accounts for a subinventory.
        Cost group associations define the accounts.
    Cost Groups - collection of valuation and variance accounts tied to a subinventory (originally the accounts were individually tied to the subinventory but OWM separated these)
    Material Statuses include a list of disallowed transactions - the status can be attached to a lot or serial item to prevent these transactions occuring.
    Miscellaneous transactions allow transfer between inventory and non-inventory departments like research or accounting.
        The transfer is to/from GL accounts
    Mass moves and mass issues from the Materials Workbench move all materials in a subinventory in one transaction
    Direct shipment mode on an inter-org transfer moves items to their destination directly,
        whereas intransit mode moves items to an intermediate account pending delivery
    Estimated arrival dates for in-transits can be updated on the 'Maintain Shipments' window
    Move orders are requests or nominations to move material rather than actual immediate movements. Entered via 'Create Move Orders' form
    Move orders can perform subinventory transfers, pick waves for shipping, replenishments, and pick release to WIP.
    Pick wave move orders for shipping are created automatically when sales order lines are released for picking.
    Move orders are 'transacted' to actualize.
    Lots are groups of items with similar characteristics - you can classify output from production batches into lots with similar properties
    Lot attributes can be numeric, descriptive or date. Attributes are primarily dates: use by, made on, matures for use on, retest required on, etc.
    Lots can be split into multiple new lots: full split eliminates the parent and leaves children. Partial split leaves a smaller parent and new children
    Lots can be merged fully or partially: full merge eliminates the originating lots whereas partial merge leaves a portion.
        Attributes of the merged lot default from the largest contributing lot
    Lot merging and splitting are executed from the Oracle Mobile Transactions: Lot Split, and Lot Merge
    Lot geneology tracks lot merging and lot splitting transactions in a geneology window
    Serialized items allow tracking of individual items in inventory as well tracking as their 'as-built' configurations
    Serial attributes include standard and user defined values to track individual item information
    'As-Built' configurations are multilevel records of the actual items, lots and serial numbers of items. Serial numbers are entered in the Serial Entry Form
    The Quantity Tree is a hierarchical structure of available quantities for items. Hierarchy top to bottom is: Item/Revision/Lot/SubInv/Locator/LPN. Qty's tracked are: on-hand, reservable, reserved, suggested, available to transact, available to reserve
    There is a public interface to the quantity tree for third party applications: INV_QUANTITY_TREE_PUB.QUERY_QUANTITIES
    Reservations are associations between supply and demand. Viewed through the Item Reservation form
    Consignment Inventory can be implemented as commingled inventory using cost groups and rules, rather than default subinventory account values
    The Rules Framework can be setup to choose values for: pick, putaway, labeling, cost group assignment, and task management such as task type assignment (these are rule types) - on the WMS Rules form
    Rules are established as complex expressions (or/and) for multiple lines comparing business objects and values to constants or other business objects and values
    Rules are grouped into strategies and strategies are tied to named business objects to fire the rules. If no rule fires, default org assignments are used to determine accounts, pick and putaway locations
    Physical inventory count methods include cycle count (which relies on ABC prioritization) and physical count.
    ABC (meaning count in classes A, B, C where A has the most value/impact) Analysis provides count guidelines based on content scope (inventory org or subinventory included) and valuation scope (inv org or sub org used as scope for determining value rank) using the ABC Compile form
    Content scope decides what items are included in the ABC inventory. Valuation scope decides what inventories are included in ranking the relative value of the items in the content scope
    ABC Criteria on the ABC Compile form provide a range of criteria to select. Quantity criteria rank in terms of FSN, and value criteria rank in terms of usage value (quantity times unit price)
    ABC Classes are predefined cycle counts. The compile is defined and linked to the class to provide a definition for each class
    Hit or Miss reporting on cycle counts includes all items as hits if the count is within the defined tolerance, and a miss if the count is outside the tolerance
    Count requests are specific OWM tasks to perform counts and are generated by the Count Request concurrent process after cycle counting is scheduled
    Min-Max or Reorder-Point planning is set at the item level - on the General Planning tab. It can be one method or the other, not both
    Reorder Point Planning is set at the item level using the Inventory Planning Method attribute and related parameters. Reorder is defined as safety stock plus forecast demand during reorder lead time. Reorder quantity is calculated using the standard EOQ formula
    Safety stock is set on the item attributes on the planning tab.
    Replenishment counting can be used where perpetual inventories are not maintained - by entering counts and generating reorder calculations (on items such as supply items)
    Labeling consists of label types and formats. Type dictate the data contents of a label and each type has multiple formats but only one default format.
    Containers are items - tagged as a container on the Physical Attributes tab of item attributes. LPN's provide serial number control over containers but the same LPN's can be assigned to different containers over their lifetime
    Cartonization is the process of packing items into containers to match the loading restrictions of the containers.
    Container transactions allow dealing with containers as units without reference to the contents. Includes prepack, move (referencing the LPN) and unpack transactions.
    Warehouse tasks identify resources, locations and activities to perform. Processes such as picking and cycle count generate tasks to complete these activities.
    Task types define resources needed for tasks (eg pallet trucks) and task types are assigned to tasks using the task type assignment engine. Task type assignment rules are part of the rules framework
    Label types are assigned to warehouse business flows and each business flow triggers label generation by selecting the default label for the label type
    Cross docking (if enabled for the org) will suggest moving any receiving goods that are back ordered be moved to a shipping dock immediately, unless it is rejected on receipt inspection
    Pick execution has three supported modes: system directed (based on the rules engine, each new pick is determined to match your pick resources), manual picking (pick lines are followed for a pick slip), and label based (for conveyors where cartons are loaded and moved down a pick line)
    Picking methods in a warehouse include: order, cluster, zone, build, paper-based, pick and pass, and wave (consolidated multi-order picking)

Warehouse Management System (WMS) Notes on Kanban:
    Kanban means sign/signal - applies to decentralized inventory management of items with stable demand and medium to high volume
    Pull sequences for Kanbans are defined for each item and subinventory/locator combination (usage point) - they define the replenishment source for each source type (production/supplier/intra-org/inter-org)
    Kanban size or number of cards is calculated by the system when the other value is input (unless the 'do not calculate' option is enabled) based on lead time to resupply and physical container constraints (plus min re-order quantity, lot multipler, safety stock days, and allocation percent)

Warehouse Management System (OWM) Best Practices:
    Cycle counting of physical inventory using ABC analysis

Warehouse Management System (OWM) Responsibilities:
    WAREHOUSE MANAGER

Warehouse Management System (OWM) Profile Options:
    INV:Transaction Date Validation - determines if backdated transactions are allowed
    INV:Allow Expense to Asset - allows a subinventory tranfer from an expense inventory to an asset inventory
    INV:Detail Serial Numbers - enforces serial number control in picking and requires specific serial number items to be picked. Normally turned off.
    INV:Split Lots Enables - allows splitting of lots: partial or full splits
    INV:Geneology Prefix or Suffix - determines if lot numbers are prefixed or suffixed to item numbers in inventory

Warehouse Management System (OWM) Forms:
    Transaction Reasons -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Transaction Setup/Inventory Transactions/Transaction Reasons
    Cost Groups -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Material Setup/Costs/Cost Groups
    Material Status -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Transaction Setup/Inventory Transactions/Material Status - defines which transactions can be performed at subinventory level
    Subinventory Transfers -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inventory Management/Material Transactions/Subinventory Transfers - to transfer between subinventories and locators
    Interorganization Transfers -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inventory Management/Material Transactions/Inter-Organization Transfers- to transfer items between inventory organizations. Items must be defined in both orgs.
    Create Move Orders -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inventory Management/Material Transactions/Create Move Orders - to nominate a future material movement
    Material Workbench -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inquiry/Material Workbench - to perform common inventory transactions and inquire on availablity
    View Movement Statistics -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inquiry/View Movement Statistics - to view intrastat movement statistics for EU reporting
    Item Lots -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inquiry/View Lot Numbers - to view existing lots
    Lot Geneology -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inquiry/View Lot Numbers and click on View Geneology - shows a tree of item/lots and their composition
    Serial Entry -> .... - to enter serial numbers for a component and sub-components
    Serial Numbers (view) -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inquiry/View Serial Numbers
    Serial Geneology -> Click View Geneology from the Serial Numbers form
    Availability -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inquiry/Material Workbench and click on Availability for an item
    Item Reservations -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inventory Management/Material Maintenance/Reservations
    WMS Rules -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Warehouse Configuration/Rules/Rules - to setup rules for picking, putaway, cost group assignment, task type assignment, label selection
    WMS Strategies -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Warehouse Configuration/Rules/Strategies - to define collections of rules and sequences of rules for evaluation, and to assign to business objects: item, locator, org - to trigger evaluation
    Strategy Assignments -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Warehouse Configuration/Rules/Strategy Assignment - to assign strategies/rule groups to named business objects
    Strategy Search Order -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Warehouse Configuration/Rules/Strategy Search Order - to define the order/hierarchy of business objects evaluated to find a strategy
    Strategy Where Used -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Warehouse Configuration/Rules/Strategy Where Used - to analyze where strategies are associated with objects for testing and validation of rule setups
    ABC Compile -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inventory Management/ABC Analysis/ABC Compiles - to set the content and value scope and generate/compile a cycle count plan
    ABC Classes -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inventory Management/ABC Analysis/ABC Classes - to define ABC classes which will be linked to ABC compiles for future cycle counts
    Cycle Counts -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inventory Management/Counting/Cycle Counting/Cycle Counts - to define a named cycle count and schedule it, and decide to include serialized items
    Cycle Count Classes ->     WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inventory Management/Counting/Cycle Counting/Cycle Counts - and click the classes button after querying a cycle count - to enter specific cycle counts already defined, to include in the actual cycle count. Also enter tolerances for each class that override the standard class tolerances
    Define Label Formats -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Warehouse Configuration/Printers and Devices/Define Label Formats - to define label formats for a specific label type and further define the fields in the format
    Assign Label Types to Business Flows -> wAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Warehouse Configuration/Printing/Assign Label Types to Business Flows
    Warehouse Control Board -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Inquiry/Warehouse Control Board - to view pending and actual tasks in a warehouse, and to reassign tasks between users
    Pick Slip Grouping -> WAREHOUSE MANAGER/Setup/Rules/Pickwave/Pick Slip Grouping - to define pick methods or view seeded picking methods (which cannot be modified). Seeded methods are order, zone, bulk and cluster

Warehouse Management System (OWM) Concurrent Processes:
    Material Manager - processes the physical move side of a material transaction
    Costing Manager - processes the accounting and costing side of a material transaction - the restock option/parameter triggers resupply orders
    Count Requests Generation - generates count request tasks for a cycle count after the cycle count is scheduled
    Min-Max Planning Report - to execute the min-max planning process for inventory replenishment
    Reorder Point Planning Report - to execute the ROP replenishment process and generate requisitions for resupply (based on setting the Create Req's option to YES)

Warehouse Management System (OWM) Tables:
    MTL_LOT_NUMBERS - Stores user-defined additional lot attributes for dates, character and numerics
    MTL_SERIAL_NUMBERS - Stores user-defined additional serial attributes for dates character and numerics
    WMS_LABELS, WMS_LABEL_FIELDS - store label information
    WMS_LICENCE_PLATE_NUMBERS, WMS_LPN_CONTENTS, WMS_LPN_HISTORIES - store LPN information

Warehouse Management System (OWM) Interfaces:
    Item Import
    Transactions Open Interface - import inventory transactions: issue and receipts, subinv transfers, inter-org transfers, intransit transfers
    Cycle Count Entries API - process cycle counts
    Kanban API - update the supply of KanBan cards
    Lot API - create lots by inserting entries into MTL_LOT_NUMBERS
    Material Reservations API - query or create reservations, update existing reservations and delete reservations
    Sales Order API - create sales orders in the INV local format and update sales orders
    Move Order API - create, modify or delete move orders
    Pick Release API - release a set of move order lines for picking waves and run a pick confirm for picked items
    Pick Confirm API - confirm picked items

Warehouse Management System (OWM) Localizations:
    Movement Statistics: reports all material movements to comply with Intrastat EU regulatory reporting

Work in Process (WIP) Notes:
    WIP accepts planning workorders from MRP and tracks actual completions data in manufacturing as well as actual resources and waste/scrap.
    WIP uses BOM information as a 'budget' in creating the actual WIP work order
    Work orders in WIP describe how many items to make, when the assemblies are supposed to be completed and where to put the finished assemblies
    Discrete jobs are the same thing as workorders and production orders. Generated by discrete planning and sales orders.
    WIP accounts for most functionality in Manufacturing Execution: involves work orders, jobs, operations, scheduled dates
    OSFM provides additional WIP functionality for lot based manufacturing like semiconductors
    Discrete jobs or manufacturing work orders are generated from planning (MRP, ASCP) or from sales orders
    Unplanned work in manufacturing can be rework and prototypes
    Backflushing is automatic inventory relief based on job completion, operation completion or work orderless completion
    The backflush is automatically executed when a job completes (for any 'assembly pull' material) or when an operation completes (for any 'operation pull' material)
    For flow manufacturing there are flow schedules but no work orders or discrete jobs.
    The progress on a job is recorded using 'movements' between operations or 'intra-operation' movements, based on routings
    Jobs are charged material costs and labor costs and overheads (resources) as each operation is completed (autocharging)
    Jobs or schedules (for flow or repetitive mfg) are 'completed' adding to finished goods. Flow uses work orderless completions
    Jobs are created from snapshots of their BOM's, extended by the quantity of the job to estimate material requirements
    WIP Supply Type drives material issue: 'push' for issued material, 'operation pull' for backflushed material after an operation, and 'assembly pull' for backflushed material after an assembly is completed
    Jobs are scheduled by assigning start and end dates to each operation (or the first and last operation for repetitive jobs)
    Jobs are copied with the required resources for each operation, for each resource type: labor, materials, overhead.
    There are five intra-operaton steps or stages: queue (wait to start), run (in process), to (complete and wait to exit), scrap (complete and in scrap), reject (complete and held pending move to rework or scrap)
    Production methods are: discrete (MTS), repetitive, flow, ATO and CTO
    Shop floor statuses can be defined as hold statuses, and attached to steps (stages within a sequence) in jobs to force a hold for QA or other purposes
    Discrepant material is material that fails inspection and must be isolated and ultimately returned to a vendor or reworked
    Discrete jobs are created by: releasing planned orders, autocreating from ATO/CTO sales orders, by open interface, or manually
    Discrete job statuses are: unreleased, released, complete, complete-no charges, closed, hold and cancelled
    Repetitive schedules require a production line to be defined first and then associate repetitive assemblies to the line
    Tolerance fences on production lines define the percent increase in production possible for a given number of lead days
    WIP materials must be specifically issued to a discrete job using the WIP Material Transactions form
    Backflushing relieves inventory of components after the assembly is complete - it assumes that completed components mean materials were issued.
    Post-deduct and backflush are the same thing.
    Work orderless completions backflush all materials: push, assembly pull and operation pull. It won't backflush bulk or vendor supplied items
    By product recovery is accomplished with negative quantities in the BOM: backflushing sends these byproducts to inventory, as does explicit material issue
    Phantom assemblies are collections of parts that may exist in many products - changing the phantom updates all products. Phantoms are not inventoried.
    A dispatch list is a report of scheduled work by department to guide shop floor work
    A job packet or job traveller is attached to an assembly as it is built - including a routing of operations, a BOM of materials, and drawings.
    The Discrete Job Routing Sheet is the primary traveller report in Oracle WIP (online version is Discrete Workstation form)
    Overcompletion is when more unit of an assembly are moved than are available. Overcompletion tolerances for items limit the percentage of overcompletion
    Completions move WIP to inventory: use completion moves for discrete jobs and work orderless completions for flow routings.
    Discrete jobs are ultimately closed to post variances to the GL for differences between BOM budgeted amounts and WIP actual completed amounts for materials and resource usage.
    Repetitive jobs are only completed - never closed

Work in Process (WIP) Best Practices:
    Constraint-based scheduling (using Oracle Manufacturing Scheduling functionality) for resources and materials

Work in Process (WIP) Responsibilities:
    WORK IN PROCESS

Work in Process (WIP) Forms:
    WIP Parameters: WORK IN PROCESS/Setup/Parameters - establishes defaults and accounting codes for each production method: discrete, repetitive, flow
    WIP Accounting Class: WORK IN PROCESS/Setup/WIP Accounting Classes - define GL accounts for valuation and variance reporting for different types of production
    Shop Floor Statuses: WORK IN PROCESS/Move Transactions/Shop Floor Statuses/Shop Floor Statuses - can prohibit moves out of a specific step for QA review
    Employee Labor Rates: WORK IN PROCESS/Setup/Employees/Labor Rates
    Material Requirements: WORK IN PROCESS/Job-Schedule Details/Material Requirements - to modify material required for a job
    Operations: WORK IN PROCESS/Job-Schedule Details/Job - to modify or delete operations or resource requirements
    Production Lines -> WORK IN PROCESS/Setup/Production Lines - to setup lines required to define repetitive schedules
    Repetitive Line/Assembly Associations -> WORK IN PROCESS/Repetitive/Associate Lines and Assemblies - to define repetitive schedules
    WIP Material Transactions -> WORK IN PROCESS/Material Transactions/WIP Material Transactions
    Discrete Workstation -> WORK IN PROCESS/.... (Counterpart of Flow Workstation) - graphical dispatch list, allows shop floor moves, changes to resources, links to other transaction forms
    Move Transactions -> WORK IN PROCESS/Move Transactions/Move Transactions - to record moves between operations or intra-operation moves (use 'Move Lot Based Jobs' form for lot based jobs)
    Assign Shop Floor Statuses -> WORK IN PROCESS/Move Transactions/Shop Floor Statuses/Assign Shop Floor Statuses - to put a hold on a move
    Discrete Workstation -> WORK IN PROCESS/Discrete/Discrete Workstation
    Scheduler Workbench -> graphical gantt chart form for rescheduling jobs, operations and resources in a constraint based engine
    Scheduling Exceptions -> Right Click any job and 'view exceptions' from the scheduler workbench. Lists scheduling exceptions generated by the Scheduler Workbench
    Lot Based Jobs -> Define lots where component parts do not exist (use Lot Creation Form where component parts are already lotted)
    Move Lot Based Jobs -> WORK IN PROCESS/.... - to record moves between operations for lot based jobs
    Inventory Lot Transactions -> WORK IN PROCESS/...... - to split lots, merge lots, translate lots (to a different BOM/product), transfer lots to different subinventory.
    Completion Transactions -> WORK IN PROCESS/Material Transactions/Completion Transactions - to complete WIP jobs to inventory
    Work Orderless Completions -> WORK IN PROCESS/Material Transactions/Work Orderless Completions - to complete flow manufacturing schedules
    Flow Workstation -> FLOW MANUFACTURING/Production/Flow Workstation (counterpart of Discrete Workstation) - shows flow status and links to transaction forms
    Close Discrete Jobs -> WORK IN PROCESS/Discrete/Close Discrete Jobs/Close Discrete Jobs (Form)....
    Purge Discrete Jobs -> WORK IN PROCESS/Discrete/Purge Discrete Jobs/.... to purge jobs after the accounting period is closed and jobs are closed.

Work in Process (WIP) Exercises:
    Manually create a WIP job -> WORK IN PROCESS/Discrete/Discrete Jobs ('New' on the Find dialog)

Work in Process (WIP) Interfaces:
    WIP Job/Schedule Interface - to import WIP jobs from third party systems or from the MRP/ASCP module, using WIP Mass Load concurrent process
    Workorder Interface - import discrete jobs and repetitive routings (WIP_JOB_SCHEDULE_INTERFACE and WIP_JOB_DTLS_INTERFACE tables). Run the WIP Mass Load program. Review errors in the Pending Jobs and Schedules form
    Inventory Open Transaction Interface - can process WIP issues and returns, since they are the same as any other inventory transaction.
    Move Transaction Interface - to import WIP moves intra or interoperation. WIP_MOVE_TXN_INTERFACE move and CST_COMP_SNAP_INTERFACE cost tables are populated
    Open Resource Transaction interface - to import resource usage transactions to cost WIP jobs. Uses WIP_COST_TXN_INTERFACE table and Cost Mgr concurrent process

Work in Process (WIP) Concurrent Processes:
    Autocreate Final Assembly Schedules - create discrete jobs from ATO item orders
    Autocreate Configuration Items - creates discrete routings and bills from CTO item orders, prior to generating final assembly jobs
    Close Discrete Jobs - to close discrete jobs and post final variances to the GL (counterpart of form: Close Discrete Jobs)

Work in Process (WIP) Profile Options:
    TP: WIP Completion Transaction First Field - specifies the field with focus when the WIP completion transaction form is opened
    WIP: See Engineering Items - controls access to engineering items for creating jobs or schedules
    WIP: Exclude Open ECO's - to exclude open ECO's from affecting material requirements
    WIP: Discrete Job Prefix - to specify a prefix rule for system generated discrete job numbers
    WIP: Job Name Updateable - locks or unlocks WIP job names from changes
    WIP: Requirement Nettable Option - allows access to subinventories designated as non-nettable (eg discrepant materials) in materials planning
    WIP: Move Completion Default - specifies if a move t the 'To Move' step of the last operation for a job triggers completion for inventory.
    INV: Override Neg for Backflush - controls whether negative inventory is allowed for backflushed items
    WIP: Define discrete jobs - sets manufacturing scheduling (constraint scheduler) to real time, or via concurrent manager

Work in Process (WIP) Tables:
    WIP_REQUIREMENT_OPERATIONS - stores the material requirements for a job: quantity, supply type, supply subinventory, locator, for each component
    WIP_DISCRETE_JOBS - job definitions for discrete jobs and lot-based discrete jobs
    WIP_TRANSACTION_ACCOUNTS - subledger journal entries posted to GL

Work in Process (WIP) Sequences:
    WIP_JOB_NUMBER_S - sequence for autonumbering WIP jobs

Workflow (WF) (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Tips and Tricks:
    Restart an errored workflow by clearing the cause of the error then rewinding the workflow to a prior point
        Workflow Administrator -> Status Monitor -> Search for Item -> Rewind -> Choose Point to Rewind To
        This will resume processing at an earlier point in the workflow
    Run workflows by choosing the Workflow Administrator Responsibility, then
        choose 'Workflow Background Process' and specify the workflow parameters
            This will run workflow actions in deferred status
    Always Log onto Workflow Builder as "Apps" to get grants to all needed tables,
        otherwise you get errors like "Unable to set NLS_LANGUAGE.".
            ORA-000942: table or view does not exist.
    The workflow administrator role must be set to a responsibility that you are assigned,
        in order to modify other people's workflows - see workflow scripts below
    If the workflow admin role is a responsibility that you are not assigned ...
       you will not be able to see workflow items.
    To see and change the Workflow Administrator, find the current value (it can be a user or responsibility) -see scripts below
        select text from APPLSYS.WF_RESOURCES where name = 'WF_ADMIN_ROLE'
        Log in using the current value user or responsibility
        If you log in as a user workflow administrator, choose 'Workflow Administrator Web Applications' and go to Administer Workflow > Administration
            See and change the value of Workflow System Administrator
        Patches often over-ride non-default settings and need to be reset
    Verify workflow and the notification mailer through the Oracle Applications Manager
        Navigate to Workflow Manager within OAM from the Application Dashboard page.
    You cannot use a URL to view a report provided by a workflow notice more than once
        See metalink note 77576.1 - using the link a second time will cause an 'authentication failure'
    You can set another person's vacation rules if the leave w/out doing it themselves
        Navigation: Workflow  (Administration) -> Administrator Workflow -> Administration -> Vacation Rules (in menu)
    You can redirect a notification on an existing workflow if a person is out
        Workflow Adminstration -> Status Monitor -> Activity History -> Activity -> Reassign

Workflow (WF) (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Schemas
    APPLSYS - the core FND schema (with table prefixes 'WF_')

Workflow (WF) Notes on General Functions
    Workflow is part of AOL and prescribes how different types of information flow among people
        in accordance with business rules
    Workflow is primarily used for approval processes and Account Generater within the apps
    Components of Oracle Workflow are:
        Builder (client),
        Monitor (client tier),
        Definitions Loader (for text file definitions),
        Notifications Mailer and Directory Services (apps tier - send and receive email notifications),
        Engine (db tier) and
        Notification Server (db tier)
    Workflow Notification Mailer and Directory Services performs the following:
        maintains users,
        maintains roles (users or groups of users or positions) and
        maintains user/role cross references for routing notifications to roles (user names)
    Workflow Engine is a PL/SQL program on the server which executes the workflow process and monitors the workflow state
        It includes an event manager that triggers any subscribed activity/function to an event
        It provides callable services that may be needed by PL/SQL functions which execute activities
    The workflow engine supports rules such as looping, branching, parallel flows and subflows
    Workflow Monitor provides a graphical status on a workflow, allows expediting or restarting a workflow
        Workflow Monitor provides detailed information on the attributes of a workflow.
        It is primarily used by the Workflow System Administrator
    Workflow Definitions Loader allows uploading or downloading workflow definitions from the database or text files
        It can also load definitions from a development instance to a test or production instance
    Workflow rules (aka process definitions) include:
        activities that occur in a process and
        the relationships/dependencies between those activities
    An instance of a workflow is a specific item travelling through the workflow
        e.g. PO in an approval process
        there may be many instances of a single workflow active at any time
    Each instance or item of a workflow has a number of data attributes that describe
        the state of the instance in the workflow based on the status of each activity
    The state of an item or instance of a workflow at any one time is defined by
        the status of all the activities for that instance of the workflow
        some activities may be complete and some may not, one may be active
    Each activity in a workflow can have one of the following states for each instance:
        Active,
        Complete,
        Deferred,
        Error,
        Notified,
        Suspended, and
        Waiting
    Transition occurs when an activity returns a status of complete to the Workflow Engine
        the engine will then set to active the next dependent activity in the workflow definition and execute that activity.
    If the final activity returns a complete status, the Engine will mark the entire workflow instance as complete
    An incomplete workflow can be restarted by clicking the start button on the workflow Monitor diagram
    The default workflow administrator is the System Administrator
        this can be changed in the global preferences of the system admin menu (Sysadmin/Workflow/Global Preferences)
    Seeded workflows stored on the database can be accessed using File/Open on the Workflow builder
        You need a TNS Names database connection string (same as SQL Plus) and user id/password to download workflows
    If an activity returns an error to the workflow engine:
        the engine rolls back the activity and executes error functions at the lowest level, or
            at successive parent workflow levels until it reaches the default highest level workflow error handler
    Exercise: Check for suspended notifications -> WFA/Find Processes, and choose item type
        (purchase order notifications begin with PO...)

Workflow (WF) (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Workflow Builder and Message Designer:
    Log onto workflow builder with the apps userid or you will not get access - you will get an NLS_LANGUAGE error
    Workflow Builder Clients are available on My Oracle Support as follows:
        How To Download and Install the Latest Oracle Workflow Builder (Client Tool) and XML Gateway Message Designer for E-Business [ID 261028.1]
        Recommended Set Up for Client/Server Products with Oracle E-Business Suite 11i and R12 (Doc ID 277535.1)
            Oracle Workflow Client 2.6.3.5 for Microsoft Windows is Patch 4096620 for R12
            Oracle Workflow Client 2.6.3.0 for Microsoft Windows is Patch 4066964 for 11i

Workflow (WF) (APPLSYS Schema) Notes on Item Type Property:
    Each item type has six major properties shown as branches in the Workflow Buider Navigator Window
        Attributes, Processes, Notifications, Functions, Events, Messages and Lookup Types
    Workflow also has an "Activities" concept - an activity is a node in the workflow
        An activity can be a notification, process or function
    Attributes: are the data value holders for the item type
        e.g. 'Requisition Number' or 'PO Approval Limit'.
        These attributes hold the data associated with the individual items
    Processes (Activities): are the activities that the workflow item transitions into and out of
        The full set of activities constitutes the overall workflow performed
    Notifications (Activities): are the notifications within the current item type.
        Notifications send messages to user roles and prompt for simple responses.
    Functions (Activities): are stored PL/SQL procedures that are executed.
    Event Activities): are business events that the item type will receive, process or raise and send/notify
    Messages: are text that a notificatin activity can send to a user role
    Lookup Types: are lists of valid values used by notifications or messages

Workflow (WF) (APPLSYS Schema) Notes Finding and Monitoring Workflows and Notifications:
    You must know the workflow item type (or user item type) and the workflow key
        The workflow item key is a unique identifier for an item type
        The workflow item key is built differently for each workflow item type
        Examples of workflow item keys are:
            Purchase Orders -> WF_ITEM_KEY  in PO.PO_HEADERS_ALL
                Build with PO_HEADER_ID & sequence number (e.g. '3702-147435')
                WF_ITEM_TYPE = 'POAPPRV'
            Requisitions -> WF_ITEM_KEY in PO.PO_REQUISITION_HEADERS_ALL
                Built with REQUISITION_HEADER_ID and a sequence number
                WF_ITEM_TYPE = 'REQAPPRV'
        The key can be found from the Workflow Status page within each application
    Alternatively query the WF_ITEMS table based on Item Type, beginning and ending dates
    Monitor the workflow from the Workflow Administrator responsibility
    Exercise: Monitor workflow item ->
        Workflow Administrator/Administrator Workflow/Status Monitor
    Find a Notification and Force a Response
        Log on as SYSADMIN or change the Workflow Administrator to your User or to Global ('*')
        Navigation: 'Workflow Administrator Web (New)' > Administration > Notification Search and search for the notification (see attached doc for the search values) and act on the notification

Workflow (WF) Notes on Notfication/Delegation Rules (also known as Vacation Rules) and Worklist Access
    You can create Vacation Rules for others via Workflow Administration
        Navigation: Workflow  (Administration) -> Administrator Workflow -> Administration -> Vacation Rules (in menu)
    Workflow notification rules can be established to respond to notifications automatically
        These include: cancel, redirect or respond
    Exercise: Enter a notification rule -> WFA/Notification Rules,
        and enter new notification rules for specific workflow item types and notifications
    Worklist Access allows other users to access a user's worklist - notifications are not redirected

Workflow (WF) Notes on Roles:
    Roles cannot be defined in the Workflow Builder and can only be referenced from the Oracle applications database
        This is where they are defined
    A performer associated with an activity like a notification translates into a role
        Or it can by an item type attribute that dynamically translates into a role

Workflow (WF) Notes on Customization Levels and Protection Levels
    Each workflow has a customization level (default is zero) and protection level (default is 1000)
    Your access level must be between these two values if you want to modify the workflow

Workflow (WF) Notes on Scripts
    Workflow scripts have a .wft extension and can be saved on the local host file system
    They are also saved on the database (Use File/Open/Database within Workflow Builder)
    The WFLOAD file system script can be used to upload or download .wft files on the database
        The syntax is WFLOAD <apps/pwd> 0 Y {UPLOAD|DOWNLOAD|UPGRADE|FORCE} <filepath> [<item type>]
            The <item type> is only used with the DOWNLOAD mode
    To find the current workflow administrator use this SQL:
        select text from APPLSYS.WF_RESOURCES where name = 'WF_ADMIN_ROLE'
        The result is applicationID/responsibilityID - the workflow administrator can be either
    The base application workflows are generally stored in "<APP_TOP>/admin/import" directory

Workflow (WF Schema) Notes on Workflow Directory Services
    New users are created in WF_LOCAL_ROLES with USER_FLAG set to 'Y'
    New responsibilities are created in WF_LOCAL_ROLES with USER_FLAG set to 'N'
    Associations between users and responsibilities are in WF_LOCAL_USER_ROLES
        The user is in USER_NAME and the responsibility is in ROLE_NAME
        The responsibility can be found by querying DISPLAY_NAME and NAME in WF_LOCAL_ROLES
    Views in the APPS schema based on these tables are WF_USERS and WF_ROLES

Workflow (WF) Notes on Concurrent Processes:
    Workflow Background Process - from the WFA responsibility.
        Run two processes scheduled every 5-15 mins for
        1) timed out processes,
        2) deferred processes (these are program parameters)
    Workflow Background Process - options are:
        item type,
        min threshhold (0),
        max threshhold (100),
        process deferred (yes),
        process timeout (yes),
        process stuck (yes).
    Synchronize WF Local Tables
        updates the WF_LOCAL_X tables from the Oracle apps tables to register new users and employees in workflow

Workflow (WF) Notes on Key Packages:
    WR_ENGINE - contains all the workflow engine API's

Workflow (WF) Notes on Key Tables:
    WF_ITEM_TYPES (and _TL) - contains workflow item types
    WF_ITEMS - instances of item types - actual workflow occurances
    WF_MESSAGES (and _TL) - workflow messages
    WF_USERS - are people in the superset of the various application tables like PER_PERSON_F and FND_USERS
    WF_ROLES - contains the information on workflow roles
    WF_USER_ROLES - tags users to roles. Workflow works with roles and sends notifications to users within those roles
    WF_USER_ROLE_ASSIGNMENTS - table that underlies the view WF_LOCAL_USER_ROLES
    WF_NOTIFICATIONS - holds all notifications (until purged) for each item type
    WF_NOTIFICATION_ATTRIBUTES - carries one line for each attribute defined for a single notification
    WF_RESOURCES - stores the Workflow Administrator against name = 'WF_ADMIN_ROLE' and all form headings and form error messages

Workflow (WF) Notes on Technical Configuration and Versions:
    For custom workflows, the code is under ORACLE_HOME/wf directory an the applications server
    For Oracle applications, the code is under $FND_TOP directory for the application
    Workflow version 2.6 is the latest available version but only as a standalone.
        WF 2.5 is embedded in the applications
    Release 11.0 of Applications uses Workflow Ver 2.0.3
    Release 11.5 (11i) uses Workflow Ver 2.5 (more recently 2.6)
    Version 2.0.X and Versions 2.5/2.6 are not compatible
    wfver.sql displays the version of workflow installed with the applications

XML Gateway (ECX Schema) Notes in Message Designer Installation
    Oracle Workflow Client 2.6.3.0 for Microsoft Windows is Patch 4066964 for 11i
    It is not included in the Worflow client patch for R12 which is Patch 4096620
    See "How To Download and Install the Latest Oracle Workflow Builder (Client Tool) and XML Gateway Message Designer for E-Business [ID 261028.1]"

XML Gateway General Notes:
    XML Gateway is an Http protocol tool for Enterprise Application Integration (EAI), Business to Business (B2B),
        Application to Application (A2A) and web service integration
    XML Gateway provides a set of services to send and receive XML formatted records
        It can send from the Oracle applications and receive to the Oracle standard interface tables
    XML processing is real time and event driven, whereas EDI (via eCommerce gateway) is batch oriented
    XML Gateway supports all standards for Document Type Definitions (DTD's)
        These include: RosettaNet, Open Applications Group (OAG), SOAP and iFX
    XML Gateway works with the Oracle Workflow Business Event System (BES) to create event based messages
        It can also 'consume' incoming messages for processing
        BES utilizes publish and subscribe features to create and consume messages
        BES is implemented through Oracle Workflow and Oracle Advanced Queuing (AQ)
            Workflow creates business events and places them on the queue for processing
            Business events can be raised (added to the queue) or received (taken off the queue)
    XML Gateway feeds Oracle Advanced Queuing to send XML messages and subcribe to inbound messages
        It also uses Oracle Transport Layer (OTL) for message transmission.
            The Oracle Transport Layer (OXTA) monitors the outbound queue (ECX_OUTBOUND) and sends out the documents
            The documents are sent based on the information that is included in the document itself
            OXTA can send documents in HTTP, HTTPS and SMTP protocol formats
    The Advanced Queuing Engine uses the Transport Layer for confirmation of delivery and recipient authentication
    XML Gateway can support business to business integration as well as Application to Application (A2A) integration
        Both types of integration can be accomplished within the same environment
        A2A integration can be between Oracle Applications and legacy systems
    Primary components are: Message Designer, Execution Engine, Trading Partner Directory Service,
        Message Setup, Workflow Integration for Error Handling, Advanced Queuing Integration,
            and Servlet Based Transport Agent
        Message Designer is a visual message mapping tool that maps source formats to target formats for data conversion
            It supports XML to XML and Table/View to XML
            The XML portion of the map can be based on an actual XML message, or a DTD (Data Type Definition)
            Message Designer maps the structure of the source and target messages (level hierarchy)
            Message Designer also maps the individual element mapping and needed transformations, such as formatting and masking
            Data mapping can be conditional, string oriented, mathematical and date conversion types
        The Execution Engine uses the finalized message maps as the mechanism for processing incoming or outbound message transformations.
            The Execution Engine process includes: Validating the Trading Partner, Retrieving the Message Map, Retrieve the Message,
                Apply Transformations, Validate XML Using a Parser, Enqueue and Dequeue Messages, and Transmit Confirmations
    Message definitions are provided for some pre-built messages to use immediately
        Oracle XML Gateway supports all DTD based XML standards
            including the OAG (Open Application Group) standard as the default standard for pre-built messages
        Any prebuilt message can be modified by remapping to serve local needs
    Meta data is used to build the outbound message
        Metadata is obtained from the XML Gateway repositories: trading partner, message maps, process controls, data transformation rules,
            Syntax and semantic validation rules
        Changes to the message can be achieved by changing the mapping in the meta data definitions.
            Changes take effect at runtime without any code modifications
    Monitoring transaction activity can be accomplished using the Transaction Monitor or by using Workflow notifications
        Notifications can go to the e-Business Suite administrator or the Trading Partner
        Notifications provide the option to abort or retry message processing
        If aborted, errors must be corrected at the source to maintain a complete audit trail
    Flat files are handled via the e-Commerce gateway to extract or import flat files of repeated records
        Flat files require a third party EDI translator if the output or input to e-Commerced Gateway is EDI transactions

XML Gateway (ECX Schema) Setup Notes
    A trading partner is set up and can be a hub or an individual business partner.
        Definition includes:name, enabled messages, confirmation, message maps, email address for error notices,
            partner specific code conversions, and transport protocol (HTTP, SMTP, HTTPS)
    Code conversions are lookup values that transform Oracle codes to meaningful trading partner codes, or vice versa
        Code conversion categories are assigned to messages in the 'Category' column of message designer
    All the buyers and sellers within a hub are defined and linked to the hub trading partner record
    Transaction names are cross-referenced so that Oracle names can be transformed into trading partner names for outgoing messages
        Reverse cross-references can be created for incoming messages

XML Gateway (ECX Schema) Forms
    Inbound posting form
    Document Transfer Summary -- for outbound documents in Receivables Manager (under Print Documents)

XML Gateway (ECX Schema) Profile Options
    ECX: Log File Path - application level profile option, holds the destination ECX system log files

XML Gateway (ECX Schema) Tables and views
    ECX_INQUEUE -- stores a transaction record for each inbound XML post
    ECX_INBOUND_LOG -- stores log messages for inbound activity
    ECX_IN_OAG_Q_TABLE -- stores a transaction for inbound OAG compliant transactions
    ECX_TP_DETAILS_V -- a view of everything
    ECX_TP_HEADERS -- trading partner headers
    ECX_TP_DETAILS -- trading partner details
    ECX_DTDS -- DTDs
    ECX_MAPPINGS -- mappings
    ECX_DOCLOGS -- runtime logs
    ECX_ERROR_MSGS -- runtime messages
    ECX_INBOUND_LOGS -- inbound logs
    ECX_MSG_LOGS -- message logs
    ECX_PROC_MAPPINGS -- Procedure Mappings
    ECX_ATTRIBUTE_MAPPINGS; -- mappings
    ECX_LEVEL_MAPPINGS -- mappings
    EXC_DOCLOGS -- XML payload
    AR_DOCUMENT_TRANSFERS
    ECX_OXTA_LOGMSG -- shows status of transmissions

XML Gateway (ECX Schema) Notes on Troubleshooting
    The troubleshooting guide on Metalink is Doc 167474.1 "XML Troubleshooting Guide"
    An XML Gateway test posting page can be used to post XML to the Gateway, receive a confirmation and Message ID.
    The Message ID is tagged to the XML transactions in the internal ECX tables
    ECX_OXTA_LOGMSG holds ecx log for timeout messages
    Open 'Document Transfer Summary' form to view status of AR documents sent to customers

XML Gateway AR Invoice Send
    Run jobs
        Document Transfer Scheduling
        Document Transfer Program - raises business event for workflow to pick up
    Screens
        Receivables Manager > Print Documents > Document Tranfer Summary - to view sends and errors
